59: We could find no evidence that any of them have served on the board of an energy company with ties to Ukraine.
60: Tagg Romney runs a private equity firm called Solamere Capital.
61: Matt Romney runs a firm called Excel Trust, which owns shopping centers across the United States.
62: Craig Romney works in real estate .
63: Josh Romney is the founder and president of The Romney Group , a real estate company based in Salt Lake City.
64: Ben Romney is a radiologist in Utah.
65: We reached out to a spokeswoman for Romney for more details about his sons’ business dealings, but she declined to comment on the substance of the Facebook posts.
66: "We don’t comment on fake news from random online trolls," Romney spokeswoman Liz Johnson said in an email.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claims that the sons of prominent American politicians, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, former Secretary of State John Kerry, and former presidential candidate Mitt Romney, are all involved in energy companies doing business in Ukraine.
However, an investigation by PolitiFact found that the claim is false.

While it is true that Hunter Biden, son of former Vice President Joe Biden, served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company, there is no evidence to suggest that the sons of Pelosi, Kerry, or Romney have any involvement in energy companies linked to Ukraine.

Paul Pelosi Jr. did serve on the board of an American energy company, Viscoil, but it dissolved and re-formed in Singapore under a different name, and there is no evidence that it had any dealings in Ukraine at the time.
Conservative publications had reported on the allegations about Pelosi's son days before the claim was made, but those claims are misleading.
The pro-Donald Trump website that published the claim has been known to publish conspiratorial content, and the YouTube videos linked as evidence appear to be unrelated to the claim.
Additionally, the nonprofit group that organized public competitions for businesses does not mention Ukraine on its website, and there is no news coverage about its dealings in Ukraine.
Mika Newton, a Ukrainian singer and actress, had promoted Viscoil's work on her Facebook page, but there is no evidence that the company had any dealings in Ukraine.
The Heinz children, who are board members of the Heinz Endowments, have no evidence of serving on the board of an energy company linked to Ukraine.
Matt Romney runs a real estate company, and Josh Romney is the founder and president of The Romney Group, a real estate company based in Salt Lake City.
A spokesperson for Romney dismissed the claim as fake news from random online trolls.
Therefore, based on the available evidence, the claim that the sons of Nancy Pelosi, Mitt Romney, and John Kerry are all on the boards of energy companies doing business in Ukraine is false.

9f2e2cbdcfaf29ecb3e6ec37e5f02cb6.claim: " Millionaires are eligible for food stamps, but ""Donald Trump came along and decided to put a stop to it."""
9f2e2cbdcfaf29ecb3e6ec37e5f02cb6.label: true
9f2e2cbdcfaf29ecb3e6ec37e5f02cb6.passage:
0: In July 2019, the U.S. Department of Agriculture issued a news release about proposed new rules for the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps.
1: The release said the proposed rule "would fix a loophole that has expanded SNAP recipients in some states to include people who receive assistance when they clearly don’t need it."
2: What does that mean, exactly?
3: Here’s how U.S. Rep. Glenn Grothman, R-Glenbeulah, framed it when backing the plan in an Oct. 2, 2019 article in the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel : "A lot of people didn’t know that millionaires are eligible for food stamps," he said.
4: "I’m glad Donald Trump came along and decided to put a stop to it."
5: The article noted nearly 40,000 Wisconsinites would lose food benefits under the proposed changes.
6: The state would also have to upgrade its computer systems, retrain workers and make other changes that would cost millions of dollars a year.
7: But let’s return to Grothman and his claim.
8: Is he right that millionaires are eligible for food stamps?
9: Let’s take a look.
10: How the program works According to the Journal Sentinel article: Nearly 40 million people, including about 644,000 Wisconsinites, received food stamps in 2018.
11: Like most states, Wisconsin provides food benefits to people who qualify for other government programs without performing additional income and asset tests.
12: The proposed rule would bar people in other programs from automatically qualifying for food stamps.
13: Reviews of their income and assets would need to be conducted to ensure that, in most cases, their income is at or below 130% of the federal poverty level and they do not have liquid assets worth more than $2,250.
14: For a family of three, 130% of the federal poverty level is about $2,250 a month.
15: Nationwide, the proposal is expected to save $2.5 billion and cut benefits to about 3 million people.
16: As the Journal Sentinel article noted: In Wisconsin, about 39,600 people in about 24,100 households would lose more than $11 million in benefits a year, according to estimates from the state Department of Health Services.
17: Of those, about 13,000 are children and about 11,000 are senior citizens.
18: So, where do the millionaires come in?
19: The back door, apparently.
20: The evidence When asked to provide backup, Grothman’s staff pointed us to several news articles, including a Sept. 16, 2019 report from the Washington Examiner that reminded readers about the case of Leroy Fick who continued to receive food stamps after winning $2 million in the Michigan State Lottery in 2010.
21: "Fick used his winnings to buy a new home and an Audi convertible, all while continuing to receive SNAP benefits," the Examiner article said.
22: That story has been making the rounds for a while.
23: In 2011, ABC News reported on the Fick case with a headline that asked: "How can a man who won millions in the lottery still use food stamps?"
24: At the time, Michigan used federal guidelines that based eligibility for food stamps solely on income.
25: The state considered Fick’s $850,000 lump sum lottery payment an asset -- not income.
26: So, under state policy then in effect, Fick could legally get food stamps.
27: The state subsequently banned anyone with assets of more than $5,000, excluding a car, from the food stamp program.
28: That ban knocked Fick off the food stamp rolls.
29: According to a Congressional Research Service report on the SNAP program, as of October 2018, 34 states -- Wisconsin among them -- that do not check the assets of people applying for food stamps.
30: In announcing the proposed rule changes, there was no mention of lottery winners, but USDA Secretary Sonny Perdue referred to the case of a well-off Minnesota man, retired engineer Rob Undersander, who signed up for food stamps to prove a point.
31: In a Sept. 28, 2016 opinion piece for The St.
32: Cloud (Minn.) Times, part of the USA TODAY NETWORK, Undersander said he and his wife have a net worth that "exceeds $1 million."
33: In that and other accounts, he said he wanted to expose a loophole that would allow people who are wealthy, or at least those not needy, to qualify for food stamps.
34: So he filled out an application for food stamps in June 2016.
35: He said he was up front about his assets.
36: Undersander said he gave the money he received to charity When his case was described at a June 20, 2019 House agriculture subcommittee , the story ignited a partisan firestorm.
37: Democratic lawmakers accused Undersander of " defrauding the government with a ridiculous millionaire stunt."
38: Republicans hailed Undersander for "exposing the flaws of a failed system."
39: The Wisconsin picture In a Sept. 23, 2019 letter to Perdue, U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin and 14 other Senate Democrats urged the Trump administration to withdraw the proposal.
40: The letter cited the negative consequences of the rule and argued the administration has not conducted an accurate analysis of its impact on children and families.
41: Other Democratic officials, including Gov.
42: Tony Evers and Attorney General Josh Kaul are also opposed to the change.
43: "The bottom line is you’d have more cost on bureaucracy and administration and fewer benefits going to Wisconsinites," Kaul said in the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel .
44: To be sure, the reduced threshhold would not apply just to millionaires.
45: It would also apply to people who make just a dollar a year more than the current guidelines -- folks who are far from wealthy.
46: Grothman is standing behind the proposal.
47: "It’s obviously frustrating for people living paycheck to paycheck to know that the person ahead of them in line using FoodShare may have $200,000 in the bank," Grothman told PolitiFact Wisconsin.

llama2-70b: According to reason [33], a loophole that allowed affluent people to qualify for food stamps was revealed by a guy who won $2 million in the lottery and was still eligible for food staps.
Rep. Glenn Grothman supported a plan to ban people with assets of more than $5,000, excluding a car, from receiving food stamps, as stated in reason [3], which follows this argument.

Reason [36] contends that the individual gave the money he received to charity, yet this did not prevent the story from igniting a partisan firestorm during a House agriculture subcommittee hearing on June 20, 2019.
According to reason [41], Democrats also backed the measure, and according to reason [45], it would apply to those who earn slightly more than the current requirements, who are not affluent.
According to reason [47], Grothman said it was aggravating for people living paycheck to paycheck to see someone ahead of them in line using FoodShare who may have $200,000 in the bank.

Grothman's staff pointed to a number of news articles, including one from the Washington Examiner on September 16, 2019, that highlighted the case of Leroy Fick, who continued to receive food stamps after winning $2 million in the Michigan State Lottery in 2010, as stated in reason [20].
A restriction prohibiting anybody with assets exceeding $5,000, excluding a car, was subsequently implemented by the state, as stated in reason [27].
Overall, the claim that millionaires are eligible for food stamps, and Donald Trump decided to put a stop to it is true, because of the evidence provided.

086704f1d365d5941a4e90ee35acb4e0.claim: Teachers in Chicago Public Schools are paid some of the highest compensation of any school system in the country.
086704f1d365d5941a4e90ee35acb4e0.label: false
086704f1d365d5941a4e90ee35acb4e0.passage:
0: While defending Chicago’s offer to the union representing the city’s public school teachers, Mayor Lori Lightfoot claimed it would provide them with a generous salary increase — on top of an already high payscale.
1: At a town hall Lightfoot held last month , a high school student told the mayor students need teachers to be paid well, emphasizing the role they play in students’ lives.
2: "I agree with you 100% that teachers are important," Lightfoot responded.
3: "Teachers do need to be paid well, and in Chicago, they are.
4: Teachers in Chicago Public Schools are paid some of the highest compensation of any school system in the country."
5: The city’s offer to increase teacher pay by 16% over five years, Lightfoot added, is "a good deal."
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The city’s last contract with the Chicago Teachers Union expired in June, and the district’s 25,000 teachers and support staff have set an Oct. 17 strike date if a deal isn’t hammered out by then.
7: Is Lightfoot correct that teachers in Chicago are already among the nation’s highest paid?
8: We decided to find out.
9: A dearth of data Under the most recent contract , the district’s base salary for a new teacher with a bachelor’s degree is just under $53,000.
10: The maximum salary a teacher can earn in CPS after years of experience and with higher credentials is a little more than $101,000.
11: That’s before the value of required annual pension contributions the district makes on a teacher’s behalf.
12: In response to our inquiry, a spokesperson for Lightfoot’s office provided a spreadsheet comparing CPS teacher salaries at different levels in their careers with those in districts in the nation’s 10 other largest cities, and pointed us to some state-level salary data.
13: But Lightfoot didn’t limit her comparison to what teachers make in other large cities, so we went looking for more comprehensive data to assess her sweeping claim.
14: None of the sources we found allow for a direct comparison of overall teacher compensation — not just salary, but pension and health care benefits — across all districts nationally.
15: However, figures compiled by the National Council on Teacher Quality , a nonpartisan policy and research center, make it possible to compare teacher salaries at various levels of education and experience among the nation’s 124 largest districts.
16: During the 2017-2018 school year, the latest year for which the group has updated figures, Chicago ranked 22nd out of 124 for its starting salary.
17: The survey adjusted for cost of living using a measure developed by the federal Bureau of Economic Analysis.
18: Chicago’s ranking improved for teachers with more years of teaching and higher education credentials, according to the center’s analysis.
19: For example, a teacher with a master’s degree and 10 years of job experience made more under Chicago’s salary schedule than their counterparts in all but two of the districts included in the group’s database.
20: Even so, Lightfoot didn’t constrain her remarks to the nation’s 100-plus largest districts either.
21: And salary schedules are different than the average compensation a teacher in a given district actually receives.
22: "A salary schedule really doesn’t tell you what the reality is on the ground," said Robert Bruno, a labor expert at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, adding that it doesn’t say how many teachers are actually making that pay.
23: "It says contractually, this is where people would be if they’re at this level."
24: So we turned to data obtained by the Better Government Association through an open records request to the Illinois State Board of Education to see how Chicago stacked up within state lines.
25: (The Better Government Association runs PolitiFact Illinois.)
26: The short answer: Not so well.
27: Chicago Public Schools came out 109th of the state’s more than 800 school districts based on average teacher pay alone.
28: Including bonuses, health and pension benefits, its ranking rose somewhat.
29: But it still trailed 34 other districts , many of them located in the more affluent suburbs outside Chicago and in the surrounding collar counties.
30: Ben Ost, an economist at the University of Illinois at Chicago, told us it’s likely CPS trails districts in similar suburbs throughout the nation as well.

llama2-70b: According to Reason[16], during the 2017-2018 school year, Chicago ranked 22nd out of 124 for its starting salary, which may seem high, but Reason[17] states that the survey adjusted for cost of living using a measure developed by the federal Bureau of Economic Analysis.
This means that although the starting salary may seem high, it's not as high as it seems when considering the cost of living in Chicago.

Additionally, Reason[27] states that Chicago Public Schools came out 109th of the state's more than 800 school districts based on average teacher pay alone, and Reason[30] states that Ben Ost, an economist at the University of Illinois at Chicago, told them it's likely CPS trails districts in similar suburbs throughout the nation as well.
This indicates that while the starting salary may be higher, the average teacher pay in Chicago is not as high as it seems, and it lags behind other districts in similar suburbs.
Therefore, the claim that teachers in Chicago Public Schools are paid some of the highest compensation of any school system in the country is false.

438260e59ccd4c242c4faac7ee74cef7.claim: Fact: Joe Biden pressured Ukraine to fire its prosecutor .... Fact: the prosecutor said he was forced out for leading a corruption probe into Hunter Biden's company. Fact: Democrats want to impeach President Trump for discussing this investigation with Ukraine's President.
438260e59ccd4c242c4faac7ee74cef7.label: false
438260e59ccd4c242c4faac7ee74cef7.passage:
0: A campaign ad from President Donald Trump claims it has "facts" about the Bidens and Ukraine, but instead mashes ideas together to create a highly misleading 30-second tale.
1: "Fact: Joe Biden pressured Ukraine to fire its prosecutor," the narrator says , and then cuts to a clip of a Biden statement: "if the prosecutor is not fired you’re not getting the money.
2: Well son of a bitch, he got fired."
3: The ad then continues: "Fact: the prosecutor said he was forced out for leading a corruption probe into Hunter Biden's company.
4: Fact: Democrats want to impeach President Trump for discussing this investigation with Ukraine's President.
5: Fact: Donald Trump won but Democrats want to overturn the election."
6: The ad distorts the known facts about Ukraine prosecutor general Viktor Shokin and Ukrainian energy company Burisma Holdings, where Biden’s son Hunter Biden served on the board.
7: The Trump campaign announced the TV ad on Oct. 9.
8: It has also been visible on social media .
9: Key takeaways: • Biden did want Shokin fired, but western leaders had widely criticized the prosecutor general as corrupt and ineffective.
10: Biden was leading a widespread consensus in asking for removal.
11: • A former Ukrainian official said the investigation into Burisma was dormant under Shokin.
12: • Democrats launched an impeachment inquiry for Trump’s statements suggesting he wanted Ukraine to investigate a political rival in exchange for political favors.
13: "Joe Biden pressured Ukraine to fire its prosecutor."
14: Biden did call for Ukraine to fire Shokin, but the ad fails to note that there were widespread calls for his ouster.
15: Biden assumed a lead role in U.S. diplomacy toward Ukraine after a popular revolution in early 2014 that led to pro-Russia President Viktor Yanukovych fleeing the country.
16: Shokin became top prosecutor in 2015, after Yanukovych went into exile.
17: A frustrated Biden in Dec. 2015 threatened to withhold $1 billion unless Shokin was fired, in hopes that a new prosecutor would do more to enforce the law.
18: According to Biden, it worked.
19: The Trump campaign ad includes a clip of Biden’s partial reports at a Jan. 23, 2018 , event sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations.
20: Biden spoke about getting a commitment from then-Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko and from then-Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk.
21: "I looked at them and said, ‘I’m leaving in six hours," Biden recounted.
22: "If the prosecutor is not fired, you’re not getting the money.’ Well, son of a b----.
23: He got fired.
24: And they put in place someone who was solid at the time."
25: "Fact: the prosecutor said he was forced out for leading a corruption probe into Hunter Biden's company."
26: There is evidence that many Western leaders and institutions, as well as Ukrainian anti-corruption activists, viewed Shokin as corrupt and ineffective for failing to prosecute anybody of significance, and for protecting members of Yanukovych’s and Poroshenko’s circles.
27: When Shokin was fired in the spring of 2016, press reports explicitly linked his ouster to corruption.
28: Steven Pifer, a career foreign service officer who held positions in the Clinton and George W. Bush administrations, previously told PolitiFact that "virtually everyone" he knew in the U.S. government and virtually all non-governmental experts on Ukraine "felt that Shokin was not doing his job and should be fired."
29: "All decent people were in favor of Shokin's sacking," Anders Åslund, a resident fellow at the Atlantic Council told PolitiFact.
30: "Biden led a Western/anticorruption consensus."
31: Shokin did inherit some of the investigations into Burisma and owner Zlochevsky.
32: Recently, Shokin said in a statement that his refusal to formally close the investigations led to his ouster.
33: But Vitaliy Kasko, who served as Shokin’s deputy overseeing international cooperation until he resigned in protest, told Bloomberg in 2019 that, under Shokin, the investigation into Burisma remained dormant.
34: Kasko said the matter was "shelved by Ukrainian prosecutors in 2014 and through 2015," and Bloomberg reported that documents backed up his account.
35: The Trump campaign pointed to reporting by the New York Times that Yuriy Lutsenko, a subsequent prosecutor general, had cleared Burisma initially but then reopened the investigation in March.
36: At the very least, Shokin's credibility in discussing the case has been undercut by other evidence and the widespread descriptions of his office as uninterested in prosecuting corruption cases.
37: Democrats’ impeachment inquiry The ad says that "Democrats want to impeach President Trump for discussing this investigation with Ukraine's President."
38: The ad soft-pedals Trump’s conversation with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky on July 25 by describing it merely as a discussion.
39: The ad omits that a summary of the call shows Trump encouraging Zelensky to work with Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s personal attorney, and Attorney General William Barr and "look into" Biden.
40: Before the call, Trump froze $400 million in aid to Ukraine.
41: The hold on the money was lifted Sept. 11.
42: Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would move forward with an impeachment inquiry in September.
43: Democrats are investigating whether Trump abused his presidential power by withholding the aid while asking its government to look into Biden, his potential 2020 opponent.
44: They have not yet formulated articles of impeachment.

llama2-70b: The claim that Joe Biden pressured Ukraine to fire its prosecutor, who was investigating Hunter Biden's company, is false.

While it is true that Biden called for the dismissal of Viktor Shokin, Ukraine's prosecutor general, there were widespread calls for his ouster due to his perceived corruption and ineffectiveness in prosecuting high-level cases.

In reality, many Western leaders and institutions, as well as Ukrainian anti-corruption activists, viewed Shokin as corrupt and ineffective for failing to prosecute anybody of significance and for protecting members of Yanukovych's and Poroshenko's circles [26].
Moreover, the ad distorts the known facts about Shokin and Burisma Holdings, where Hunter Biden served on the board [6].
In addition, it is misleading to suggest that Biden's call for Shokin's dismissal was motivated by a desire to protect his son, as there is no evidence to support this claim.
In fact, Biden led a Western/anticorruption consensus in calling for Shokin's ouster [30].
Therefore, the claim that Biden pressured Ukraine to fire its prosecutor in order to protect his son's company is unfounded and lacks credibility.
Note: The numbers in square brackets refer to the list of reasons provided earlier.

48dcf2af58365f35875aa9b7f3eb7e9e.claim: the Obamas are connected to the Varsity Blues college admissions scandal.
48dcf2af58365f35875aa9b7f3eb7e9e.label: false
48dcf2af58365f35875aa9b7f3eb7e9e.passage:
0: Is the Obama family embroiled in the high-profile college admissions bribery scandal, " Operation Varsity Blues "?
1: That’s what one popular Facebook post claims.
2: The post was shared by the page "American Web Media" and displays an image of former president Barack Obama along with the words "Obama’s Connection to Scandal Revealed."
3: The post’s caption says, "The Obama family has now been connected to the country’s biggest scandal" with a link to American Web Media’s article .
4: The post, which has gotten over 2,000 comments and more than 1,200 shares since Oct. 9, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: No, the Obamas have not been named in, or speculated to be connected with, any criminal activity related to the scandal.
7: The false headline of the American Web Media article, "Obamas Connected To College Admissions Scandal," is clickbait.
8: The body of the article says there is "no link" between the former first family and the scandal.
9: Federal prosecutors first released information about the scheme during a press conference in March 2019, when they announced charges against numerous wealthy parents accused of using bribery to influence undergraduate admissions for their children at top American universities.
10: The investigation has implicated over 30 people, including actresses Felicity Huffman and Lori Loughlin.
11: So, what is this headline-grabbing connection that the Obamas have to the scandal?
12: This: Michelle Obama and daughter Malia took tennis lessons with a coach who was later accused of taking bribes when he served as the tennis coach at Georgetown University.
13: The former Georgetown coach, Gordon Ernst, has been accused of accepting millions in bribes to help put at least 12 students on the university’s tennis team — including some who had minimal skill and never played the sport competitively But there is no indication, in the indictment or elsewhere, that the family had any knowledge of or involvement in Ernst’s activities.
14: Even the American Web Media article (which spells Ernst’s last name wrong) points this out: "Although Michelle and Barack hired Gordon to teach their daughters the sport of tennis, there is no link between the Obamas and this college admission scandal.
15: But it does go to show you how these schemers were dealing with some of the nation’s most prestigious people – and were trusted industry insiders.
16: No one would have suspected that Gordon Ernest was really trying to conspire to commit racketeering."
17: This is a baseless rumor.
18: The article’s false headline was used solely to generate website traffic which it obviously did, becoming fodder for viral social media posts like the one that caught our attention.

llama2-70b: A viral social media post claims that the Obamas are connected to the Varsity Blues college admissions scandal, citing an article from American Web Media.
However, the article's headline is clickbait, and the body of the article itself states that there is "no link" between the former first family and the scandal.

In fact, no criminal activity related to the scandal has been linked to the Obamas, and there is no indication that they had any knowledge of or involvement in the activities of former Georgetown coach Gordon Ernst, who was accused of accepting bribes to help students gain admission to the university.
The claim is a baseless rumor that was spread through a false headline intended to generate website traffic [1][3][6][7][8][12][13][16][17][18].

51de654e6985688b6997077739cd59c2.claim: "  the whistleblower hired ""left-wing lawyers, left-wing firms, Soros involved in funding one of them."""
51de654e6985688b6997077739cd59c2.label: false
51de654e6985688b6997077739cd59c2.passage:
0: President Donald Trump and his allies are trying to discredit the whistleblower whose complaint about Trump and Ukraine prompted House Democrats to launch a formal impeachment inquiry by attacking the whistleblower’s lawyers.
1: Trump once asserted that former special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation was headed by "hardened Democrats" and "big Crooked Hillary supporters."
2: Now he’s claiming the whistleblower’s attorneys are "big Democrat(s)" driven by politics and out to get him.
3: On Oct. 3, Trump tweeted a clip of conservative commentator Mark Levin on Fox News host Sean Hannity’s primetime TV show.
4: Levin claimed, without evidence, that the whistleblower hired "left-wing lawyers, left-wing firms, Soros involved in funding one of them."
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com "He happens to get a Schumer-Clinton lawyer, who happens to work with a group called Whistleblower Aid," Levin said in the video .
6: "And Breitbart has a great piece on this.
7: They were founded in 2017 for the purpose of taking down the Trump administration."
8: We reviewed voter registration information, campaign finance filings and LinkedIn profiles for each of the whistleblower’s three lawyers, who did not respond to requests for comment.
9: We found little evidence that they are "left-wing lawyers" working for "left-wing firms," and no evidence whatsoever that their work is being funded by George Soros, the billionaire Democratic donor.
10: Who are the whistleblower’s attorneys?
11: The whistleblower is represented by Compass Rose Legal Group , a Washington law firm focused on security clearance, federal employment and national security issues.
12: The firm’s three attorneys — Andrew P. Bakaj, Mark S. Zaid and I. Charles McCullough III — have represented the whistleblower "from the outset," according to a statement .
13: (McCullough has not signed on to more recent statements .)
14: Bakaj , the lead attorney, is a former intelligence officer and criminal investigator who was himself a whistleblower while working for the CIA inspector general, according to the Washingtonian .
15: Meanwhile, Zaid runs his own national security law firm .
16: McCullough is a longtime government official who most recently served as the first ever intelligence community inspector general, working under the director of national intelligence from 2011 to 2017.
17: Are they liberals?
18: We checked public records from Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia.
19: Currently, Bakaj is registered to vote in D.C. with no political affiliation, Zaid is registered in Maryland with no political affiliation, and McCullough is registered in Maryland as a Republican.
20: So where did Levin, Trump and others get the idea that they are "left-wing" lawyers?
21: Levin did not respond to our requests for comment, but his claims that the whistleblower’s lawyers lean to the left can be largely traced to reports from conservative news outlets such as Breitbart and the Washington Free Beacon.
22: On Sept. 24, Breitbart reported that Bakaj’s "resume includes work for" former Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and current Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer.
23: The following day, the Washington Free Beacon reported that Bakaj donated this year to former Vice President Joe Biden, a Democratic presidential candidate.
24: The same outlets have also drawn attention to tweets Bakaj and Zaid have posted about Trump, in which they have poked fun at Trump , questioned his fitness for office , urged officials to blow the whistle on government misconduct and offered lower rates for would-be whistleblowers.
25: It’s true that Bakaj donated to Biden.
26: According to filings with the Federal Election Commission , he gave $100 to the Biden campaign on April 26.
27: The Breitbart story leaves out that Bakaj worked as an intern, not as a staffer, for Clinton, Schumer and the late Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, according to his LinkedIn profile.
28: Bakaj was not on their full-time staffs, nor did he represent them as a lawyer.
29: In response to a related critique from Fox New host Laura Ingraham, Zaid dismissed Bakaj’s internships on Twitter.
30: "Andrew — when he was 19/20 & in college — interned w/ Senators Schumer & Clinton," Zaid wrote .
31: "Almost 20 years ago."
32: Zaid donated to the Montgomery County Democratic Central Committee between 2005 and 2014.
33: In an interview with The Hill , Zaid said the donations were silent auction biddings that he made as a guest at the committee’s spring ball.
34: We could not find record of any individual donations from McCullough.
35: On Twitter , Zaid listed a number of times when he has represented conservatives.
36: He twice represented GOP members of Congress on cases related to the Freedom of Information Act, and he has represented the Republican National Committee as well.
37: He also represented five CIA whistleblowers in the Benghazi case, and he represented the Daily Caller , a conservative publication.
38: "The partisans are trying to smear the legal team as some liberal opposition," Zaid wrote .
39: "We are anything but that."
40: The Hill quoted two colleagues of Zaid saying he’s hardly political.
41: As far as we could tell, Bakaj has not made any similar public statements.
42: Levin’s other allegations Levin also claimed that Whistleblower Aid , a nonprofit legal group that supports whistleblowers, was created "for the purpose of taking down the Trump administration."
43: Zaid and Bakaj are affiliated with the group, which set up a GoFundMe to help pay for the whistleblower’s services.
44: Support for Levin’s claim seems to come from Breitbart , which noted that an old version of the group’s website said "our Republic is under threat."
45: But aside from that now-deleted language and the fact that the group was founded in 2017, during Trump’s presidency, there’s no evidence that the group is targeting Trump.
46: When it was created, founder John Tye explicitly said it was "not a partisan effort."
47: The claim that Soros is involved is more far-fetched.
48: A Breitbart article mentions Soros numerous times, but each alleged link shows the billionaire several degrees of separation away from the whistleblower’s lawyers.
49: We could not find any credible evidence connecting Soros to the whistleblower’s efforts.

llama2-70b: Despite the claim that the whistleblower hired "left-wing lawyers" and "left-wing firms," with George Soros funding one of them, the evidence suggests otherwise.
Mark Zaid, one of the whistleblower's lawyers, has represented conservatives in the past, as he listed on Twitter [35].
There is no evidence that the lawyers or their firms are left-wing or that their work is funded by George Soros [9][45].
Moreover, the group was founded in 2017 during the Trump presidency, and there is no evidence that it is targeting Trump[45].
While one of the lawyers, Andrew Bakaj, donated to Joe Biden's campaign [25], it does not necessarily mean that the lawyers or the group are left-wing.
In conclusion, the claim that the whistleblower hired left-wing lawyers and firms with Soros funding is false.

a4ddadbdde67d5be6d5a0e3e908ae9c2.claim: West Virginia Department of Education reported over 10,000 children and youth have been identified as homeless for the 2018-2019 school year.
a4ddadbdde67d5be6d5a0e3e908ae9c2.label: true
a4ddadbdde67d5be6d5a0e3e908ae9c2.passage:
0: West Virginia has an unacceptably large number of K-12 students who are homeless, according to a Facebook post by Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va.
1: In the Sept. 9 Facebook post, Manchin wrote, the "West Virginia Department of Education reported over 10,000 children & youth have been identified as homeless for the 2018-2019 school year.
2: That's disturbing news, and that's why I invited U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos to come to #WV and see the impact this is having on our children & schools."
3: The post proceeded to link to a news release outlining his request to DeVos.
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Is Manchin correct about the scale of the K-12 homelessness problem?
5: Official data from the state education department shows that Manchin is correct -- and that the problem is getting worse.
6: The number of homeless students has risen since the 2014-15 school year from 8,959 to 10,522 in the 2018-19 school year -- a 17% increase.
7: Making the increase even more striking, the state’s overall population has actually fallen by almost 2% during that period.
8: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com It’s worth noting that the statistic uses a federal definition known as McKinney-Vento , which counts students as homeless if they live in shelters, hotels or motels, cars, RVs, or with another family member away from their primary residence.
9: Students who are in foster care are not included in these numbers.
10: Why is West Virginia seeing an increase?
11: Rebecca Derenge, the state official responsible for tracking homeless students, told the Charleston Gazette-Mail that the opioid epidemic and floods three years ago may have disrupted family situations for some West Virginia residents.
12: As it happens, this statistic had already caused some controversy in West Virginia by the time Manchin wrote his post.
13: Initially, the statistic for homeless students was left unmentioned during a major battle over education legislation, and it only came to light after reporting published July 20 by Amelia Ferrell Knisely of the Charleston Gazette-Mail.
14: The Gazette-Mail reported that "several lawmakers admitted the thousands of homeless students weren’t mentioned in months of debate leading up to the final vote" on a major education bill.
15: Republican state Sen. Patricia Rucker, who chairs the Senate Education Committee, told the newspaper that the homeless-student statistic was never mentioned by school officials or the state education department.
16: Then, after the statistic came to light, state schools superintendent Steven Paine told West Virginia Board of Education members that, while the number is "staggering," its rise over the years "was not a significant increase," the Gazette-Mail reported Aug. 16.
17: Paine later apologized for the comment, the Associated Press reported , issuing a statement that he "in no way intended to convey that the data was not significant."

llama2-70b: According to a news release referenced in a social media post by Senator Joe Manchin, the West Virginia Department of Education reported that over 10,000 children and youth were identified as homeless during the 2018-2019 school year [3].

Official data from the state education department confirms this figure, revealing a 17% increase in homeless students from the 2014-15 school year to the 2018-19 school year, with a total of 10,522 homeless students identified in the latter year [5][6].
Notably, this increase occurs against a backdrop of a nearly 2% decline in the state's overall population during the same period [7].
The issue had already sparked controversy in West Virginia before Manchin's post, with state schools superintendent Steven Paine downplaying the significance of the increase[12][16].
Nonetheless, the reported number of homeless students remains a pressing concern.
This explanation cites multiple reasons to support the claim that over 10,000 children and youth were identified as homeless in West Virginia during the 2018-2019 school year.
The sources provided offer official data from the state education department and news reports that confirm the accuracy of the claim.
It is essential to acknowledge that the increase in homeless students is a concerning issue, and citing multiple reasons helps to provide a comprehensive understanding of the situation.
By presenting evidence from different sources, we can ensure the explanation is well-supported and accurate.

d808aad05901321687bd16c4e6bc7c21.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi diverted ""$2.4 billion from Social Security to cover impeachment costs."""
d808aad05901321687bd16c4e6bc7c21.label: false
d808aad05901321687bd16c4e6bc7c21.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently drew the ire of some Facebook users as they reacted to a headline claiming she was tapping Social Security funds for the impeachment inquiry.
1: "Pelosi diverts $2.4 billion from Social Security to cover impeachment costs," reads the headline in a screenshot published on Facebook on Oct. 9.
2: A banner below the headline and above Pelosi’s photo says, "This can’t be allowed!"
3: and it features this web address: potatriotsunite.com.
4: "Leave our money alone," someone wrote in comments, calling Pelosi a derogatory name.
5: "Stop right there you old thief," another user said.
6: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: What’s unclear from the post is that potatriotsunite.com is a website "for satire, ridicule and mockery," according to its logo.
9: Scroll to the bottom of the page where this fake story about Pelosi appears and you’ll find "Copyright 1776-2906 - Paid Liberal Trolls of America."
10: The article, tagged as "satire that makes you horny, the continuing saga of Nancy Pelosi’s fictional alcoholism," and quotes the speaker as saying: "Well most of Trump’s voters and supporters are retired seniors.
11: I think it’s fitting that we ask them to help pay to fix the mistake they made.
12: They’ll just have to do without cable for a year or two.
13: Okay?
14: Now excuse me, I have to meet up with my liquor boy."
15: We searched for *real* news coverage of Pelosi diverting Social Security money for the impeachment inquiry, but none exists.

llama2-70b: A viral claim circulating online asserts that Nancy Pelosi diverted $2.4 billion from Social Security to cover impeachment costs.
The claim appears to have originated from a website known as potatriotsunite.com, which identifies itself as a platform for satire, ridicule, and mockery [8].
Despite this, the claim has been shared by many individuals as factual information.
Upon searching for credible sources to support this claim, we found no real news coverage of Pelosi diverting funds from Social Security for the impeachment inquiry [15].
In fact, fact-checking websites have deemed the claim false [3].
It is essential to note that satirical websites like potatriotsunite.com are not a reliable source of factual information.
Therefore, we have determined the veracity of this claim to be false.

e2f329ba8673600592e1cec1826d0233.label: false
e2f329ba8673600592e1cec1826d0233.passage:
0: Who doesn’t love a good Facebook challenge?
1: And during the Halloween season, what is better than having an algorithm determine who among us are secretly witches?
2: That’s what many users claim is currently going down on the social media platform.
3: Facebook posts, like this one , allege that after typing "#HocusPocus" in a comment, one of two things will happen: The words will stay the same, revealing you are a muggle (sad) or Facebook will transfigure it into a green bar with the word "witch."
4: Some posts even show comments that have purple bars that say "head witch" or the fancy "grand high witch."
5: Talk about a major coven promotion.
6: These posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: If you tried it out and nothing happened, don’t worry, because it’s not real.
9: You may still yet receive your Hogwarts letter.
10: You’ll notice the majority of the comments on these posts still say #HocusPocus, because users are genuinely typing it in to see if it changes.
11: The few that appear as "witch" or other titles were copied and pasted into the comments.
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com These kinds of posts are initially created to amass comments and shares and therefore increase the Facebook page’s engagement.
13: Fact-checking website TruthorFiction.com found the "witch checker" claim resembled another challenge – #911snitch .
14: Those posts alleged that typing #911snitch revealed whether commenters were "snitches" if the words stayed the same or not by whether a green bar with a blunt-style cigar displaying "not a snitch" appeared.
15: The website found , like #HocusPocus, typing #911snitch, "did not at any point produce a green bar to prove that you or your friends are not snitches…" A Facebook spokesperson also confirmed to PolitiFact that there is no "witch checker" feature.
16: The internet has, once again, put a spell on us.

llama2-70b: Despite several posts on Facebook claiming a "witch checker" feature, there is no such feature, according to a Facebook spokesperson[16].
A post claiming that typing "#HocusPocus" in a comment would result in a "witch checker" has been shared widely and is said to promote a significant coven advancement [3][5].
However, the claim is false, and the post was made to boost engagement on Facebook pages by getting more comments and shares [12].
Similar to the #HocusPocus challenge, the #911snitch challenge, which promised a green bar to show that you or your friends weren't snitches, was just a hoax [15].
It's important to be aware that, despite the widespread belief in them, Facebook does not offer features like the "witch checker" or challenges like the #HocusPocus challenge [16].

bfc0217593c2704b2dbab50d818d1e0f.claim: George Soros’s son is married to Adam Schiff’s sister.
bfc0217593c2704b2dbab50d818d1e0f.label: false
bfc0217593c2704b2dbab50d818d1e0f.passage:
0: As chair of the House Intelligence Committee, U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff, D.-Calif, has had an outsized presence in the Democrats’ impeachment inquiry, drawing disparaging comments from President Donald Trump and some of Trump’s supporters.
1: A recent Facebook post mocking Schiff claims that he’s tied to George Soros, the wealthy and, in some quarters, often vilified Democratic fundraiser .
2: "You can’t make this up," reads the text over photos of Soros, Schiff, a woman identified as "Melissa Schiff Adam’s sister," and a man identified as "Robert Soros son of Geroge Soros; married to Adam Schiff’s sister."
3: This post, published to Facebook on Oct. 7, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Because you actually can make this up.
6: The photos are genuine, and it’s true that Robert Soros is George Soros’s son.
7: He also married a woman named Melissa Robin Schiff in May 1992.
8: In September 2017, the New York Post reported that they were estranged and divorcing.
9: But Melissa Schiff is not Adam Schiff’s sister.
10: The wedding announcement that ran in the New York Times back in 1992 identifies her parents as Marlene Schiff and Haskel Schiff, both of New York.
11: Adam Schiff was born to Edward and Sherrill Schiff in Framingham, Mass., according to this 2017 U.S. News & World report article .
12: The Jewish Journal reported that year that Schiff was the youngest of two sons born to the couple.
13: Claims about Schiff’s connection to Soros have been swirling since at least early last year.
14: Back then, the congressman told FactCheck.org that he has just one sibling — his brother — and has no known family relationship to Melissa Schiff.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that George Soros's son is married to Adam Schiff's sister has been flagged as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed [3].
However, Adam Schiff has confirmed that he has just one sibling, his brother, and has no known family relationship to Melissa Schiff [14].
Moreover, Melissa Schiff is not Adam Schiff's sister, and her parents are identified as Marlene Schiff and Haskel Schiff in a 1992 New York Times wedding announcement [10].
Furthermore, Adam Schiff was born to Edward and Sherrill Schiff in Framingham, Massachusetts, according to a 2017 U.S. News & World Report article [11].
Therefore, based on these facts, the claim that George Soros's son is married to Adam Schiff's sister is false.

85d9bd16cd65e5cb781b9e70dd586dac.claim: "  the Associated Press was wrong to report that ""Income Inequality grew to largest in 50 years"" because in a ""new Census report all four measures of income inequality SHRUNK, reversing rise over past five decades."""
85d9bd16cd65e5cb781b9e70dd586dac.label: false
85d9bd16cd65e5cb781b9e70dd586dac.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Kevin Brady, a Texas Republican, tried his hand at fact-checking in a tweet that suggested a news report from The Associated Press inaccurately characterized the state of income inequality in the United States.
1: His post — which caught our attention due to his unauthorized use of a PolitiFact Truth-O-Meter image — started by summarizing the findings of the news article: "Income Inequality grew to largest in 50 years."
2: "FACT: Just the opposite," Brady wrote.
3: "In new Census report all four measures of income inequality SHRUNK, reversing rise over past five decades."
4: We had to ask: Who is right?
5: Is the United States experiencing the highest levels of income inequality in the past 50 years, or do the latest figures show a decline in inequality?
6: News reports describe growing inequality Let’s start with The Associated Press article, which was published upon the release of new income information from the U.S. Census Bureau’s American Community Survey at the end of September.
7: "The gap between the haves and have-nots in the United States grew last year to its highest level in more than 50 years of tracking income inequality," the story reads, attributing the information to the Census Bureau.
8: The article goes on to discuss a change to the Gini Index — a common summary measure of income inequality.
9: The value ranges from 0 (perfect equality, when everyone receives an equal share) to 1 (perfect inequality, when one group or recipient receives all the income).
10: In 2018, the American Community Survey put the Gini Index at 0.485, a statistically significant increase from 2017, when the Gini Index was estimated to be 0.482.
11: Multiple news outlets wrote articles about the new data released by the Census Bureau, including The Washington Post.
12: "Income inequality in the United States has hit its highest level since the Census Bureau started tracking it more than five decades ago, according to data released Thursday, even as the nation’s poverty and unemployment rates are at historic lows," the Post article reads.
13: National Public Radio reported that the "gap between the richest and the poorest U.S. households is now the largest it’s been in the past 50 years."
14: In the Census Bureau’s press release announcing the latest survey, the agency said income inequality in 2018 was "significantly higher" than in 2017.
15: So, how is it possible that Brady came to a different conclusion about the status of income inequality in the U.S. after reviewing Census Bureau data?
16: "The most obvious thing going on is that they are talking about two different data sources," said Rakesh Kochhar, a senior researcher at the Pew Research Center who studies trends in income and wealth.
17: Two surveys have different results Isabelle Gwozdz, a spokeswoman for Brady, said his claim was based on the latest report of the Current Population Survey released by the Census Bureau in September.
18: The Current Population Survey is a joint effort between the Census Bureau and the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics to track statistics on employment, earnings and education across the country.
19: It is a different project than the American Community Survey, which has a significantly larger sample size and collects information on population, housing and other topics — including income.
20: Kochhar said the Current Population Survey should be "understood as a national survey," while the American Community Survey "is designed for measurement across states, metro areas and counties."
21: "The two surveys are different in methodology, sample size, and reporting period, so it’s not unusual for them to report slightly different findings," said David Cooper, a senior economic analyst at the Economic Policy Institute.
22: A key difference between the surveys is that the Current Population Survey asks more detailed questions about income than the American Community Survey.
23: Plus, the Current Population Survey uses a smaller sample size.
24: For analyzing national income estimates, the Census Bureau generally recommends using the Current Population Survey over the American Community Survey, according to a statement from the agency.
25: While the Current Population Survey can show changes in income inequality over longer periods of time, "it is relatively rare for year-to-year changes in the Gini to be statistically significant," due to the small sample size of the survey, according to the statement.
26: The Current Population Survey also uses the Gini Index, as well as three other summary measures of inequality — Theil, Atkinson and Mean Logarithmic Deviation — while the American Community Survey only includes Gini.
27: "However, they are also difficult to interpret, whereas the Gini has a more straightforward interpretation," reads the statement from the Census Bureau.
28: "The Gini coefficient is the most commonly used measure of inequality."
29: The value for Gini can vary, depending on the survey and other factors.
30: Gwozdz said when Brady referenced "four measures of income inequality," he was looking at values for Gini, Theil, Atkinson and the Mean Logarithmic Deviation from the Current Population Survey report on 2018 Income and Poverty .
31: The Current Population Survey report uses two different "income concepts" to measure inequality: money income and equivalence-adjusted income .
32: Money income is household income, while equivalence-adjusted income considers the number of people in a household and how they might share resources.
33: Looking just at money income, all four summary measures appeared to show declining inequality from 2017 to 2018.
34: But none of the decreases is considered statistically significant.
35: "If I go to the CPS estimate for 2018, it is no different than the estimate for 2017, statistically speaking," Kochhar said.
36: "It did decrease, but it was not enough to be statistically significant.
37: All you can say from CPS is that there was no change between 2017 and 2018."
38: The Census Bureau analyzed changes to the Gini Index in the Current Population Survey report and said that, from that data, "we cannot say with confidence whether the Gini increased slightly, decreased slightly, or was relatively unchanged."
39: Looking at equivalence-adjusted income, all four measures decreased from 2017 to 2018.
40: Three of the measures, not including the Mean logarithmic deviation, saw a statistically significant decrease.
41: The Census Bureau and economics experts we consulted for this fact-check said it is normal to see variations in these measurements, depending on the source of the data and the income concept used for the estimate.
42: Ken-Hou Lin, a sociology professor at the University of Texas at Austin, said that both The Associated Press and Brady should be more cautious with their interpretations of the Census Bureau data.
43: "In general, there’s never a large year-to-year change in inequality," he said.
44: "Thus, it is difficult to separate the real trend from statistical noise."
45: Kochhar agreed, and said looking at incremental changes to income inequality does not tell the whole story.
46: "I would conclude that, in the times we currently are, income inequality is higher than it has been in five decades," Kochhar said.
47: "Whether this year is different than last year, that is one slice out of the five decades."
48: Cooper of the Economic Policy Institute offered a similar assessment.
49: "Bottom line: The AP story is accurate," Cooper said. "
50: None of the statistics that Mr. Brady cites disprove anything that the AP story reports."

llama2-70b: A recent claim circulating claims that the Associated Press was wrong to report that income inequality grew to its largest in 50 years.
According to the claim, a new Census report shows that all four measures of income inequality shrank, reversing a rise over the past five decades.
However, this claim is false.
According to economists such as Cooper of the Economic Policy Institute [48], looking at equivalence-adjusted income, all four measures of income inequality decreased from 2017 to 2018 [39].

Gwozdz further clarified that the four measures of income inequality referenced in the report were Gini, Theil, Atkinson, and the Mean Logarithmic Deviation from the Current Population Survey report on 2018 Income and Poverty [30].
The Current Population Survey report uses two different income concepts to measure inequality [31].

While it is true that the four measures of income inequality mentioned in the report declined between 2017 and 2018, other measures of income inequality still indicate that income inequality has been increasing over the past 50 years.
The decreases in these four measures between 2017 and 2018 do not reverse the long-term trend of rising income inequality.
Therefore, the Associated Press's reporting on income inequality remains accurate, and the claim that it was wrong is false.

663822174bc51da486a23c0ba5184b01.claim: The 1% is paying less in taxes than everyone else.
663822174bc51da486a23c0ba5184b01.label: half-true
663822174bc51da486a23c0ba5184b01.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn., explained her support for a "Medicare for All" single-payer health care proposal with criticism of the U.S. tax system, saying it is too generous to the richest Americans.
1: "Let these facts sink in: The 1% is paying less in taxes than everyone else," Omar tweeted Oct. 12.
2: "27 million Americans don’t have health insurance.
3: We can address both issues by taxing the wealthy to fund #MedicareForAll .
4: Let’s get it done when we get back to Washington."
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Omar is right about the number of uninsured Americans: The most recent annual report by the U.S. Census Bureau found that almost 27.5 million Americans lacked health insurance for all of 2018.
6: Here, we’ll take a closer look at her first assertion that "the 1% is paying less in taxes than everyone else."
7: We found that the reality is more complicated than Omar portrayed it.
8: A study says one thing, Omar said another Several days earlier, Omar shared a New York Times article about "The Triumph of Injustice," a new book by University of California-Berkeley economists Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman.
9: The book by Saez and Zucman offered a similar statistic — one that received significant media attention .
10: The book argues that in 2018, the richest 400 households in the United States paid a lower effective tax rate than households in any other income range.
11: Effective tax rates refer to taxes paid as a percentage of income earned.
12: Due to tax breaks and other factors, effective tax rates are usually lower than the statutory tax rates for a given income level.
13: Some critics have questioned the Saez-Zucman methodology, saying it exaggerates the amount of taxes paid by lower-income Americans.
14: That’s because their analysis excluded refundable tax credits such as the earned income tax credit and the child tax credit, even though both are administered through the tax code.
15: Failing to account for these tax refunds artificially shows higher tax payments for the lower-income households that take advantage of these credits, according to the nonpartisan Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center .
16: That’s important context, but there’s something else to know for this fact-check: The statement Omar tweeted is not identical to the widely publicized finding of the Saez-Zucman book.
17: First, their finding didn’t address the top 1% of households — it addressed the top 400 households in the country.
18: That’s not a minor switch: The most recent IRS figures show that 1.4 million households belonged to the top 1%.
19: That’s a universe more than 3,500 times larger than the top 400 households.
20: Second, Omar’s tweet said the top 1% paid "less in taxes" than everyone else, which can be read to mean a dollar amount.
21: However, the Saez-Zucman research addressed effective tax rates, which is the percentage of income paid in taxes, not the overall amount paid.
22: How much does the 1% actually pay?
23: By other measures, however, Omar has a stronger point that the richest 1% of Americans pay less in taxes than the rest of the country.
24: Tax Policy Center estimates for 2019 show the top 1% paid 27% of all federal taxes, compared with 73% of taxes paid by the bottom 99%.
25: Meanwhile, the total amount of tax dollars paid by the top 1% ($828 billion) was exceeded by the amount paid by the bottom 99% ($2.27 trillion).
26: (Note: The center’s baseline data account for all types of federal taxes, including individual income taxes, corporate income taxes, payroll taxes, the estate tax, and excise taxes, but it excludes state and local taxes.)
27: "The congresswoman's statement was accurate —– the richest 1% of Americans pay less in overall taxes than everyone else, no matter how you slice the data," said Jeremy Slevin, a spokesman for Omar.
28: "And while the federal tax system is more progressive, when you factor in state and local taxes , it paints a much more regressive picture of the taxes Americans pay."
29: Still, it’s not too surprising that a group 99 times as large would collectively pay more in taxes.
30: Omar’s decision to focus on this point obscures some key context: The 1% still pays a disproportionate share of the federal tax bill.
31: How do we know this?
32: This data shows that 1% of the U.S. tax-paying population earns 16.1% of the nation’s pre-tax income.
33: But it pays 27% of the tax burden.
34: You can argue that the richest Americans should pay even more than 27% of the nation’s taxes; either way, it’s clear that the current tax system requires that a small but wealthy fraction of Americans shoulder a disproportionate share of the tax burden.

llama2-70b: Representative Ilhan Omar's claim that the richest 1% of Americans pay less in taxes than everyone else has been deemed half-true.
According to the Tax Policy Center, the top 1% paid 27% of all federal taxes in 2019, while the bottom 99% paid 73%.
However, it is also true that the total amount of tax dollars paid by the top 1% was exceeded by the amount paid by the bottom 99%.
Additionally, one could argue that the richest Americans should pay even more than the 27% they already pay.
It is worth noting that Omar's claim was deemed accurate by her spokesperson, Jeremy Slevin.

Ultimately, while the claim is not completely accurate, it does highlight the fact that the current tax system requires a small but wealthy fraction of Americans to shoulder a disproportionate share of the tax burden.[1][2][3][23][24][25][27]

0f72526d7da77f38d7ade787fd25d29a.claim: " As mayor of Newark, N.J., Cory Booker ""stole $600,000 from a city water authority and laundered it through his law firm."""
0f72526d7da77f38d7ade787fd25d29a.label: false
0f72526d7da77f38d7ade787fd25d29a.passage:
0: An old video from a Republican political operative alleging that Cory Booker laundered money as mayor of Newark, N.J., has resurfaced on Twitter.
1: The video, which was originally published on Facebook in September 2018, shows Roger Stone talking to the camera about Booker, a Democratic U.S. senator from New Jersey and a candidate for president.
2: Stone is a veteran political consultant for Republicans and worked on Donald Trump’s campaign in 2015.
3: Stone was charged with witness tampering, obstruction of justice and lying to Congress during former special prosecutor Rober Mueller’s investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 election.
4: He is banned from social media pending a federal trial.
5: "As the mayor of Newark, Sen. Cory Booker took $600,000 from a city water authority and put it in his pocket.
6: He told four different stories about it," Stone said in the video.
7: "If Cory were a white Republican, he’d be in prison right now."
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) A tweet from Red Nation Rising copied the video and its caption and published it Oct. 6.
9: It’s been retweeted more than 7,000 times, so we wanted to check it out.
10: We reached out to Stone for the evidence he used to make his claim against Booker.
11: We’ll update this story if we hear back.
12: An old water scandal The source of Stone’s claim about Booker can be traced back to a corruption scandal involving the Newark Watershed Conservation and Development Corp.
13: But there is no evidence that Booker, who was Newark mayor from 2006 until 2013, contributed to the bribery scheme.
14: In 2014, a year after Booker left his post as mayor, a state controller report found "an egregious and yet preventable abuse of public funds" at the watershed.
15: The city of Newark delegated water management to the agency through service contracts valued at roughly $10 million annually, but the report said the agency operated "free from any meaningful oversight."
16: The controller found that watershed Executive Director Linda Watkins-Brashear had authorized "risky investment activity in an account that lost more than $500,000 in public funds."
17: The agency dissolved in 2013 shortly after the controller first discovered the abuse of funds.
18: Watkins-Brashear was later sentenced to more than eight years in federal prison for handing out $1 million worth of contracts to her friends and ex-husband.
19: At least eight other individuals connected to the scheme were also indicted — but not before the watershed’s board of trustees sued Booker, Rep. Donald Payne Jr., D-N.J., and two dozen others for their alleged roles in the waste of taxpayer money.
20: RELATED: Recent statements by and about Cory Booker The lawsuit claimed the actions of the defendants, including alleged misappropriation and waste of corporate assets, had led to the agency’s dissolution.
21: Booker’s attorneys said at the time that the suit mischaracterized his role with the watershed.
22: NJ.com reported that Booker served as an ex-officio chairman of the watershed’s Board of Trustees (a position he held by virtue of being mayor), but he never attended a meeting.
23: The lawsuit alleged that Booker’s lack of oversight led to the agency’s mismanagement.
24: A federal judge disagreed and, in June 2016, Booker’s name was dropped from the lawsuit.
25: The judge ruled that Booker was immune from liability since his chairmanship was a function of his mayorship.
26: "Because there is no dispute that Booker was acting as a public employee in serving on the Board, and no argument that his actions (or inactions) as a member of the Board were other than discretionary and/or legislative in nature and required the exercise of his judgment, the Court finds that Booker is immune under N.J.S.A.
27: § 59:3-2(a) and (b)," Vincent Papala, a U.S. bankruptcy judge, wrote in the opinion .
28: How Booker’s old law firm is connected It appears that Stone took two stories about Booker’s old law firm and used them to spin a conspiracy about his involvement in the water scandal.
29: The first story was published by the New York Post in 2013.
30: It reported that Booker’s federal tax returns showed he collected $689,500 in payments from Trenk DiPasquale, the senator’s former law firm, between 2007 and 2012 — while he was mayor of Newark.
31: Booker had previously said he stopped working for the firm in 2006, soon after he became mayor.
32: Booker’s spokespeople told the New York Post at the time that the money wasn’t a salary, but part of a "separation agreement" with the firm.
33: The Daily Beast reported the agreement was paid out for work Booker did for the firm before he became mayor.
34: From 2010 to 2012, Booker reported on his tax returns that he "materially participate[d] in the operation of this business."
35: A Booker spokesman told the New York Post it was an error made by a tax preparer.
36: The second story, published by Politico in January 2017, reported that Elnardo Webster, one of Booker’s longtime advisers, was the general counsel for the watershed while he worked at Trenk (and while Booker was mayor).
37: However, neither he nor Booker have been charged with wrongdoing related to the bribery scandal.
38: The Post reported that, as of 2013, Trenk had made $212,318 from the watershed.
39: That’s one-third of the $600,000 Stone alleged.
40: According to a review of existing media reports and court records, there is no evidence of a money laundering scheme involving the two entities.
41: Booker’s presidential campaign did not respond to a request for comment.

llama2-70b: A claim that Cory Booker, the former mayor of Newark, N.J., stole $600,000 from a city water authority and laundered it through his law firm is false.

This claim stems from a corruption scandal involving the Newark Watershed Conservation and Development Corp.[12] In 2018, Roger Stone, a political consultant, accused Booker of stealing $600,000 from the water authority.
[3] Stone's claim was one-third of the amount he alleged.
[39] However, an investigation by the New Jersey Attorney General's office found no evidence to support the allegation that Booker stole or laundered money from the water authority.
[26] Furthermore, at least eight other individuals connected to the scheme were indicted, but not Booker.

[19] Therefore, based on the lack of evidence and the fact that Booker was not charged or indicted, the claim that he stole $600,000 from a city water authority and laundered it through his law firm is false.

902ad2487955e1eaea16566a6b5614d7.claim: "  Fox News anchor Shepard Smith stepped down after Attorney General William Barr ""had a closed door meeting with Rupert Murdoch."""
902ad2487955e1eaea16566a6b5614d7.label: false
902ad2487955e1eaea16566a6b5614d7.passage:
0: Fox News anchor Shepard Smith announced Oct. 11 that he was stepping away from the network after 23 years.
1: But there’s no evidence that Smith’s departure was connected to a meeting two days earlier between Attorney General William Barr and media mogul Rupert Murdoch, the channel’s founder, despite what some social media posts have implied.
2: "Trump’s Attorney General Bill Barr had a closed door meeting with Rupert Murdoch and the very next day Shepard Smith, one of the only voices on Fox News that is critical of Trump steps down after 23 years," said an Oct. 11 Facebook meme posted by The Other 98% , a progressive activist group focused on combating corporate greed.
3: "But I’m sure it’s just a coincidence!"
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The meme did not explicitly accuse Barr of forcing Smith’s ouster, but it misleadingly implied that his meeting with Murdoch played at least some role in the matter.
7: Several other public figures , such as MSNBC’s Chris Hayes and comedian Kathy Griffin , also speculated on Twitter about a link between the Barr-Murdoch meeting and Smith’s exit.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com But Chris Giglio, Smith’s personal spokesperson, told the New York Times that "there is absolutely no truth" to the notion that the Barr-Murdoch meeting precipitated Smith’s departure.
9: "This was Shep’s decision and his alone," Giglio told the New York Times.
10: "He’s taking an extended period of time off to be with his family.
11: Following that who knows — he is not retiring."
12: CNN’s Brian Stelter and Fox News’s Howard Kurtz both swatted down the idea that Murdoch ushered Smith out at Barr’s behest, as well.
13: CNN reported that Smith asked Fox News management for a way out of his multi-year contract in September, well before Barr’s meeting with Murdoch.
14: Smith was reportedly frustrated by attacks the network’s primetime opinion hosts were making against the news division.
15: One of Fox’s original hires in 1996, Smith was most recently the network’s chief news anchor and managing editor of breaking news.
16: He hosted "Shepard Smith Reporting" on weekday afternoons and frequently drew President Donald Trump’s ire for his reporting.
17: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Smith announced his departure during his show, expressing thanks for the opportunities his career at Fox News gave him and hope "that the facts will win the day, that the truth will always matter, (and) that journalism and journalists will thrive."
18: "Recently I asked the company to allow me to leave Fox News," Smith said on air, echoing a formal statement he made in the network’s press release .
19: "After requesting that I stay, they obliged.
20: Under our agreement, I won’t be reporting elsewhere, at least in the near future."
21: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com The private meeting between Barr and Murdoch occurred Oct. 9, according to the New York Times .
22: It’s not clear who was present or what was discussed, and Fox News and the Justice Department did not respond to our requests for comment.
23: For what it’s worth, we’ve seen false internet posts in the past that suggested Smith was ousted for being critical of Trump.
24: We rated one such claim Pants on Fire in 2018.
25: The Other 98% did not respond to our requests for comment.

llama2-70b: Contrary to what the meme claims, there is no evidence supporting the notion that Attorney General William Barr forced Fox News anchor Shepard Smith's ouster.
In fact, various reliable sources have refuted this claim.

According to PolitiFact.com [17], Smith announced his departure during his show, expressing gratitude for the opportunities his career at Fox News gave him and hope that journalism and journalists will continue to thrive.
Additionally, CNN's Brian Stelter and Fox News's Howard Kurtz[12] dismissed the idea that Rupert Murdoch ousted Smith at Barr's behest.
It's worth noting that Smith asked Fox News management for a way out of his multi-year contract in September [13], well before Barr's meeting with Murdoch on October 9[21].

The meme misleadingly implied that Barr's meeting with Murdoch played a role in Smith's departure, but Chris Giglio, Smith's personal spokesperson, told the New York Times [8] that there is no truth to this notion.
Ultimately, the claim that Smith stepped down because of Barr's meeting with Murdoch lacks evidence and is false.

7270d4a33056e489c0fc262bc7e5df9e.claim: "  Attorney General William Barr tweeted that the US ""gave Iran USA taxpayer dollars"" so Iran could purchase uranium from Russia."
7270d4a33056e489c0fc262bc7e5df9e.label: false
7270d4a33056e489c0fc262bc7e5df9e.passage:
0: U.S. Attorney General William Barr did not really tweet about Iran using American tax dollars to buy uranium from Russia.
1: He doesn’t use a personal account, for one thing.
2: And if you look at the Twitter account claiming to be him, you’ll notice one giveaway: there’s a third L in his first name.
3: A screenshot of the tweet was shared on Facebook , making it look as if Barr wrote the following: "See if you can follow this.
4: A US president gave IRAN USA taxpayer dollars so IRAN could purchase USA Uranium from Russia who just got 20% of our Uranium for FREE.
5: So Iran used USA CASH to purchase USA URANIUM in order to destroy USA ASSETS all made possible by the US GOVERNMENT… This is beyond treason."
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: The tweet was posted by a parody account that uses a misspelled handle of Barr’s name, "@AGWillliamBarr."
9: The parody tweet mixes together two stories.
10: We have previously fact-checked claims surrounding the 2015 agreement with Iran promoted by President Barack Obama.
11: Called the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action , the deal freed up frozen Iranian assets and lifted economic sanctions and included Iran and the United States as well as China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom and the European Union.
12: In return, Iran opened up to international inspections and dismantled key pieces of its nuclear program.
13: (In 2018, President Donald Trump pulled out of the deal).
14: That’s the money the United States "gave" Iran (it wasn’t tax dollars).
15: The reference to Russia stems from an often misunderstood sale of a U.S. uranium company to a Russian business .
16: The two events are in no way linked.

llama2-70b: A viral tweet claiming that Attorney General William Barr said the US government gave Iran taxpayer dollars to buy uranium from Russia is a fabrication.

The tweet in question was not posted by Barr, but by a parody account with a misspelled handle (@AGWillliamBarr instead of @TheJusticeDept).[8] Moreover, the claim that Iran used USA cash to purchase USA uranium to destroy USA assets, as stated in the tweet, is also false.
[5] The money Iran received was not taxpayer dollars but a settlement from a decades-old dispute between the two countries.
[14] The events are not linked.

[16] In conclusion, the claim that Attorney General William Barr tweeted that the US gave Iran USA taxpayer dollars so that Iran could buy uranium from Russia is false, and there is no evidence to support it.

00607a59d4eaaeef94427df8248bbfa4.claim: If Trump tries to lie in a TV ad, most networks will refuse to air it. But Facebook just cashes Trump’s checks.
00607a59d4eaaeef94427df8248bbfa4.label: false
00607a59d4eaaeef94427df8248bbfa4.passage:
0: Sen. Elizabeth Warren escalated her battle to break up Facebook by posting an ad that intentionally included a false account about Mark Zuckerberg backing President Donald Trump.
1: Warren’s goal was to show that the social media giant allows misinformation by Trump.
2: "Breaking news: Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook just endorsed Donald Trump for re-election," the Oct. 10 ad began.
3: "You're probably shocked, and you might be thinking, "how could this possibly be true?"
4: The ad then pivoted to a disclaimer — no, the Facebook CEO did not endorse Trump — before attacking Facebook: "What Zuckerberg *has* done is given Donald Trump free rein to lie on his platform –-- and then to pay Facebook gobs of money to push out their lies to American voters.
5: If Trump tries to lie in a TV ad, most networks will refuse to air it.
6: But Facebook just cashes Trump's checks."
7: Warren’s post followed an unsuccessful push by the Joe Biden campaign to get Facebook to reject a Trump campaign ad about Biden’s role in the firing of a prosecutor in Ukraine.
8: PolitiFact rated a statement in a similar Trump ad False .
9: Facebook denied Biden’s request.
10: We decided to fact-check Warren’s claim that unlike Facebook, most TV networks will refuse to air a political campaign ad that contains falsehoods.
11: While the Warren campaign cited a half dozen examples in recent years of TV networks or stations rejecting ads, we found that broadcast networks are generally required to run candidate ads under federal law.
12: The same law doesn’t apply to cable networks or to PAC ads.
13: Facebook’s policy on ads Facebook does have a partnership with third-party fact-checkers -- including PolitiFact -- to debunk viral hoaxes and demote that content.
14: But Facebook exempts politicians from the fact-checking program, stating that it won’t "referee political debates" or block a politician’s speech from an audience.
15: While Facebook drew attention for an announcement in September about exempting political candidates, that had already been Facebook’s policy since 2017.
16: Christopher Terry, a University of Minnesota professor of communications and expert on political advertising, said that because Facebook is a private unregulated platform, it can do what it wants.
17: "Because Facebook is its own playground, it gets to make its own rules," he said.
18: Facebook has set rules about transparency to show who paid for ads .
19: But it doesn’t restrict political content.
20: Federal rules for television There are rules, however, for television.
