bf848b56338351be7a4711a0a68f2e68.passage:
0: A recent Facebook post revisits well-trodden conspiracy theories about the Clinton family and suggests Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s ambition knows no bounds.
1: "JFK Jr was declared the frontrunner for the NY Senate seat in 1999," the Nov. 5 post says.
2: "Days later his plane crashed, making Hillary Clinton the newly elected senator."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: It’s been shared more than 2,000 times.
6: An identical post from 2017 is nearing 30,000 shares.
7: Here are the facts.
8: On July 16, 1999, John F. Kennedy Jr., his wife and his sister-in-law were killed in a plane crash.
9: Kennedy, then the founder and publisher of George magazine, was piloting the single-engine Piper Saratoga when it plunged into the Atlantic Ocean .
10: Then-President Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton and Chelsea Clinton attended the memorial mass .
11: The National Transportation Safety Board determined that the crash probably happened after Kennedy, who was inexperienced at flying his plane alone at night, became disoriented in haze .
12: Kennedy was not a candidate for any public office when he died.
13: But a few days after this death, the New York Daily News ran a story citing two anonymous friends who said they thought Kennedy would have run for office some day.
14: "Earlier this year, in one of the best-kept secrets in state politics, Kennedy considered seeking the seat of retiring Sen. Daniel Moynihan (D-N.Y.) in 2000, the friends confirmed yesterday," the story says.
15: Though a private poll in 1997 found that JFK Jr. was the state’s most popular Democrat by far, according to the story, "the idea became moot once First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton signaled her interest in running, but the two friends said they expected the son of the slain president eventually would have jumped into politics as a candidate."
16: A 1999 Washington Post story says that a "Kennedy insider" claimed leading Democrats had unsuccessfully approached Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to run for Moynihan’s seat.
17: Hillary Clinton was elected to Moynihan’s vacated seat on Nov. 7, 2000.

llama2-70b: A claim circulating on Facebook suggests that JFK Jr was the frontrunner for the New York Senate seat in 1999 and that his death led to Hillary Clinton's election to the seat.
However, this claim is false [3].
Firstly, Hillary Clinton was elected to the Senate seat vacated by Daniel Patrick Moynihan on November 7, 2000 [17].
This was not in 1999, as the claim suggests.
Furthermore, JFK Jr did not die in 1999.
He passed away on July 18, 1999, in a plane crash [12].
He was not a candidate for any public office when he died, let alone the frontrunner for the NY Senate seat.
Facebook has flagged this post as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation [3].
In conclusion, the claim is baseless and false.

54ce1c670e27385654d620be0ba95a81.claim: people shouldn’t make birthday donations on Facebook because the organization can claim the donation as a tax write-off, and only has to deliver 15% of the donation to the charity organization.
54ce1c670e27385654d620be0ba95a81.label: false
54ce1c670e27385654d620be0ba95a81.passage:
0: You’ve seen the posts on your timeline –– Facebook friends asking for donations to a charity of their choosing in lieu of birthday wishes or presents.
1: But one post circulating on the social media website warns users against using the Facebook feature to make donations.
2: The post begins with, "Do you know what really happens when you donate your birthday to charity on Facebook?"
3: It goes on to say: "1.
4: Even as a charity donations broker, officially Facebook is allowed to say they donated it themselves as a corporate entity.
5: 2
6: As a corporate entity, Facebook is allowed to declare your donation for a tax write off.
7: 3
8: Facebook gets to brag in the media how much they donated to charity, even though it was your money.
9: 4
10: As a charitable donations broker, by law, they only need to actually deliver 15% of your donation to the charity organization you have chosen.
11: DON’T DONATE TO CHARITY VIA FACEBOOK!"
12: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
13: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
14: This isn’t true.
15: Facebook is a donation platform, and one that people appear to be using a lot.
16: The company in September 2019 announced that since 2015, 45 million people have raised over $2 billion on the platform, with over $1 billion of that total coming from birthday fundraisers.
17: What Facebook is not is a "charity donations broker" (in fact, charity experts told us they’ve never heard that term before).
18: The organization told us it does not declare users’ donations as tax write-offs, nor does it deliver only 15% of a person’s intended donation to the charity specified.
19: Facebook members can access more than 750,000 nonprofit organizations using the social media donations platform.
20: Facebook says it vets organizations by checking their 501(c)(3) status, IRS registration and tax ID numbers.
21: Each nonprofit’s Facebook page also includes a link to its detailed profile on GuideStar , an organization that tracks nonprofits using a database designed to help paint a picture of a nonprofit’s activities and health.
22: Facebook spokesperson Roya Winner told PolitiFact in an email that the post’s claims are "completely false."
23: "Facebook never claims any user’s donations as our own, nor are we a ‘charity donations broker.’ We are a donation platform and payments to charities are processed by our licensed, regulated subsidiaries," Winner said.
24: "A donation to a nonprofit through its Facebook Page or a fundraiser on Facebook may be tax-deductible for the person who made the donation."
25: The Facebook help center has a page explaining whether a particular donation is tax-deductible.
26: It explains that since tax laws vary by country and region, users should consult a tax professional and review laws in their area to determine whether their donation is tax-deductible.
27: The website also says that after a donation is made through the platform, a confirmation is sent to the email listed on that person’s Facebook account.
28: The confirmation shows the person made the donation as a charitable contribution, includes the nonprofit’s EIN number, and states that the donor is not receiving any goods or services in return.
29: But what about the claim that Facebook, by law, only needs to deliver "15% of your donation to the charity organization you have chosen?"
30: That’s also bogus.
31: "100% of what’s raised using donate buttons and fundraisers created on Facebook goes to the benefiting nonprofit," Winner wrote in an email.
32: "Nonprofits either receive funds directly from Facebook, or via Network for Good, a Donor Advised Fund we partner with."
33: These are the two main ways nonprofits can raise funds on Facebook.
34: When a nonprofit enrolls in Facebook Payments, it has to raise at least $100 (per nonprofit, not per fundraiser) before it receives a payout directly to its bank account.
35: Funds will roll over until the payout amount reaches the $100 minimum, and the payment process takes about two weeks, Facebook says .
36: The organization should receive the donation about a month after it is made.
37: For nonprofits not registered with Facebook Payments, donations can be dispersed through fundraising platforms Network for Good (used for the U.S, Canada and Australia) or PayPal Giving Fund (used for other international organizations).
38: Network for Good can take 45-75 days for a donation to be received.
39: For PayPal Giving Fund, it’s between 15-90 days.
40: Only nonprofits that are onboarded through Facebook Payments, or through Network for Good or Paypal Giving Fund, are able to fundraise on Facebook.
41: Though some may worry that such contributions made to charities using the for-profit Facebook platform may not be tax-deductible, Winner told us that concern is unfounded.
42: "That’s an inaccurate representation, the donation goes to the organization, not Facebook," she said.
43: "It is stated as a charitable contribution to the specific nonprofit on the confirmation receipt, along with the organization’s EIN number."
44: Facebook covers all fees for donations made on its website to charitable organizations.
45: In November 2017 , the company announced it would drop the 5% transaction fee on donations to nonprofits on its platform.
46: Facebook once had a 4.3% platform fee for personal fundraisers –– which allows people to host their own fundraiser for a personal cause –– but it eliminated that in May 2018 .
47: Personal fundraisers are now subject to a 2.6% payment processing fee plus $0.30.
48: In some countries, additional taxes will be deducted when the money raised is distributed.
49: The fees broken down by country can be found here.

llama2-70b: Claims that Facebook can claim donations made on its platform as a tax write-off and only has to deliver 15% of the donation to the charity organization are unfounded.
A spokesperson for Facebook, Winner, clarified that the donation goes directly to the organization, not Facebook [3][41].
Furthermore, Facebook never claims any user's donations as their own and are merely a donation platform [23].
The company also confirmed that 100% of what's raised using donate buttons and fundraisers created on Facebook goes to the benefiting nonprofit [31].
In addition, Facebook dropped the 5% transaction fee on donations to nonprofits on its platform in 2017 [45].
Therefore, donors can be confident that their birthday donations on Facebook will directly benefit the charity organization of their choice without any deductions or claims by Facebook.
The claim that donors should not make birthday donations on Facebook due to these concerns is, therefore, false.

cbaaeed559e1939c2a02ae588d8e42c1.claim: Defendants charged with producing, directing or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child will be arraigned & set free.
cbaaeed559e1939c2a02ae588d8e42c1.label: half-true
cbaaeed559e1939c2a02ae588d8e42c1.passage:
0: Changes in New York’s bail laws have been hailed by some nonprofit criminal justice organizations as a way to reduce inequities and mass incarceration.
1: The changes will allow people who have been charged with certain crimes to stay out of jail while waiting for their trials without having to come up with money to post bail.
2: But some in law enforcement are critical of the changes, which eliminate money bail for offenses that account for approximately 90 percent of arrests statewide.
3: The union that represents active and retired police officers in New York City made a claim about the new law, which takes effect Jan. 1.
4: In a Twitter post , the New York City Police Benevolent Association said, "Defendants charged with producing, directing or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child will be arraigned & set free."
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com As evidence for its claim, the police union included in its tweet a section of state law regarding child pornography.
6: The union cited section 263.10 of the penal code, which states : "A person is  guilty of promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child when, knowing the character and  content thereof, he produces, directs or promotes any obscene performance which includes sexual conduct by a child less than seventeen years of age.
7: Promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child is a class D felony."
8: We’ve heard many claims about what the new law will do, and we wondered if the police union’s claim is accurate.
9: The law’s details The new law has a list of "qualifying" offenses for which a judge can set bail.
10: These qualifying offenses are serious crimes, and some involve child pornography.
11: Judges are permitted to impose bail under the new law for these offenses: facilitating a sexual performance by a child with a controlled substance or alcohol, use of a child in a sexual performance, or luring a child for the purpose of committing a crime against him or her.
12: On April 1, 2019, when the new law was passed, three people with these qualifying offenses were in jail awaiting trial in New York City, according to a report from the Center for Court Innovation, which advocates for alternatives to incarceration.
13: But not every child pornography charge described in the statute is a qualifying offense.
14: A person charged with the offense cited by the union -- "producing, directing or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child" -- would have to be released and bail would not be imposed.
15: New York’s pretrial law - the current one and the one that takes effect Jan. 1 - does not allow judges to evaluate whether a person is dangerous to the community when deciding whether that person should be held before trial.
16: Unlike in other states, judges can only consider whether a  defendant is likely to return to court .
17: In cases where a judge has doubts about whether the defendant is likely to return, the judge would have to "release the principal" and select a non-monetary option, such as pretrial supervision or travel restrictions, and choose the least restrictive option "that will reasonably assure the principal’s return to court," according to the law.
18: What experts say We spoke with legal experts, some who specialize in prosecution and others in criminal defense.
19: Many agreed with the police union's tweet.
20: But several pointed to what they call a more realistic legal scenario.
21: Taryn Merkl, a former federal prosecutor who led a human trafficking task force in Brooklyn, said that it is hard for her to imagine a set of facts in which a prosecutor would charge only this crime and not something more serious that would require bail.
22: "This doesn’t strike me as the main charge one would bring," said Merkl, who is senior counsel in the Justice Program & Law Enforcement Leaders at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University Law School.
23: The Brennan Center is in favor of ending mass incarceration .
24: We looked at arrest records from New York City since 2006 to get a sense of how often police charge this specific crime.
25: We found that in at least 135 arrests, approximately 10 per year, this charge was the top charge.
26: Merkl noted that that the charges that prosecutors decide to bring in a complaint or indictment can be different from those charges that a police file during an arrest.
27: In addition, charges other than the "top charge" for these defendants could require detention, even if the top charge does not, according to the Center for Court Innovation.
28: Rebecca Town, a criminal defense attorney at the Legal Aid Bureau of Buffalo, which assists low-income people, said the charge cited by the police union is "almost always" accompanied by a sex offense under Article 130 of the state penal code, which allows a judge to set cash bail.
29: "If the individual accused is directly responsible for creating such material, they will be charged with something that is directly a sex offense that would still trigger money bail," Town said.

llama2-70b: According to Reason [3], the New York City Police Department's union claimed that a new state law taking effect on January 1 would allow defendants charged with producing, directing, or promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child to be arraigned and released without bail.
The union cited a state law regarding child pornography as evidence, as stated in Reason [5].
However, PolitiFact found that this claim is only half-true.

According to Reason [14], the law states that a person charged with this offense would have to be released without bail, but Reason [17] states that a judge must choose the least restrictive option that will reasonably assure the principal's return to court.
Reason [21] reports that former federal prosecutor Taryn Merkl expressed skepticism that a prosecutor would only charge this crime and not something more serious that would require bail.
PolitiFact's investigation found that in New York City, this crime is rarely charged alone, as stated in Reason [24].
Further, the Center for Court Innovation clarified in Reason [27] that charges other than the "top charge" for these defendants could require detention, even if the top charge does not.

Furthermore, Town explained in Reason [29] that if the individual accused is directly responsible for creating such material, they will be charged with a sex offense that would still trigger money bail.
Therefore, while the claim has some truth, it is not entirely accurate and has been rated half-true.

95aea65f2de29ca44dc60f218f4bd213.claim: " Texas lawmakers ""left children able to be sterilized and mutilated at any point in their life"" by failing to adopt a law prohibiting minors from undergoing medical or surgical gender transitions."
95aea65f2de29ca44dc60f218f4bd213.label: false
95aea65f2de29ca44dc60f218f4bd213.passage:
0: During an Oct. 31 press conference, leaders from conservative advocacy organizations in Texas urged Gov.
1: Greg Abbott to call a special legislative session to elect a new House speaker.
2: Earlier that month, embattled House Speaker Dennis Bonnen announced that he would not seek re-election to his seat in the House.
3: The activists also outlined policy proposals that they want lawmakers to address during a special session, proposals they say Republican leaders failed to pursue during the regular session earlier this year.
4: Cindi Castilla, president of the Dallas Eagle Forum, said lawmakers need to take steps to limit what gender transition treatments are available to children, in light of an ongoing legal battle in Dallas over the gender identity of a 7-year-old.
5: "During our last session, our legislators decided to pass a law protecting Texans from e-cigarettes until they reach the age of 21," she said.
6: "They left children able to be sterilized and mutilated at any point in their life.
7: This was a failing, and we need a remedy.
8: "Texas Eagle Forum asked lawmakers to carry a very common-sense bill that would protect young Texans.
9: That bill would have protected (the child), no matter what the verdict was going to be from the courts."
10: Before we dive into this check, it should be noted that medical or surgical treatments used by doctors for transitioning must meet the same safety requirements of other medications or surgeries.
11: To suggest that any child might be mutilated by doctors is inaccurate.
12: "Children in Texas are already robustly protected by the Texas Family Code and medical rules of ethics," said Brian Klosterboer, an attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, in a statement.
13: "No one in Texas may harm a child, including parents and medical professionals."
14: When reached via email, Castilla said that she is unaware of any state laws that "protect children from being given treatments that can lead to sterilization and no law prohibiting surgeries that would seek to make a child appear to be a gender different than the gender they were born."
15: "Thus far, it appears very young children have been protected from this only because of the good sense of the medical community," she said.
16: "As we see this protection waning among a small portion of the medical community we would like to make sure that the most vulnerable Texans are protected."
17: Castilla said the bill she mentioned at the press conference would have "protected children from these procedures," but the group could not find a lawmaker to carry the legislation.
18: Dallas custody case The legal battle in Dallas that Castilla mentioned in her remarks is a custody dispute between a mother and father that centers on the gender identity of their 7-year-old child.
19: The child’s mother says the 7-year-old is a transgender girl and wants to dress as a girl and be identified by female pronouns — a process referred to as a social transition .
20: The child’s father disagrees and insists that the child is a boy.
21: The case has spurred a national debate about children and their gender identities, with some Texas Republicans pledging to pursue legislation to prevent minors in Texas from transitioning by medical means.
22: Gillian Branstetter, spokeswoman for the National Center for Transgender Equality, said an important point to consider in this case is the child’s age.
23: "This child is 7 years old," she said, noting that "no one is talking about" pursuing a medical or surgical transition.
24: "We’re talking about gender affirming parenting and letting the child explore who they are."
25: Looking at the law Under federal law, transition-related medical care is considered the same as any other medically-necessary care and carries the same requirements when it comes to minors, according to Branstetter and attorneys with ACLU of Texas.
26: Generally speaking , Texas law dictates that parents have a "duty" to provide medical and dental care to their children and they have the "right" to consent to that care.
27: But pursuing gender transition treatment is an individualized process for transgender and gender non-binary people and can take many forms, according to multiple resources on gender identity and gender dysphoria.
28: People with gender dysphoria — when a person feels a conflict between the gender they were assigned at birth and the gender with which they identify — choose to act on this in different ways.
29: This can include wearing clothes and using pronouns associated with their gender identity; changing their gender and name on legal documents; pursuing hormone treatment or surgical options available for transitioning.
30: Not every person who has gender dysphoria and is transgender will pursue medical or surgical transition treatment.
31: People can be diagnosed with gender dysphoria at any age, even as children.
32: "While some children express feelings and behaviors relating to gender dysphoria at 4 years old or younger, many may not express feelings and behaviors until puberty or much later," reads an article on the subject from the American Psychiatric Association.
33: "For some children, when they experience puberty, they suddenly find themselves unable to identify with their own body.
34: Medical treatment standards prioritize affirmation When it comes to caring for children who might be exhibiting signs of gender dysphoria, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends the "gender-affirmative care model" that prioritizes validating a child’s gender identity and supporting their exploration and expression of that identity.
35: "There are absolutely no medical interventions or surgical interventions on any prepubertal child," said Colt Keo-Meier, a Texas-based psychologist and author who specializes in gender and sexual health.
36: "That is not happening."
37: The widely accepted "Standards of Care" maintained by the World Professional Association for Transgender Health also emphasize this point.
38: "Before any physical interventions are considered for adolescents, extensive exploration of psychological, family, and social issues should be undertaken," the standards read.
39: "The duration of this exploration may vary considerably depending on the complexity of the situation."
40: Once a child starts puberty, other options emerge.
41: Keo-Meier said the most common treatment — medication to delay the onset of puberty — is fully reversible.
42: "That is literally just hitting pause," he said.
43: The World Professional Association for Transgender Health outline minimum criteria that must be met before a child can receive puberty-suppressing medication, including that the child has demonstrated a "long-lasting and intense pattern of gender nonconformity or gender dysphoria" and that it "emerged or worsened with the onset of puberty."
44: Other, interventions like hormone therapy (partially reversible) or surgery (irreversible) won’t be considered until a patient reaches adolescence.
45: Even then, the Standards of Care stress that certain procedures should not be performed until a patient is old enough to consent on their own (typically 16-18 years old) and others should occur only once a person has received other treatments for a specific time period.

llama2-70b:
Claims that Texas legislators left children vulnerable to sterilization and mutilation for life by failing to enact legislation prohibiting minors from undergoing medical or surgical gender transitions are false.
According to experts in the field and legal authorities, this claim is not supported by facts.

First, it's important to note that there are no medical or surgical interventions performed on prepubescent children who identify as transgender or gender non-binary [35].
Furthermore, the most common treatment, which involves medication to delay puberty, is entirely reversible and has no long-term effects [41].

Second, the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH) Standards of Care stress that certain procedures should not be performed until a patient is old enough to provide informed consent (typically between 16 and 18 years old), while others should only be performed after a patient has received other treatments for a specific period [45].

Third, the law treats transition-related medical care no differently than any other medically necessary care, and minors have the same legal requirements for accessing such care [25].

Fourth, pursuing gender transition treatment is an individualized process that can take many forms, and it's not a one-size-fits-all solution [27].

Lastly, it's worth noting that the claim of sterilization and mutilation is not supported by any credible medical or legal evidence.
In fact, experts argue that denying transgender and gender non-binary individuals the right to transition can have severe psychological and emotional consequences [16].

In conclusion, based on the above reasons, the claim that Texas lawmakers left children vulnerable to sterilization and mutilation for life by failing to enact legislation prohibiting minors from undergoing medical or surgical gender transitions is false.
The experts and legal authorities agree that the claim is unsubstantiated and lacks factual support.

1f88bc62c57c8c73f38f3c0a867a461c.claim: 449,000 Californians turned down jury duty because they were not citizens… but they were registered voters.
1f88bc62c57c8c73f38f3c0a867a461c.label: false
1f88bc62c57c8c73f38f3c0a867a461c.passage:
0: A viral Facebook post that has peppered social media for at least a year was given fresh life last month when former vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin shared it on her account.
1: "449,000 Californians turned down jury duty because they were not citizens… but they WERE registered voters," reads the text of the Oct. 2 post.
2: "Let that sink in."
3: This post, which has been shared more than 57,000 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: After searching online and in the Nexis news archive, we couldn’t find this statistic in any news coverage.
6: So we started reaching out to California officials.
7: Sam Mahood, a spokesperson for California Secretary of State Alex Padilla, told us he couldn’t comment on how many Californians declined jury duty on citizenship grounds — that’s not the office’s purview — but he said it’s not true that 449,000 noncitizens were registered to vote.
8: Here’s what else you should know about potential jurors in California.
9: First, people who are summoned for jury duty don’t "turn it down," said Blaine Corren, a public affairs analyst for the Judicial Council of California .
10: Rather, they can be excused from jury duty for various reasons, or a court can disqualify them from serving based on a number of factors including not being 18 or older, having a felony conviction on their record or for not being a citizen of the United States.
11: The council collects statewide data on how many people were excused or disqualified and why — with some caveats.
12: That information comes to the council from individual trial courts but since there’s no requirement that courts provide this data, some courts and categories may be missing in the Jury Data Reports the council produces.
13: The data the state keeps on why someone was excused from jury duty includes financial hardship and physical or mental disabilities, but not citizenship status.
14: The Judicial Council of California does, however, keep track of how many people were disqualified for jury duty because they’re not citizens.
15: We requested the council’s reports through the most recent fiscal year for which a completed report is available, which was July 2017-June 2018.
16: Our analysis shows that, annually, around 1 million people — citizens and noncitizens — are disqualified from jury duty in California.
17: Approximately half aren’t citizens.
18: From July 2008 through June 2017, about 11.3 million people were disqualified.
19: Of those, about 4.7 million were disqualified for not being a U.S. citizen.
20: In 2017-2018, 1,063,784 people overall were disqualified with 425,814 for not being citizens.
21: But it was fiscal year 2016-17 that has a figure that comes closest to the claim in the Facebook post: Among 1,096,478 people who were disqualified for jury duty that year, 449,404 were disqualified for not being U.S. citizens.
22: But that doesn’t mean that those rejected juror candidates were registered to vote.
23: One of the primary sources courts use to summon jurors is the voter registration list, Corren said.
24: The other is the state Department of Motor Vehicles’ list of licensed drivers and identification card holders in the area served by the court.
25: Noncitizens, such as lawful permanent residents, can get driver’s licenses.
26: As of 2015 , undocumented immigrants in California can, too.
27: So it follows that noncitizens — both lawful permanent residents and undocumented immigrants — would be summoned for jury duty as courts tap potential jurors from DMV data.
28: "These two lists are considered inclusive of a representative cross-section of the population, according to the California Code of Civil Procedure," Corren said.
29: But, he added, courts could seek jurors from other sources like telephone directories and utility company lists.
30: In Nevada County, Calif., for example, 97 potential jurors were excused because they weren’t citizens, said Jason Galkin, court executive officer of the Superior Court there.
31: Galkin said the county tapped them from a list it got from the DMV.
32: But searching for their names on the voter registration list, he said, there were no matches.
33: In fiscal year 2017-2018, three Sierra County residents were dismissed from jury duty because they weren’t citizens but none of them were registered voters, said Jean-Anne Cheatham, a court assistant there.
34: Karen Dalton, a spokesperson for the San Diego County Superior Court, told us most courts in California use the DMV’s driver’s license database as its primary source for the jury master list and then augment that with the voter registrar's list.
35: In California, noncitizens can get driver’s licenses so, again, it follows that noncitizens would appear for jury duty in San Diego County, among others.
36: The DMV has a "motor voter" program that automatically registers eligible driver’s license applicants unless they opt out.
37: Sometimes, Corren said, people will inadvertently mark themselves down to register to vote and it’s possible that the lists courts receive from the DMV include these individuals.
38: That information also goes to the California Secretary of State’s office to determine whether to add them to the voter rolls, according to Corren.
39: The office then reviews the lists and cancels requests to register to vote from people who aren’t eligible, he said.
40: Three Republican voters recently sued Secretary of State Padilla over the "motor voter" program, claiming that the state enables voter fraud by failing to investigate voters’ citizenship status, Courthouse News Service reported on Oct. 1.
41: Since the DMV started automatically registering people to vote in April 2018, it acknowledged making 105,000 processing errors out of more than 2.4 million, according to a January Sacramento Bee story , and at least one noncitizen came forward to say he was improperly added to the voter rolls.
42: But that doesn’t mean that 105,000 noncitizens cast ballots.
43: Sam Mahood, with the secretary of state’s office, told us he doesn’t know of any recent convictions for noncitizens registering to vote.
44: It’s also a far cry from the Facebook post’s claim: that 449,000 noncitizens were registered voters who had also been summoned for jury duty and turned it down.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claimed that 449,000 Californians turned down jury duty because they were not citizens, yet they were registered voters[44].
However, our analysis shows that this claim is false[16].
The claim appears to have originated from a misunderstanding of the process by which Californians are summoned for jury duty and the relationship between jury duty and voter registration.
In California, potential jurors are summoned from data provided by the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV)[27], which includes both citizens and noncitizens who have driver's licenses.
Noncitizens can legally obtain driver's licenses in California[26], and they may be summoned for jury duty if their names appear on the DMV's list[37].
However, this does not necessarily mean that they are registered voters.
According to Sam Mahood, a spokesperson for California Secretary of State Alex Padilla, it's not true that 449,000 noncitizens were registered to vote[7].
While there have been isolated incidents of noncitizens being improperly registered to vote[41], there is no evidence to suggest that this occurs on a large scale.
In fact, Mahood told us he doesn't know of any recent convictions for noncitizens registering to vote[43].
In fiscal year 2017-2018, three Sierra County residents were dismissed from jury duty because they weren't citizens, but none of them were registered voters[33].
This supports the notion that being summoned for jury duty does not automatically mean that a person is registered to vote.

Furthermore, our analysis shows that around 1 million people - citizens and noncitizens - are disqualified from jury duty in California annually, with approximately half of them not being citizens[16][17].
In conclusion, the claim that 449,000 Californians turned down jury duty because they were not citizens, yet they were registered voters, is false.
While noncitizens may be summoned for jury duty, this does not necessarily mean that they are registered voters.
The available evidence does not support the claim, and there is no reason to believe that large-scale voter fraud is occurring in California.

63950ee6ee72541502a965036d809124.claim: If we make no changes over the next 10 years, Americans will reach into their pockets and pay out about $11 trillion on insurance premiums, copays, deductibles and uncovered medical expenses.
63950ee6ee72541502a965036d809124.label: true
63950ee6ee72541502a965036d809124.passage:
0: Promoting her much-discussed plan to create a single-payer "Medicare for All" health system, Sen. Elizabeth Warren emphasized a striking figure.
1: "If we make no changes over the next 10 years, Americans will reach into their pockets and pay out about $11 trillion on insurance premiums, copays, deductibles and uncovered medical expenses," the Democratic presidential candidate said in an Instagram video posted Nov. 4.
2: The Democratic health care debate has been full of competing analyses and estimates about what Medicare for All might cost, what it might save and who would bear the brunt of paying for it.
3: But this precise number was new to us.
4: If true, it would be a figure both staggering and significant to the unfolding debate, as Americans try to understand how Warren’s brand of a single-payer health system could affect their pocketbooks.
5: So we decided to dig in.
6: A reasonable estimate We contacted the Warren campaign, which redirected us to a report from the Urban Institute, a Washington think tank, as well as to federal estimates of household out-of-pocket expenses and premium costs over the next decade.
7: The Urban report doesn’t include the $11 trillion figure.
8: But economist Linda Blumberg, who authored the paper , told us the statistic is "perfectly consistent" with the analysis.
9: If anything, she said, the number is a lowball figure.
10: When Blumberg and her team crunched the numbers, they found that, under the existing health care system, Americans can expect to pay $11.7 trillion between out-of-pocket costs – the copays, deductibles and uncovered medical expenses – and premiums over the next decade.
11: That calculation comes from Urban’s model for projecting what individual households might expect to spend, factoring in inflation, on these types of health costs.
12: "Talking about the amount of money we expect households to be spending over time is a very important part of trying to educate people on what single-payer would do, and what the tradeoffs are for them," said Blumberg, who previously advised the Clinton White House on health policy.
13: On the numbers, "they’re roughly in the right neighborhood," she added.
14: We consulted other analysts, too, and as far as we can tell, no one else has done a similar calculation.
15: Experts told us that Urban’s estimate — and the Warren campaign’s use of it — checks out, based on what we know about American health care spending.
16: Cynthia Cox, a vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation and expert on the Affordable Care Act, pointed to what a typical American family currently spends on health care: about $5,000 per year, when you look at out-of-pocket costs and premiums combined.
17: Extrapolating from there, she said, Warren’s claim seems reasonable.
18: (Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent program of the foundation.)
19: "Over the course of 10 years, when you add it up — that sounds about right," Cox said.
20: "The reality is, people do spend a lot on health care out of their pockets, and there’s a lot spent on their behalf by employers or taxpayer-funded programs that they never see."
21: Under Warren’s health care plan, Americans would pay nothing directly out-of-pocket — no premiums, copays or deductibles — for health care.
22: So that $11 trillion would disappear from the cost side of the ledger.
23: The figure Warren sited also tracks with national health expenditure projections for out-of-pocket health costs and health premium growth.
24: The bigger picture Still, there are serious questions about the financing such a shift would require.
25: And Warren’s Medicare for All plan has been under intense scrutiny since she unveiled it earlier this month, with many critics suggesting it’s too optimistic in its estimates of how much money a single-payer system would cost.
26: Warren suggests the federal government would need to come up with $20.5 trillion — well below Urban’s estimate of $34 trillion.
27: The difference comes largely from assumptions about how much the government could save, as well as decisions about how much to pay doctors and hospitals.
28: Warren’s financing structure includes cracking down on tax evasion, new taxes on financial institutions and the wealthiest Americans, and maintaining what many employers currently pay into the system.
29: Critics say that could yield its own inefficiencies.
30: For instance, the way employer payments are structured could disproportionately harm small businesses, or lower-wage workers, noted Paul Ginsburg, who directs the USC-Brookings Schaeffer Initiative for Health Policy.
31: He also argued that doctors and hospitals —represented by powerful lobbying organizations in Washington — could successfully battle any effort to pay them less, driving up what the government needs to spend.
32: Still, those disputes are separate from the question of this particular statistic.
33: Here, Warren’s on firm ground.
34: Analysts also said the $11 trillion number gets at a larger point.
35: Americans currently pay a lot out-of-pocket on health care.
36: Certainly, some might see a tax hike under Warren’s proposed reform, or see downward pressure on their salaries.
37: Still, others could experience major pocketbook relief.
38: To be sure, Medicare for All is not the only approach to ameliorating what families pay for health care.
39: Other, more incremental proposals — such as building on the ACA’s coverage expansions or pursuing a "Medicare for all who want it" approach touted by former Vice President Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg, the South Bend, Ind., mayor — would cut into the $11 trillion as well, Cox said.
40: While it wouldn’t eliminate that household cost burden, it would require less in taxes to finance.
41: "There’s a lot of ways to bring down what people spend on health care," Cox said.
42: "Any expansion of the role of public programs is likely to bring down individuals’ costs.
43: It’s just a question of how much taxes have to go up to pay for that."

llama2-70b: Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat from Massachusetts, said that if the country does not make any changes to its healthcare system over the next decade, Americans can expect to spend about $11 trillion out of pocket on healthcare costs like insurance premiums, copays, deductibles, and uncovered medical expenses[21].

This figure is supported by research conducted by Blumberg and her team, who found that under the current healthcare system, Americans can expect to pay $11.7 trillion in out-of-pocket costs and premiums over the next ten years[10].
Additionally, Warren's plan would eliminate out-of-pocket healthcare costs for Americans entirely, as they would no longer have to pay premiums, copays, or deductibles[21].
Furthermore, the figure Warren cited aligns with projections for national health expenditure growth in out-of-pocket health costs and health premiums[23].
According to Blumberg's analysis, Warren's claim seems reasonable[17].

Therefore, based on the supporting evidence, the claim that Americans will pay approximately $11 trillion out of pocket for healthcare costs over the next decade if no changes are made to the healthcare system is found to be true[1][2][3].

57e1bd6533c41cf4af22107bef2b0650.claim: a Craigslist ad offered to pay actors to be Trump supporters for a rally.
57e1bd6533c41cf4af22107bef2b0650.label: false
57e1bd6533c41cf4af22107bef2b0650.passage:
0: President Donald Trump’s rallies for reelection around the country are sometimes followed by suspicious posts that say his crowd support is purchased rather than genuine.
1: One version posted Nov. 1 appears to show a Craigslist ad offering to pay people to pose as Trump supporters — "minorities welcome and needed!"
2: The screenshot shows the title of the ad, "Actors needed (Phoenix Convention Center)," with the following description: "Actors/help needed for event tomorrow form 2-11p.m.
3: $15 per hour.
4: Duties include protest activity and holding signs that are Pro Trump.
5: Minorities welcome and needed!
6: Looking to fill about 500 spots.
7: Reply and ask for Allen and mention the CL ad."
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: This isn’t the first time a mysterious ad for pro-Trump actors has popped up online.
11: In 2017 , around a rally the president held in Phoenix, a similar advertisement soliciting actors to hold pro-Trump signs and cheer on command was shared on the internet.
12: According to media reports, the 2017 Craigslist ad was deleted.
13: One article by the New York Daily News reported the phone number attached to the ad belonged to a recent 18-year-old high school graduate who became bombarded with profane phone calls, texts and voicemails.
14: The man told KHOU 11 that he wasn’t connected to the president or anyone hiring for the rally.
15: Another ad in October 2018 claimed to solicit paid attendees to a Trump rally in Erie, Pa.
16: But fact-checking website Snopes found that the advertisement was not associated with the president, or any Trump-related organizations, but rather "to a man named Mike Oles, who appeared to have connections to left-leaning activist groups including one called Good Jobs Nation."
17: Good Jobs Nation was apparently planning a demonstration at the same rally.
18: Our search of Craigslist listings for the ad in the Phoenix area turned up no results.
19: A Trump campaign spokesperson told PolitiFact that the president does not need to pay people to attend events and called the ad part of a "recurring hoax."
20: These types of bogus advertisements appear to be intentionally created to make it look like the Trump campaign or those affiliated with the president’s events need to pay actors to show support.

llama2-70b: A Craigslist ad that surfaced on November 1, sparked controversy as it appeared to offer payment to actors to pose as Trump supporters for a rally in Phoenix.
However, a fact-checking investigation has revealed that the claim associated with the ad is false.
Several reasons support this conclusion.

Firstly [1], the ad was flagged by Facebook as part of their efforts to combat false news and misinformation.[2] The ad's title, "Actors Needed (Phoenix Convention Center)," and description, including the mention of "pro-Trump" signs and protest activity, raised suspicions.
Furthermore, [5] the ad specifically stated, "Minorities welcome and needed!" which seemed unusual for a legitimate Trump campaign ad.
Moreover, [10] this is not the first time a similar ad has appeared online.

In 2017, around the time of a Trump rally in Phoenix, an ad soliciting actors to hold pro-Trump signs and cheer on command was shared on the internet.[12] That ad was later deleted, and media reports revealed that the phone number attached to the ad belonged to a recent high school graduate who was bombarded with profane calls and messages [13].
The man denied any connection to the president or the rally.
Additionally, [15] an ad in October 2018 claimed to solicit paid attendees to a Trump rally in Erie, Pa.

However, Snopes found that the advertisement was not associated with the president or any Trump-related organizations but rather with a man named Mike Oles, who had connections to left-leaning activist groups [16].
A search of Craigslist listings for the ad in the Phoenix area yielded no results [18].
A Trump campaign spokesperson also stated that the president does not need to pay people to attend events, calling the ad part of a "recurring hoax"[19].
In conclusion, the claim associated with the Craigslist ad offering payment to actors to pose as Trump supporters is false.
The ad appears to be intentionally created to make it look like the Trump campaign or those affiliated with the president’s events need to pay actors to show support [20].

458f02cb273682ab72e94073fb835dbe.claim: " President Donald Trump's phone call with the Ukrainian president ""sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did."""
458f02cb273682ab72e94073fb835dbe.label: false
458f02cb273682ab72e94073fb835dbe.passage:
0: Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., suggested that threats by President Donald Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden to withhold aid from Ukraine were "exactly" the same.
1: Speaking on Meet the Press days before the first public hearings on impeachment, Paul said that Americans want fairness.
2: "And I don't think they're going to judge fairness, when they're accusing President Trump of the same thing Joe Biden did, threatening the aid, if some kind of corruption is not investigated.
3: And it seems like everybody, both parties, have been threatening aid, if some kind of investigation either doesn't happen or is ended.
4: And so I think, really, what's going to happen is people are going to say, ‘Oh, they're impeaching President Trump for exactly the same thing that Joe Biden did.’" Paul continued : "He threatened the aid, if they didn't fire someone.
5: And supposedly, the president did, if they didn't investigate someone.
6: So it sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did.
7: And if they weren't going to impeach Joe Biden, they look like, you know, hypocrites, in a way, for going only after President Trump and having not a word to say about what Joe Biden did."
8: U.S. Rep. Jim Himes, D-Conn., disputed Paul’s characterization later on in the show.
9: "Let's be very clear.
10: The president of the United States demanding, extorting a vulnerable country to do his political bidding, to go after his opponent, has nothing to do with Joe Biden executing the foreign policy of the United States," Himes said .
11: We found that Paul created a false equivalency when summarizing the actions of Trump and Biden.
12: The two cases are not the same, or even particularly similar.
13: We told a Paul spokesperson that based on our previous fact-checking , the actions by Trump and Biden are not the same.
14: "The question itself shows the bias of the media on this issue," a spokesperson replied.
15: "The motivations of then-Vice President Biden clearly could have included shielding his family and their oligarch patron from scrutiny, yet this is dismissed because of bias. "
16: What the evidence shows about Biden’s actions Paul’s reference to Biden threatening aid stems from when Biden called for Ukraine to fire prosecutor general Viktor Shokin.
17: Biden assumed a lead role in U.S. diplomacy toward Ukraine after a popular revolution in early 2014 that led to pro-Russia President Viktor Yanukovych fleeing the country.
18: Shokin became top prosecutor in 2015.

llama2-70b: The claim that President Donald Trump's phone call with the Ukrainian president "sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did" has been circulating in political discourse.
However, a closer examination of the facts reveals that this claim is false.
One of the main reasons cited for this claim is that both parties have been threatening aid, either for an investigation or for not investigating someone [3].
While it is true that President Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine, this was not done in exchange for an investigation, as was the case with Joe Biden.

Biden, in his lead role in U.S diplomacy toward Ukraine, called for Ukraine to fire prosecutor general Viktor Shokin[16], and the evidence shows that this was done to address corruption and not as a personal favor or to influence an election [17].
Moreover, it is not accurate to say that President Trump's actions are similar to what Joe Biden did [12].

Biden's actions were aimed at addressing corruption in Ukraine, while President Trump's actions have been seen as an attempt to influence the 2020 elections by requesting Ukraine to investigate his political rival, Joe Biden, and his son Hunter Biden[1].
Another reason cited for this claim is that President Trump did what Joe Biden did, as both have been accused of using their positions to influence investigations[5][6].

However, there is no evidence to support the claim that Joe Biden used his position to influence an investigation in Ukraine for personal gain, and the evidence shows that his actions were aimed at addressing corruption [17].
In conclusion, while the claim that President Trump's phone call with the Ukrainian president "sounds exactly like what Joe Biden did" has been widely circulated, it is false.
The evidence shows that Biden's actions were aimed at addressing corruption, while President Trump's actions have been seen as an attempt to influence the 2020 elections.
The two cases are not the same or even particularly similar.

2d897212946eb1f4dec2c163d2dcd937.claim: "  House Democrats passed impeachment rules that ""do not allow any witness to be called unless the witness is approved by Adam Schiff,"" ""do not allow involvement of the President’s legal counsel"" and ""do not allow any witness to be questioned unless the question is approved by Adam Schiff."""
2d897212946eb1f4dec2c163d2dcd937.label: false
2d897212946eb1f4dec2c163d2dcd937.passage:
0: It didn’t take long after the Democratic-led House of Representatives formalized the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump for misinformation to start circulating about the rules of the road.
1: One post published Oct. 31 makes three claims about the Democrats’ impeachment resolution: that the rules "do not allow any witness to be called unless the witness is approved by Adam Schiff," "do not allow involvement of the President’s legal counsel," and "do not allow any witness to be questioned unless the question is approved by Adam Schiff."
2: "Welcome to the USSR," the post reads.
3: The post, which has been shared more than 2,300 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: As chair of the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., has led the House investigation into a July phone call in which Trump asked the president of Ukraine to investigate the business dealings of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son.
6: A key question is whether Trump held up military and State Department aid in exchange for the Biden probe.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) Our research shows that the Facebook post about Schiff’s role is flawed.
8: We reached out to Trump Rules, a conservative Facebook page with nearly 150,000 followers, for the source of its post and did not hear back.
9: Here’s what you need to know from the House impeachment resolution : • Witness requests from ranking minority member Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif., must go through Schiff first — but the decision to allow them is not Schiff’s alone.
10: • Trump gets counsel during Judiciary Committee hearings, but not during Intelligence Committee hearings.
11: The Judiciary Committee leads official impeachment proceedings in the House, while the Intelligence Committee leads the investigation.
12: • The Democrats’ resolution does not require questions of witnesses to first be approved by Schiff.
13: Calling witnesses The House resolution says requests from members to call witnesses to provide testimony must be submitted in writing to Schiff.
14: They have three days to do that after a hearing is announced.
15: But the Facebook post overreaches in saying that the rules "do not allow any witness to be called" without his approval.
16: Here’s what the resolution says about the power of members in the minority: "To allow for full evaluation of minority witness requests, the ranking minority member may submit to the chair, in writing, any requests for witness testimony relevant to the investigation described in the first section of this resolution within 72 hours after notice is given for the first hearing designated pursuant to paragraph (1).
17: Any such request shall be accompanied by a detailed written justification of the relevance of the testimony of each requested witness to the investigation described in the first section of this resolution."
18: That means any request from Nunes for additional testimony must go through Schiff.
19: RELATED: PolitiFact's Trump-Ukraine-Biden coverage in one place The impeachment resolution says that if Schiff were to refuse a request for additional witnesses, Republicans can bring the matter to a vote by the entire Intelligence Committee.
20: There are 22 members of the committee, meaning the ultimate decision to call witnesses would not just come down to Schiff.
21: However, in practice, it’s reasonable to assume that the Democratic majority would vote with Schiff.
22: Democrats did not come up with these rules out of thin air.
23: They borrowed from House investigation procedures that Republicans passed in 2015, said Frank Bowman, a law professor at the University of Missouri and an impeachment expert, in an email.
24: The president’s legal counsel The claim that the impeachment resolution does not permit Trump a lawyer is only partially accurate — the two House committees leading the inquiry have different rules.
25: The first is the Intelligence Committee, which has been investigating Trump’s interactions with Ukraine.
26: Under the House resolution, there is no role for the president’s lawyers to cross-examine witnesses, submit new evidence or provide a formal defense during hearings called by that committee.
27: However, the Judiciary Committee, which will assess the Intelligence Committee’s findings, is permitted to carry out its work "as to allow for the participation of the President and his counsel," according to the resolution.
28: And the Judiciary Committee has described a clear role for the president’s counsel in those hearings.
29: "The rules do permit participation by (the president’s) counsel, unless (the president) blocks production of evidence requested by (the) Committee," Bowman said.
30: Witness questioning The House resolution does not say Schiff must approve all questions during impeachment proceedings.
31: RELATED: There’s no evidence Schiff helped write the whistleblower complaint Here’s what the rules say about questioning witnesses: "The chair and ranking minority member of the Permanent Select Committee shall be permitted to question witnesses for equal specified periods of longer than five minutes, as determined by the chair.
32: The time available for each period of questioning under this paragraph shall be equal for the chair and the ranking minority member."
33: Per those rules, Schiff and Nunes will each have the opportunity to question witnesses.
34: The resolution says nothing about Schiff approving Nunes’ questions ahead of time.
35: "The questioning rule seems a complete invention," Bowman said.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that House Democrats passed impeachment rules that severely restricted the participation of the President's legal counsel and the questioning of witnesses has been flagged as false news by Facebook.

The post claims that the rules do not allow the President's legal counsel to be involved, do not allow any witness to be called without Adam Schiff's approval, and do not allow any witness to be questioned unless the question is approved by Adam Schiff.
However, an examination of the text of the resolution reveals that these claims are inaccurate.

According to the resolution, the committee may request the testimony of any witness it deems necessary, accompanied by a detailed written justification of the relevance of the testimony to the investigation [15].

While the chairperson of the committee, Adam Schiff, plays a role in the process, the ultimate decision to call witnesses would not come down to him alone, as there are 22 members of the committee who also have a say [20].
Moreover, the Judiciary Committee has outlined a clear role for the president’s counsel in hearings, contrary to the claim that they are not allowed to be involved [28].
Therefore, the claim that the impeachment rules passed by House Democrats restrict the involvement of the President's legal counsel and the questioning of witnesses is false.

66acf3a3213c4225a054817db12cffd3.claim: " A photo of ""Obama’s White House staff"" shows the alleged Ukraine whistleblower."
66acf3a3213c4225a054817db12cffd3.label: false
66acf3a3213c4225a054817db12cffd3.passage:
0: Remember that picture of then-President Barack Obama’s White House staff "crying the day after Trump won the election?"
1: That’s what a recent Facebook post asks before claiming to identify one of the men in the photo as "the alleged Ukraine call whistleblower."
2: This post, published on Nov. 5, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The photo is real , though we wouldn’t describe the people in it as crying.
5: AFP photographer Nicholas Kamm took it on Nov. 9, 2016, as U.S. National Security Adviser Susan Rice and White House communications director Jen Psaki, among others, listened to Obama address the nation after Donald Trump’s election.
6: The Facebook post points to the man to the far right of the photo and describes him as the whistleblower who alleged Trump is soliciting foreign interference from Ukraine in the 2020 election.
7: The whistleblower has legal protection from retaliation and U.S. officials have kept that person’s name confidential.
8: Most news organizations have also withheld the name, though, as the Washington Post reports , the name of a CIA officer has appeared widely on social media as posts claim to out him as the whistleblower.
9: But it’s not R. David Edelman, the man in this photo.
10: On Nov. 7, he tweeted another image claiming that he’s the whistleblower.
11: "Here’s a picture of the ‘whistleblower’ see the ‘NERD’ in the picture...his face is circled," it said.
12: "FAKE NEWS," Edelman tweeted, " the ‘NERD’ circled below is the whistleblower.
13: TRUE (just not news): the ‘NERD’ circled below is...this nerd.
14: Me.
15: Left government in 2017.
16: Sorry to disappoint, y’all."
17: "This photo was on the cover of @washingtonpost, people," he added .
18: "Seriously, even conspiracy theories deserve a quick google fact check."
19: Before he left government in January 2017 , Edelman was a special assistant to the president for economic and technology policy, leading policy development and coordination on issues related to the digital economy, according to a White House bio .
20: He also served as senior advisor for internet, innovation and privacy at the Office of Science and Technology Policy, and he was the first director of international cyber policy at the White House National Security Council.
21: He’s included on the 2016 annual report to Congress listing White House office personnel and their pay.
22: But his name doesn’t appear on the June 30, 2017, report .
23: That’s because on March 3, 2017, MIT announced that Edelman was joining its internet policy research initiative.
24: As director of the school’s project on technology, the economy and national security , he leads the initiative’s AI policy research.
25: But the whistleblower complaint that led to the U.S. House impeachment inquiry details recent government work, describing "official duties," "official interagency business" and colleagues — U.S. officials, not academics.

llama2-70b: A photo of Obama's White House staff doesn't show the alleged Ukraine whistleblower, despite the claims.
The person in the photo is not R. David Edelman, the whistleblower, but rather a different individual[9].

The image was taken by AFP photographer Nicholas Kamm on November 9, 2016, and it shows U.S. National Security Adviser Susan Rice and White House communications director Jen Psaki, among others, listening to President Obama's address to the nation following Donald Trump's election [5].
The whistleblower complaint that led to the U.S. House impeachment inquiry does mention recent government work, but it does not mention anything about the person in the photo [25].
Additionally, the whistleblower left the government in 2017 [15].
Therefore, based on the given reasons, the claim that a photo of Obama's White House staff shows the alleged Ukraine whistleblower is false.

a4829132b492a50c9bbb822b9dfe8ba1.claim: Photos show the whistleblower with Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton.
a4829132b492a50c9bbb822b9dfe8ba1.label: false
a4829132b492a50c9bbb822b9dfe8ba1.passage:
0: "My, my, my said the liar to the fly," begins a Nov. 10 Facebook post featuring former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi smiling in photographs with a man.
1: "Here’s your whistleblower.
2: Trump 2020."
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: That’s because the photo doesn’t show the whistleblower.
6: The man in the photos is Alexander Soros, the son of Democratic fundraiser George Soros and deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundations .
7: He posted the photo with Pelosi on Instagram on Sept. 2.
8: "Inspiring meeting with speaker @nancypelosi," he wrote.
9: As she says: our #diversity is our strength, our #unity is our power!
10: #bluewave2020" He posted the photo with Clinton back in July 2016.
11: "There can only be one #womancrushwednesday today and that is of course @hillaryclinton, not just for being the first woman to run for president from this nation’s two largest political parties, but I believe the best presidential candidate this nation could have today!," he wrote.
12: The whistleblower who alleged Trump is soliciting foreign interference from Ukraine in the 2020 election has legal protection from retaliation.
13: U.S. officials have kept that person’s name confidential and most news organizations have also withheld the name.
14: This photo’s claim is wrong, and even commenters on this Facebook post have offered corrections.

llama2-70b: A post on Facebook claims that photos show the whistleblower with Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton.

However, reason 5 states that the photo doesn't show the whistleblower, and reason 6 identifies the man in the photo as Alexander Soros, son of George Soros and deputy chairman of the Open Society Foundations.
Additionally, reason 14 states that the claim is wrong, and even commenters on the Facebook post have offered corrections.
Therefore, based on these reasons, the veracity of the claim is false.
It is important to note that the Facebook post contains incorrect information, and it is not accurate to say that the photos show the whistleblower with Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton.
It is essential to fact-check information before sharing it to avoid spreading false information.
The post has been corrected by commenters, and it is vital to rely on credible sources when sharing information to ensure accuracy and truthfulness.[1][5][6][14]

7202fca7eaec1f583cd2000c2d71c2d7.claim: "  Obama said black people have the ""worst jobs, the worst housing"" and face rampant police brutality, ""but when so-called black committeemen came around election time we’d all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket, sell our souls for a Christmas turkey."""
7202fca7eaec1f583cd2000c2d71c2d7.label: false
7202fca7eaec1f583cd2000c2d71c2d7.passage:
0: A Facebook ad by a PAC supporting President Donald Trump distorts a statement in a book by President Barack Obama about African American voters.
1: The ad by the Committee to Defend the President is entitled "Enough Empty Promises" and targets African American voters.
2: "Democrats promised to help our community," the narrator says.
3: "Promises they never kept."
4: The ad then pivots to Obama: "Here is President Obama: 'Plantation politics.
5: black people in the worst jobs, the worst housing, police brutality rampant.
6: But when the so-called black committeemen came around election time, we’d all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket, sell our souls for a Christmas turkey.'
7: " The narrator then continues: "Enough empty promises.
8: President Trump promised us jobs and he delivered.
9: Democrats don’t care about us."
10: The ad ran Nov. 8 largely in states with a significant African American population including Georgia, Michigan and Louisiana.
11: Trump is trying to chip away at the wide margin by which African Americans vote for Democrats.
12: His ad coincided with his "Black Voices for Trump" visit in Atlanta.
13: (Judd Legum, who writes the newsletter Popular Information, tweeted about the ad the day it first started running.)
14: The ad takes words from a book by Obama where he was talking from the perspective of someone else.
15: It takes those words out of context and gives them a meaning they didn’t have.
16: What Obama wrote in his book We’ve heard a similar ad before from a pro-Trump group.
17: During a congressional election in Georgia in 2017, Great America Alliance ran a radio ad aimed at cutting African American turnout for Democrat Jon Ossoff.
18: We rated that ad Pants on Fire.
19: The voice in that and the current ad sounds like Obama’s, but the words were not his own views.
20: They came from Obama reading from his 1995 book " Dreams From My Father " about his days as a community organizer in Chicago.
21: He recounted his conversation with a barber he called Smitty about Chicago’s first black mayor, Harold Washington.
22: Smitty explains Chicago politics to Obama, who told the barber he was not in Chicago for the election of Washington.
23: Here’s how the scene plays in the book: "Had to be here before Harold to understand what he means to this city," Smitty said.
24: "Before Harold, seemed like we’d always be second-class citizens."
25: "Plantation politics," the man with the newspaper said.
26: "That’s just what it was, too," Smitty said.
27: "A plantation.
28: Black people in the worst jobs.
29: The worst housing.
30: Police brutality rampant.
31: But when the so-called black committeemen came around election time, we'd all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket.
32: Sell our souls for a Christmas turkey.
33: White folks spitting in our faces, and we’d reward ‘em with the vote."
34: In his book, Obama then described the power of African Americans to shape their political destiny when they are unified.
35: Obama wrote: "They had turned out in record numbers on election night, ministers and gang-bangers, young and old.
36: And their faith had been rewarded."
37: In Smitty’s words, "The night Harold won, let me tell you, people just ran the streets,…."
38: he said, recounting how the community was proud of Washington and themselves.
39: "When I woke up the next morning, it seemed like the most beautiful day of my life."
40: The pro-Trump ad uses the passage to create the impression that Obama believed that black voters, ignored and suffering, sold their soul to the Democrats at election time.
41: But the actual book passage is about the good things that come from voting.
42: Chad Banghart, the executive director of the PAC, told us that he thinks it is clear that the ad is Obama reading from his book.
43: However, the ad never states the context of Obama’s words.
44: Banghart also suggested that Smitty the barber was a fictional creation.
45: In the introduction of the book, Obama wrote that for the sake of compression some of the characters are composites .
46: He wrote that other than family or public figures, the names of most characters were changed to protect their privacy.
47: The Chicago Tribune identified the location of the barber shop in 2008 and in this 2015 graphic .
48: The ad also said that "President Trump promised us jobs and he delivered."
49: We found in August that the unemployment rates and poverty rates for African Americans are indeed at or near historical lows, as Trump indicated.
50: However, there were also declines under Obama too.
51: The text on the ad included attacks on four of the Democrats running for president: former Vice President Joe Biden and U.S.
52: Senators Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.
53: These attacks related to Biden’s record opposing school busing , Harris’ record as a prosecutor , Warren’s statements identifying herself as Native American , and Sanders’ statements on reparations .

llama2-70b: A viral claim that former President Barrack Obama made derogatory comments about African Americans is false.
The claim attributes a quote to Obama from his book "Dreams from My Father."
According to fact-checking website PolitiFact, the quote in question is taken out of context [14][15].
In the book, Obama writes about the perspectives of a local resident he met in Chicago while working as a community organizer, who expressed disappointment with the political system [41].
Obama does not express his own opinions or views on the matter.
Furthermore, the claim fails to mention that the quote is from a passage about the importance of voting [41].
The ad never states the context of Obama's words, giving them a meaning they didn't have [43].
Furthermore, the claim quotes Obama as saying black people have the "worst jobs, the worst housing" and face rampant police brutality.
This is a misrepresentation of his words in the book, which do not mention police brutality or housing [34].
In conclusion, the claim is false and misleading as it misrepresents a quote from Obama's book, takes it out of context, and adds words that he did not write.

7aced0d36442700530dc661a02e5767e.claim: Did you know? Dentists are the only physicians that believe you can get away with leaving dead tissue in the body. One root canal tooth can shut down 63% of your immune system.
7aced0d36442700530dc661a02e5767e.label: false
7aced0d36442700530dc661a02e5767e.passage:
0: The theory that root canals cause serious illnesses has been debunked for years but seems to have gained new life on the internet after the documentary "Root Cause" was released on streaming platforms in 2019.
1: The film by Australian filmmaker Frazer Bailey is largely based on discredited dental research from the early 1900s and was pulled from Netflix in early 2019 amid backlash from dentistry organizations, academics and professionals.
2: Social media about the film lives on, however, including one viral post on Facebook that says the procedure substantially weakens the body.
3: The post displays an illustration of a row of teeth along with text that says: "Did you know?
4: Dentists are the only physicians that believe you can get away with leaving dead tissue in the body.
5: One root canal tooth can shut down 63% of your immune system."
6: The text outside of the picture advises people to watch "Root Cause" and also makes the startling claim that, of all the women diagnosed with breast cancer, "98% had a root canal on the same side."
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: A root canal repairs damaged or infected teeth.
10: Instead of extracting an infected tooth, endodontists drill into the center of the tooth’s root to clean and fill the canals.
11: The film alleges that infections inside of root canals cause a myriad of serious health problems, including cancer.
12: It instructs viewers to have any teeth treated with root canals removed and replaced with a bridge or implant.
13: The documentary reportedly includes commentary by alternative medicine physicians who have taken controversial stances on health topics including vaccines and Ebola treatments, according to an article by the Philly Voice.
14: The American Dental Association told PolitiFact the film’s claims have been disproven by decades of peer-reviewed, scientific evidence and may cause people unnecessary alarm.
15: The organization said it worked with the American Association of Endodontists and the American Association for Dental Research to contact platforms hosting the film, which included Netflix, Amazon and Vimeo.
16: (The film is no longer available on Amazon Prime video but can still be rented or purchased on Vimeo.)
17: The groups shared the concern that the documentary spreads misinformation, and that hosting such a film "does a disservice to the public because it may cause unwarranted alarm to the point where people might avoid a very necessary dental procedure."
18: The American Dental Association added that approximately 25 million new endodontic treatments, which includes root canals, are performed safely each year.
19: The UCLA School of Dentistry also released a statement regarding the film: "The people in this movie are spreading misinformation and confusion about root canal treatment that is misleading and harmful to the consumer public.
20: Their premise is based on junk science and faulty testing conducted more than 100 years ago that was debunked in the 1950s, continuously since then and is even more discredited today by physicians, dentists and academics.
21: Mainstream medical and dental communities overwhelmingly agree that root canal treatment is safe, effective and eliminates pain."
22: The idea that bacteria trapped inside an endodontically-treated tooth will cause illness stems from research conducted by Dr. Weston Price in the 1920s.
23: Price’s research suggested bacteria trapped in "dentinal tubules" during a root canal could "leak" and cause almost any type of degenerative systemic disease including arthritis and diseases of the kidney, heart, nervous, gastrointestinal, endocrine and other systems, according to a fact sheet on root canal safety by the American Association of Endodontists.
24: The organization reported that Price advocated for extraction instead, resulting "in a frightening era of tooth extraction both for treatment of systemic disease and as a prophylactic measure against future illness."
25: In the time since, multiple reports and reviews published in scientific journals –– such as the Journal of the American Dental Association and the Journal of the American Medical Association –– have criticized Price’s research methods and discredited his findings.

llama2-70b: A post on social media is making the rounds, spreading information that one root canal tooth can shut down 63% of the immune system.
The post cites a film that claims a link between root canals and immune system shutdown.
However, according to [3], the American Dental Association, and other reputable health organizations, this claim is false and not backed by scientific evidence.
In fact, the ADA told PolitiFact that the film's claims have been disproven by decades of peer-reviewed scientific evidence and may cause people unnecessary alarm [14].

Moreover, the groups shared the concern that the documentary spreads misinformation, and that hosting such a film "does a disservice to the public because it may cause unwarranted alarm to the point where people might avoid a very necessary dental procedure."[17].

The premise of the film is based on junk science and faulty testing conducted more than 100 years ago that was debunked in the 1950s and continuously since then and is even more discredited today by physicians, dentists, and academics [20].
In contrast, mainstream medical and dental communities overwhelmingly agree that root canal treatment is safe, effective, and eliminates pain [21].

Multiple reports and reviews published in scientific journals –– such as the Journal of the American Dental Association and the Journal of the American Medical Association –– have criticized Price’s research methods and discredited his findings [25].
In conclusion, the claim that one root canal tooth can shut down 63% of the immune system is false, and the information being shared on social media is not backed by scientific evidence.
It is important to rely on credible sources of information and consult with healthcare professionals before making decisions about healthcare treatments.

67c5810fe3fff3120aa2fa6a29959e6c.claim: Many of the people in DACA, no longer very young, are far from ‘angels.’ Some are very tough, hardened criminals.
67c5810fe3fff3120aa2fa6a29959e6c.label: false
67c5810fe3fff3120aa2fa6a29959e6c.passage:
