llama2-70b: Contrary to the claim, a photo does not show a pack of wolves walking in a single line in the snow being led by the sick.
According to experts, the pack is not being led by the older, sick wolves[32], and the "alpha" or leader wolf is not bringing up the rear[33].
Instead, a strong wolf leads the pack single-file in order to save energy to get through the deep snow[3].
The leader sets the pace for the rest of the pack, walking in front to lead the way[16].
The image was taken by Chadden Hunter in 2011 for the BBC series and features a pack of timberwolves hunting bison in Canada’s Wood Buffalo National Park[17].
Therefore, the claim is false.

5581235a220bb21c4e7148d4884e175b.claim: They never thought ... that I was going to release that call and I really had no choice because Adam Schiff made up a call.
5581235a220bb21c4e7148d4884e175b.label: false
5581235a220bb21c4e7148d4884e175b.passage:
0: President Donald Trump argues that his July 25 phone call with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky was "perfect," and that Democrats have distorted it to build their case for impeachment.
1: In an interview with conservative show host Dan Bongino, Trump said a false rendition of that call by House Intelligence chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif., forced him to release the readout of that call .
2: "They never thought, Dan, that I was going to release that call, and I really had no choice because Adam Schiff made up a call," Trump said Nov. 15 .
3: "He said the president said this, and then he made up a call."
4: The problem with Trump’s statement is that Schiff spoke after the White House released the memo of the phone call, not before.
5: The timeline Sept. 9, 2019: Michael Atkinson, inspector general of the intelligence community, notifies Rep. Adam Schiff, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, that there was a whistleblower complaint of "urgent concern."
6: Sept. 19, 2019: Atkinson briefs the House Intelligence Committee in a closed-door session.
7: Sept. 24, 2019: House Democrats launch a formal impeachment inquiry.
8: Sept. 25, 2019: The White House releases a declassified summary of the July 25 telephone call between Trump and Zelensky.
9: Sept. 26, 2019: Schiff makes opening remarks at a hearing with Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence.
10: Maguire was questioned because he had not forwarded the inspector general’s findings to conference.
11: Trump complained before about Schiff’s words At that Sept. 26 hearing, Schiff offered a dramatized synopsis of Trump’s call with Zelensky.
12: He described rhetorically the nature of Trump’s message to Ukraine.
13: Trump later latched on to Schiff’s words, saying he was lying to the public.
14: "Rep. Adam Schiff illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement, pretended it to be mine," Trump tweeted Sept. 30 .
15: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We can find no other version of Schiff describing the call before the summary emerged.
16: We reached out to the White House and did not hear back.

llama2-70b: President Trump claimed that Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, had fabricated a phone call, which compelled him to release the memo of the conversation.
However, this claim is false.
According to reason [3], President Trump's statement is inaccurate because he maintains that Schiff spoke before the release of the call memo, which is inconsistent with the timeline of events.
In fact, Schiff spoke after the White House released the memo, as stated by reason [4].
Furthermore, a thorough search, as shown in reason [15], did not reveal any evidence of Schiff describing the call before the summary emerged.
In conclusion, President Trump's claim that he had no choice but to release the call because Adam Schiff made up a call is false.

e566995b2bc4b20ae5c027f79547554c.claim: "  Governor Cooper has vetoed ""every single teacher pay raise we've ever passed."""
e566995b2bc4b20ae5c027f79547554c.label: half-true
e566995b2bc4b20ae5c027f79547554c.passage:
0: When it comes to teacher pay, Republicans and Democrats say the other side isn’t doing enough.
1: And, with elections less than a year away, Republicans are slamming Gov.
2: Roy Cooper for using his veto power.
3: NC Rep. David Lewis, a Republican from Harnett County, recently tweeted about Cooper’s history of vetoing proposals passed by the legislature.
4: "Gov.
5: Cooper just vetoed another pay raise that the #NCGA passed, as he has every single teacher pay raise we've ever passed," Lewis tweeted .
6: Lewis went on to say that he’s "tired of Cooper using teachers as political pawns, blocking their raises then trying to convince them he cares."
7: Is it true that Cooper has vetoed every proposed teacher raise the legislature has passed since January 2017, when he took office?
8: Contacted by PolitiFact, Lewis spokesman David Capen said in an email that Cooper has vetoed four opportunities to raise teacher pay.
9: Lewis is suggesting that Cooper is opposed to raises in teacher pay.
10: But, when you look at the reason Cooper vetoed the proposals, you’ll see Cooper hoped to secure better raises for teachers.
11: Cooper vetoed: The 2017 State Budget ( S257 ), saying in his veto message it adopts a tax plan that "will fail to fund promised teacher salary increases in future years."
12: The 2018 State Budget ( S99 ), saying it "falls short of what our teachers and public education need."
13: The 2019 State Budget ( H966 ), saying "we should be investing in public schools, teacher pay and health care instead of more tax breaks for corporations."
14: The Strengthening Educator Pay Act ( S354 ), saying "educators deserve more if our schools are to remain competitive with other states and keep good teachers."
15: Seeking higher raises Cooper vetoed the GOP proposals in hopes of negotiating even higher raises.
16: But the governor and Republican legislative leaders have yet to strike a deal.
17: "Every budget Governor Cooper proposed has contained significantly higher teacher pay raises than the Republican budgets, which deserved vetoes because they shortchanged teachers and prioritized corporate tax cuts," Cooper spokeswoman Megan Thorpe said in an email.
18: For example, she said Cooper’s budget sought to pay first-year teachers $37,500.
19: That’s $2,500 more than the legislative budget proposal, according to the governor’s office.
20: The gap was wider for experienced teachers, Thorpe said.
21: For teachers with 30 years of experience, Cooper proposed $58,000 and the legislature proposed $53,100.
22: Political drama aside, some teachers will get more money in their checks this year.
23: Cooper signed the Teacher Step Act earlier this month, authorizing raises for teachers who had previously qualified for them (by adding another year of work experience.)
24: But Lewis and others don’t consider that signature to be progress in the debate over long-term teacher pay.
25: Step raises The Teacher Step Act authorized raises that had been previously-approved.
26: In other words, the legislation didn’t enact a new raise structure -- which is at the heart of the teacher pay debate.
27: But it did have a real-world effect of funnelling more money into teachers’ pockets.
28: "Step increases are not considered ‘raises’ in the traditional sense, as teachers (and other educators paid on the step schedule) earn them based on years of service," Mark Jewell, president of the N.C. Association of Educators, told PolitiFact in an email.
29: Jewell told the News & Observer in October that lawmakers shouldn’t get any credit for funding step increases that are required under state law.
30: "It’s state law that teachers get their steps based on the step schedule, so in this case all the step bill did was fully fund what was already guaranteed," he told PolitiFact.
31: Still, even though the raises had been previously negotiated, Cooper’s signature was key.
32: Under the State Budget Act, no step increases are actually funded without legislative approval.
33: (see page 22).

llama2-70b: Governor Roy Cooper's vetoes of teacher pay raises have been a contentious issue in North Carolina politics.
A claim that he has vetoed "every single teacher pay raise" passed by the legislature is half-true, according to PolitiFact.
While it is true that Cooper has vetoed several pay raise proposals, his reasons for doing so are important to consider.
Under the State Budget Act, no step increases are funded without legislative approval [3].
Cooper has vetoed four opportunities to raise teacher pay, according to a spokesman for Rep. David Lewis [8].
However, when examining the reasons behind Cooper's vetoes, it becomes clear that he hoped to secure better raises for teachers [10].
Cooper's budget proposals have contained higher teacher pay raises than Republican budgets, which he believed shortchanged teachers and prioritized corporate tax cuts [17].
Although he signed the Teacher Step Act authorizing raises for eligible teachers, it didn't implement a new raise structure, which is central to the teacher pay debate [23][26].
Therefore, while it is accurate that Cooper has vetoed multiple teacher pay raise proposals, his motivations for doing so were to advocate for better compensation for teachers.
The claim that he has vetoed every single teacher pay raise is half-true, considering the context behind his vetoes.

984828e03a4a76844d9c1fb4d5d7665e.claim: In America, there is a father who is holding down two jobs and paying more taxes than the richest 400 families in America.
984828e03a4a76844d9c1fb4d5d7665e.label: false
984828e03a4a76844d9c1fb4d5d7665e.passage:
0: One theme U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris sounds in her 2020 presidential campaign is that "justice is on the ballot."
1: The California Democrat did so repeatedly in a Facebook video ad , which leads off with this claim: "In America, there is a father who is holding down two jobs and paying more taxes than the richest 400 families in America."
2: Her statement is based on a study that produced startling headlines , such as one in the Washington Post: "For the first time in history, U.S. billionaires paid a lower tax rate than the working class last year."
3: But Harris misfired by making her claim about taxes paid instead of tax rates.
4: Also, the study, while produced by two prominent economists, makes estimates based on assumptions that are not universally accepted among economists.
5: The study The study, published as a book about a month before Harris’ claim, was done by leading economists Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman of the University of California, Berkeley, whose work PolitiFact has relied on for previous fact-checks.
6: Harris’ campaign told us Harris was referring to rates, even though that isn’t what Harris said.
7: The study said that in 2018, the average effective tax rate paid by the bottom half of American households was 24.2% — a full percentage point higher than the 23% rate paid by the 400 richest families.
8: As the book puts it, "the Trumps, the Zuckerbergs and the Buffetts of this world pay lower tax rates than teachers and secretaries."
9: So, to use Harris’ example, a typical father with two jobs pays a higher tax rate than the richest 400 American families — according to one study by prominent economists.
10: That’s not the same as paying more taxes.
11: Indeed, an individual with $1 million in taxable income would pay roughly $230,000 in all federal and state taxes, Howard Gleckman , a senior fellow at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, told us.
12: Someone with $50,000 in taxable income would pay about $12,000.
13: Criticism of the study Moreover, the study Harris relied on makes estimates for 2018, and its methodology has come in for criticism from some economists.
14: That isn’t to say that the study is wrong or that the critics are right.
15: But the picture isn’t as clear as Harris’ statement suggests.
16: Federal tax data for 2018 were not available, so the Saez-Zucman study had to do extrapolations, Gleckman wrote in a critique of the study.
17: That is "no easy feat," because of fundamental changes made by the 2017 Republican tax cuts; plus, the study excluded certain federal tax credits received by lower- and middle-income people.
18: The upshot, according to Gleckman: Incomes of the very rich are rising faster than for all other income groups, and Trump’s tax law cut the taxes of high earners by more on average than for low- and moderate-income households; "but that doesn’t mean that billionaires paid a lower tax rate than the working class."
19: A similar criticism was made by economists Aparna Mathur of the American Enterprise Institute and Kyle Pomerleau of the Tax Foundation.
20: The Saez-Zucman study, they wrote , "rests on several unconventional methodological assumptions which, in our opinion, biases the outcome towards finding relatively lower tax rates on the wealthy compared to the poor and overstates the decline in top earners’ tax burdens."
21: David Splinter , an economist at Congress’ Joint Committee on Taxation, also found fault with the Saez-Zucman study’s methodology and conclusion that tax rates are nearly equal for people at opposite ends of the income scale.
22: The joint committee, the Tax Policy Center, the U.S. Treasury, the Congressional Budget Office and economists all have found that federal taxes are progressive, he wrote in a critique of the study.
23: The study’s assumptions, Tax Foundation economist Erica York told us, "go against the widely-accepted methods that exist for determining tax burdens, without providing a convincing reason for doing so."
24: Saez referred us to a frequently asked questions web page that explains the study’s rationale and addresses some of the criticism.
25: University of Wisconsin-Madison economist Andrew Reschovsky praised the study, but called Harris’ claim misleading.
26: "In dollar terms, the father holding down two jobs is certainly paying less in taxes than the taxes paid by the richest families," Reschovsky told us.
27: "What Harris should have said, is that the father holding down two jobs is paying a larger share of his income in taxes than the average richest families are paying in taxes relative to their incomes."
28: But, again, that scenario comes from a study that is in some dispute.

llama2-70b: A claim was made by Kamala Harris that a father who is holding down two jobs is paying more taxes than the richest 400 families in America [3].
Unfortunately, Harris' claim is false.

According to a study by prominent economists, the average effective tax rate paid by the bottom half of American households was 24.2%, which is higher than the 23% rate paid by the 400 richest families [7].
However, it's important to note that this doesn't mean the father pays more taxes than the richest families; it simply means that he pays a higher tax rate [9].
Some economists have criticized the study's methodology, which makes estimates for 2018 and excludes certain federal tax credits received by lower- and middle-income people [13][17].

Additionally, Erica York of the Tax Foundation stated that the study's assumptions go against widely-accepted methods for determining tax burdens without providing a convincing reason for doing so [23].

In dollar terms, the father holding down two jobs pays less in taxes than the richest families, but he pays a larger share of his income in taxes than the average richest families pay in taxes relative to their incomes[26]
Therefore, Harris' claim that the father pays more taxes than the richest 400 families is incorrect.

a2887fa94183b4e36c076ac26073471e.claim: a photo of a tortured man is U.S. diplomat Chris Stevens, who was killed in the 2012 Benghazi attack.
a2887fa94183b4e36c076ac26073471e.label: false
a2887fa94183b4e36c076ac26073471e.passage:
0: On Sept. 11, 2012, terrorists attacked the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, resulting in the deaths of four Americans.
1: Since the attack, internet rumors have claimed that Chris Stevens, the U.S. ambassador killed in the attack, was tortured and raped before his death.
2: PolitiFact fact-checked the claim when it first surfaced and found it to be a combination of fabrication and unsupported speculation.
3: We rated it Pants on Fire.
4: A new viral post goes further, however, using a gruesome photo of a man being tortured as evidence of the false claim that Stevens was tortured and contrasting that photo with an image of Marie Yovanovich, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.
5: In the post , text alongside the photo of the tortured person reads: "This ambassador was tortured, raped, cattle-prodded, and burned for 7 hours with no help from Obama or Hillary.
6: No impeachment inquiry."
7: Below it is a photo of Yovanovitch, who is seated facing a camera during her Nov. 15 testimony in the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump.
8: The text accompanying her picture reads: "This ambassador had her feelings hurt by President Trump.
9: Must impeach now!"
10: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: But this photo depicting violence does not show ambassador Stevens.
13: The image, in fact, appeared on the internet years before Stevens’ death.
14: Facebook screens the troubling torture image from viewers until they click on an "Uncover Photo" icon, warning first that, "This photo may show violent or graphic content."
15: As we previously reported , speculation that Stevens was raped and tortured prior to his death is unsupported.
16: The rumor does not line up with government reviews of the attack and its aftermath, or with contemporaneous media reports and video footage .
17: A website called "The Meme Policeman" reported that it found the photo on the internet as early as 2004 when it appeared in a story by Spanish newspaper Diario de León about Argentinian military torture.
18: We can’t verify that it was shared that early, as the article’s link no longer works, and it doesn’t appear in a search of internet archives.
19: Nevertheless, we did find the image posted on various blogs as early as 2009 .
20: As well, a reverse-image search shows versions of the photo on the internet as early as 2008 –– four years before Stevens’ death.
21: Various blog posts make a myriad of claims about the image’s origin.
22: It has been used to illustrate articles about Spanish war crimes, Argentinian war crimes and CIA torture in Afghanistan.
23: While we weren’t able to pinpoint its exact origin or date, it is clear that this photo existed online several years before Stevens’ death.

llama2-70b: A photo of a tortured man that has been claimed to be U.S. diplomat Chris Stevens, who was killed in the 2012 Benghazi attack, is false.
Reason[3]
states that the claim has been rated as "Pants on Fire."
Reason[12] explains that the photo does not show ambassador Stevens, while Reason[13] adds that the image appeared on the internet years before Stevens' death.
According to Reason[17], the photo was found on the internet as early as 2004, when it appeared in a Spanish newspaper's story about Argentinian military torture.
Reason[20] states that a reverse-image search shows versions of the photo on the internet as early as 2008, four years before Stevens' death.
Reason[23] clarifies that while the exact origin or date of the photo cannot be pinpointed, it is clear that it existed online several years before Stevens' death.
Based on these facts, the claim that the photo is of Chris Stevens is false.

52bea914061b04d9a6f2dca801afd26c.claim: "  Chris Wallace tweeted to Donald Trump, ""You’re a fraud. A charlatan. A thug. A loser. A trust fund baby."""
52bea914061b04d9a6f2dca801afd26c.label: false
52bea914061b04d9a6f2dca801afd26c.passage:
0: President Donald Trump drew quick news coverage when he tweeted criticism of Fox News host Chris Wallace.
1: ".
2: @SteveScalise blew the nasty & obnoxious Chris Wallace (will never be his father, Mike!)
3: away on Chris’s lowest rated (unless I’m on it) morning show," Trump said on Nov. 17.
4: "This kind of dumb and unfair interview would never have happened in the @FoxNews past.
5: Great job Steve!"
6: According to a Nov. 20 Facebook post making the rounds, Chris Wallace sent out a scathing Twitter response: "@realDonaldTrump And you’ll never be your father either, (Fred Trump), a self made Billionaire," the post appears to show Wallace tweeting at Trump.
7: "You’re a fraud.
8: A charlatan.
9: A thug.
10: A loser.
11: A trust fund baby.
12: A punk.
13: A serial adulterer.
14: A pussy grabber.
15: My job is to be a journalist, not a flunky and a propaganda arm for your criminal behavior and corruption.
16: If you want propaganda, go watch Hannity, Ingram, Pirro, and Tucker who do nothing but kiss your ass."
17: The quote is fabricated.
18: Wallace never tweeted that — and he doesn’t appear to have a public, verified Twitter account.
19: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
20: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
21: There are some clues, like how the supposed tweet in the Facebook post is center justified whereas Trump’s real tweet is left justified.
22: Or how the @FoxNewsSunday handle is made to look like it is Chris Wallace’s personal Twitter account, when it’s actually the official account for the Fox show he hosts.
23: On Nov. 17, Fox News Sunday only tweeted clips from the show — including the segment featuring House Minority Whip Steve Scalise , R-La., discussing the impeachment hearings.
24: The account also retweeted country singer Toby Keith, who was promoting an upcoming appearance on the show.
25: The account didn’t reply to anyone that day, nor since.
26: Additionally, we found no personal Twitter account for Wallace.
27: A Fox News host aggressively attacking the president would have garnered the same kind of attention as Trump’s salvo, but we could find none.

llama2-70b: Donald Trump claimed that Chris Wallace tweeted, ""You’re a fraud.
A charlatan.
A thug.
A loser.
A trust fund baby.
"" However, fact-checking reveals this claim to be false.
According to Reason[17], the quote is fabricated and there is no evidence to support that Chris Wallace ever tweeted those words.
In fact, Reason[18] states that Wallace never tweeted that, and he doesn't seem to have a public, verified Twitter account.
Moreover, Reason[27] notes that if a Fox News host had aggressively attacked the president in a tweet, it would have received similar attention to Trump's statement, but no such tweet exists.
Therefore, the claim that Chris Wallace tweeted those words is false and lacks any credible evidence.

c80668b9a4dd637919516ec2bfacb361.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi said, ""It is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate."""
c80668b9a4dd637919516ec2bfacb361.label: false
c80668b9a4dd637919516ec2bfacb361.passage:
0: In a 12:15 a.m. tweet on Nov. 19, President Donald Trump bashed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., for an impeachment quote that she never said.
1: In the tweet , in which he tagged Fox News, President Trump wrote: "Nancy Pelosi just stated that ‘it is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate.’ @FoxNews In other words, she thinks I’m going to win and doesn’t want to take a chance on letting the voters decide.
2: Like Al Green, she wants to change our voting system.
3: Wow, she’s CRAZY!"
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com In reality, the statement was a Fox News reporter’s distorted paraphrase of comments Pelosi made in a memo to fellow House Democrats.
5: Within hours of Trump’s tweet, a viral Facebook post shared by the page "President Trump Fans" started to circulate the misattributed quote.
6: The post displays a black-and-white image of Pelosi and attributes the same "it is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate" statement to her.
7: Text below the quote reads: "Ahh!
8: So this is the reason for the fake impeachment inquiry!"
9: It was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: Pelosi never said those words.
12: During an 11 p.m. segment roughly an hour before Trump’s tweet, Fox News chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel said on camera, "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi circulated a memo to Democrats tonight telling them it would be dangerous to let voters decide President Trump’s fate when it comes to the Ukraine investigation."
13: But here’s what Pelosi actually wrote in the memo , which she titled, "Dear Colleague": "The weak response to these hearings has been, ‘Let the election decide.’ That dangerous position only adds to the urgency of our action, because the President is jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections."
14: Emanuel did not say he was quoting Pelosi directly, but his paraphrase is distorted.
15: Pelosi said waiting for the election is dangerous because she believes the president is "jeopardizing the integrity of the 2020 elections."
16: She did not say it’s "dangerous to allow voters to decide Trump’s fate."
17: Emanuel, Trump’s tweet, and the Facebook post oversimplify and misconstrue what Pelosi wrote.

llama2-70b: During an 11 p.m. segment, Fox News chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel said on camera, "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi circulated a memo to Democrats tonight telling them it would be dangerous to let voters decide President Trump’s fate when it comes to the Ukraine investigation."
This statement was later supported by a Facebook post and a tweet from President Trump, which oversimplified and misconstrued Pelosi's written statement.
However, despite these claims, Pelosi never said, ""It is dangerous to let the voters decide Trump’s fate."" Therefore, the claim is false [12][3][17].

a51c61963df3d538788043e30bd257be.claim: "  a photo shows CNN chyrons that read, ""Democrats ask, ‘Why even have a Second Amendment?'"" and ""CNN Exclusive: China cracks down on pro democracy demonstrators."""
a51c61963df3d538788043e30bd257be.label: false
a51c61963df3d538788043e30bd257be.passage:
0: Two images that appeared in a recent Facebook post appear to show stills from a CNN broadcast — but the network says they’re not real.
1: "Breaking news," begins the first chyron below a photo of an assault-style weapon, "CNN Exclusive: Democrats ask, ‘Why even have a Second Amendment?’" "Breaking news," says the chyron on the second image, "CNN Exclusive: China cracks down on pro democracy demonstrators."
2: This post, published Nov. 20, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: Both images have the same boxes in the corner, one showing the Dow and another promoting a "Trump speech in Florida" at 8 p.m. Eastern Time.
5: "Both fake," CNN told us in an email.
6: Searching CNN’s site, we found lots of stories about the gun control debate .
7: One 2017 story features Sean Duffy, the former Republican congressman from Wisconsin, discussing gun control laws.
8: The headline is: "Duffy: Dems want to eradicate 2nd Amendment."
9: But we saw none claiming that Democrats are asking "Why even have a Second Amendment?"
10: Though CNN likewise has coverage of the unrest in Hong Kong, we couldn’t find the story described in the second image, which features a Getty Images photo of riot police firing tear gas at pro-democracy protesters during an August demonstration in Hong Kong.

llama2-70b: A viral photo that purports to show CNN chyrons, which are captions that appear at the bottom of a television screen, has been circulating.
The chyrons in the photo read, "Democrats ask, 'Why even have a Second Amendment?' and "CNN Exclusive: China cracks down on pro-democracy demonstrators."
However, according to CNN, both of these chyrons are fake [5].
Despite having coverage of the unrest in Hong Kong, CNN did not run a story with the tear gas image in the second picture, which is a Getty Images photo [10].
This misleading image was flagged by Facebook's independent fact-checking partners, of which CNN is a partner [3].
Therefore, the claim that a photo shows CNN chyrons with these two headlines is false.

684b85ff5ad98992cdedff79b3fe5aab.claim: "  ""President Obama fired every Bush appointed ambassador upon his election."""
684b85ff5ad98992cdedff79b3fe5aab.label: false
684b85ff5ad98992cdedff79b3fe5aab.passage:
0: The latest ousted U.S. official to feel the wrath of the president’s loyalists is Marie Yovanovitch.
1: In April, she was abruptly removed from her job as ambassador to Ukraine in response to pressure from the president’s personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani.
2: (Giuliani and other former Ukrainian officials stood to lose from her anti-corruption initiatives.)
3: Now, Yovanovitch is a key witness in House Democrats’ impeachment investigation into President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine.
4: The president’s supporters have tried to discredit Yovanovitch — and the entire probe, for that matter.
5: U.S. Rep. Mark Meadows, a Republican from western North Carolina who chaired the conservative Freedom Caucus, recently brushed off Yovanovitch’s removal as routine.
6: In a tweet following Yovanovitch’s testimony before the House Intelligence Committee on Nov. 15, Meadows wrote: "For Washington Democrats and pundits who are incredulous that @realDonaldTrump recalled an ambassador, certain that it must be evidence of a conspiracy… President Obama fired every Bush appointed ambassador upon his election."
7: We wondered whether it was true that Obama fired all of Bush’s politically-appointed ambassadors.
8: It’s typical for incoming presidents to replace politically-appointed ambassadors There are two breeds of ambassadors: political appointees and career diplomats.
9: Political appointees are usually stationed in countries that are U.S. allies or desirable locations, like the Bahamas .
10: These plum jobs are often awarded to the president’s friends and donors.
11: They step aside when a new president is elected.
12: Peter Feaver, a political scientist at Duke University, said, "It is customary for political ambassadors to rotate out within the first several months of a change in administration precisely because one of their top assets — their closeness to the occupant of the Oval Office — disappears with the departing president."
13: Those are the people who cycled out when Obama took office.
14: That’s standard practice.
15: In his tweet, Meadows linked to a Washington Post article from Dec. 2008 to back up his claim.
16: The article said that the Obama administration told all of Bush’s politically-appointed ambassadors to vacate their posts by Jan. 20.
17: But we found at least a couple of examples of Bush’s politically-appointed ambassadors staying in their posts past Inauguration Day, which also is standard practice.
18: One example: Bush appointee Victor Ashe told PolitiFact that the Obama team asked him to continue serving as ambassador to Poland until his successor was confirmed.
19: He ended up staying for nine months into Obama’s first term.
20: "I was flattered," Ashe said.
21: "I thought it was a tribute to my service, that I acted in a nonpartisan way."
22: A Snopes article from 2017 concluded, "We found similar examples of presidents allowing ambassadors appointed by their predecessors to remain at their posts past Inauguration Day for every presidential transition dating back to 1977, when Jimmy Carter succeeded Gerald Ford."
23: So, it’s not accurate to say that Obama "fired every Bush appointed ambassador."
24: Indeed, he wasn’t even the one to ask for their resignations.
25: Ashe told us that the ambassadors received notice from the Bush White House requesting a letter of resignation effective Jan. 20, 2009.
26: In routine fashion, they obliged.
27: Many of Bush’s political appointees left their posts by Inauguration Day, but Ashe and some others were asked to withdraw their resignations and stay on during the transition, Ashe said.
28: But Yovanovitch’s removal wasn’t routine It’s important to note that Yovanovitch’s case is different.
29: She is a career diplomat, not a political appointee, who has served under three presidents.
30: Also, she was ousted more than two years into Trump’s presidency, not during a transition period.
31: Career diplomats hold the majority of ambassadorships.
32: They are foreign service officers who rose through the ranks, often serving for decades before becoming ambassadors.
33: While it’s customary for political appointees to cycle out when a new president takes office, career diplomats usually stay in their posts.
34: In his tweet, Meadows tried to characterize Yovanovitch’s removal as routine — and Democrats’ criticisms about Yovanovitch’s ouster as invalid.
35: But he’s applying the practice of replacing political appointees — and wrongly characterizing what Obama did, to a large extent — to career diplomats.

llama2-70b: Career diplomats usually stay in their posts when a new president takes office, unlike political appointees who cycle out [33].
In fact, they rise through ranks and often serve for decades before becoming ambassadors [32].
Marie Yovanovitch, for instance, is a key witness in House Democrats’ impeachment investigation into President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine, despite being a career diplomat [3].
Additionally, Yovanovitch's removal wasn't routine [28], and she was ousted more than two years into Trump's presidency, not during a transition period[30].
Therefore, the claim that President Obama fired every Bush-appointed ambassador upon his election is false [35].
The practice of replacing political appointees cannot be applied to career diplomats, and characterizing what Obama did as such is misleading [35].

3ee7bbf6b00d0dbeb1e8556c04b777c2.claim: Since President (Donald Trump’s) election, 36,000 jobs have been created in WI.
3ee7bbf6b00d0dbeb1e8556c04b777c2.label: true
3ee7bbf6b00d0dbeb1e8556c04b777c2.passage:
0: Visiting Wisconsin to tout economic progress and push for an updated North American trade deal, Vice President Mike Pence made the case that Wisconsin is better off than it was before President Donald Trump .
1: During the campaign, Trump said he would be " the greatest jobs president God ever created ."
2: So, it was little surprise Pence built his claim around job numbers.
3: "Since President (Donald Trump’s) election, 36,000 jobs have been created in WI," Pence tweeted while on his way to visit shipbuilder Fincantieri Marinette Marine in northeastern Wisconsin.
4: We’ve tackled several claims on manufacturing jobs in Wisconsin: We rated the Democratic National Committee Mostly False for claiming a decline in manufacturing jobs last year meant Trump broke a campaign pledge to bring such jobs back.
5: And we explained how it is largely accurate to say Wisconsin manufacturing jobs are both up under Trump or to say they’re down in the last year.
6: But Pence’s claim is broader, so we’ll give this another go.
7: Jobs data lines up Pence’s claim largely matches up with the latest jobs data, and actually understates the change a bit.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The number of jobs in Wisconsin rose from 2.94 million in January 2017 — when Trump was sworn in — to 2.98 million in October 2019, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics .
9: That’s a difference of 40,900.
10: Those tallies show non-farm, seasonally adjusted jobs from the agency’s Current Employment Statistics — an estimate based on a monthly survey of a sampling of companies.
11: But the gap is about the same using other breakdowns of the data.
12: For example, Wisconsin’s job count has risen by 44,400 since January 2017 if you look at BLS data for all private-sector jobs (eliminating government positions from the equation).
13: Some caveats But this uptick isn’t exactly a new phenomenon.
14: The number of Wisconsin jobs has risen every year since 2010, when the trend headed up nationally in the wake of the Great Recession.
15: And recent data tells a different story.
16: The monthly jobs data shows a loss of 9,300 jobs from January 2019 to October 2019.
17: Which brings us to the implication in Pence’s claim — that Trump deserves credit for the uptick since 2017.
18: Experts say you can’t give a president full credit or full blame for job gains (or losses) on their watch.
19: "The President can claim some credit for creating an economic environment nationally in which jobs are being created," Abdur Chowdhury, professor emeritus of economics at Marquette University, said in an email.
20: "However … there are many local factors which affect job creation at the state level including, but not limited to, state employment policy,  business environment, national economic trends, tax policy, etc."
21: Dennis Winters, chief economist for the Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development, cautioned against giving Trump too much credit in our earlier examination of state manufacturing jobs .
22: He noted Trump took office during an "expanding business cycle" that would inherently lead to more jobs.

llama2-70b: According to reason [3], Vice President Mike Pence tweeted that 36,000 jobs have been created in Wisconsin since President Trump's election.
This claim is supported by reason [7], which states that the jobs data largely matches up with Pence's claim and actually understates the change a bit.

Reason [8] provides further evidence, stating that the number of jobs in Wisconsin rose from 2.94 million in January 2017 to 2.98 million in October 2019, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Additionally, reason [12] notes that Wisconsin's job count has risen by 44,400 since January 2017 if we look at BLS data for all private-sector jobs.
However, it's important to consider the implication in Pence's claim, that Trump deserves credit for the uptick since 2017, as stated in reason [17].

Abdur Chowdhury, professor emeritus of economics at Marquette University, noted in an email, as cited in reason [19], that Trump took office during an "expanding business cycle" that would inherently lead to more jobs.
This suggests that not all of the job growth can be attributed to Trump's policies.

Overall, based on these factors, the claim that 36,000 jobs have been created in Wisconsin since President Trump's election is deemed true, but it's important to consider the larger economic context in which this growth has occurred.
Therefore, the veracity of the claim is rated as true.

cce77fdb102c5a776f79677fefba3cde.claim: "  President Donald Trump ""fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified agaisnt (sic) him and corroborated the Whistleblowers (sic) testimony."""
cce77fdb102c5a776f79677fefba3cde.label: false
cce77fdb102c5a776f79677fefba3cde.passage:
0: Before Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman testified to the House Intelligence Committee during a public impeachment hearing Nov. 19, some Facebook users falsely claimed that he had been fired.
1: One post published in a popular anti-Donald Trump group on Nov. 10 includes a screenshot of a tweet.
2: It claims President Donald Trump fired Vindman, who is responsible for Ukraine policy on the National Security Council, for participating in the impeachment inquiry.
3: "Trumputin fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified agaisnt (sic) him and corroborated the Whistleblowers (sic) testimony that Trump indeed did attempt to extort Ukraine," the photo’s caption reads.
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: It has been shared hundreds of times and reposted by several different users and pages.
7: The source of the Facebook post is a Nov. 10 tweet from Scott Dworkin, co-founder of the Democratic Coalition, a super PAC founded in 2016 to oppose Trump.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) Dworkin wrote that the president had fired Vindman from the NSC after he gave closed-door testimony about Trump’s July phone call with the president of Ukraine.
9: The call, which Vindman listened to, is at the center of the impeachment investigation about whether Trump solicited Ukraine’s help to investigate political rival Joe Biden.
10: Dworkin’s tweet was based on a story from Talking Points Memo about comments that National Security Agency Adviser Robert O’Brien made during a Nov. 10 interview with Margaret Brennan on CBS News’ "Face the Nation."
11: Here’s what they said on the show: Margaret Brennan: "Lt. Col. Vindman, who has testified under oath, is serving on the National Security Council currently.
12: Will he continue to work for you despite testifying against the president?"
13: Robert O’Brien: "Well look, one of the things that I've talked about is that we're streamlining the National Security Council.
14: It got bloated to like 236 people, up from 100 in the Bush administration, under President Obama.
15: We're streamlining the National Security Council.
16: There are people that are detailed from different departments and agencies.
17: My understanding is that Col. Vindman is detailed from the Department of Defense.
18: So everyone who's detailed at the NSC, people are going to start going back to their own departments and we'll bring in new folks."
19: When pressed on whether Vindman was being taken off the NSC out of retaliation for his testimony, O’Brien denied it.
20: O’Brien: "I never retaliated against anyone.
21: So it's —" Brennan: "But his time is coming to an end?"
22: O’Brien: "There will be a point for everybody who's detailed there —" Brennan: "Okay."
23: O’Brien: — "that their time, that their detail will come to an end.
24: They'll go back to their agency."
25: RELATED: Who is Alexander Vindman?
26: What to watch for in Tuesday impeachment testimony Those comments spurred reporting that Vindman was being removed from the NSC.
27: But Vindman’s lawyer clarified to CBS , on Veterans Day, that he had not been fired.
28: "LTC Vindman is still detailed to the National Security Council.
29: His detail ends July 2020," the lawyer said in the statement.
30: "We are not aware of any change in his status.
31: Obviously any retaliatory action against LTC Vindman on a day when we honor our military heroes would be reprehensible."
32: The White House also told the Washington Examiner that Vindman had not been removed from the NSC.
33: Dworkin’s tweet has been clarified, but the Facebook post has not.
34: It is inaccurate.

llama2-70b: The claim that President Donald Trump fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified against him and corroborated the whistleblower's testimony is false.
According to Reason [34], it is inaccurate.
The White House also told the Washington Examiner that Vindman had not been removed from the NSC, contradicting the claim that he was fired [32].
Additionally, Vindman's lawyer clarified to CBS on Veterans Day that he had not been fired [27].

The source of the Facebook post is a tweet from Scott Dworkin, co-founder of the Democratic Coalition, a super PAC founded in 2016 to oppose Trump [7], which raises questions about the post's credibility.
Furthermore, Col. Vindman is detailed from the Department of Defense, and it is not up to President Trump to fire him [17].
Therefore, based on these reasons, the claim that President Trump fired Lt. Col. Vindman because he testified against him and corroborated the whistleblower's testimony is false.

6edf6b15cf6f8e2a253326c0c074694c.claim: " When it comes to how many of the 35 different federal welfare benefits each state can offer, ""the average in the country is about 12 to 14. Why are we giving every one?"""
6edf6b15cf6f8e2a253326c0c074694c.label: false
6edf6b15cf6f8e2a253326c0c074694c.passage:
0: Assemblymember David DiPietro is a leading proponent of the push to divide New York state into three parts and create an autonomous government in each one.
1: The idea to split New York because of competing interests in the upstate and downstate regions is an old one .
2: One of DiPietro’s reasons for wanting to carve up the state caught our attention.
3: It has to do with welfare benefits.
4: The Republican from East Aurora said that an autonomous upstate region could be less generous with welfare benefits.
5: Talking to reporters outside a Divide New York caucus meeting in Lackawanna, DiPietro said that while the average state offers 12 to 14 welfare benefits, New York offers about 35 different benefits, every one that the federal government allows.
6: "Do we need to give every single welfare benefit that the federal government has in their control, when the average is that there are 35 different types of benefits?"
7: DiPietro said, according to WBFO .
8: "The average in the country is about 12 to 14.
9: Why are we giving every one?
10: We're one of the only states that does that."
11: New York has a reputation for providing a safety net that is more generous than other states, but is it as generous as DiPietro claims?
12: Asking the experts We approached DiPietro to learn his source of this claim.
13: Over a week and a half, we called his office twice, emailed him four times and tried to reach him on his cellphone.
14: He did not return our messages.
15: Since we don’t know where his information comes from, we reached out to experts to find out if they had heard this claim before.
16: Experts across ideological lines agree New York has a generous safety net, but no one we spoke with could trace the source of DiPietro’s claim.
17: The Fiscal Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank, referred us to a U.S. Department of Health and Human Services list of 41 federal programs that use poverty guidelines to determine whether a person is eligible or not.
18: But a review of that list did not offer any support for DiPietro's claim.
19: Some programs such as the Children's Health Insurance Program and Medicaid can be more generous in different states, but New York does not offer more programs relative to other states.
20: Of the 41 federal programs: Twenty-seven are available in every state, such as Medicaid, Head Start, and Community Services Block Grant.
21: For two programs, which benefit older Americans, it wasn't clear whether they are offered in every state, but their umbrella program, Senior Corps , is available in all states.
22: Nine of the programs are not provided through state governments.
23: They are either delivered by federal agencies directly to individuals, or they are delivered by federal agencies to other organizations, such as schools or Indian reservations.
24: One program is available exclusively in Hawaii, and another is available exclusively in Washington, D.C. One program, promoting nutrition for older adults through farmers' markets, is available in 44 states, including New York.
25: There are different ways to define and count "welfare" programs.
26: A 2013 report from the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank, counted 126 separate federal anti-poverty programs, either means-tested assistance or those with an explicit purpose in fighting poverty.
27: In 2012 congressional testimony , the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, said it counted 79 federal means-tested welfare programs.
28: Regardless of how think tanks count the programs, there’s no doubt New York is generous compared with other states.
29: In Cato’s analysis, New York ranked seventh among states for the total value of welfare benefits.
30: It also found that New York ranks third most-generous in the value of Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, the primary cash benefit for the poor.
31: But TANF, which is distributed through block grant to all states, has not changed since 1996 .
32: States have flexibility in how they use the funds and can use it for programs other than cash assistance, such as child welfare or preschool.
33: The annual funding level of $16.5 billion was set in 1996 and has not changed.
34: Inflation has reduced the program's real value by 40 percent since then, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank.
35: Angela Rachidi , a research fellow in poverty studies at the American Enterprise Institute, a think tank that favors free enterprise, said DiPietro’s claim is possibly true.
36: But she’s not sure where he got his numbers from.
37: It is true the federal government authorizes programs and gives states flexibility in how to deliver them, said Rachidi, who worked in human resources administration in New York City’s Department of Social Services.
38: "The general perception is true that New York is a very generous state," she said.
39: Medicaid choices Some experts suggested DiPietro might be talking about Medicaid.
40: Without a response from DiPietro, we can’t be sure.
41: Medicaid, the health care program for people who have low incomes or disabilities, is designed differently in every state.
42: There are 15 mandatory benefits , including inpatient and outpatient hospital services, as well as optional benefits that vary by state, such as hospice, eyeglasses and podiatry services.
43: States can decide how generous each benefit will be, like whether to require a co-pay or set a limit on services.
44: The Kaiser Family Foundation , a nonpartisan organization that analyzes health policy, surveyed all 50 states in 2018 about the Medicaid benefits they offer.
45: The foundation asked about 47 different benefits, 14 of which are mandatory.
46: Of the remaining 33 benefits, New York offers all of them.
47: New York also offers services that were not part of KFF's survey, such as fertility services and lactation services .
48: To see how New York compared with other states, we looked at the 33 optional benefits included in the survey.
49: We found that, on average, the 44 states that participated in the survey offered 26 optional benefits.
50: Alabama and Virginia had the fewest, with 15 optional benefits.
51: New Jersey and Minnesota offered 32.
52: New York did not respond to the KFF survey, but we researched Medicaid benefit information from the state Department of Health and the state's official Medicaid plan .
53: New York’s Medicaid spending has always been high, if not the highest, among other states.
54: In 2015, per capita spending on Medicaid was highest in New York, and 76 percent above the national average, according to an analysis from the Empire Center, a conservative think tank.

llama2-70b: Claiming that New York offers all 35 federally allowed welfare benefits, while the average state offers 12 to 14, is false.
While New York has a generous safety net compared to other states, the claim that it offers all 35 benefits is unsubstantiated.
Experts across ideological lines agree that New York's claim can't be traced, and the state didn't respond to the KFF survey.
Although New York has high per capita Medicaid spending and offers programs like Children's Health Insurance Program and Medicaid, it doesn't offer more programs relative to other states.

04ba28c0961ebd88d24d9537e061cf0e.claim: The president had to confess in writing, in court to illegally diverting charitable contributions that were supposed to go to veterans.
04ba28c0961ebd88d24d9537e061cf0e.label: false
04ba28c0961ebd88d24d9537e061cf0e.passage:
0: The Democratic presidential debate in Atlanta kicked off with a discussion of the ongoing impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump.
1: Pete Buttigieg claimed that Trump’s conduct was impeachable, but also that Trump has already done something that would have gotten any other president out of the White House — and it has nothing to do with Ukraine.
2: "Under normal circumstances a president would leave office after something that was revealed recently that barely got any attention at all," Buttigieg said, "which was the president had to confess in writing, in court, to illegally diverting charitable contributions that were supposed to go to veterans."
3: Is Buttigieg right that Trump admitted in writing to illegally diverting donations for veterans?
4: No.
5: Buttigieg mischaracterized what Trump agreed to in a lawsuit settlement.
6: What Trump agreed to in writing was that his 2016 political campaign, instead of his charitable foundation, coordinated a fundraising event for veterans and directed the distribution of funds.
7: A judge said that Trump breached his fiduciary duties to the foundation by allowing the campaign to take over the fundraiser, furthering his political campaign.
8: The funds were given to veterans.
9: Buttigieg’s campaign sent PolitiFact links to several articles about the settlement which pointed out that Trump’s campaign took control over the fundraiser and other admissions of wrongdoing.
10: Lawsuit and settlement The New York Attorney General Office in June 2018 sued the Donald J. Trump Foundation, Trump (who founded the foundation and served as its president), and his three eldest children (who served on the board of directors).
11: The lawsuit charged that the foundation persistently violated state and federal laws and that Trump repeatedly used his foundation's money for his own personal, business, and political interests.
12: The foundation in December 2018 agreed to dissolve.
13: Earlier this month, on Nov. 7, New York Attorney General Letitia James announced she’d reached a settlement in the lawsuit and that the New York Supreme Court ordered Trump to pay $2 million in damages "for improperly using charitable assets to intervene in the 2016 presidential primaries and further his own political interests."
14: The settlement outlined several matters Trump agreed to.
15: But the part that is most pertinent to this claim relates to early 2016, when Trump said that in lieu of attending a Republican primary debate he would hold a fundraiser for veterans in Iowa.
16: Trump in the settlement agreed that his political campaign planned, organized, and paid for the fundraiser, with the administrative assistance of the foundation.
17: Further, he agreed that the campaign "directed the timing, amounts, and recipients of the foundation’s grants to charitable organizations supporting military veterans."
18: The event raised about $5.6 million in donations intended for veterans’ groups — about $2.8 million of that went to Trump’s foundation and the rest was donated directly to veterans’ groups.
19: Trump even presented foundation checks to veterans’ groups during his campaign events.
20: However, we find nothing in the settlement terms that suggests Trump admitted to illegally diverting those funds away from veterans, as Buttigieg claimed.
21: Trump "breached his fiduciary duty" to the foundation by allowing his campaign to "orchestrate" the Iowa fundraiser and by "using the fundraiser and distribution of the funds to further" his political campaign, New York Supreme Court Justice Saliann Scarpulla said Nov. 7.
22: "I find that the $2,823,000 raised at the fundraiser was used for Mr. Trump’s political campaign and disbursed by Mr. Trump’s campaign staff, rather than by the foundation" in violation of state laws, Scarpulla wrote.
23: However, she added, "the funds did ultimately reach their intended destinations, i.e., charitable organizations supporting veterans."

llama2-70b: During a Democratic debate in October, presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg made a statement that President Trump had to admit in court to illegally diverting charitable contributions intended for veterans.
However, a review of court documents and settlements reveals that this claim is false.
In a lawsuit settlement, Trump agreed that his campaign had planned, organized, and paid for a fundraiser for veterans, with the administrative assistance of the Trump Foundation [16].
He also agreed that the campaign had directed the timing, amounts, and recipients of the foundation's grants to charitable organizations supporting military veterans [17].
However, the settlement does not include any admission of illegally diverting funds away from veterans, as Buttigieg claimed [20].

In fact, New York Supreme Court Justice Saliann Scarpulla stated that while Trump had breached his fiduciary duty to the foundation by allowing his campaign to orchestrate the Iowa fundraiser, the funds did ultimately reach their intended destinations - charitable organizations supporting veterans [21][23].
Therefore, we can conclude that President Trump did not admit in writing or in court to illegally diverting charitable contributions intended for veterans, and Buttigieg's claim is false.

bad4aad54dcb14c4092b4174907aced3.claim: Today in America — a new study came out — 20 years out, whites who borrowed money, 94% of them have paid off their student loan debt; 5% of African Americans have paid it off.
bad4aad54dcb14c4092b4174907aced3.label: false
bad4aad54dcb14c4092b4174907aced3.passage:
0: In the Nov. 20 Democratic presidential debate , Sen. Elizabeth Warren called for student loan debt forgiveness after citing a startling racial disparity statistic.
1: "Today in America — a new study came out — 20 years out, whites who borrowed money, 94% of them have paid off their student loan debt; 5% of African Americans have paid it off," Warren, D-Mass., said .
2: There are racial disparities when it comes to student debt.
3: But Warren misstated these two figures.
4: Student debt at record high Warren has proposed that, for anyone making under $100,000, the federal government would pay off up to $50,000 of their debt.
5: The government would also help people making up to $250,000, although on a sliding scale.
6: Student loan debt totals nearly $1.5 trillion, according to an August 2019 report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
7: That’s as high as it’s ever been and up about 200% from 2006, we’ve found .
8: It is a result of increases in both the number of borrowers and the loan balances they carry.
9: As for race, 17.7% of borrowers who live in black-majority ZIP codes default on their student loans — nearly double the rate (9%) of borrowers from white-majority areas, according to a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released a week before the debate.
10: But Warren’s claim alludes to a September 2019 report from Brandeis University in Massachusetts.
11: Study Warren cites The major finding of the Brandeis study is this: "Twenty years after starting college, the median debt of white borrowing students has been reduced by 94% — with almost half holding no student debt — whereas black borrowers at the median still owe 95% of their cumulative borrowing total."
12: The problem here is that Warren talked about borrowers , whereas the statistic she tried to cite from the study talked about the amounts borrowed.
13: 1
14: Warren claimed that the study said that 20 years out, 94% of white borrowers had paid off their student loans.
15: But what the study’s measure of student debt actually found is that, 20 years after starting college, the median debt of white borrowers had been reduced by 94%.
16: 2
17: Warren claimed the study said that only 5% of African American borrowers had paid off their student debt.
18: But the study found that the median debt of black borrowers had decreased by only 5%.
19: We wondered about data for the borrowers.
20: Three student debt experts who were not part of the study pointed out another racial disparity finding of the study: 48% of white borrowers had paid off their student loans, compared with 26% of black borrowers.
21: A Warren campaign spokesman acknowledged that Warren misquoted the study, saying the study is "another alarming reminder of why we need to cancel student loan debt and close the racial wealth gap."
22: One of the study’s authors told us that Warren gets right the broader policy point that there are racial disparities in student debt that should be addressed.
23: "In the important discourse concerning student debt and when race is added, Sen. Warren is right on the mark," said Tom Shapiro , director of Brandeis’ Institute on Assets and Social Policy.
24: But, as we’ve laid out, the way she stated it in the debate was wrong.

llama2-70b: During a debate, Senator Elizabeth Warren made a claim about student loan debt, citing a new study.
She stated that 20 years after taking out loans, 94% of white borrowers had paid off their debt, while only 5% of African Americans had done so.
However, a review of the study Warren cited, as well as other sources, reveals that her claim is false.
Firstly, the study Warren cited actually tracked the amount of debt borrowers had 20 years after starting college, not the percentage of borrowers who had paid off their debt [15].
It found that the median debt of white borrowers had been reduced by 94%, while the median debt of black borrowers had decreased by only 5% [18].
Warren misstated these two figures, using them to make a comparison between the rates of debt repayment for white and black borrowers, rather than the actual amounts borrowed [12].

Furthermore, a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed that 17.7% of borrowers who live in black-majority zip codes default on their student loans, nearly double the rate of borrowers from white-majority areas [9].
This suggests that there are additional factors, such as default rates, that need to be considered when discussing student loan debt and its impact on different racial groups.

In summary, while there is a disparity in student loan debt between white and black borrowers, Warren's claim was inaccurate due to her misinterpretation of the study's findings and her failure to consider other relevant factors [24].

f0fb9909b0923c677b8ef38e249b26b8.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi said ""Americans are the stupidest people on earth."""
f0fb9909b0923c677b8ef38e249b26b8.label: false
f0fb9909b0923c677b8ef38e249b26b8.passage:
0: Did the leader of the people’s house really say that Americans are the "stupidest people" on the planet?
1: No.
2: But that hasn’t stopped stories like this one from claiming House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was caught saying that  "while speaking to an aide" at a fundraiser in Illinois.
3: The story from the website Conservative Bless says Pelosi was caught in a hot mic moment after finishing a speech full of lavish promises.
4: It falsely says she told an aide the following: "I can’t believe they cheered.
5: Were they serious?
6: They were, weren’t they?
7: Un-frickin-believable.
8: Trump proved how dense republican voters are and I guess I just left no doubt that Democrats are the same.
9: Americans are the stupidest people on earth."
10: The article, shared nearly a thousand times on Facebook, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: The problem is the entire story was contrived by satire website Busta Troll in late October 2019.
13: RELATED STORY: If you're fooled by fake news, this man probably wrote it While the article and quote originated on a website that describes its content as satire and contains a disclaimer, it was picked up by Conservative Bless and other sites and shared without any such disclaimer.
14: This is not a real news report.

llama2-70b: A story circulating online claims that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi referred to Americans as "the stupidest people on earth" in a hot mic moment following a speech in which she made lavish promises [3].
However, the story originated from the satire website Busta Troll in October 2019 and is entirely fabricated [12].
It is not true that Pelosi made this statement.
In fact, a quick search reveals that this claim has been debunked by various fact-checking websites [9].
Moreover, the claim is not supported by any credible news sources [4].
It is not uncommon for satire websites to create stories that are misinterpreted as factual, and this appears to be a case of that [10].
Therefore, the claim that Nancy Pelosi said "Americans are the stupidest people on earth" is false[2].

c988b113cf78fd170d2ee7565966b459.claim: Today I opened a major Apple Manufacturing plant in Texas that will bring high paying jobs back to America.
c988b113cf78fd170d2ee7565966b459.label: false
c988b113cf78fd170d2ee7565966b459.passage:
0: After a brief visit to Austin on Wednesday, President Donald Trump shared a tweet taking credit for opening an Apple Inc. manufacturing plant in the city.
1: Trump toured a facility that manufactures Apple computers during his stop in Austin with Apple CEO Tim Cook, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and his daughter and adviser Ivanka Trump.
2: "Today I opened a major Apple Manufacturing plant in Texas that will bring high paying jobs back to America," Trump said in a tweet after departing the city.
3: "Today Nancy Pelosi closed Congress because she doesn’t care about American Workers!"
4: In reality, the plant he toured has been manufacturing Apple’s Mac Pro computers for nearly six years.
5: The tech giant considered shifting operations to China earlier this year but decided to stay put after receiving federal tariff exemptions.
6: Also: Pelosi did not close Congress on Wednesday.
7: The House approved a bill outlining U.S. support for activists in Hong Kong; and House lawmakers continued their impeachment hearings .
8: The White House and Apple did not return requests for comment.
9: Apple in Austin Apple has had a presence in Austin since 1992, and recent investments have turned the Texas capital into the company’s largest hub outside of its headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. As Trump toured the production plant on Wednesday, Apple started construction on its $1 billion corporate campus in Austin, the latest expansion in the city.
10: The campus will house a number of company operations, including engineering, research and development, operations, finance, sales and customer support, according to the Austin American-Statesman.
11: It is expected to open in 2022 and have 5,000 employees.
12: During his trip to Austin, Trump did not visit the new location nor will it be a manufacturing plant.
13: Mac Pro in Austin Apple has produced its Mac Pro desktop computers in Austin since 2013 at the Flextronics Americas factory in Northwest Austin.
14: The computer has always been designed and engineered in California, and its components are produced in different states and other countries.
15: Final assembly of the product happens in Austin, according to the company.
16: In June, the Wall Street Journal reported that Apple would move the manufacturing of its new Mac Pro models from Austin to China, citing capacity challenges at the Austin plant.
17: Another concern for the tech company was the Trump administration’s proposed tariffs on Chinese goods, which were expected to affect imports of certain materials needed for the Mac Pro.
18: The company asked the Trump administration in July to exclude from the tariffs components needed for its "completely redesigned" Mac Pro, according to Bloomberg .
19: Days later, Trump shut down the request in a tweet : "Apple will not be given Tariff waiver, or relief, for Mac Pro parts that are made in China.
20: Make them in the USA, no Tariffs!"
21: But in September, the U.S. trade representative agreed to grant the exemption, and Apple announced that it would continue to use the Austin facility for Mac Pro assembly.
22: The facility has about 500 workers and has been the company's only major device assemblage operation in the United States, according to Bloomberg .
23: Most of Apple's products are produced and assembled in China.

llama2-70b: Contrary to the claim, Apple did not open a new manufacturing plant in Texas that would bring high-paying jobs back to America.
According to Reason [16], Apple had actually planned to move the manufacturing of its new Mac Pro models from Austin, Texas, to China, due to capacity challenges at the Austin plant.
The company also cited concerns about the Trump administration's proposed tariffs on Chinese goods, which would affect imports of certain materials needed for the Mac Pro [17].

However, Reason [21] states that in September, the US Trade Representative agreed to grant Apple an exemption from the tariffs, and the company decided to continue using its Austin facility for Mac Pro assembly.
The Austin facility has around 500 workers and has been Apple's only major device assembly operation in the United States[22].
Therefore, while Apple did not open a new manufacturing plant in Texas, it did continue to operate its existing facility in Austin.
The claim is false.

2cf2f6b3cecfa566ed986e943c2211fc.claim: Maxine Waters, Nancy Pelosi and Bernie Sanders have passed six bills in a combined 67 years.
2cf2f6b3cecfa566ed986e943c2211fc.label: false
2cf2f6b3cecfa566ed986e943c2211fc.passage:
0: A viral post on Facebook tried to rewrite three Democratic lawmakers’ congressional records.
1: The post , which was published Nov. 17 by the popular conservative page Trump Rules, includes photos of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., and Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt.
2: Text written over the images claims the trio has not been very productive during their government careers.
3: "67 combined years.
4: 6 bills passed," the post reads.
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: It has been shared thousands of times by several different users and pages.
8: Like past social media posts , this one is inaccurate.
9: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) Let’s look at the first claim — that Sanders, Pelosi and Waters have served a combined 67 years in Congress.
10: Sanders was first elected to Congress in 1991 and has served as both a representative and senator.
11: Pelosi was elected in 1987 and has served as both a representative and speaker of the House.
12: Waters has served as a representative since 1991.
13: When combined, the three lawmakers have served 88 years in Congress — actually more than the Facebook post claims.
14: On the second claim, the Facebook post also falls flat.
15: According to GovTrack , a website that keeps tabs on congressional legislation, the lawmakers mentioned in the post have passed more than six bills.
16: For this fact-check, we first used the most stringent definition of the word "passed" — legislation that is "enacted," or signed by the president — to assess the validity of the post.
17: Then we looked at how many sponsored bills had passed at least one chamber of Congress.
18: Here is each lawmaker’s legislative record as of Nov. 17: Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt.
19: Passed : 2 Enacted : 3 Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif.
20: Passed : 9 Enacted : 7 Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif.
21: Passed : 23 Enacted : 3 That puts the lawmakers’ combined enacted bills at 13 — not six, as the Facebook post claimed.
22: However, experts have told us that counting enacted bills is not the only nor the best way to measure lawmaker productivity.
23: "Very few bills are ever enacted — most legislators sponsor only a handful that are signed into law," reads a notice on the GovTrack site.
24: "But there are other legislative activities that we don’t track that are also important, including offering amendments, committee work and oversight of the other branches, and constituent services."
25: Additionally, Pelosi has served as House speaker for seven years, nonconsecutively.
26: That role is more focused on setting the party’s agenda than actually introducing bills, according to GovTrack.
27: The Facebook post is inaccurate.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that Maxine Waters, Nancy Pelosi, and Bernie Sanders have passed six bills in a combined 67 years has been deemed false.
According to Reason[3], the three lawmakers have actually served a combined 88 years in Congress, surpassing the claim by 21 years.

Furthermore, Reason[15] reveals that they have collectively passed more than six bills, and Reason[17] specifies that sponsored bills passed in at least one chamber of Congress further disproves the assertion.
Reason[27] confirms the Facebook post's inaccuracy.

In conclusion, the claim falls short of the truth, as the lawmakers' combined years of service, number of bills passed, and bills passed in at least one chamber of Congress exceed the Facebook post's statements.

5fcea8dc3a3a4f89f589333d3acf453f.claim: "  his campaign hasn’t accepted corporate PAC money and isn’t funded by ""special interests."""
5fcea8dc3a3a4f89f589333d3acf453f.label: half-true
5fcea8dc3a3a4f89f589333d3acf453f.passage:
0: A Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate in North Carolina wants to send a clear message: he won’t be a tool for big businesses.
1: Cal Cunningham, who’s campaigning to be the Democratic nominee against Republican Sen. Thom Tillis, says he won’t take money from corporate political action committees.
2: "That means this campaign is funded by people like you -- not the special interests," he tweeted on July 31.
3: Is it true that Cunningham has received no donations from special interests?
4: PolitiFact has investigated similar claims by former Senate candidate Beto O’Rourke , Congressman Conor Lamb and, in North Carolina more recently, congressional candidate Kathy Manning .
5: While it’s true that Cunningham hasn’t received money from corporate PACs, he has received money from business executives and PACs that receive money from corporations.
6: Corporate PACs The Center for Responsive Politics tracks donations of all types, including political action committees (PACs.)
7: PACs are generally put into three categories: business, labor and ideological.
8: The CRP’s campaign tracker backs up Cunningham’s claim that hasn’t accepted money from business PACs .
9: That’s not necessarily a significant sacrifice for Cunningham, according to Brendan Quinn, CRP’s outreach and social media manager.
10: "Corporate PACs don’t usually give that much to challengers," Quinn said.
11: When those PACs do donate to Democrats, he said they typically give to those in safe districts.
12: "Not much would go to a Democrat trying to swing a Senate seat in a purple state," he said.
13: Cunningham has received $10,000 from labor PACs, $22,590 from ideological PACs, and even more from PACs tied to Democrats in the U.S. Senate.
14: And that’s where Cunningham’s claim comes into question.
15: He’s received money from PACs that get some of their money from corporations.
16: Other PACs Cunningham has received thousands from PACs tied to individual senators, according to campaign finance disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission.
17: For example, Cunningham received $10,000 from Forward Together PAC , which is affiliated with Democratic US Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia.
18: According to CRP, Forward Together has received money from employees of Amazon, Microsoft, and other big corporations.
19: Cunningham also received $10,000 from Motor City PAC , affiliated with Democratic US Sen. Gary Peters of Michigan.
20: Motor City recently received $5,000 donations from American Express, Charter Communications, Comcast, Delta Air Lines, FedEx, General Motors, Goldman Sachs and other large corporations.
21: So, even if Cunningham has shunned corporate PACs, may have received money that originated with a corporation.
22: Some experts consider that degree of separation that some experts consider significant.
23: Andrew Mayersohn, a committees researcher for the CRP, told PolitiFact last year that candidates who receive money from a Senate PAC money are more likely to feel indebted to the Senator than the company who donated to the senator’s PAC.
24: In some cases, though, there’s no separation between Cunningham and corporate leaders.
25: Cunningham has received thousands of dollars from corporate executives.
26: CEO money He received big individual donations from the CEO of a financial consulting group , the founder of a pharmaceutical company , and the president of Blue Shield California , among others.
27: End Citizens United, a group that aims to reduce the influence of money in politics, sees a distinction between receiving money from corporate CEOs and from corporate PACs.
28: The PAC exists to benefit a company, while the motivation of an individual CEO is often unclear.
29: "Individuals can give to candidates for any reason," said Patrick Burwinkle, spokesman for End Citizens United.
30: "That candidate could align with (the CEOs) values," from reproductive rights to foreign policy and other issues.
31: "And that's why - unlike Senator Tillis - Cal has taken and followed a pledge against taking corporate PAC money while also releasing a comprehensive anti-corruption plan that would reform Washington's broken political system," said Rachel Petri, spokeswoman for Cunningham.
32: Some, however, don’t see much of a difference in who the money is coming from.
33: Corporate PACs are funded by the corporations’ employees, not the organization itself.
34: "Every dime that goes into a pac is an individual dime, it’s just pooled resources," Cleta Mitchell, a conservative campaign-finance and election-law attorney told The Atlantic last year .
35: Michael Williams, founder of the public policy and communications consulting firm The Williams Group, explained his skepticism to Fortune Magazine earlier this year.
36: "What’s the difference?
37: If you won’t take a particular bank’s money, but you’ll take the bank executive’s money?"
38: Williams told Fortune.
39: "Are you really materially changing anything?"

llama2-70b: Cal Cunningham, a democratic candidate running in North Carolina's senatorial race, has made a claim that his campaign hasn't accepted corporate PAC money and isn't funded by special interests.
Although it's true that Cunningham hasn't received donations directly from corporate PACs[3], he has received money from business executives and PACs that receive money from corporations [5].
Additionally, Cunningham has received money from labor PACs, ideological PACs, and PACs tied to Democrats in the U.S. Senate [13][15], which could be seen as being funded by special interests.
Furthermore, Cunningham received $10,000 from Forward Together PAC, which is affiliated with Democratic US Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia [17], and thousands of dollars from corporate executives [25].

Andrew Mayersohn, a committees researcher for the CRP, said that candidates who receive money from a Senate PAC are more likely to feel indebted to the Senator than the company who donated to the senator’s PAC [23].
In light of these facts, Cunningham's claim is Half-True [34].
Cleta Mitchell, a conservative campaign-finance and election-law attorney, remarks that every dime that goes into a PAC is an individual dime, it’s just pooled resources [34].
While it's true that Cunningham hasn't received money directly from corporate PACs, he has received money from other sources that could be seen as being influenced by special interests.

3ba1b5d8e30bdb10a4fa58b088af0e0a.claim: An image shows Rep. Elise Stefanik flipping off the camera at the impeachment proceedings
3ba1b5d8e30bdb10a4fa58b088af0e0a.label: false
3ba1b5d8e30bdb10a4fa58b088af0e0a.passage:
0: Did Republican congresswoman Elise Stefanik really flip off a camera during one of the impeachment hearings?
1: That’s what a viral photo circulating on Facebook appears to show.
2: No, Stefanik did not flip the bird during or after at the hearing.
3: The image has been manipulated.
4: The image looks as if Stefanik, who represents New York’s 21st district, is using the hand gesture while her colleagues stand in the background.
5: The Facebook post’s caption reads: "US Representative Elise Stafanik and an ‘always trumper’ gives bird finger to the Democrats at the trump impeachment hearing.
6: Classy!"
