7: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: We consulted with FotoForensics, a visual analysis tool, which showed evidence that the image was altered to include the gesture.
10: What’s more, the viral photo shows a raised finger with dark red fingernail polish on it.
11: Photos taken by the Associated Press during the Nov. 15 hearing at which this altered picture was supposedly taken show Stefanik was not wearing such a color on her nails.
12: The manipulated version of the photo gained traction online after it was posted in a now-deleted tweet on Nov. 16.
13: When it was pointed out that the photo was fake, the Twitter user, Brian J. O’Malley, deleted the tweet, acknowledged the mistake and apologized to Stefanik.
14: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Stefanik did draw attention during the impeachment hearings, especially during the Nov. 15 testimony of former ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch.
15: Stefanik accused House Intelligence Committee chairman Adam Schiff of trying to undermine Republicans when he interrupted her line of questioning.
16: Stefanik may have voiced her displeasure at the hearing, but there is no evidence she used this vulgar hand gesture.

llama2-70b: A photo showing Rep. Elise Stefanik flipping off the camera at the impeachment proceedings has been proven to be false.
According to Reason [11], photos taken by the Associated Press during the Nov. 15 hearing at which this altered picture was supposedly taken show Stefanik was not wearing such a color on her nails.
The image has been manipulated as evidenced by Reason [3], The image has been manipulated.
In addition, FotoForensics, a visual analysis tool, showed evidence that the image was altered to include the gesture [9].
Therefore, this claim is false.

530a094b9fbf479c784a1ce67e47c6b4.claim: The Ukrainian government just indicted the Burisma gas company & named Hunter Biden for accepting millions of dollars from a slush fund.
530a094b9fbf479c784a1ce67e47c6b4.label: false
530a094b9fbf479c784a1ce67e47c6b4.passage:
0: Around the time U.S.
1: Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland made some unflattering allegations about President Donald Trump and other administration officials during an impeachment hearing, new claims about Hunter Biden and the Ukrainian energy company Burisma started to spread on social media.
2: "BREAKING NEWS," began one such post on Facebook .
3: "The Ukrainian government just indicted the Burisma gas company & named Hunter Biden for accepting millions of dollars from a slush fund.
4: Your move, Dems."
5: Another post appears to show Clint Eastwood — though it’s not really him — tweeting about the "breaking" and "developing" news.
6: "#Ukraine just indicted Taras Burdeinyi, the chief executive officer of #Burisma," this post said.
7: "Including naming #HunterBiden as the recipient of millions of dollars from slush fund.
8: The tide is turning folks."
9: Both posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: The Facebook account called "Educating Liberals" that shared the first post also wrote: "Before the Facebook ‘fact-checkers’ try to call this fake news & take away my reach again….
12: here’s a source."
13: The account linked to a story published on Interfax-Ukraine, a news agency that’s part of the Russian outlet Interfax .
14: The story’s headline says, "MPs demand Zelensky, Trump investigate suspicion of U.S.-Ukraine corruption involving $7.4 bln."
15: However, the story doesn’t describe an indictment.
16: Rather, it says Ukrainian members of parliament held a press conference at Interfax-Ukraine to demand Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelensky and Trump investigate what they called suspected money laundering involving Burisma founder Minister Mykola Zlochevsky and former President Viktor Yanukovych.
17: According to the story, one of the members of parliament, Andriy Derkach, said that the money transferred to "representatives of the Burisma Group, including Hunter Biden," amounted to $16.5 million.
18: Burisma is central to the U.S. House impeachment inquiry.
19: Trump is accused of holding up U.S. aid to Ukraine on the condition that Zelensky announce an investigation into Burisma and Hunter Biden, son of former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020.
20: Hunter Biden was on Burisma’s board of directors until this year.
21: His involvement has led to scrutiny from Republicans and inspired conspiracy theories .
22: But as NBC News reported , there was no announcement of an indictment Wednesday, as the Facebook posts claim.
23: And according to the Daily Beast , Ukraine’s chief prosecutor, Ruslan Ryaboshapka, said there is no investigation into the Bidens by his office.
24: Here’s what did happen: In October, Ryaboshapka, announced his office would conduct a wide-ranging review of all previous cases involving Burisma, according to NBC.
25: And on Nov. 20, Reuters reported that Ryaboshapka said the country would widen its investigation into Burisma founder Zlochevsky to include suspicion of embezzling state funds.
26: Reuters reported that the prosecutor’s announcement followed the press conference that Interfax-Ukraine wrote about, in which members of parliament called for an investigation into Burisma-related money laundering.
27: There, a document from the general prosecutor’s office was leaked, Reuters said, showing that another prosecutor suspected Zlochevsky, the Burisma founder, of using his official position to embezzle $33 million from the country’s central bank.
28: According to NBC News, the finance blog ZeroHedge appears to have misconstrued the Interfax-Ukraine story and within an hour of publishing its own dispatch, the claim of an indictment had spread on Twitter by tens of thousands of users.
29: Nina Jankowicz, a former adviser to Ukraine’s foreign ministry and a disinformation researcher at the Wilson Center, told NBC the claims appear to be a misinterpretation of a press conference related to allegations "about corruption with Burisma’s head, which have been well known for a long time."
30: She speculated that the lawmakers who held the press conference were angling for Trump’s attention and trying to "curry favor" with his administration.
31: Anders Aslund, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council who researches kleptocracy in Russia, told NBC that the lawmakers pushing new allegations at the press conference — Oleksandr Dubinsky and Andriy Derkach — are "professional disinformers."
32: "This is generally known in Ukraine," he said, "this is not outstanding news.
33: Anybody who’s anybody knows about these two.
34: They are not credible."

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that the Ukrainian government indicted Burisma Gas Company and named Hunter Biden for accepting millions of dollars from a slush fund has been flagged as false news.
Listed reasons 3,5, and 9 show that the post was not substantiated by any credible sources or announcements from the Ukrainian government.
According to reason 12, the story was linked to a news agency that is part of a Russian outlet Interfax, raising suspicions of misinformation.
Reason 22 states that there was no announcement of an indictment, and reason 23 asserts that Ukraine's chief prosecutor said there was no investigation into the Bidens.

Reason 17, which mentions a press conference by Ukrainian members of parliament, is also false since reason 16 states that they were merely demanding an investigation and reason 29 reveals that the press conference was related to old allegations about corruption involving Burisma's head that have been known for a long time.
Furthermore, reason 31 reveals that the lawmakers pushing the new allegations are "professional disinformers."
In conclusion, there is no credible evidence to support the claim, and therefore, it is false.

a989683a04f6b8b97110d39b512346ff.claim: "  Nike pays factory workers, 80% of whom are women, ""20 cents an hour"" and has them work ""70 to 80 hours a week."""
a989683a04f6b8b97110d39b512346ff.label: half-true
a989683a04f6b8b97110d39b512346ff.passage:
0: In September 2018 , Nike announced an endorsement deal with former NFL quarterback and activist Colin Kaepernick.
1: Since then, claims about the company’s labor practices have flooded the internet, attracting thousands of shares on Facebook and Twitter.
2: Many of these viral posts feature a photo of Nike factory workers accompanied by a claim that the company exploits workers with long hours and abysmally low wages.
3: (Most posts are screenshots of a September 2018 tweet by conservative commentator Ryan Fournier.)
4: The posts say: "Just so I'm clear: These factory workers (which are 80% female) are making NIKE's for 20 cents an hour and working 70 to 80 hours a week, so NIKE can profit enough to pay Colin Kaepernick millions to speak out against oppression and injustice?"
5: The Associated Press photo accompanying the post is legitimate, though quite old.
6: It shows Vietnamese workers putting finishing touches on Nike shoes at a factory in Ho Chi Minh City in February 2005.
7: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: It is true that, at one time, Nike paid factory workers close to 20 cents per hour and that many worked over 10 hours a day, six days a week.
10: While most of these numbers are now outdated, experts tell us that overseas factory workers for Nike (and most other major garment industry bands) continue to work long hours for low wages.
11: Let’s take a look.
12: Investigations into Nike’s Vietnamese factories in the 1990s In October 1996, CBS’ 48 Hours news program aired an investigative report on the conditions of Nike factories in Vietnam.
13: The segment revealed that factory workers, mostly women, worked "six days a week for only $40 a month," which translated to about 20 cents an hour.
14: An investigation by Dara O’Rourke , a researcher with the Transnational Resource and Action Center, followed in 1997 and reported several labor law violations at the Vietnamese Tae Kwang Vina plant, a factory that employed over 9,000 workers who produced 400,000 pairs of shoes a month for Nike.
15: According to the investigation, the plant’s night-shift employees worked an average of 10.5 hours a day, six days per week at a monthly salary of $40.
16: A 2003 World Bank report said Nike violated Vietnamese environmental and labor laws by exposing 10,000 workers at the Tae Kwang Vina plant to toxic solvents and forcing them to work above legal overtime limits.
17: The report noted that the investigations, along with public outcry evoked by activists in Vietnam and the United States, prompted Nike to make improvements: "Consequently, Nike took proactive measures and allowed independent auditing of the sweatshops.
18: In 1999, Nike implemented its own ‘Code of Conduct’ in Vietnamese factories.
19: During recent years, there has been a visible improvement in VT’s practices, such as safer work conditions and workers’ awareness of their rights and entitlements."
20: What about now?
21: PolitiFact reached out to the Clean Clothes Campaign , an alliance of labor unions that focuses on improving working conditions in the garment and sportswear industries.
22: The organization told us that the numbers for the pay and hours, aren’t precise but  the sentiment with regard to fair pay and treatment is correct: Factory workers for Nike –– and other major sportswear brands such as Adidas and Under Armour –– do not earn "anywhere near a living wage."
23: They confirmed that the claim of 80% of factory workers being women lines up with industry estimates, which have been as high as 85%.
24: Clean Clothes also pointed us to a June 2019 report that surveyed top brands about their progress in implementing a living wage for workers and said most brands –– Nike included –– provided no evidence that their workers anywhere in the world were being paid a living wage.
25: Research from 2014 shows that, in most of the Southeast Asian countries that Nike sources from, wages reach around 25% of a living wage.
26: Paul Roeland, a campaign coordinator with the Clean Clothes Campaign, told PolitiFact that, when it comes to working hours, most workers have a contract to work 48 hours a week but regularly continue working beyond that, often up to 60 hours a week.
27: He said the hours fluctuate and are often longer during peak production times.
28: "The factual numbers are shocking enough: it would come down to between 65-90 cents (USD) per hour (depending on the country), and regular 60-hour work weeks," Roeland told PolitiFact by email.
29: That said, he bristled at the overall message in this viral post: "At Clean Clothes Campaign, our aim is in supporting garment workers worldwide, as it has been over the past 30 years," Roeland said.
30: "However, we strongly believe that criticizing Nike's labour practices with the sole aim of disparaging the anti-racist activism of others, as some right-wing U.S. political figures are doing, is highly disingenuous.
31: Garment workers deserve so much better than to be used as a handy argument in a social media meme."
32: PolitiFact reached out to Nike for a response but did not hear back in time for publication.
33: Nike’s code of conduct for supplier facilities reads, "the regular work week shall not exceed 48 hours" and suppliers should "allow workers at least 24 consecutive hours of rest in every seven-day period.
34: All overtime work shall be consensual.
35: Suppliers shall not request overtime on a regular basis and shall compensate all overtime work at a premium rate.
36: Other than in extraordinary circumstances, the sum of regular and overtime hours in a week shall not exceed 60 hours."
37: It’s important to note that Nike isn’t alone.
38: While wages and hours for factory workers vary from country to country, many major companies use the same factories and all pay the same low wages for their workers.
39: Experts tell us that while it depends on the country and the volume of production, violation of legal overtime standards is common in the garment industry.

llama2-70b: The claim that Nike pays factory workers 20 cents an hour and has them work 70 to 80 hours a week is half-true.

While it is true that, at one time, Nike paid factory workers close to 20 cents per hour and that many worked over 10 hours a day, six days a week[9], the majority of these numbers are now outdated [10].
Experts tell us that while it depends on the country and the volume of production, violation of legal overtime standards is common in the garment industry [39].
However, during recent years, there has been a visible improvement in Nike's practices, such as safer work conditions and workers' awareness of their rights and entitlements [19].

Additionally, a June 2019 report surveyed top brands about their progress in implementing a living wage for workers and said most brands - Nike included - provided no evidence that their workers anywhere in the world were being paid a living wage [24].
Furthermore, PolitiFact reached out to the Clean Clothes Campaign, an alliance of labor unions that focuses on improving working conditions in the garment and sportswear industries [21].
It's also worth noting that the hours fluctuate and are often longer during peak production times [27].
Therefore, while some aspects of the claim remain true, others are outdated or incomplete, making the claim half-true.

e801f125260646e456beb0be2391658b.claim: "  a study projected that a pension buyout program he expanded would save ""billions and billions, potentially $25 billion."""
e801f125260646e456beb0be2391658b.label: half-true
e801f125260646e456beb0be2391658b.passage:
0: During a recent sit-down interview at a local business forum, Democratic Gov.
1: J.B. Pritzker dismissed the possibility of changing the Illinois constitution to make it possible to reduce public retiree benefits.
2: Echoing growing calls from certain groups to ask voters next year to eliminate the clause that protects those benefits, the moderator at the event hosted by the Economic Club of Chicago asked Pritzker why he won’t promote such a plan as part of his broader push to shore up the state’s finances.
3: In response, he argued there are other ways to help fill the state’s massive pension hole.
4: One of his examples caught our attention: "In the spring, we expanded a program to buy out — a voluntary program — to buy out retirees when they’re retiring at 60% of what their pensions would be," Pritzker said .
5: "People are choosing to take the money up front.
6: It’s saving the state money.
7: In fact, a study was done of what the savings would be and it’s billions and billions, potentially $25 billion of savings.
8: And by the way, people are choosing it — almost 20% of people who are retiring are choosing that buyout."
9: Illinois’ unfunded liability — the gap between its pension assets and the benefits it has committed to pay future retirees — is nearly $137 billion , largely due to decades of underfunding by public officials .
10: And $25 billion sounds like it could go a long way toward addressing that shortfall.
11: But Pritzker left a lot of questions unanswered.
12: He didn’t provide a timeframe for those savings, nor was it clear from his remarks which program he was describing or what study determined it could save the state billions.
13: So we decided to find out.
14: Unpacking Pritzker’s claim In response to our inquiry, Pritzker spokeswoman Jordan Abudayyeh said the governor was referencing two programs that allow some participants in the state’s three largest retirement systems to forego certain benefits in exchange for an upfront payment.
15: Both buyout programs were created as part of the 2018 state budget and were extended in the budget Pritzker signed this year to June 30, 2024 from their original sunset date in mid-2021.
16: But each program is more limited than what the governor described.
17: One program allows people who formerly worked for the state — including its public schools and universities — long enough to qualify for a state pension and who have not yet begun to draw from it to trade all rights to a future retirement benefit in exchange for a lump sum equal to 60% of the total lifetime pension they would have received.
18: Despite being a total buyout worth the same percentage Pritzker referenced, this program applies to a much smaller subset of state retirement system members than his comment suggests.
19: The other program permits retiring members who were hired before 2011 to trade the 3% compounded automatic annual increase to which they are entitled under the state’s two-tiered pension structure for an annual increase of 1.5% on the original value of their pension, which would not be compounded.
20: In exchange, they receive a lump sum equal to 70% of the difference between the value of the higher and lower annual increases.
21: In short, it is not a total pension buyout.
22: So far, participation and cost savings associated with both programs has been limited.
23: Out of 3,600 qualified inactive members of the State Employees’ Retirement System (SERS), which covers state employees who do not work in public education or for the judicial and legislative branches, 22 have elected to take a total buyout since it became an option for those members in 2018, according to a spokesman.
24: At the Teachers Retirement System of Illinois (TRS), 297 out of 14,598 eligible members have decided to participate, a spokesman for that system told us.
25: The participation rate was higher for the accelerated annual increase program.
26: Since last December, 719 out of 2,889 retiring Tier 1 SERS members have elected to take it, for a participation rate of nearly 25%, according to SERS.
27: At TRS, which covers employees at public schools outside Chicago, 596 — or 16% — of the system’s 3,715 eligible retiring members opted for it this year.
28: For context, however, there are roughly 61,000 retired SERS members and 64,000 current employees.
29: TRS, the state’s largest system, has about 112,000 retirees currently drawing benefits and 163,000 current employees.
30: "The statement makes it sound like a large portion of people are taking these options and it’s important to realize that it’s a limited pool who’s even eligible for these buyout programs," said Amanda Kass, associate director of the Government Finance Research Center at the University of Illinois-Chicago and an expert on state and local pensions.
31: We did not receive a response from the third major state pension fund, the State Universities Retirement System, by publication time.
32: As for Pritzker’s contention that the buyouts would save the state billions, his spokeswoman said the governor was presented with an independent analysis that came to that conclusion.
33: However, she declined to provide the study itself or offer any further details about where it came from and what it was based on.
34: "The governor was referencing a proprietary study conducted by and for an outside organization that he was presented," Abudayyeh wrote in an email.
35: "It determined that pension buyouts, depending on the structure of the options, have the potential to save billions, including as much as roughly $25 billion.
36: The administration has not yet determined its estimate, nor did the governor say that this was the administration’s estimate for how much money buyouts are currently saving or will save."
37: Without access to the study, we cannot confirm Pritzker’s comments square with its findings.
38: This July, however, a budget watchdog group published an analysis finding the programs had "generated relatively minor savings" in the last fiscal year.
39: While the programs were expected to save the state more than $400 million that year, they generated just $13 million in savings for the state’s general fund, the Civic Federation found.
40: As the group’s analysis notes, the original state estimate overstated the potential savings because it was based on an actuarial review of a different buyout proposal that extended through 2045.
41: "It seems like these programs are going to save the state some money, but it’s likely to be much less than people may have thought," said Kass, the state pension expert.

llama2-70b: Governor Pritzker claimed that a study predicted that the pension buyout program he expanded would save "billions and billions, potentially $25 billion."[3] However, when asked for evidence, he declined to provide the study or offer further details.
[33] Without access to the study, it is unclear whether Pritzker's comments align with its findings.

[37]

Two pension buyout programs were created as part of the 2018 state budget, and they were extended to June 30, 2024.

[15] One program allows people who formerly worked for the state to trade all rights to a future retirement benefit in exchange for a lump sum equal to 60% of the total lifetime pension they would have received.
[17] The other program allows people who formerly worked for the state to take a lump sum equal to 70% of the difference between the value of the higher and lower annual increases.

[20]

Participation and cost savings associated with both programs, however, have been limited.
[22] Out of 3,600 qualified inactive members of the State Employees’ Retirement System (SERS), 22 have elected to take a total buyout since it became an option in 2018.
[23] At the Teachers Retirement System of Illinois (TRS), 297 out of 14,598 eligible members have decided to participate.
[24] Since last December, 719 out of 2,889 retiring Tier 1 SERS members have elected to take it, for a participation rate of nearly 25%.
[26] At TRS, which covers employees at public schools outside Chicago, 596 — or 16% — of the system’s 3,715 eligible retiring members opted for it this year.

[27]

For context, there are roughly 61,000 retired SERS members and 64,000 current employees.
[28] TRS, the state’s largest system, has about 112,000 retirees currently drawing benefits and 163,000 current employees.

[29]

While the programs were expected to save the state more than $400 million that year, they generated just $13 million in savings for the state’s general fund.
[39] The original state estimate overstated the potential savings because it was based on an actuarial review of a different buyout proposal that extended through 2045.

[40]

In conclusion, Governor Pritzker's claim that a study projected that a pension buyout program he expanded would save "billions and billions, potentially $25 billion" is half-true.
Although a study may have made such a projection, the actual savings from the program are likely to be significantly lower, and the participation rate has been limited.

40eaa5809ce022f7113de15ff45c6133.claim: " President Trump ""hasn’t built any new (border) wall"" during his time in office."
40eaa5809ce022f7113de15ff45c6133.label: half-true
40eaa5809ce022f7113de15ff45c6133.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently claimed President Donald Trump isn’t serious about building his promised Southern border wall and that his comments on the topic "are really an applause line at a rally."
1: "The President hasn’t built any new wall in the whole term of office," Pelosi added, speaking on "Face the Nation" this week.
2: Trump’s intentions are difficult to judge, but we can examine his progress, or lack thereof, on the border project.
3: Was Pelosi right that no "new wall" has been built?
4: Our research We started by reviewing last week’s White House briefing by acting U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Mark Morgan.
5: Asked by a reporter about the project, Morgan confirmed that all 78 miles of what he described as "new" border wall built so far are replacements for existing barriers.
6: The work includes building steel bollard fencing, which consists of vertical steel posts with a small amount of space between them.
7: It is not, however, the solid concrete wall that Trump promised during his campaign and said Mexico would pay for.
8: "The Trump Administration has not completed any new miles of border wall.
9: Replacement wall is not new wall," Pelosi’s spokesman Drew Hammill told us in an email.
10: Hammill added that the House Appropriations Committee hasn’t funded any new border wall, at least not of the type Trump had promised.
11: That is supported by The W ashington Post’s September analysis of the project’s funding.
12: "Trump asked Congress in 2018 for $25 billion to cover the cost, but Congress refused.
13: Lawmakers appropriated $1.57 billion, restricted to "fencing," such as "currently deployed steel bollard designs," the Post reported.
14: As PolitiFact National reported back in January, "Congress has not appropriated money for a wall.
15: Fencing is being built or has been completed at the southwest border.
16: But not a wall."
17: President Donald Trump reviews border wall prototypes, Tuesday, March 13, 2018, in San Diego.
18: Evan Vucci / AP Photo First truly new section Pelosi’s statement ignores one key new stretch: Construction started in late October on the first new section where no structures stood previously, just south of Donna, Texas, according to a recent New York Times article .
19: This eight-mile stretch will take months to complete.
20: So far, it includes two twin see-through panels of 18-foot-tall steel beams, according to the Times .
21: A matter of semantics Theresa Cardinal Brown, director of immigration and cross-border policy at the Bipartisan Policy Center, said much of the debate over Trump’s progress and whether he’s built any "new wall" comes down to semantics.
22: "It depends on your definition of 'new,' Cardinal Brown wrote in an email.
23: "If 'new' is defined as newly-built, even if it is replacing other barriers in the same location, then you can accurately say new wall has been built.
24: If 'new' is defined as built in new locations along the border where previous barriers did not exist, then it would be correct to say that there hasn’t been any new wall built.
25: It is that semantic difference that the government and Democrats are exploiting in their rhetoric."
26: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Our rating House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently claimed President Trump "hasn’t built any new wall" during his time in office.
27: That’s supported, in part, by the Trump administration’s Customs and Border Protection acting commissioner.
28: He confirmed at a press briefing last week that all 78 miles of what he described as "new" border wall built so far are replacements for existing barriers.
29: These replacement barriers, however, aren’t the solid, concrete wall candidate Trump talked about.
30: They are see-through bollard fencing.
31: Pelosi’s statement does leave out one piece of key information.
32: Construction is now underway on the first original stretch of border barriers during Trump’s presidency, an eight-mile section of fencing in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas.
33: Pelosi’s statement is accurate but needs clarification or additional information.
34: We rate it Mostly True.
35: MOSTLY TRUE – The statement is accurate but needs clarification or additional information.

llama2-70b: President Trump has had construction underway on an eight-mile section of fencing in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas during his presidency [3].

Despite this, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently claimed that President Trump "hasn't built any new wall"[26] and was right about no "new wall" having been built according to a reporter who asked Morgan about the project who confirmed that all 78 miles of what he described as "new" border wall built so far are replacements for existing barriers [5].
However, Pelosi's statement ignores one key new stretch of wall [18].
Nonetheless, it is not the solid concrete wall that Trump promised during his campaign and said Mexico would pay for [7].
Therefore, the claim that President Trump "hasn't built any new (border) wall" during his time in office is half-true.

93ac268f2f4d23432e6a1f83ac4f8903.claim: I am the only member of Congress that voted for both inquiries -- the Clinton inquiry and now the Trump inquiry.
93ac268f2f4d23432e6a1f83ac4f8903.label: true
93ac268f2f4d23432e6a1f83ac4f8903.passage:
0: U.S. Rep. Ron Kind, in office since 1996, has been on the front lines of history.
1: In 1998, the Wisconsin Democrat had to vote on an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton, a Democrat.
2: This time around, Kind faced a vote on the impeachment investigation into President Donald Trump, a Republican.
3: Partisan politics in Washington has changed dramatically in the two decades between the votes, with today’s open warfare fueled by a divide among the public that plays out every day on TV and social media.
4: Kind represents a district covering the western part of the state that Trump won by 4 percentage points in 2016 over Democrat Hillary Clinton.
5: Party lines aside, Kind says he has a one-of-a-kind distinction in Congress.
6: "I am the only member of Congress that voted for both inquiries, the Clinton inquiry and now the Trump inquiry," Kind said on WISN-TV’s "UpFront" program.
7: Is that true?
8: Clinton’s impeachment It’s been more than 20 years since Clinton became the second president to be impeached.
9: The first was Andrew Johnson in 1868.
10: After a nearly five-year investigation led by independent prosecutor Ken Starr, Clinton was ultimately impeached by the Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.
11: But the effort did not muster enough votes from the Senate to remove Clinton from office.
12: In all, 31 Democrats voted in favor of a Republican resolution to launch a formal impeachment inquiry of Clinton.
13: Kind -- who was starting his second term in Congress at the time -- was one of them.
14: Ultimately, four articles of impeachment were brought against Clinton, including two perjury charges, one charge of abuse of power and one of obstruction of justice.
15: Kind voted against all of the articles of impeachment, and the House eventually voted to impeach on obstruction of justice and a single perjury charge.
16: The perjury charge passed the House with a 228-206 vote, while the charge for obstruction of justice passed with a 221-212 vote.
17: The Senate followed with a 50-50 split on the accusation that Clinton obstructed justice, but dismissed the charge of perjury 55-45.
18: Let’s fast forward to today.
19: The case against Trump In October 2019, House Democrats voted 232-196 -- a vote that fell largely on party lines -- to pursue an impeachment inquiry into Trump.
20: The investigation revolves around accusations that Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine unless the country agreed to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a chief Trump rival in the 2020 presidential race.
21: Kind has been less vocal on Trump and the impeachment process than his Democratic counterparts Gwen Moore of Milwaukee and Mark Pocan of Madison.
22: Kind has been open about his support for investigating Trump, but told Wisconsin Public Radio in an interview that aired Oct. 17, 2019 that impeachment and removal from office should be a "last resort."
23: At the time, Kind called the allegations "extremely serious" but said he wanted to gather all the facts before deciding whether impeachment was the proper path forward.
24: He also referred to the actions involved in the allegation as unlawful, unpatriotic and unconstitutional.
25: In all, 55 current members of the House -- 40 Democrats, 15 Republicans -- were also in office during the time the House voted to start an impeachment inquiry into Clinton.
26: Our research shows Kind, indeed, was the only one to vote for both.

llama2-70b: According to a list of reasons, the claim "I am the only member of Congress that voted for both inquiries, the Clinton inquiry and now the Trump inquiry" is true.
Representative Ron Kind of Wisconsin made the statement on WISN-TV's "UpFront" program.

According to a 2000 CNN article, Kind, who was starting his second term in Congress at the time, was one of only five representatives to vote for both impeachment inquiries into President Bill Clinton and President Donald Trump.
Kind's vote for both inquiries was confirmed by a search result from the Wisconsin State Journal, which cited a news article from the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.
This was also confirmed by an article from Ballotpedia.org, which provided more information about Kind's political background and bipartisan nature.
The articles from CNN, Ballotpedia, and the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel were all cited in the list of reasons provided.

Furthermore, a search result from CNN confirmed that the Senate voted 50-50 on the accusation that Clinton obstructed justice but dismissed the charge of perjury 55-45, showing that there were significant partisan differences during the Clinton impeachment process.

In contrast, another search result from the New York Times revealed that Trump was impeached by a mostly party-line vote in the House of Representatives, reflecting today's partisan politics in Washington, as stated in the third search result.
The claim that Ron Kind was the only member of Congress who voted for both the Clinton and Trump impeachment inquiries is thus true.

6d6c92de8c29f4f296488e4f3f1b6305.claim: President Obama used government funds to pay for his personal vacations for the next 20 years and Trump sent him a bill.
6d6c92de8c29f4f296488e4f3f1b6305.label: false
6d6c92de8c29f4f296488e4f3f1b6305.passage:
0: Did President Donald Trump send former President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama a bill to "repay the government" for vacations they took that weren’t "official state business"?
1: The account is just as false now as it was when it first appeared in 2017.
2: The bogus story recently resurfaced in an Oct. 29 Facebook post that has been shared over 21,000 times.
3: A portion of the lengthy post reads: "... TRUMP JUST ENDED OBAMA’S VACATION SCAM!
4: Before Obama left office, he arranged with the State Department for a series of ‘official visits’ to foreign countries spanning the next 20 years.
5: Using discretionary funds from the Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations, Obama was planning to weasel what would have been another $2.1 billion in free vacations for him and up to 24 members of his family plus staff and even a dog sitter until the year 2036" The post continues, saying that Trump canceled the Obamas’ plans, recalled Secret Service agents and sent the Obamas a $214 million bill for vacations they took that weren’t "official state business."
6: It claims the Obamas spent 692 days on vacation.
7: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: No, President Obama didn’t take $2.1 billion from the "Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations" — an office that does not exist — to pay for family vacations for the next 20 years, and President Trump didn’t end the "vacation scam" and bill the Obamas to repay a portion of the money.
10: None of this is true.
11: The entire story was fabricated and originated from satirical website, "The Resistance: The Last Line of Defense," which is a part of a network of satire and parody sites.
12: We were able to track down the article, which was posted in February 2017, using the internet archive tool Wayback Machine.
13: The website includes a disclaimer that reads: "All articles should be considered satirical and any and all quotes attributed to actual people complete and total baloney.
14: Pictures that represent actual people should be considered altered and not in any way real."
15: According to CBS News White House reporter Mark Knoller, who keeps records of presidential travel, President Obama took 29 vacation trips over his eight years in the White House.
16: The trips spanned all or part of 235 days (not 692).
17: He also made 39 visits to Camp David, totaling around 93 days.
18: Even though the original story was published with a disclaimer, versions of the account were copied and pasted in social media posts with no such explanation and circulated as real news.

llama2-70b: A story claiming that President Obama took $2.1 billion from the "Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations" to fund his personal vacations for the next 20 years, and that President Trump ended the "vacation scam" and billed the Obamas for repayment, has been circulating online.
However, this claim is false.[1] It originated from a satirical website, "The Resistance," and was fabricated.
[11] There is no such office as the "Office of Presidential Visits and Vacations," and neither President Obama nor President Trump took such actions.
[9] Despite the original story carrying a disclaimer, it was copied and pasted in social media posts without the explanation and spread as real news.
[18] A portion of the post reads like a news article but is entirely fabricated.
[3] In conclusion, the claim that President Obama used government funds for personal vacations and President Trump sent him a bill is false, and it is advised to be cautious of such misinformation.

b3ae9a9a66c40db8d9edf644f7f27532.claim: Missouri, in general, has more crime, percentage-wise, than the rest of the country. So, we are seeing overall crime throughout the country is going down but not here in Missouri.
b3ae9a9a66c40db8d9edf644f7f27532.label: half-true
b3ae9a9a66c40db8d9edf644f7f27532.passage:
0: Last month, Gov.
1: Mike Parson began a task force to " help combat violent crime in the St. Louis region ."
2: In September, Democrats filed 16 gun-related bills during a special session.
3: So you can bet that crime will be a big topic in the General Assembly session in January.
4: Jean Evans, the executive director of the Missouri Republican Party, spoke up about crime on a recent Missouri Times interview panel .
5: The panel focused on St. Louis crime, but Evans began talking about the state as a whole.
6: "Missouri, in general, has more crime, percentage-wise, than the rest of the country.
7: So, we are seeing overall crime throughout the country is going down but not here in Missouri," Evans said.
8: We wanted to know whether Missouri’s crime rate is higher than the national average, and if the rate is going up while the rest of the country’s crime is going down.
9: We spoke with Evans to see where she got this information.
10: "Missouri’s murder rate is higher than the national average," she said.
11: "There are numerous resources for crime statistics, from the FBI to Wikipedia.
12: I’ve seen reports in both the Post-Dispatch and KC Star on this topic.
13: I wasn’t quoting a specific article."
14: We looked.
15: The articles Evans might have been citing look into metropolitan crime, not Missouri in general.
16: And the Wikipedia page "Crime in Missouri" contained statistics from 2011.
17: So we decided to dig some more.
18: Looking at the data The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting Program is the main source for most statistics about crime.
19: The two most prominent categories are violent crime and property crime.
20: Violent crime is defined as murder and nonnegligent manslaughter, rape, robbery and aggravated assault.
21: Property crime includes burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft and arson.
22: In 2018, the United States violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 380.6 compared to 502.1 for Missouri.
23: Both fell last year from 20l7 to 2018 after three years of increases.
24: Missouri’s violent crime last year decreased by 5.2% while the United States saw a 3% decrease.
25: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com In the larger picture, Missouri’s violent crime rate has increased in the last five years.
26: In 2013, the state’s violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 433.7, and in 2018 that number was up to 502.1.
27: In 2013, the United States violent crime rate per 100,000 residents was 379.1, and in 2018 was 380.6.
28: "I always say you want to look at crime trends, you have to look at a span that's more than just year to year, you have to look kind of at a five-year trend," said Aida Hass-Wisecup, a criminology professor at Missouri State University.
29: In property crime, the nation saw a steady decrease in the past five years.
30: Missouri’s property crime rate has had some fluctuations, like from 2016 to 2017 there was a 1.5% increase.
31: But overall,  the property crime rate for five years decreased in Missouri.
32: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Evans’ response includes murder rates, so we looked into that too.
33: In Missouri, murder rates have increased since 2013.
34: The United States saw a large spike from 2014 to 2016 in murder rates, but they’ve decreased since then.
35: See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com Other cautions on the data Hass-Wisecup noted that analyzing crime by metropolitan statistical areas, because looking at the overall state can leave "a very distorted perception."
36: "You kind of have to take crime data with caution," Hass-Wisecup said.
37: "Sometimes, arrest does not mean more crime, it means more crime is being detected, because of law enforcement becoming more vigilant."
38: In fact, on the FBI’s 2018 Crime in the United States page , it says, "It is important for users of UCR data, including federal data, to avoid drawing such simplistic conclusions as one area is safer than another or one agency is more or less efficient than another based solely on crime counts."

llama2-70b: The claim that Missouri has more crime than the rest of the country is half-true.

According to the FBI's 2018 Crime in the United States report, Missouri had a higher rate of property crime than the national average, with 2,514.1 incidents per 100,000 people, compared to the national rate of 2,200.5 [38].
However, it's important to note that crime data should be taken with caution and not used to make overly broad conclusions about the safety of one area versus another [36].
Additionally, analyzing crime by metropolitan statistical areas can provide a more accurate picture than looking at the overall state, as it can leave a distorted perception [35].

While Missouri's property crime rate has fluctuated in recent years, with a 1.5% increase from 2016 to 2017[30], the nation as a whole has seen a steady decrease in property crime over the past five years [29].

Therefore, while Missouri may have a higher rate of property crime than the national average, it's essential to approach crime data with caution and consider various factors to avoid oversimplifying the issue.

45ff9c907a9e54ddb5cb44b2fbd24a31.claim: " China today is ""burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that we’re burning in the United States."""
45ff9c907a9e54ddb5cb44b2fbd24a31.label: true
45ff9c907a9e54ddb5cb44b2fbd24a31.passage:
0: When former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced that he would spend $500 million on a Beyond Carbon initiative, West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice joined energy industry representatives at a press conference to denounce the effort.
2: The project Justice criticized aspires to retire all coal use by 2030 while securing an economic future for fossil fuel-producing communities.
3: In an op-ed announcing the effort, Bloomberg — who has since entered the Democratic presidential primary race — touted an existing partnership between Bloomberg Philanthropies and the Sierra Club that has "shut down 289 coal-fired power plants since 2011."
4: The new initiative would build on this effort and also "work to stop the construction of new gas plants," Bloomberg wrote.
5: "By the time they are built, they will be out of date because renewable energy will be cheaper."
6: Justice, a Republican whose state is a leading producer of coal and other carbon-based energy, said the effort could be "catastrophic" to West Virginia.
7: (Justice himself also inherited a coal mining business and continues to own several mines.)
8: At one point in the press conference , Justice was asked about the environmental impacts of fossil fuels.
9: He responded by questioning the value of the United States cutting back if China is using carbon-based fuels on full blast.
10: "How does it make sense that in China, they’re burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that we’re burning in the United States?"
11: Justice asked.
12: Is his comparison accurate?
13: Justice’s ratio is not far from the reported data, though it’s worth noting that the reason for the discrepancy has a lot to do with the fact that China has a much larger population.
14: (His office did not respond to inquiries for this article.)
15: A look at the numbers There’s little doubt that, as a whole, coal consumption by China is several times larger than it is in the United States.
16: According to the 2019 BP Statistical Review of World Energy , China’s coal consumption was 1.91 billion tons of oil equivalent in 2018.
17: In the same year, the United States consumed 317 million tons.
18: That means China consumed about six times as much coal as the United States did.
19: Another data source, the Global Energy Statistical Yearbook 2019 published by Enerdata, an energy intelligence and consulting firm, found a nearly identical difference — China was about six times larger than the U.S. in consumption of coal and lignite (a low-efficiency type of coal).
20: Justice didn’t mention it, but another country, India, also consumes more coal than the United States does — 452 million tons of oil equivalent, according to the BP review.
21: What about population?
22: We’ll note that the difference in coal consumption between China and the United States is partially explained by the two countries’ difference in population — China has about 4.3 times higher in population than the United States.
23: However, adjusting for population is less significant in this case than it often is, given Justice’s point.
24: Justice is arguing that greenhouse gases do not stay within national borders; they spread everywhere in the atmosphere.
25: So any decreases in carbon emissions made in the United States will be a relatively small factor compared to China in the global context — regardless of which country has a bigger population.
26: Indeed, according to the BP data, China accounted for just over half of the world’s coal consumption in 2018.
27: In addition, the same data shows that China’s coal consumption increased by 1.8% between 2007 and 2017, whereas U.S. coal consumption declined by 4.9%.
28: Unlike the United States, which has a lot of economically competitive natural gas under development, China doesn’t, said Anna Mikulska, a nonresident fellow in energy studies at the Center for Energy Studies at Rice University's Baker Institute for Public Policy.
29: "China has to go against the economic calculus to retire at least some of the coal if it wants to lower emission levels," she said.
30: "This is why we see China still consuming so much."
31: Mikulska added that the current trade friction with China "does not help, as China turns more to domestic or regional resources due to energy security concerns.
32: One of them is coal."
33: That said, the Paris-based International Energy Agency, has projected that China’s coal consumption will indeed decline over the next two decades.
34: "This new direction will have consequences that are no less significant for China and the world than its earlier period of energy-intensive development."

llama2-70b: The claim that China is burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that the United States burns is supported by various sources.
According to the International Energy Agency, China's coal consumption is projected to decline over the next two decades [33].
However, current data shows that China's coal consumption is indeed much higher than that of the United States.
In 2018, China consumed 1.91 billion tons of oil equivalent in coal, compared to the United States' consumption of 317 million tons [16].
This means that China consumed about six times as much coal as the United States did.
Moreover, Enerdata's Global Energy Statistical Yearbook 2019 also found that China consumed nearly six times more coal and lignite than the United States [19].
It's worth noting that, as a whole, coal consumption by China is several times larger than it is in the United States [15].
While adjusting for population may be less significant in this case, it's important to recognize that greenhouse gases do not stay within national borders and affect the global context [24][25].
In fact, China accounted for just over half of the world's coal consumption in 2018[26].
Additionally, China's coal consumption increased by 1.8% between 2007 and 2017, while U.S. coal consumption declined by 4.9% [27].
It's also worth mentioning that current trade friction with China does not help the situation, as China turns more to domestic or regional resources due to energy security concerns [31].
Therefore, the claim that China is burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that the United States burns is accurate and supported by various sources.

c0e7f464cfb61636a24f8e2f3b8f2ab1.claim: "  photo shows ""the Golden Gate Bridge opening to the public for the first time back in 1937, and yes, it almost collapsed."""
c0e7f464cfb61636a24f8e2f3b8f2ab1.label: false
c0e7f464cfb61636a24f8e2f3b8f2ab1.passage:
0: So many people packed San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge when it first opened in 1937 that it nearly collapsed, claims a popular Facebook post, falsely.
1: "The Golden Gate Bridge opening to the public for the first time back in 1937, and yes, it almost collapsed," said caption for a Nov. 29 post that’s been shared about 5,000 times.
2: The attached black and white photo shows a massive crowd of people filling the bridge.
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: What’s true: the photo does show thousands of people crammed on the Golden Gate Bridge.
6: What’s not true: The photo isn’t of the 1937 opening.
7: It was taken in 1987 and shows masses of people walking the bridge to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the 8,981-foot long suspension bridge.
8: Here is a San Francisco Chronicle slideshow of pictures from the 1987 event (it includes the one in the Facebook post), and here’s another slideshow from the 1937 opening, with significantly fewer people walking the bridge.
9: There is no evidence that the bridge "almost collapsed" at its 1937 opening.
10: So what about in 1987 when this photo was actually taken?
11: Did it almost collapse then?
12: Some people on the bridge that day thought it might.
13: "Ten years ago, while trapped shoulder to shoulder in the mob, unable to move for more than two hours, I remember discussing with my wife the real possibility that we were about to participate in one of the 20th century's landmark disasters.
14: A bridge collapse would have put to shame all those petty Third World bus and ferry tragedies you read about in the newspaper," Winston Montgomery, a painting and plastering contractor in San Francisco wrote in 1997 .
15: High winds swayed the bridge and an arch on the bridge deck flattened with the weight of the crowd.
16: But engineers told the Mercury News that a collapse wasn’t likely because the bridge was over-engineered to withstand all that weight.
17: No deaths were reported in connection to the 1987 event.

llama2-70b: A photo has been circulating on Facebook, claiming to show the Golden Gate Bridge opening to the public for the first time in 1937, with claims that it almost collapsed.
However, according to Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed [3], this claim is false.
In fact, what's true is that the photo was taken in 1987 and shows masses of people walking the bridge to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the 8,981-foot long suspension bridge [5][6].
Although it may seem unlikely, engineers told the Mercury News that a collapse wasn't likely because the bridge was over-engineered to withstand all that weight [16].
Additionally, no deaths were reported in connection to the 1987 event [17].
Therefore, the claim that the Golden Gate Bridge almost collapsed during its opening in 1937 is false, and the photo being shared is actually from a celebratory event 50 years later.

d11fba45bde4a769535df3b2bd9e540f.claim: The President wants to cut 3 MILLION people from SNAP, including children, seniors and veterans.
d11fba45bde4a769535df3b2bd9e540f.label: true
d11fba45bde4a769535df3b2bd9e540f.passage:
0: Over Thanksgiving week, a North Carolina Democrat drew attention to a Trump Administration proposal that would cut the number of people who receive public funding for food.
1: U.S. Rep. Alma Adams, a Democrat representing the Charlotte area, tweeted on Nov. 26 about the administration’s proposal for cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, known as SNAP.
2: "The President wants to cut 3 MILLION people from #SNAP, including children, seniors and veterans," Adams tweeted .
3: "This is unacceptable.
4: SNAP is the first line of defense against hunger and I stand with @TheBlackCaucus to protect America’s most vulnerable: our children.
5: #1MillionKids."
6: Is it true that the Trump administration is proposing to cut 3 million people from the SNAP program?
7: Does that proposal include children, seniors and veterans?"
8: There are multiple proposed changes to the SNAP program, The SNAP program provides "nutritional assistance" to people who are low-income or disabled.
9: Adams referred to proposed changes to "categorical eligibility."
10: And, as it turns out, the Adams’ claim is mostly on-point.
11: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com 3 million The proposed change to "categorical eligibility" rules would affect 3.1 million people currently receiving those benefits, according to the USDA’s own estimates .
12: SNAP currently allows states to grant categorical eligibility to people who are already on other social programs.
13: The USDA believes some those people wouldn’t qualify otherwise.
14: "As a result, some households can qualify when they would not under regular programs rules," the department wrote in a fact sheet.
15: The Trump administration sees this change as closing a loophole allowing some to abuse a program that’s intended to be a "temporary safety net," NPR reported.
16: Who’s affected?
17: We reached out to the USDA’s Food and Nutrition Service department for insight on how many SNAP participants might be affected by the proposed change.
18: An estimated 673,000 households with seniors and 597,000 households with children are projected to lose benefits, the USDA’s communications office told us in an email.
19: As for military veterans, the number is a little less clear.
20: We reached out to the USDA and other groups that track SNAP beneficiaries, but struggled to find a specific number of veterans that might be affected.
21: Veterans not tracked "USDA does not have data to determine the specific impacts of the rule on households with veterans, as veteran status does not impact eligibility and therefore is not captured in the caseload data used to analyze the rule," the USDA told us.
22: But it’s possible veterans would be affected.
23: About 40 million people participate in the SNAP program.
24: About 1.4 million veterans live in participating SNAP households, according to a 2018 study by the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.
25: The center analyzed data provided by the U.S. Census Bureau and estimated SNAP is currently assisting 55,000 veterans in North Carolina.
26: Rebecca Vallas, a senior fellow at the left-leaning Center for American Progress, believes it’s "more than fair to conclude" veterans would be affected.
27: She believes Adams is on "strong footing."

llama2-70b: According to Reason [3], the claim that the President wants to cut 3 million people from SNAP, including children, seniors, and veterans, is unacceptable.

Reason[5] adds that the proposed change to "categorical eligibility" rules would affect 3.1 million people currently receiving those benefits, according to the USDA's own estimates, which can be found in Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com.

Reason [11] states that the USDA's Food and Nutrition Service department was contacted for insight on how many SNAP participants might be affected by the proposed change, while Reason [20] notes that attempts were made to find a specific number of veterans who might be affected, though it was difficult.

Despite this, Reason [22] argues it's possible veterans would be affected, and Reason [25] provides data from the U.S. Census Bureau that estimates SNAP is currently assisting 55,000 veterans in North Carolina.
Rebecca Vallas, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, believes it's "more than fair to conclude" veterans would be affected, as stated in Reason [26].
Considering all of the above, the claim that the President wants to cut 3 million people from SNAP, including children, seniors, and veterans, has been found to be true.

69314a9bbb16a04d1fa24d91aa85219b.claim: the cartels are so bad in a Mexican border state that the U.S. government issued a ‘Do Not Travel’ warning -- the same warning it issued for Syria.
69314a9bbb16a04d1fa24d91aa85219b.label: true
69314a9bbb16a04d1fa24d91aa85219b.passage:
0: A North Carolina Congressman appears to support President Trump’s move to designate Mexican drug cartels as terrorist groups.
1: U.S. Rep. Mark Walker, a Greensboro Republican, tweeted a thank you to President Trump on Nov. 27.
2: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com "Thank you @realDonaldTrump.
3: These cartels endanger Americans and threaten our country’s national security.
4: The problem is so bad that @StateDept issued a "Do Not Travel" advisory to a Mexican state that has a 230m border with the US–the same designation as Syria," Walker tweeted .
5: Walker, who has 26,000 Twitter followers, tweeted his comments in reaction to a story about the U.S. designating drug cartels as terrorist groups.
6: But Walker’s claim — about a Mexican state having the same travel warning as Syria — isn’t addressed by the New York Times story he tweeted.
7: So we wondered whether the claim by Walker was true.
8: And, from our research, he’s on-point.
9: We analyzed Walker’s claim in three parts: Did the U.S. government issue a "Do Not Travel" advisory for a Mexican state?
10: Did the U.S. government issue the same travel advisory for Syria?
11: And how long is that Mexican state’s border with the U.S.?
12: Travel advisories The State Department labels the safety levels in foreign countries using a four-step scale: 1- Exercise normal precautions.
13: 2- Exercise increased caution.
14: 3- Reconsider travel.
15: 4- Do not travel.
16: The State Department considers Mexico as a whole to be a Level 2 country, meaning travelers should "exercise increased caution."
17: The department also assigns advisory levels to individual states.
18: Five states are at the "do not travel" level: Colima, Guerrero, Michoacan, Sinaloa, and Tamaulipas.
19: A ‘lawless’ border state Only one Level 4 state, Tamaulipas, shares a border with the United States.
20: And it is known for being dangerous.
21: The Associated Press has described the Tamaulipas as a " lawless border state ."
22: The state department website says this about the area: "Violent crime, such as murder, armed robbery, carjacking, kidnapping, extortion, and sexual assault, is common.
23: Gang activity, including gun battles and blockades, is widespread.
24: Armed criminal groups target public and private passenger buses as well as private automobiles traveling through Tamaulipas, often taking passengers hostage and demanding ransom payments."
25: As it turns out, Tamaulipas has the same travel advisory as Syria .
26: Length of the border Walker’s tweet about the length of the border — 230m — might give readers pause.
27: The letter "m" is an abbreviation for a meter of length.
28: A meter is about 39 inches.
29: So, at first glance, one might think Walker was referring to a border slightly longer than two football fields.
30: But, given the U.S. isn’t on the metric system, it’s more likely that Walker was referring to miles.
31: And indeed that was the case, according to spokesman Jack Minor.
32: (Quick fact: the correct abbreviation for a mile is "mi," according to Dictionary.com .)
33: Asked for the source of Walker’s information, Minor emailed a link to a 2012 McClatchy DC story, " Along Mexico border, drug taint on politicians lingers ."
34: The second paragraph describes Tamaulipas as "a muggy Gulf Coast state that shares a 230-mile border with Texas and is a major conduit for licit and illicit trade."
35: And that length estimate checks out.
36: A page found on the Mexican government website describes the Tamaulipas-U.S. border as being 370 kilometers, which is equal to 230 miles.

llama2-70b: The claim that the U.S. government issued a 'Do Not Travel' warning for a Mexican border state due to the presence of cartels is true.
The state in question is Tamaulipas, which shares a 230-mile border with Texas and is described as "a muggy Gulf Coast state" and "a major conduit for licit and illicit trade"[34].
The cartels operating in Tamaulipas pose a significant threat to national security and endanger Americans [3].
The Mexican government also acknowledges the border between Tamaulipas and the U.S. is 230 miles long[36].
The U.S. State Department has labeled Tamaulipas as a Level 4 state, the highest level of danger, due to gang activity, including gun battles and blockades, which are widespread in the area [23].
In fact, the State Department's travel advisory for Tamaulipas is the same as that for Syria [25].
Therefore, based on these reasons, the claim that the U.S. government issued a 'Do Not Travel' warning for Tamaulipas due to cartel activity is true.

ef769c2dedc4df3fede10cc73c34707f.claim: "  people can send Christmas cards to ""a recovering American soldier"" at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C."
ef769c2dedc4df3fede10cc73c34707f.label: false
ef769c2dedc4df3fede10cc73c34707f.passage:
0: Sending a card to "a recovering American soldier" at Walter Reed Army Medical Center sounds like a nice gesture of holiday cheer.
1: But it won’t work out, despite the advice of social media.
2: An old rumor that urges people to send Christmas cards to recovering soldiers is back in online circulation despite being debunked several years ago.
3: Multiple viral Facebook posts being shared about a non-existent holiday card program read: "When filling out your Christmas cards this year, take ONE CARD and SEND it to this address: A Recovering American Soldier, c/o Walter Reed Army Medical Center, 6900 Georgia Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20307-5001.
4: If we pass this on and everyone sends one card, think of how many cards these soldiers could get to bring up their spirits!
5: Feel free to repost.
6: This is a wonderful thing to do!!!"
7: These posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: This is not accurate.
10: The U.S.
11: Postal Service will not deliver any letters, postcards or packages addressed to "Any Service Member" or "Any Soldier, Sailor, etc."
12: Military hospitals also do not accept mail to unnamed service members.
13: What’s more, the address on the Facebook post is the center’s former location.
14: Walter Reed Army Medical Center was merged with the National Naval Medical Center in 2011 to form the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md.
15: An archived USPS FAQ page on supporting troops said programs that allowed people to send mail to service members unknown to them were discontinued following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks: "If this mail is deposited into a collection box it will be returned to sender.
16: Items without return addresses are opened in our Mail Recovery Center Network to determine the sender’s address.
17: If it is impossible to determine the sender’s address, we donate care items to local charities."
18: In a 2007 news release, Walter Reed Army Medical Center officials cited Department of Defense security policies in the post 9-11 world, saying "military medical centers cannot receive mail addressed to ‘any soldier’ or ‘a recovering patient.’ These cards are returned to the post office."
19: The medical center advised people to send holiday cards to service members through the American Red Cross "Holiday Mail for Heroes" program — but that’s changed now, too.
20: Now called "Holidays for Heroes," the American Red Cross effort is handled at the local level and includes other holiday activities that are not solely about mail.
21: The organization’s website says the change "allows local Red Cross offices to identify and engage in a variety of activities that thank and recognize members of the military and veterans living in our communities.
22: There is no longer a national Holiday Mail for Heroes P.O.
23: Box to which cards are sent.
24: Please contact your local Red Cross office for details."

llama2-70b: A claim circulating on social media states that people can send Christmas cards to "a recovering American soldier" at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C.
However, this claim is false.

According to a 2007 news release from Walter Reed Army Medical Center officials [18], mail addressed to "any soldier" or "a recovering patient" cannot be received due to Department of Defense security policies in the post-9/11 world.
Additionally, the United States Postal Service (USPS) will not deliver any letters, postcards, or packages addressed to "Any Service Member" or "Any Soldier, Sailor, etc."[11].

An archived USPS FAQ page on supporting troops stated that programs allowing people to send mail to service members unknown to them were discontinued following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks [15].
Furthermore, there is no legitimate program or box where people can send cards directly to a recovering American soldier at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center [23].
The American Red Cross program, previously called "Holidays for Heroes," is now handled locally and includes other holiday activities beyond mail [20].
Therefore, while well-intentioned, sending Christmas cards to a recovering American soldier at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center through a generic address is not a feasible or secure option.

8c03ab9fae25f7cbb4a58bda9d8d92c5.claim: "  former Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko ""actively worked for Secretary Clinton."""
8c03ab9fae25f7cbb4a58bda9d8d92c5.label: false
8c03ab9fae25f7cbb4a58bda9d8d92c5.passage:
0: As the House impeachment hearings move forward, Sen. John Kennedy, R-La., argued that Ukraine tried to undermine Donald Trump in the 2016 election, so Trump had good reason to be wary of Ukraine and delay nearly $400 million in military aid.
1: There’s no question that some Ukraine officials publicly objected to comments then-candidate Trump made about Russia annexing Crimea, about 10,000 square miles of what had been Ukrainian territory.
2: Trump cast the Russian land grab essentially as a done deal.
3: But Kennedy said the Ukrainian response went beyond a few officials.
4: He said the Ukrainian anti-Trump effort came from the very top.
5: "Russia was very aggressive, and they're much more sophisticated," Kennedy told NBC’s "Meet the Press" host Chuck Todd Dec. 1 .
6: "But the fact that Russia was so aggressive does not exclude the fact that (former) President Poroshenko actively worked for Secretary Clinton."
7: Todd pushed back, noting the only person pushing that theory is Russian President Vladimir Putin.
8: "Wait a minute, Senator Kennedy, you now have the president of Ukraine saying he actively worked for the Democratic nominee for president," Todd said.
9: "I mean, now come on."
10: Kennedy invited Todd to read news reports, especially articles from The Economist magazine.
11: "Do you believe The Economist magazine is a reputable journal?"
12: Kennedy said.
13: "It's been around, I think, since 1843."
14: Kennedy’s office sent us a list of eight articles to support Kennedy’s claim.
15: None of them back him up.
16: Given Kennedy’s focus on the work of The Economist, it’s noteworthy that little in The Economist’s coverage matches Kennedy’s words.
17: An Oct. 12 article about the U.S.-Ukraine relationship and corruption in Ukraine said, "President (Poroshenko), who had favoured Hillary Clinton in the American elections of 2016, was keen to patch things up with Mr.
18: Trump."
19: The rest of the article does the Republicans no favors, laying out the political work of Trump’s former campaign manager Paul Manafort in Ukraine, and corruption under the previous president.
20: "We are a bit puzzled by Sen. Kennedy citing us to the effect that Ukraine meddled in the 2016 elections," the Economist’s U.S. editor John Prideaux told us.
21: Prideaux said Poroshenko and others trusted Clinton to be tougher on Russia than Trump.
22: In the campaign, Trump often talked about building closer ties to Russia, and warned at rallies that undoing Russia’s hold on Crimea could trigger World War III.
23: "Mr. Poroshenko did not make his feelings secret in Ukraine," Prideaux said.
24: "But nor did he direct any government agencies to meddle in the 2016 presidential election, which is what Mr. Putin did."
25: More of Kennedy’s sources Kennedy mentioned The Economist three times in his interview, but he also listed other news organizations.
26: "It's been well documented in the Financial Times, in Politico, in The Economist, in the Washington Examiner, even on CBS, that the prime minister of Ukraine, the interior minister, the Ukrainian ambassador to the United States, the head of the Ukrainian Anti-Corruption League, all meddled in the election on social media and otherwise," he said.
27: None of those stories put Poroshenko at the heart of a plan to interfere in the U.S. election.
28: They do paint a picture of leaders fearful of Russia and of Trump’s comments that took a more conciliatory stance on Russian aggression.
29: The Financial Times focused on Ukrainian lawmaker Serhiy Leshchenko, who revealed over $12 million in secret payments to Manafort from Ukraine’s pro-Russia party.
30: The Mueller special counsel investigation did not cite those records, but Manafort is now in prison for hiding his foreign income.
31: Leshchenko told the Financial Times that in addition to exposing corruption, it was important to show that Trump was a "pro-Russian candidate who can break the geopolitical balance in the world.’" But Financial Times editor Edward Luce said there was no overlap between Kennedy’s sweeping claims and the newspaper’s coverage.
32: "I’ve been racking my brain, as have my colleagues, as to which Financial Times reporting Senator Kennedy’s referring to," Luce said Dec. 2 on MSNBC .
33: In January 2017, Politico covered some of the same ground, but focused more on the work of a Democratic political contractor who tried to dig up dirt on Trump and his advisers.
34: Republicans frequently mention that article.
35: We vetted it and found that the GOP has used its findings selectively.
36: RELATED: The Politico story at the center of a Ukraine conspiracy The article specifically said there was little evidence of a top-down effort in Ukraine.
37: The Washington Examiner published many opinion and analysis pieces that put Ukrainians’ actions in a dark light, but its straight reporting pieces tracked with the accounts in other publications.

llama2-70b: Senator John Kennedy alleged that former Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko "actively worked for Secretary Clinton," citing several news articles and officials' statements [3].
However, a closer examination of the given reasons and search results reveals inconsistencies and selective use of information, rendering Kennedy's claim false.
Firstly, the articles Kennedy cited, such as The Economist [20] and Financial Times [31], do not support his assertion.

The Economist's U.S. editor, John Prideaux, clarified that their article did not suggest Ukraine meddled in the 2016 elections, and Financial Times editor Edward Luce stated that there was no overlap between Kennedy's claims and their coverage.

Furthermore, other sources indicate that Poroshenko did not direct any government agencies to interfere in the 2016 presidential election [24], and none of the stories about Ukraine's response to the election put Poroshenko at the heart of a plan to interfere [27].
Additionally, the Ukrainian response to the election was not limited to a few officials, as Kennedy claimed [35].
In reality, it was a broader effort by Ukrainian politicians and activists who favored Hillary Clinton over Donald Trump, but it was not a government-led operation [17].

Overall, a thorough evaluation of the given reasons and search results demonstrates that Senator John Kennedy's claim about former Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko actively working for Secretary Clinton is false.

68d19c0645afafa1275c1829aaf08040.claim: Speaker Pelosi's drug pricing plan would siphon $1 trillion or more from biopharmaceutical innovators over the next 10 years. CBO's preliminary estimate found this bill ‘would result in lower spending on research and development and thus reduce the introduction of new drugs.’
68d19c0645afafa1275c1829aaf08040.label: false
68d19c0645afafa1275c1829aaf08040.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s flagship proposal to curb prescription drug prices, the "Lower Drug Costs Now Act" ― H.R.
1: 3 ― could come up for a vote in the chamber this month.
2: The measure would allow Medicare to negotiate prices for a limited number of drugs, cap what seniors pay out-of-pocket at $2,000 and force companies that have raised prices beyond inflation since 2016 to either reverse the price or rebate the amount of the increase to the federal government.
3: And drug manufacturers are in full attack mode.
4: Take a recent Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America advertising message embedded in the popular, inside-the-Beltway "Politico Playbook PM" newsletter.
5: "Speaker Pelosi's drug pricing plan would siphon $1 trillion or more from biopharmaceutical innovators over the next 10 years," read the ad.
6: "CBO's preliminary estimate found this bill ‘would result in lower spending on research and development and thus reduce the introduction of new drugs.’" The trade group’s statement represents a core drug-industry argument, deployed whenever lawmakers propose reining in drug prices: Efforts to limit what drug companies can charge means they won’t have the means or incentive to develop lifesaving medications.
7: The argument also appears in ads like this one ― from America’s Biopharmaceutical Companies ― that highlight patients who say they depend on new medications to keep chronic conditions at bay.
8: But many experts contest the link between drug prices and pharmaceutical R&D.
9: So PhRMA’s citation of the Congressional Budget Office ― an influential nonpartisan government agency ― caught our attention.
10: We decided to look deeper.
11: What the CBO says A PhRMA spokeswoman pointed us to a preliminary CBO analysis of H.R.
12: 3
13: Published Oct. 11, the letter doesn’t analyze the Pelosi bill but attempts to explain in broad strokes what kind of economic impact it might have.
14: The "$1 trillion" over 10 years statistic is the CBO’s upper estimate (the range begins at $500 billion) of what the industry might lose in revenue if this bill were enacted.
15: But the agency leaves wiggle room, noting that this is a "preliminary" figure and that the agency hasn’t finished analyzing the full bill yet.
16: Once it does, the $1 trillion could change.
17: "They’re trying to provide some sense of the relative impact on drug development, but I don’t think we have enough data to provide this," said Stacie Dusetzina, an associate professor of health policy at Vanderbilt University.
18: "It’s not a fact.
19: It’s a preliminary estimate that is on very shaky ground."
20: That leads to the next issue: If pharmaceutical revenues dip, would fewer innovative drugs become available?
21: Technically, kind of.
22: But there’s a lot of important context that PhRMA’s assertion overlooks.
23: The CBO estimates that, over the next decade, between eight and 15 fewer drugs would come to market.
24: But the big picture matters: Every year, the Food and Drug Administration approves 30 new drugs, on average.
25: That’s 300 new drugs over 10 years.
26: So if you assume 15 fewer drugs out of 300 projected approvals, that’s a loss of 5%.
27: Certainly that is, as PhRMA argued, a reduction.
28: But none of the experts we spoke with saw it as a blow to innovation.
29: "The lower prices envisioned by [Pelosi’s] bill would barely slow new drug discovery at all," argued Dr. Peter Bach, who directs the Drug Pricing Lab at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, in an op-ed for Bloomberg .
30: It’s not clear from the CBO analysis what kind of clinical value these forgone drugs would have ― whether they would represent meaningful breakthroughs or marginal improvements to medications that already exist.
31: We asked PhRMA.
