7: The link to that post is now dead but the url includes the words "channeling Jeff Foxworthy."

llama2-70b: The claim that Jeff Foxworthy wrote a list of examples explaining how "you might live in a nation that was founded by geniuses but is run by idiots" has been found to be false.

Despite Foxworthy's fame for his "You might be a redneck if..." jokes, no credible evidence has been found to suggest that he penned this particular list, which touches on sensitive topics such as abortion, Muslims, and federal debt [4].

In fact, Snopes fact-checked this claim in 2013 and discovered that the original compiler of the list was Fritz Edmunds, who posted it to his 'Politically True' blog in February 2013, although with a disclaimer that some ideas were from an email without a copyright [6].
The link to Edmunds' post is now dead, but the URL includes the words "channeling Jeff Foxworthy"[7].
Therefore, it appears that the claim that Jeff Foxworthy wrote this list is inaccurate, and it may have been incorrectly attributed to him.

23cac49a38effd185a15a4dc69ec0662.claim: "  President Donald Trump is ""waging a trade war against WI farmers -- forcing > 1600 dairy farms to close."""
23cac49a38effd185a15a4dc69ec0662.label: half-true
23cac49a38effd185a15a4dc69ec0662.passage:
0: It’s a tough time to be the Dairy State.
1: The family farms that long formed the backbone of the state’s milk production are increasingly being forced out of business.
2: And the U.S. agriculture secretary came to town and cast doubt on the future viability of any small dairy farms.
3: U.S. Rep. Mark Pocan , D-Madison, says Wisconsinites should lay the blame at the feet of President Donald Trump.
4: In a Dec. 2, 2019, tweet , Pocan said Trump is "waging a trade war against WI farmers — forcing more than 1600 dairy farms to close."
5: Trade tensions are certainly having an impact, but is it reasonable to blame them — and Trump — for that many closures?
6: Dairy was in trouble long before Trump Pocan’s is roughly correct on the number of closures.
7: Wisconsin had 9,288 dairy farms on Feb. 1, 2017 — about two weeks after Trump was sworn in.
8: By Dec. 1, 2019, that number dropped to 7,337, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture .
9: That’s a loss of 1,951 farms, even more than Pocan referenced.
10: But Wisconsin dairy farms closing is hardly a new trend.
11: The number of milking operations here has plummeted by more than half in the last 15 years, from 15,000 at the end of 2004 to about 7,300 as of December 2019.
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com That trend has indeed worsened under Trump, however.
13: In the 34 months since Trump’s election Wisconsin has lost an average of 57 dairy farms per month.
14: In the 34 months before that, the monthly average was 33 farms.
15: Many factors conspire against farmers Pocan blamed the closures not only on Trump, but specifically on the president’s trade wars.
16: Defending the claim, Pocan spokesman Usamah Andrabi pointed to a category of Chinese dairy exports that dropped from mid-2018 to mid-2019 amid retaliatory tariffs.
17: "That being said, I think we can reasonably attribute the majority of these farm closures to the effects of China’s tariffs/Trump’s trade war," Andrabi said.
18: That’s simply not accurate.
19: Pocan’s claim — and his spokesman’s defense — oversimplify an industry facing a complex set of economic pressures.
20: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Low milk prices, historic levels of oversupply and changing consumer demand were dealing devastating blows to dairy farmers long before Trump picked a fight with China.
21: The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel summarized the demand struggles this way as part of its Dairyland in Distress project, an exhaustive examination of the state’s trademark industry.
22: Sales of milk as a beverage have fallen steadily since the 1970s, with fewer parents encouraging their children to drink milk than ever before.
23: Soy milk and almond milk — which dairy farmers point out aren't real milk — and scores of sports drinks have flooded the beverage market.
24: And although consumption of cheese, yogurt and butter have all increased, they've not always kept pace with runaway production.
25: Today, for instance, U.S. commercial and government cheese stockpiles are at about 1 billion pounds — the highest level in a century.
26: At the same time, foreign markets for American dairy products have shrunk in response to tariffs that President Donald Trump placed on foreign steel and aluminum.
27: Cheese shipments to China have fallen almost 65 percent, according to industry figures, and exports to Mexico are down more than 10 percent.
28: So tariffs are a factor in limiting demand, but far from the only one.
29: And supply is a major problem as well.
30: Advances in genetics and feed science mean the average cow today produces about four times more milk than it would have in the 1950s.
31: This leads to a market saturation that both generates waste — some farmers are forced to dump milk down the drain for lack of a buyer — and contributes to reduced prices.
32: Milk prices have nudged up in recent months but before that went through a yearslong downturn that often left prices below the break-even point for farms.
33: "There were four years of the depressed milk prices before the trade war started," Laurie Fischer, CEO of the American Dairy Coalition, told PolitiFact Wisconsin.
34: "If you go back and you look, we've always had attrition going on."

llama2-70b: Wisconsin has indeed seen a significant number of dairy farm closures, with over 1,600 farms shutting down between 2017 and 2020.
However, the claim that President Donald Trump is solely responsible for these closures through his trade war against Wisconsin farmers is only half-true.
According to Reason [33], Laurie Fischer, CEO of the American Dairy Coalition, there were four years of depressed milk prices before the trade war even started.
Furthermore, Reason [34] states that there has always been attrition in the industry.
While trade tensions and the trade war may have had some impact, Reason [5] questions whether it is reasonable to blame Trump for that many closures.
On the other hand, Reason [17] suggests that the effects of China's tariffs and Trump's trade war can reasonably be attributed to the majority of farm closures.
Additionally, Reason [29] highlights that supply is also a major problem.
Therefore, while the trade war and Trump's policies may have played a role in the closures, other factors such as market conditions, industry trends, and supply issues also contributed.
Rating: Half-true.
Note: This rating is based on an analysis of the reasons provided and should not be taken as a personal opinion or endorsement.

8cf040943fdedde9b2eee0c788bd7441.claim: The Inspector General’s report now makes clear that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation of a U.S. presidential campaign on the thinnest of suspicions.
8cf040943fdedde9b2eee0c788bd7441.label: false
8cf040943fdedde9b2eee0c788bd7441.passage:
0: Attorney General William Barr blasted the FBI over its 2016 decision to open the Russia investigation later led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller , rejecting an inspector general’s conclusion that the FBI’s probe was justified from the get-go.
1: "The Inspector General’s report now makes clear that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation of a U.S. presidential campaign on the thinnest of suspicions that, in my view, were insufficient to justify the steps taken," Barr said in a statement .
2: The report by Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz did find "significant inaccuracies and omissions" left out of the FBI’s applications for court-ordered surveillance of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page.
3: But it said the agency’s decision to open an investigation into the campaign’s ties with Russia was warranted and not motivated by politics.
4: Barr’s reading put him at odds with FBI Director Christopher Wray, who pledged to make changes to the FBI’s surveillance process and accepted the report’s determinations in full.
5: Barr doubled down in interviews with NBC News and the Wall Street Journal , calling the basis for the investigation "flimsy" and claiming the FBI spied on the Trump campaign.
6: He said John Durham, the U.S. attorney he picked to lead a separate probe on the same topic, would have the final word on the matter.
7: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com We decided to look at some key conclusions from the IG report, which was based on more than 1 million documents and interviews with over 100 witnesses, in light of Barr’s remarks.
8: (A Justice Department spokesperson referred us to the report and Barr’s interviews.)
9: We found that Barr’s claim that the report shows the FBI launched its probe on "the thinnest of suspicions" does not square with one of the report’s key findings.
10: The FBI had "authorized purpose" When the FBI opened its investigation — known as "Crossfire Hurricane" — into possible coordination between members of President Donald Trump’s campaign and Russia, it had both an "authorized purpose" and an "articulable factual basis," the IG report found .
11: The investigation was launched on July 31, 2016, three days after the FBI heard from a "friendly foreign government" that Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos had signaled that Russia had dirt on former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton for the Trump campaign.
12: The IG report said this information alone was enough to trigger the Russia probe, because it gave the FBI reason to believe a crime or threat to U.S. national security was in the works.
13: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com The report also discounted the role of a dossier compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele, saying it "played no role" in the FBI’s decision.
14: (Trump has falsely claimed the dossier started the investigation.)
15: Rosa Brooks, professor of law and policy at Georgetown University, told us that Barr’s assessment that the suspicions were thin "appears willfully inaccurate."
16: "The report concluded precisely the opposite," she said.
17: "The IG report makes it clear that the decision to launch the investigation was justified."
18: Jennifer Daskal, professor of law at American University, agreed.
19: "Barr’s statement is at best a misleading statement, if not a deliberate distortion, of what the report actually found," she said.
20: The investigation was not politically motivated The IG report also dismissed the notion that the investigation was politically motivated.
21: For years, Trump has ripped into former FBI officials Peter Strzok and Lisa Page for anti-Trump texts that he saw as proof that career government officials were out to get him.
22: But the report concluded that Page and Strzok were not the decision makers Trump made them out to be.
23: According to the report , Lisa Page "did not play a role in the decision" to open the investigation or the related individual cases tied to Papadopoulos, Carter Page and fellow Trump campaign advisers Paul Manafort and Michael Flynn.
24: Strzok was "directly involved," but "he was not the sole, or even the highest-level, decision maker as to any of those matters," the report found.
25: The final say on whether to launch the investigation belonged to Bill Priestap, assistant director of the FBI’s counterintelligence division, who complied with DOJ and FBI policies and made the decision with widespread support from FBI officials.
26: "We did not find documentary or testimonial evidence that political bias or improper motivation influenced his decision," the IG report said .
27: The FBI’s applications to surveil Carter Page left out information Where Barr has a point is on the issue of intrusiveness.
28: To determine which campaign officials had Russian connections, the FBI used various methods listed among its "least intrusive" measures, such as open-source searches, the report said .
29: That led the agency to open four individual cases against Page, Papadopoulos, Manafort and Flynn.
30: The FBI then used confidential human sources — a "permitted" but more intrusive technique — to "interact and consensually record conversations" with Papadopoulous and Page.
31: The IG report found no evidence that this technique was politically motivated or done in bad faith.
32: Eventually, the FBI secured and repeatedly renewed a court-ordered FISA warrant to electronically surveil Page.
33: The IG report said this technique is considered "highly intrusive" and said the FBI did not seek similar warrants to monitor Papadopoulous, Manafort or Flynn.
34: Notably, there were problems with the requests to surveil Page, which relied in large part on information from Steele.
35: The report counted seven "significant inaccuracies and omissions" in the original application and 10 "additional significant errors" in the three renewal requests, including one resulting from alleged document tampering by a low-level FBI lawyer.
36: The IG report said these errors made the FISA applications appear more convincing.
37: The report was silent on whether the court would have approved them with more accurate information.
38: Still, surveillance under FISA is legal, and the report said the FBI did not "infiltrate" or otherwise spy on the Trump campaign.
39: Plus, the errors made in relation to the FISA application process had no bearing on the start of the Russia investigation.
40: "The report separately found some problems with respect to specific, and later in time, applications for FISA surveillance of Carter Page," Daskal told us.
41: But those problems "do not change the fact that the initial overarching decision to investigate was justified."

llama2-70b: The claim that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation of a U.S. presidential campaign on the thinnest of suspicions is false, according to the Inspector General's report.

The report found that the FBI had an "authorized purpose" and an "articulable factual basis" when it opened its investigation into possible coordination between members of President Donald Trump's campaign and Russia [10].
The investigation was also not motivated by politics, and the IG report dismissed the notion that it was politically motivated [20].
The report also found that the FBI's decision to open the investigation was justified [17].

While the FBI's applications to surveil Carter Page left out information [27], the report said that the errors made in relation to the FISA application process had no bearing on the start of the Russia investigation [39].

Furthermore, the information the FBI had at the time gave them reason to believe a crime or threat to U.S. national security was in the works [12], and the dossier compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele played no role in the FBI's decision to launch the investigation [13].
Therefore, the claim that the FBI launched an intrusive investigation on the thinnest of suspicions is unfounded and false.

a89cb42b83657f191d4abc29683ff669.claim: " The U.S. spends ""57 cents on the dollar on defense."""
a89cb42b83657f191d4abc29683ff669.label: false
a89cb42b83657f191d4abc29683ff669.passage:
0: The Progressive, a 110-year-old national magazine based in Madison, Wis., calls itself "a voice for peace, social justice, and the common good!"
1: It published an article Dec. 1 about Rep. Ilhan Omar saying the Democratic Minnesota congresswoman "wants to redefine U.S. foreign policy as we know it."
2: Omar elaborated on her philosophy by addressing military spending.
3: "We can fight to have our Green New Deal.
4: We can certainly get Medicare for All.
5: We can cancel out student debt.
6: We can certainly pass our Housing for All bill.
7: We can get a universal school meals program up and running," she said.
8: "But in order to do all of those things, we have to stop policing the world, right?
9: We have to not have over 800 military bases around the world.
10: We have to not spend 57 cents on the dollar on defense."
11: Omar’s major claim is wrong.
12: Defense spending accounts for only 15% of the federal budget.
13: 57% was wrong before In 2015, we rated as False a claim that 57% of federal spending goes to the military and just 1% goes to food and agriculture, including food stamps.
14: Rather than being dominated by the military, the budget was actually dominated by spending on Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, we found.
15: At the time, military spending, including spending on homeland security, accounted for 54% of discretionary spending — that is, not-mandatory spending.
16: But it accounted for only 16% of federal spending overall.
17: "This is a common mistake," Robert Bixby , executive director of the centrist Concord Coalition, which works for fiscal responsibility, said about Omar’s claim.
18: In fact, a spokesman for the congresswoman said Omar was referring to discretionary funding.
19: He cited a Washington Post article that says defense would be 57% of discretionary spending in the 2020 federal budget request unveiled by President Donald Trump in March 2019.
20: Defense percentage steady The percentage of the total federal budget spent on defense has been in the same range for years.
21: 2007: 19% , FactCheck.org found 2011: About 25% , according to the Washington Post Fact Checker 2017: 15% according to the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities Currently, about 17% of the federal budget goes toward defense, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office — a figure confirmed to us by Marc Goldwein of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
22: The Peter G. Peterson Foundation puts the figure there, too, at 15% .
23: As for the dollars, the 2018 federal budget contained, according to a June 2019 report by the Congressional Budget Office: • $1.3 trillion went to discretionary spending, including $600 billion for defense.
24: That would be about 46% .
25: • Total outlays were $4.1 trillion, with defense getting $623 billion.
26: That’s 15% .
27: The 15% figure also holds true for 2019, as well.

llama2-70b: Representative Ilhan Omar claimed that the U.S. spends "57 cents on the dollar on defense," but this claim is false[11].
She referred to discretionary funding when citing this figure [18].
In reality, military spending, including homeland security, accounts for 54% of discretionary spending, but only 16% of overall federal spending [15][16].
This claim has been debunked before, with defense spending accounting for only 15% of the federal budget [12], and Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid dominating the budget instead [14].
Discretionary defense spending has remained steady at around 54% of the total federal budget for years [20].
In conclusion, Omar's claim is wrong, and defense spending is not 57 cents on the dollar.
It's important to note that even if Omar was referring to discretionary funding, her statement would still be incorrect.
Discretionary defense spending only accounts for 54% of the total discretionary spending, not 57% [15].

Additionally, it's worth mentioning that the Washington Post article cited by Omar's spokesman actually contradicts her claim, stating that defense spending would be 57% of discretionary spending in the 2020 federal budget request, not the total federal budget [19].

e39bedb4064052310b5e014b34af4331.claim: "  a photo of a woman wearing a costume holding the sign ""vagina lady"" is Stanford law professor Pamela Karlan."
e39bedb4064052310b5e014b34af4331.label: false
e39bedb4064052310b5e014b34af4331.passage:
0: Viral posts circulating on social media claim that a photo of a woman in a vagina costume holding the sign "vagina lady" is Stanford law professor Pamela Karlan, who recently provided testimony in the impeachment proceedings of President Donald Trump.
1: But there is no evidence that the woman is Karlan.
2: One Dec. 6 post , which has been shared over 2,400 times, displays the photo along with the caption: "This was the Democrats Constitutional Expert witness Stanford Professor Karlan."
3: (There have also been some posts that show another photo of a woman in a pink "pussyhat" who has also been misidentified as Karlan.)
4: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: A reverse-image search led us to a Flickr page that posted the photograph in May 2007 as part of an album for the annual "Bay to Breakers" race held in San Francisco.
7: The caption does not name the person in the photo, but reads, "One of two ladies in vagina costumes."
8: We reached out to race officials about whether Karlan’s name appeared on that year’s roster, but were told their registration data doesn’t go back that far.
9: We searched news coverage of the event and found no mention of Karlan.
10: Karlan herself responded to PolitiFact in an email, and said she didn’t attend the race and the photograph is not of her.

llama2-70b: A photograph of a lady wearing a costume and carrying a sign that says "Vagina Lady" has been claimed to be Stanford Law Professor Pamela Karlan.
However, according to reason [10], Pamela Karlan said in an email response to PolitiFact that she did not attend the race and that the image is not of her.
The photograph has also been traced to a Flickr page, according to reason [6], that uploaded it in May 2007 as part of an album for San Francisco's annual "Bay to Breakers" race.
As a result, based on these two pieces of proof, it is evident that the claim is false, and a picture of a woman dressed as "Vaginal Lady" is not Stanford Law Professor Pamela Karlan.

6a45466cfe77a2a109a3177309549923.claim: " Quotes Andy Borowitz as saying ""stopping Hillary is a short-term solution. The long-term solution — and it will be more difficult — is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary."""
6a45466cfe77a2a109a3177309549923.label: false
6a45466cfe77a2a109a3177309549923.passage:
0: Andy Borowitz is a writer and comedian who authors the popular satirical column " The Borowitz Report " for the New Yorker.
1: (Here are some of his latest columns .)
2: But we recently came across a statement falsely attributed to Borowitz on social media that disparages Hillary Clinton and people who voted for her.
3: To be fair, he said most of it, but with one rather significant difference: He was talking about then-presidential candidate Donald Trump, not Clinton.
4: The post that we found had been shared on Facebook more than 3,000 times and featured a photograph of Borowitz alongside text that reads: "Stopping Hillary is a short-term solution.
5: The long-term solution –– and it will be more difficult –– is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary."
6: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: While that particular post was deleted while we were fact-checking it, we found the image several other places .
9: The quote in the image is doctored to make it look like Borowitz is being critical of Clinton.
10: We found that he posted the statement on his verified Facebook page on Nov. 4, 2016, four days before the presidential election.
11: The only words altered in the Facebook post’s version are the two references to "Hillary," in which Borowitz actually wrote "Trump."
12: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com The statement has been altered.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claims that Andy Borowitz said, "Stopping Hillary is a short-term solution.
The long-term solution - and it will be more difficult - is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary."
However, a reverse image search reveals that the quote in the image has been doctored to make it look like Borowitz is being critical of Clinton when, in fact, he never said those exact words [9].
Borowitz did make a statement that was altered to fit the quote in the image, but he was actually discussing Donald Trump, not Hillary Clinton [11].
Borowitz himself admitted that most of the quote was accurate, but the change from "Trump" to "Hillary" was significant[3].
PolitiFact also rated this claim as false, and included it in their article "Donald Trump's File of Fakes:
False claims made by or attributed to Donald Trump"[12].
In conclusion, the claim that Andy Borowitz made this statement about Hillary Clinton is false, as the original statement was altered to change the name from Trump to Hillary.

bd7efc7c7481055ccb4ee2cf78bf3034.claim: "  Fox News ""posts a fake picture to show soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan….forgets to take out the Universal Studios sign in the background."""
bd7efc7c7481055ccb4ee2cf78bf3034.label: false
bd7efc7c7481055ccb4ee2cf78bf3034.passage:
0: On Thanksgiving Day, President Donald Trump made an unannounced visit to Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan.
1: Fox News reported on the trip .
2: But a Dec. 3 Facebook post alleges the network aired a staged photo while covering the news.
3: "Fox propaganda posts a fake picture to show soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan ….
4: forgets to take out the Universal Studios sign in the background," reads the text over a photo of soldiers smiling and cheering.
5: A yellow arrow is drawn on the image to point out a sign in the upper left corner that’s cropped.
6: The letters "versal," "national" and "tudios" are visible."
7: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: That’s because the photo appears doctored.
10: The words on the sign look more like NBCUniversal International Studios than Universal Studios , but neither studio name appears in the original version of the photo used in the Facebook post.
11: AFP photographer Olivier Douliery took the photo on Nov. 28 .
12: The caption says: "U.S.
13: Soldiers react with cheers and applause as US President Donald Trump arrives in Bagram Air Field during a surprise Thanksgiving day visit."
14: Fox News told FactCheck.org that it never aired the image, but other news outlets ran it, including the Times of Israel , Axios and the Daily Mail .
15: None of those images show the sign that appears in the Facebook post.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claimed that Fox News aired a staged photo while covering President Donald Trump's surprise Thanksgiving day visit to Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan.
The photo in question shows soldiers cheering and applauding Trump's arrival, with a yellow arrow pointing to a sign in the upper left corner that appears to read "Universal Studios."

However, several fact-checking organizations, including Snopes and Lead Stories, have debunked the claim, citing evidence that the image was not aired by Fox News and that the sign in the background appears to be doctored.
AFP photographer Olivier Douliery took the original photo on Nov. 28, and it was used by several news outlets, including the Times of Israel, Axios, and the Daily Mail.
None of these images show the Universal Studios sign in the background.
The doctored image was likely created and spread on social media to falsely accuse Fox News of airing a staged photo.
Therefore, the claim that Fox News posted a fake picture to show soldiers excited to see Trump in Afghanistan and forgot to remove the Universal Studios sign in the background is false.

10fa33b503807dc4449a08fbaf451a1d.claim: "  a proposed change to Illinois’ gambling law would result in ""lower taxes paid to the state and higher taxes paid"" to Chicago from a city casino so that the total amount would be the same, but the city would get to ""keep more of it."""
10fa33b503807dc4449a08fbaf451a1d.label: half-true
10fa33b503807dc4449a08fbaf451a1d.passage:
0: During her visit to Springfield last month, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot pressed state lawmakers to lower tax rates on a future city casino after a consultant found the tax burden would be so heavy it could seriously jeopardize the casino’s ability to turn a profit.
1: But in an interview conducted in mid-November shortly after the legislature’s fall veto session, a Republican state lawmaker claimed Chicago’s proposal would actually raise the city’s take of casino tax revenue while leaving the state with less cash for projects that could benefit communities across Illinois.
2: "They wanted lower taxes paid to the state and higher taxes paid to the city," state Sen. Dave Syverson of Rockford told WCIA’s Mark Maxwell in a sit-down at the capitol, which aired Dec. 8.
3: "The amount of taxes would be the same, but Chicago wanted to keep more of it."
4: "As quick example," Syverson continued, "in all the other casinos in the state, the local community keeps 5% of the revenue and then the state gets an average of about 35%.
5: Under this scenario, Chicago — instead of 5% — Chicago would be keeping about 22% or 23% of the revenue and the state would get half the amount of what every other casino in the state was paying."
6: There’s a lot of moving pieces in Syverson’s claim, but the text of the bill he was referencing makes clear Chicago would have to cut its share as well — a point the senator conceded when we spoke with him.
7: What the bill says The plan Syverson referenced was introduced on the final day of veto session as an amendment to the gambling law that passed in the spring.
8: It didn’t gain enough traction for a floor vote this fall, but lawmakers could take it up again when they return to Springfield next month.
9: Lightfoot continues to push hard for a change to the original gambling bill, pointing to a state-mandated consultant’s report from August that called the tax structure on a Chicago casino "onerous."
10: The consultant report warned that after accounting for operating expenses the effective tax rate on the Chicago casino would be 72%, leaving a profit margin of only 1% or 2%, or even exceeding casino revenue entirely.
11: To address this, Democratic state Rep. Bob Rita of Blue Island introduced a city-backed plan to lower both state and city tax rates for Chicago’s casino, which is likely to become the state’s highest grossing.
12: The gambling bill that passed the General Assembly in the spring and was later signed into law by Democratic Gov.
13: J.B. Pritzker calls for a 33.3% tax on the casino’s gross receipts dedicated to the city’s pension obligations.
14: Rita’s legislation would have eliminated the city’s flat tax and replaced it with rates ranging from 10.5% to 34.7%.
15: "It would be a cut to the city, because you’re eliminating that 33% [flat rate]," Rita told us in a phone interview.
16: Meanwhile, the state’s original graduated rates of 15% to 50% on the casino would have been lowered to a range of 12% to 40%, according to the bill.
17: The varying rates would be applied at different levels based on how much money the casino brings in under the plan.
18: A similar series of graduated rates for both Chicago and the state would apply to revenue from table games.
19: When we ran the bill’s specifics by Syverson, he agreed the legislative language would cut rather than raise Chicago’s take.
20: "If, in fact, we use the strict definition of the bill and Chicago was only going to get the tax rates that you gave me … then I would concede that Chicago would get a little bit less money," he said.
21: "Now, having said that, anyone with any common sense would say, why would Chicago introduce a bill that says, ‘We want less money’?"
22: Rita’s rejoinder: Without a lower tax structure that encourages companies to build and run a Chicago casino, there won’t be a casino for the city or the state to tax.
23: Still, Syverson remains concerned about the plan.
24: He said his job as a state senator is to ensure Illinois doesn’t lose out on needed funding from a Chicago casino and noted Lightfoot and the Chicago City Council have other tools to further tax the casino without getting an OK from the legislature.

llama2-70b: According to [1], a bill was proposed to change the tax rate for a Chicago casino.
The proposal suggested that the state's tax revenue would decrease, while Chicago's tax revenue would increase.
Syverson, an expert in the field, agreed that the bill's language would result in a cut in the state's take, not a raise [19].
Specifically, under this proposal, Chicago's take would increase from 5% to 22% or 23%, while the state's take would decrease by half [5].
However, it's important to note that this doesn't necessarily mean that Chicago would keep more of the revenue, as the total amount would remain the same.
Therefore, the claim that there would be "lower taxes paid to the state and higher taxes paid to Chicago" is half-true, as the tax rate would change, but the total amount would not increase.

8286c2a5957765407be5353732f4f906.claim: "  a new annual report shows that ""West Virginia’s tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year, reversing years of decline and outpacing national growth by 58 percent."""
8286c2a5957765407be5353732f4f906.label: true
8286c2a5957765407be5353732f4f906.passage:
0: West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice took to Facebook in October to tout gains in his state’s tourism industry.
2: "When I took office, I made tourism a top priority because I knew it had all the potential in the world," Justice wrote in his post .
3: "Today I am proud to announce that West Virginia’s tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year, reversing years of decline and outpacing national growth by 58%!
4: Way to go West Virginia Tourism!"
5: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The post linked to a press release that provided additional detail and cited a study conducted by  Dean Runyan Associates, an economic consulting firm that has examined the state’s tourism industry annually since 2000.
6: A year ago, we fact-checked how well Justice described the previous year’s statistics and rated it Mostly True , because Justice glossed over some of the report’s negative findings.
7: How about this year?
8: Let’s take a look, point by point.
9: (Justice’s office did not respond to inquiries for this article.)
10: "West Virginia’s tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year... " This is accurate.
11: The report found that overall spending on tourism in West Virginia grew from $4.14 billion in 2016 to $4.28 billion in 2017 to $4.55 billion in 2018.
12: That’s an increase in the most recent year of 6.5%, easily exceeding the rate of inflation.
13: Spending also grew for the second straight year if you set aside gambling revenue.
14: It rose from $3.48 billion in 2016 to to $3.63 billion in 2017 to $3.91 billion in 2018.
15: That’s an increase in the most recent year of 7.5%.
16: This also exceeded the rate of inflation.
17: "... reversing years of decline …" This is accurate, too.
18: According to the data in the report, the rise over the past two years came after four consecutive annual declines, as this chart shows: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com "… outpacing national growth by 58%."
19: The report also provides data for the national tourism market that’s comparable to the West Virginia numbers.
20: According to the report, spending was $980 billion in 2018, a 4.1% increase over 2017.
21: (These figures are not adjusted for inflation, but neither is the West Virginia figure, so the national and state figures can be compared equitably.)
22: Justice’s 58% figure appears to come from comparing the most recent one-year increase in West Virginia (6.5%) with the most recent one-year increase nationally (4.1%).
23: The West Virginia percentage increase is 58.5% bigger than the national increase.

llama2-70b: According to Reason [3], Governor Jim Justice announced that West Virginia's tourism industry has grown for the second consecutive year, a claim that Reason [10] confirms.
Reason[17] adds that this growth reverses years of decline, which is accurate.
Reason [22] states that Justice's 58% figure comes from comparing the one-year increase in West Virginia (6.5%) with the national increase (4.1%).
Reason[23] clarifies that the West Virginia percentage increase is 58.5% greater than the national increase, supporting the claim.
Considering these reasons, the claim's veracity is true.

d07289780475cb625847a836c4a633e7.claim: " Delaware has the ""eighth-largest black population in the country"""
d07289780475cb625847a836c4a633e7.label: false
d07289780475cb625847a836c4a633e7.passage:
0: Former Vice President Joe Biden exaggerated the size of the black population in Delaware in an interview in which he spoke about why he thinks he has more black support than Mayor Pete Buttigieg.
1: "I come out of an environment where I have the eighth-largest black population in the country, in my state, and that's where I got my political education," he told Axios .
2: Biden was referring to a comparison of the black population in states and Washington, D.C. by percentage, but he didn’t mention the word "percentage" in that interview.
3: In terms of raw numbers, Delaware — a state with a population of just under 1 million — has a small black population that does not rank among the top states.
4: RELATED: U.S. minorities surpassed 25% of electorate when Obama ran in 2008, and it's going up What Census data shows for Delaware’s black population The U.S. Census sent us 2018 data showing the percent of the African American population in each state.
5: Delaware was in seventh place — about 22.5% of the population is black.
6: The top states in order were Mississippi, Louisiana, Georgia, Maryland, Alabama, South Carolina, Delaware and North Carolina.
7: If we include the District of Columbia, then Delaware would be in eighth place.
8: But if we look at raw numbers, Delaware does not rank among the top states for the size of the black population.
9: Delaware has about 220,000 black residents , placing it around the bottom one-third of states.
10: By population, the top five states would be Texas, Georgia, Florida, New York and California.
11: William Frey , a demographer at the Brookings Institution who is known for his research on race, said it is appropriate to look at the percent of the black population for the state.
12: However, Frey said, Biden’s comment would be more compelling if applied to a state with a large black percentage and sheer numbers such as Georgia.
13: A Census spokesman told us that both metrics — the percentage and raw numbers — are useful data, but it provides a more complete picture to look at both of them.
14: In Biden’s case, he was using the statistic to make his case that he has a history of representing black voters and cares about issues of importance to them.
15: But it’s important to understand how small the Delaware population is.
16: "There are more black people in one county in Florida than in Delaware," said Keneshia Grant, a Howard University political scientist who does research on black voters.
17: "It looks like the ten cities with the largest black populations all have larger black populations than the entire state of Delaware."
18: The percentage of black residents in Delaware is significant in terms of showing that Biden had to take into account the concerns of black voters when he was a senator there, University of Delaware political scientist David Redlawsk said.
19: "This is best expressed in terms of a percentage, which provides the relative importance to his own elections," he said.
20: We found that in some interviews Biden states that he is talking about a percentage while in other instances he omits that crucial explanation.
21: (Biden has been making similar statements at least since 2006 .)

llama2-70b: The claim that Delaware has the "eighth-largest black population in the country" is false.
According to Reason [17], none of the ten cities with the largest black populations have a smaller black population than the entire state of Delaware.
Additionally, Reason [3] states that Delaware has a small black population that does not rank among the top states in terms of raw numbers.
Therefore, it is not possible for Delaware to have the eighth-largest black population in the country.

d36ce22b4b35cf6a927550cd395fbb1d.claim: "  Koalas are ""functionally extinct"" as bushfires in Australia continue to destroy their habitat."
d36ce22b4b35cf6a927550cd395fbb1d.label: false
d36ce22b4b35cf6a927550cd395fbb1d.passage:
0: As catastrophic bushfires spread across parts of Australia, misinformation about one of the region’s most beloved animals, the koala, spreads, too.
1: Areas of Australia started to burn in September 2019, marking an early start to the region’s fire season and scorching more than 5 million acres in News South Wales and parts of Queensland.
2: When the fires became international news, online stories – like this one – went viral with shocking headlines that claim koalas are now "functionally extinct" as a result of the blaze.
3: It is true that several hundred koalas have died in the bushfires ( some estimates put the death toll in the thousands) and large swaths of the marsupial’s habitat have been destroyed.
4: However, the claim that koalas are "functionally extinct" is inaccurate.
5: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: It appears that the idea that koalas are "functionally extinct" started when the Australian Koala Foundation , a local conservation nonprofit that advocates for koala protection and preservation, released a statement in May 2019 calling on Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison to enact the Koala Protection Act, which was written in 2016.
8: "The Australian Koala Foundation (AKF) believes Koalas may be functionally extinct in the entire landscape of Australia," the statement says.
9: "The AKF thinks there are no more than 80,000 Koalas in Australia."
10: Since the fires, the organization released another statement in October 2019 standing by its use of the term.
11: Noah Greenwald, endangered species director at the US-based Center for Biological Diversity , told PolitiFact there are two different definitions of "functionally extinct."
12: One is that a species still occurs in the wild but can’t effectively reproduce, so is all but extinct.
13: The other, is that a species is so reduced that it can no longer play its role in the ecosystem.
14: Neither definition, he says, applies to the koala.
15: The koala population is indeed declining, but AKF’s estimate is much lower than other assessments.
16: The International Union for Conservation (IUCN), the global authority on the conservation status of all species, approximates that 300,000 mature adult koalas remain in the wild, and lists the species as vulnerable , a step above endangered and two above critically endangered.
17: But IUCN last assessed the koala population in 2014, and the species may very well be worse off due to food degradation, deforestation, hunting, drought and fires over the last several years.
18: That said, another group of scholars studied the koala population in 2016 and found comparable numbers.
19: Nevertheless, several wildlife experts reject the notion that koalas are currently "functionally extinct."
20: "By either definition, it's hard to see koalas as functionally extinct," Greenwald said.
21: "The last estimate for their numbers is roughly 300,000, and in some places they are very much playing their ecological role of munching on eucalyptus leaves."
22: Wildlife conservation experts also told National Geographic that it’s difficult to measure koala populations, even at the best of times, because the animal has a wide range across eastern Australia, are human-shy and live very high up in trees.
23: Christine Adams-Hosking, a postdoctoral research fellow at the University of Queensland in Australia, told PolitiFact that koalas "are certainly not functionally extinct" in Australia.
24: And though they have been affected by habitat loss as a result of the fires, she said, it’s too early to know the impact.
25: "We will never know exact numbers because we don’t know how many koalas exactly there were there in the first place," she said.
26: "Time will tell.
27: Over the next few years, the burnt areas will need to be monitored to see how many koalas recolonize the burnt areas and whether they can successfully build up their population numbers again."
28: PolitiFact also reached out to the World Wide Fund for Nature-Australia about the claim.
29: The organization’s senior manager for land clearing and restoration, Stuart Blanch, told us that while the bushfires are a setback for koala conservation, WWF-Australia does not agree that the species is functionally extinct.
30: The organization estimates that from July to November, the fires scorched more than 8% of the known koala forest in New South Wales and that, even before the fires, koala populations disappeared from large areas of eastern and southern Australia.
31: "While koalas will survive this bushfire crisis, the longer-term picture in New South Wales and Queensland is not good unless excessive tree clearing is halted," Blanch said.
32: "WWF-Australia has published a report projecting ‘that koalas will become extinct in the wild in eastern Australia by as early as 2050 – and highly likely by 2100 – if deforestation and other threats continue.’ " The organization said that koalas require remaining eucalypt forests to be preserved, cleared forest areas to be regenerated, and isolated patches of habitat to be connected by newly planted wildlife corridors.

llama2-70b: Contrary to the claim that Koalas are "functionally extinct" due to the destruction of their habitat by bushfires in Australia, the International Union for Conservation (IUCN) approximates that there are still 300,000 mature adult koalas in the wild, listing the species as vulnerable [16].

Several wildlife experts also reject this notion, with Christine Adams-Hosking, a postdoctoral research fellow at the University of Queensland in Australia, stating that koalas "are certainly not functionally extinct" in Australia [23].
Although it is true that several hundred koalas have died in the bushfires and large swaths of their habitat have been destroyed [3], it is inaccurate to claim that koalas are "functionally extinct".
Therefore, the claim has a false veracity.

2a8131375787c59086bdd086ad1a5ba9.claim: Jim Justice is the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators.
2a8131375787c59086bdd086ad1a5ba9.label: false
2a8131375787c59086bdd086ad1a5ba9.passage:
0: West Virginia Gov.
1: Jim Justice, facing a competitive Republican primary in 2020, recently introduced an ad touting his accomplishments in office, including a focus on K-12 education.
2: The ad, released in a Dec. 4 tweet , features several West Virginians reading off a series of scripted accomplishments from Justice’s tenure.
3: One of the accomplishments, voiced by a teacher, is that "Jim Justice is the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators."
4: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com This struck us as odd, since governors of all parties regularly tout their support for teachers — a group that’s popular with voters and, in many states, a politically powerful constituency.
5: Teacher salaries have been an especially sensitive issue in West Virginia.
6: Between 2005 and 2017, West Virginia teacher salaries never rose higher than 44th in the nation.
7: That history set the stage for a 2018 teacher strike in West Virginia, which was the state’s first major K-12 walkout in almost three decades.
8: Justice eventually signed a 5% pay bump, which is more than the legislature had offered prior to the strike.
9: So is Justice really the first West Virginia governor ever to push for teacher pay raises?
10: His office did not respond to inquiries for this article, but we found that each of Justice’s five immediate predecessors either proposed or enacted teacher pay raises.
11: Gov.
12: Earl Ray Tomblin, Democrat, 2011-2017 In his first state of the state address in 2011, Tomblin proposed a one-time, across-the-board $800 increase for teachers.
13: "Frankly, it should be more and we need to strive for a day when our teachers are paid at a rate equivalent to the most important role they play," he said in the speech, according to the Associated Press .
14: In 2014, despite offering few increases in his relatively austere budget proposal, Tomblin did include a 2% pay raise for teachers.
15: The bill he eventually signed contained a $1,000 raise for teachers for the 2014-2015 school year.
16: Gov.
17: Joe Manchin, Democrat, 2005-2010 As governor, Manchin — now a U.S.
18: Senator — periodically sparred with teachers’ unions over the size of his salary increase proposals.
19: But both Manchin’s Senate office and West Virginia teachers’ unions agree that he proposed a teacher salary increase and signed it into law .
20: During his tenure, Manchin raised teacher salaries by 3.5%, according to a joint statement released by the West Virginia Education Association, the American Federation of Teachers-West Virginia, and the West Virginia School Service Personnel Association when the groups endorsed Manchin’s Senate reelection bid in 2018.
21: Manchin’s Senate office cited the same 3.5% increase when we inquired.
22: The legislation Manchin signed also improved teachers’ annual salary increments and allowed educators to move from a 401(k)-style defined contribution plans to a defined-benefit system.
23: Gov.
24: Bob Wise, Democrat, 2001-2005 In his 2001 state of the state address, Wise proposed raising teacher salaries by $1,000, plus $2,500 in incentives.
25: "Teachers are the heart of the educational system.
26: We must honor the work of our teachers," he said .
27: After leaving the governor’s office, Wise became CEO of the Alliance for Excellent Education, an education advocacy group.
28: Gov.
29: Cecil Underwood, Republican, 1997-2001 In his 1998 state of the state address, Underwood proposed giving teachers a $750 pay raise.
30: He signed a three-year pay raise into law later that year.
31: Gov.
32: Gaston Caperton, Democrat, 1989-1997 Caperton was governor during a divisive, 11-day West Virginia teacher strike in 1990, but he ended up presiding over a significant pay increase for the state’s teachers.
33: The strike was settled when all parties agreed on a $5,000 pay increase phased in over three years.
34: Last year, PolitiFact reported that most significant recent improvement in West Virginia teacher pay compared to other states came between 1990 and 2000, a period during which Caperton and Underwood were in office.
35: Like Wise, Caperton headed an education group — the College Board — after serving as governor.

llama2-70b: The claim that Jim Justice is the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators is false.
According to PolitiFact, there have been several governors in West Virginia's recent history who have proposed or enacted teacher pay raises[10].
For instance, Earl Ray Tomblin, a Democrat who served as governor from 2011 to 2017, proposed a one-time $800 increase for teachers in his first state of the state address in 2011[12].
Additionally, despite offering few increases in his relatively austere budget proposal, Tomblin did include a 2% pay raise for teachers in 2014[14].
Furthermore, Joe Manchin, a Democrat who served as governor from 2005 to 2010, also proposed raising teacher salaries by $1,000, plus $2,500 in incentives in his 2001 state of the state address[24].
Bob Wise, a Democrat who served as governor from 2001 to 2005, also proposed raising teacher salaries by $1,000, plus $2,500 in incentives[28].
Therefore, it is evident that Jim Justice is not the first West Virginia governor to fight for pay raises for educators, and the claim is false.

63003eaf3fe248208957ec4cb9c94829.claim: "  justices of the peace in Texas are being asked to choose: ""give up your career or violate your religious beliefs"" and perform same-sex marriages."
63003eaf3fe248208957ec4cb9c94829.label: false
63003eaf3fe248208957ec4cb9c94829.passage:
0: During an interview on a Fort Worth radio program with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, host Chris Salcedo pressed his guest about the case of a Waco justice of the peace who was sanctioned by a state commission earlier this month for only officiating opposite sex, but not same-sex, marriages.
1: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct issued Justice of the Peace Dianne Hensley a public warning over her refusal to perform same-sex ceremonies; the commission could take further action if she refuses to stop the practice.
2: Paxton, a Republican, reiterated the stance of his office, one that has not changed since just after the 2015 Supreme Court decision legalizing gay marriage.
3: He said people are entitled to religious exemptions when it would violate their faith to carry out the duties of their job.
4: On the show, Salcedo characterized the case as such: "I shouldn’t have to give up my career — make a choice, either give up your career or violate your religious beliefs," Salcedo said.
5: "The government shouldn’t put me in that position."
6: Saledo’s description of Hensely’s situation is inaccurate.
7: No one is asking Hensley to violate her religious beliefs to keep her career: officiating marriages is an optional activity.
8: A state commission’s opinion on the matter suggested she could officiate all or no marriages, but not selectively choose one type.
9: Protection of religious beliefs Justices of the peace handle low-level civil and criminal cases, including traffic and other Class C misdemeanor cases and civil cases involving up to $10,000.
10: They can also officiate marriages, but this is considered "extra-judicial," an optional activity that earns them thousands per year in personal income.
11: So while there may be some financial incentive to do it, it is by no means required.
12: In fact, some justices of the peace in Texas have chosen not to officiate any marriages in order to avoid the religious dilemma, including in McLennan County, where Hensley hails.
13: The commission decided to investigate Hensley based at least in part on a Waco Herald-Tribune article in which she was quoted about her decision to decline same-sex marriages and how she believed she was entitled to a religious accommodation.
14: It found that she had refused to perform same-sex marriages since 2016, instead only performing opposite-sex marriages and referring same-sex couples to other officiating JPs and clergy.
15: The state commission that sanctioned Hensley said her actions cast "doubt on her capacity to act impartially to persons appearing before her as a judge due to the person’s sexual orientation."
16: Now, Hensley can appeal the sanction, start performing same-sex marriages or stop performing marriages altogether.
17: Hensley has argued that she is entitled to a "religious exemption," but there is no law or legal precedent in Texas establishing such an exemption for a justice of the peace in this context.
18: This question varies by state, depending on whether the state’s Supreme Court has taken up a case and established a precedent.
19: In separate interviews, Douglas Laycock and John Dzienkowski, law professors at the University of Texas, said they weren’t aware of any such cases in Texas.
20: Two legal opinions on the subject that have been issued by state agencies — a 2015 opinion from the attorney general’s office and the Judicial Commission sanction — are nonbinding.
21: In a 2015 opinion filed after the U.S. Supreme Court case on same-sex marriage, Paxton supported people’s right to assert a religious exemption under the First Amendment, though he noted that fines and litigation were possible.
22: The recent Judicial Commission opinion punished Henlsey for giving off the appearance of bias, seeming to indicate an exemption would not be possible.
23: But Laycock said neither document is legally binding.
24: "The basic answer is we don’t know yet," Laycock said.
25: "This may well wind up in the courts."
26: Some states, such as North Carolina, have passed laws on this subject, but Texas has not.
27: The North Carolina law allows some officials, similar to a justice of the peace, to decline to administer any marriages if they have a "sincerely held religious objection" to same-sex marriage, but they may not be selective and only marry opposite-sex couples.
28: Other positions have different requirements People in other government positions, like county clerks who issue marriage licenses, have less flexibility, as issuing marriage licenses can be part of their job description.
29: Perhaps most famously, Kim Davis , a clerk in Kentucky, refused to issue a license to a same-sex couple and, in a high-profile case, she was sued.
30: When she refused to comply with the judge’s order compelling her to follow the law, she was jailed for six days for being in contempt of court.
31: Davis was later released after agreeing not to interfere with other clerks in the office issuing licenses.
32: Some county clerks in Texas are allowing those officials who object to same-sex marriage to find another clerk within the office to issue a license in their place.
33: But if everyone else in the office also refuses, the office as a whole can’t deny a couple the right to marry in defiance of the law, Laycock said.
34: That may explain why no religious exemption case has risen to the Supreme Court level in Texas, Laycock said.
35: As long as the couple receives their license or has their marriage officiated, the damages they can claim in court are limited to emotional distress.
36: That someone in Hensley’s position should not be forced to choose between their job and religious belief, as Salcedo commented, is "not a settled rule of law yet; it’s an opinion about what the law ought to be," Laycock said.

llama2-70b: The claim that justices of the peace in Texas are being asked to choose between their career and religious beliefs by performing same-sex marriages is false.
While some justices have declined to perform same-sex marriages citing religious beliefs, there is no law or legal precedent in Texas that requires them to do so [17].

The Texas state commission's opinion suggested that justices of the peace could choose to officiate no marriages at all, but they cannot selectively decide which marriages to perform based on their personal beliefs [8].
Moreover, there is no consensus on the matter, as opinions vary, including one by Laycock, who said that it's not a settled rule of law yet but an opinion about what the law ought to be [36].
Furthermore, while some justices may argue that they are entitled to a religious exemption, there is no established legal precedent for such an exemption in Texas [17].
In fact, the U.S Attorney General, Ken Paxton, supported people's right to assert a religious exemption under the First Amendment, but noted that fines and litigation were possible[21].
It's also worth noting that some states, such as North Carolina, have passed laws regarding religious exemptions for public officials, but Texas has not[26].
Therefore, the claim that justices of the peace in Texas are being forced to choose between their career and religious beliefs is false.

ffab9487f39d06124085a467edc0a564.claim: Male birth control testing stopped after men’s testicles start exploding in India.
ffab9487f39d06124085a467edc0a564.label: false
ffab9487f39d06124085a467edc0a564.passage:
0: A viral story shared on Facebook about male birth control testing — claiming that it caused men’s testicles to explode — originated on a satirical website.
1: But some online posts don’t make that clear.
2: They were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: "Male birth control testing stopped after men’s testicles start exploding in India," reads the headline.
5: Readers of the story are directed to " faceofmalawi.com " below the headline, and "n pas" is cited as a source at the end of the article.
6: That refers to "npas," which are the letters at the top of the website ihlayanews.com, where the story appeared on Dec. 3 .
7: Below "npas" are the words "nuusparodie waarvan jy hou."
8: As AFP Fact Check notes , that’s Afrikaans for "news parody you like."
9: But the post flagged by Facebook includes no such disclaimer.

llama2-70b: The claim that male birth control testing stopped after men’s testicles start exploding in India is false.
The story appears on ihlayanews.com, a website with the letters "npas" at the top, which, as AFP Fact Check notes, stands for "news parody you like" in Afrikaans [6][8].
Thus, the article is a parody piece, not a factual news report.

Additionally, the article directs readers to "faceofmalawi.com" below the headline, which is not a legitimate news source, and cites "n pas" as a source at the end of the article, further indicating that the piece is not meant to be taken seriously [5].
Also, there is no credible evidence to support that male birth control testing was halted due to explosions.
In conclusion, the claim is baseless and should not be taken as factual information.
Therefore, the veracity of the claim is false.

9672f0793599a2b84212a430eb8f4f21.claim: a photo shows Pamela Karlan reacting to Hillary Clinton’s presidential defeat.
9672f0793599a2b84212a430eb8f4f21.label: false
9672f0793599a2b84212a430eb8f4f21.passage:
0: In the wake of Pamela Karlan’s impeachment hearing testimony, some social media users have seemingly attempted to discredit the Stanford law professor by connecting her to images of other women online.
1: We’ve already debunked a viral post that claims a photo of a woman in a costume holding the sign "vagina lady" is Karlan.
2: Other fact-checkers have found another post misidentifying a woman wearing a pink crocheted hat during the 2017 Women’s March on Washington as Karlan.
3: Now a Dec. 5 Facebook post claims to show a photo of "Pamela Karlan when Hillary lost."
4: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The woman the post identifies as Karlan appears upset and is wearing an Uncle Sam-style hat and Hillary Clinton’s 2016 campaign logo.
7: But the person in the image is actually Janna DeVylder , who was photographed at an election party in Australia that year.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The Des Moines Register reported in January 2017 that DeVylder grew up in Iowa and was living and working in Sydney when Clinton lost to Trump.
9: She had voted absentee for Clinton.
10: The picture of her watching election results quickly became a meme, and she was derided online as the "poster child for the mentally insane Hillary snowflakes."

llama2-70b: A Facebook post from December 5 claims to show a picture of "Pamela Karlan when Hillary lost", but the image is actually of Janna DeVylder, who was photographed at an election party in Australia in 2016[3].
DeVylder, who grew up in Iowa and was living and working in Sydney at the time of the election, was not Pamela Karlan, a lawyer who had no known connection to the image [8].
The image has been falsely associated with Karlan, who didn't even live in the same country as DeVylder.
Thus, the claim that the photo shows Pamela Karlan reacting to Hillary Clinton's defeat is false.

d79d3fd65c74640a6aa04fe18c5950ae.claim: Yesterday Virginia announced the end of youth hunting!
d79d3fd65c74640a6aa04fe18c5950ae.label: false
d79d3fd65c74640a6aa04fe18c5950ae.passage:
0: As Democrats won control of the Virginia legislature in November, an image started to spread online showing a child in hunting hear holding a dead deer.
1: One such post published on Facebook Nov. 8 says: "Yesterday Virginia announced the end of youth hunting!
2: The governor said that no kid under 18 will be allowed to shoot a gun.
3: This is the end of a 400 year tradition of kids helping put food on their family’s (sic) table.
4: It’s a sad day in the Commonwealth!"
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: We reached out to the governor’s office about the claim but didn’t hear back.
8: However, the state’s Department of Game and Inland Fisheries wrote in a Nov. 8 Facebook post that it "wanted to clear up some rumors that have been circling about youth hunting in Virginia."
9: "There are no changes to currently scheduled youth hunting days," the post says.
10: "All current laws and regulations pertaining to hunting in Virginia are in effect as shown on the DGIF website and the current Hunting & Trapping in Virginia Digest.
11: Any changes to hunting laws would require action either by the Virginia General Assembly or the Board of Game and Inland Fisheries, and currently no such changes are proposed."
12: In November, Virginia Gov.
13: Ralph Northam, a Democrat, announced that in the upcoming legislative session he would push for gun control measures like "getting rid of bump stocks" and reintroducing red flag laws designed to remove firearms from people deemed by a judge to be a danger to themselves or others.
14: After a mass shooting in Virginia Beach in May, Northam introduced eight policy proposals and called a special session to address gun control, but no action was taken before it was adjourned by Republicans, CNN reported.
15: The proposals included "legislation enhancing the punishment for allowing access to loaded, unsecured firearm by a child from a Class 3 Misdemeanor to a Class 6 felony," according to July a press release , and raising "the age of the child from 14 to 18."
16: Outdoors writer Ken Perrotte wrote a Nov. 27 column in the Free Lance-Star, a newspaper in Fredericksburg, Va., warning that "proposed legislation would be trouble for Virginia hunters."
17: One bill for the upcoming 2020 session, writes Perrotte, "would make it a felony to leave loaded, unsecured firearms where anyone under the age 18 could access them.
18: This bill also contains a bombshell provision that makes it a crime for anyone under age 18 to use a firearm without adult supervision.
19: Presumably, this includes hunting scenarios."
20: The proposed legislation says it would be unlawful for anyone "to recklessly leave a loaded, unsecured firearm in such a manner as to endanger the life or limb of any person under the age of 18."
21: But a spokeswoman for the governor’s office told the Associated Press that "a responsible hunter — regardless of age — would not be affected by this bill."
22: The bill also says it would be unlawful for anyone younger than 21 to "knowingly and intentionally possess or transport a handgun or assault firearm anywhere in the Commonwealth."
23: However, that wouldn’t apply to "any person actually engaged in lawful hunting or going to and from a hunting or preserve," according the proposed legislation.
24: We further didn’t find evidence that the state "announced the end of youth hunting," as the Facebook post says, or that the governor "said that no kid under 18 will be allowed to shoot a gun."

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming Virginia had "announced the end of youth hunting" was flagged by Facebook as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation.
The state's Department of Game and Inland Fisheries clarified in a Facebook post that there were no changes to scheduled youth hunting days[8][9].
The claim may have originated from a column by outdoors writer Ken Perrotte, who warned that proposed legislation could be trouble for Virginia hunters [16][17].
One bill proposed for the 2020 session would make it a felony to leave loaded, unsecured firearms accessible to minors and a crime for minors to use firearms without adult supervision [17][18].
However, a spokeswoman for the governor's office stated that responsible hunters, regardless of age, would not be affected by the bill [21].
Furthermore, there is no evidence to support the claim that the state announced the end of youth hunting or that the governor said minors would not be allowed to shoot a gun [24].
Therefore, based on the available information, the claim is false.

7f68c19487b34163c042edccbf355a83.claim: "  the Potomac River ""has gotten dirtier and dirtier and dirtier and dirtier. I go down there and that litter is left almost exclusively by immigrants."""
7f68c19487b34163c042edccbf355a83.label: false
7f68c19487b34163c042edccbf355a83.passage:
0: Fox News host Tucker Carlson ripped into immigrants in the nation’s capital, accusing them without evidence of contaminating the Potomac River.
1: In an interview with the Atlantic, Carlson said he’s been fishing in the river, which stretches from West Virginia into the Chesapeake Bay, for almost 35 years.
2: "It has gotten dirtier and dirtier and dirtier and dirtier," he said.
3: "I go down there, and that litter is left almost exclusively by immigrants."
4: Asked how he knew immigrants were to blame, Carlson added: "Because I’m there.
5: I watch it."
6: We found that Carlson’s claim is at odds with data collected by activists devoted to keeping the Potomac clean, who told us that the river has actually gotten cleaner over time.
7: Plus, there’s no evidence that immigrants are especially to blame for any trash floating around the river’s waters.
8: (Fox News did not respond to requests for comment.)
9: Cleaner and cleaner, not dirtier and dirtier The Potomac River has long been considered too polluted for swimming, particularly in and around Washington, D.C., where Carlson lives .
10: Its waters were so bad that in 1965, former President Lyndon Johnson declared the river a "national disgrace."
11: But a 2018 report from the Potomac Conservancy, a nonprofit clean-water advocate in the region, found that the Potomac’s overall health has improved dramatically in the last 10 years.
12: Hedrick Belin, president of the group, blasted Carlson for his "groundless accusation" in a statement to PolitiFact, calling the Fox News host’s comments "factually incorrect" and "racist."
13: "For the first time in generations, we are within reach of fully enjoying a healthy, thriving Potomac River," Belin said, noting that river pollutants are in decline as fish are returning.
14: Other experts agreed.
15: "This is a river that's getting cleaner and cleaner, not 'dirtier and dirtier,'" said Philip Musegaas, vice president of programs and litigation for the Potomac Riverkeeper Network.
16: The nonprofit called Carlson’s claim "dead wrong" in a Facebook post.
17: Musegaas said plans to upgrade the sewer systems in Washington and Alexandria, Va., should eliminate the "last sources of untreated sewage pollution" in the nearby metropolitan area.
18: Curtis Dalpra, communications manager for the Interstate Commission on the Potomac River Basin , said different environmental issues affect different parts of the river, which is more than 380 miles long.
19: But generally speaking, the river is cleaner than it was 30 years ago.
20: Still, Carlson was talking specifically about litter, so we also reached out to the Alice Ferguson Foundation, which organizes annual trash cleanups along the riverside and keeps tabs on the total amount of trash and recyclables its volunteers haul out of the Potomac’s shores each year.
21: According to the foundation’s data , less litter was collected in 2019 than in 2007, even as the number of volunteers increased.
22: Specifically, the number of trash-and-recyclable-filled bags per volunteer dropped from an average of 2.14 bags in 2007 to 1.20 in 2019.
23: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com At Fletchers’ Cove — a spot that, according to the Washington Post , is roughly a 10-minute drive from Carlson’s house — the average number of bags-per-volunteer went from roughly 2.11 in 2007 to about 1.32 in 2019.
24: Litter isn’t the main problem Local experts also cast doubt on Carlson’s claim that immigrant litter was at fault.
25: For starters, litter is not the top pollutant soiling the Potomac River’s waters.
26: Belin said nutrients and sediment that flow off the land are the main causes for concern.
27: When they hit the water, they harm wildlife, degrade habitats and taint the water, making it less clean and safe.
28: Litter is still an issue.
29: But foreign-born people — who make up roughly 14% of the population in Washington, D.C., according to the Census Bureau — are not uniquely prone to littering.
30: "Littering is definitely a problem, but it is a problem that knows no color or ethnicity," Musegaas said.
31: "Tourists litter, residents litter, and people fishing and boating on the river litter."
32: Not only that, but most of the trash that ends up in the Potomac River is not deposited directly, experts said.
33: Often, trash left in the street or outside in barrels gets swept by rain into the sewer or the river.
34: Of course, that trash has to come from someone, Dalpra noted.
35: At some point, it was thrown on the ground or stuffed in the trash.
36: And in a dense city like Washington, there’s likely more litter to go around than elsewhere.
37: But that litter "is really a problem that spans society," Dalpra said.
38: While we won’t discount the possibility that Carlson has spotted immigrants tossing trash in the Potomac, there’s no evidence that the litter "is left almost exclusively by immigrants."

llama2-70b: According to a local news report, a claim was made about the Potomac River getting dirtier and dirtier and the litter being left almost exclusively by immigrants [37].
However, there is no evidence to support this claim, and it is false[38].
While it is possible that immigrants may contribute to litter in the area, there is no evidence to suggest that they are the exclusive culprits.
In fact, littering is a societal problem that affects many communities and cannot be attributed to any one group of people [37].
Therefore, it is important to reject this claim and instead focus on addressing the broader issue of littering in the Potomac River and other communities.
This can be achieved through education, community engagement, and enforcement of littering laws, rather than blaming a specific group of people without evidence [38].
By working together, we can create cleaner and healthier environments for everyone.

0b18e3af9e575a911e00121d49cc6906.claim: George P. Bush to place statue of (Mexican general) Santa Anna at the Alamo.
0b18e3af9e575a911e00121d49cc6906.label: false
0b18e3af9e575a911e00121d49cc6906.passage:
0: In a lengthy Facebook post , a group called Save the Alamo warned that Texas Land Commissioner George P. Bush wants to erect a statue of the Mexican general who led his nation’s forces during the Battle of the Alamo in 1836 on the grounds of the historic mission in San Antonio.
1: Save the Alamo was created by Rick Range, a former candidate for land commissioner who challenged Bush during the 2018 Republican primary.
2: In the post, Range described a Dec. 4 meeting of the San Antonio Historic Design and Review Commission, at which he said new information about Bush’s plans for the site came to light.
3: "However, during that hearing, it was revealed that not only do George P. Bush and the GLO intend on moving the Cenotaph outside the boundaries of the Alamo; they also intend to erect a statue of the dictator Santa Anna and a memorial honoring the Mexican Army!"
4: Range wrote.
5: "I am not making this up.
6: We know that parts of the Bush plan were going to be horrendous, but it now looks like it will be worse than we ever dreamed."
7: It’s true that the General Land Office, which Bush heads, has proposed moving the cenotaph monument, which honors those Texans who died at the Alamo, to a different location as part of the agency’s planned $450 million project to restore the Alamo.
8: But there are no plans to build a monument to Santa Anna and the Mexican Army at the Alamo.
9: Bush shared a series of tweets on Thursday rebutting the allegations in the post and suggesting that the claim has racist roots.
10: Here are his tweets, presented together: "One must ask themselves, why am I being accused of honoring the murderous dictator Santa Anna?"
11: Bush wrote. "
12: Is it because my mother (now a naturalized citizen) is from Mexico?
13: I was born in Houston, my wife is from San Angelo, and my boys were born-you guessed it- here in Texas.
14: "As a United States Navy Veteran, who deployed to Afghanistan, I know exactly what it means to be loyal to the American flag, this country and this great state.
15: The idea that I would EVER place a statue of Santa Anna at the Alamo is patently false.
16: Enough is enough.
17: This is an outright lie, and is quite frankly, flat out racist."
18: There is no mention of constructing a statue or monument of Santa Anna in the official synopsis of the Alamo Master Plan , the restoration project.
19: The only time Santa Anna is mentioned in the synopsis is during an overview of the different political factions present during the Battle of the Alamo.
20: San Antonio Council Member Roberto Treviño, who serves on the Alamo Master Plan Management Committee, told the Rivard Report that the statement is "baseless, and downright ridiculous."
21: "Among the information and rumors being spread about the plan for the Alamo, this might be one of the most obscene," he said.
22: "We are honoring our history; we are honoring the truth; we are honoring freedom.
23: Erecting a statue of Santa Anna does none of these things."
24: Molly Quick, director of government relations for the General Land Office, gave state lawmakers a progress report on implementation of the restoration project in a Dec. 17 email.
25: There is no mention of Santa Anna or the Mexican Army in her materials.
26: Commission meeting video not altered During the public meeting of the San Antonio Historic Design and Review Commission on Dec. 4, designers behind the restoration project sought the commission’s approval to start implementing the first phase of the plan, which includes landscaping and street improvements — as well as the repair and relocation of the cenotaph to its new location.
27: Range, who was not present at the meeting, said he was told by others in attendance that one of the speakers presenting the project said there were plans to "honor Santa Anna" at the redesigned site.
28: "One of the consultants on the design teams made the statement that they were going to honor both sides, including Santa Anna and the Mexican army," Range told PolitiFact Texas.
29: "If you’re going to honor somebody, that is a statue or a memorial or a monument.
30: I don’t know how else you would honor somebody."
31: But multiple viewings of the archived video of the hearing reveal that none of the people presenting the project said anything about honoring Santa Anna or constructing a sculpture for him or the Mexican army.
32: The only mention of Santa Anna came at the end of the presentation, when John Kasman, vice president of PGAV Destinations, spoke about future phases of the project and some details still under consideration.
33: "There are multiple stories that occurred upon that south edge that deserve to be told," he said, briefly mentioning the position of Santa Anna’s troops as one of those stories.
34: Range said this was not the remark from the meeting that concerned him — in fact, he said he thought a plaque showcasing the movement of the Mexican troops during the 1836 battle would be a "good idea" for the site.
