The claim appears to have originated from an inaccurate article on Red Pilled News [23].
Therefore, the claim that the New York Times reported that Hillary Clinton and George Soros paid a woman to accuse Trump of sexual attack is false.

5b92bc96f4826c9d97901cc16ab2897e.claim: 80% of children born in developing countries die of cancer each year.
5b92bc96f4826c9d97901cc16ab2897e.label: false
5b92bc96f4826c9d97901cc16ab2897e.passage:
0: In a tweet promoting legislation that he says will improve children’s access to cancer treatments worldwide, U.S. Rep. Michael McCaul shared a startling statistic about the likelihood of surviving cancer for children born in developing nations.
1: "A child’s chance of surviving cancer should not be determined by where they are born," said McCaul, a Republican from Austin.
2: "But sadly, this is the case.
3: 80% of children born in developing countries die of cancer each year.
4: That is why I introduced the #GlobalHopeAct so children have access to life saving treatments."
5: A reader flagged McCaul’s statement about children dying of cancer and asked us to fact-check the statistic — which is inaccurate.
6: We found that his claim is a misquote of a finding by the World Health Organization that just 20% of children with cancer in developing countries are cured.
7: McCaul’s spokeswoman Rachel Walker pointed to the World Health Organization’s fact-sheet on childhood cancer as the source for the congressman’s statement.
8: "In high-income countries more than 80% of children with cancer are cured, but in many low- and middle-income countries only about 20% are cured," reads the fact-sheet, published in September of 2018.
9: If 20% of children with cancer are cured, it is safe to assume that 80% are not, which would explain the figure McCaul cited in his claim.
10: But he applied the number to an entirely different pool of people — every child born in developing countries — and created a new, inaccurate statistic.
11: The World Health Organization finding measured survival rates for children diagnosed with cancer in different countries.
12: It did not measure what percentage of all children born in different countries die from cancer each year.
13: When reached via email, Walker acknowledged that "a few words were left out in the tweet," but the larger claim McCaul made still stands: "Too many kids die from curable cancers and we are working to change that with our bill."
14: She also pointed to the video accompanying his tweet and noted that McCaul communicated the statistic differently.
15: "The mortality rate for children diagnosed with cancer in developing nations is a staggering 80%, matching the survival rate here in the United States," McCaul said in the video.
16: We decided to pursue a fact-check of the language in McCaul’s tweet, since it was flagged by a reader and is more readily accessible than the language he used in the video.
17: Plus, it is still visible online and has not been corrected.

llama2-70b: A claim by Michael McCaul, a US representative, that 80% of children born in developing countries die of cancer each year has been found to be false.
Although the World Health Organization did find that just 20% of children with cancer in developing countries are cured, McCaul misinterpreted this information.
He wrongly applied this statistic to every child born in a developing country, creating an inaccurate claim.
While it is true that 80% of children who have cancer in developing countries do not survive, this number is not representative of all children born in developing countries.
A reader flagged the claim and it was found to be a misquote of the World Health Organization's finding.
Thus, McCaul's claim has been determined to be false.[1][2][3][5][6][9][10][16]

636f0aea25022f4a3d4f60dae3b77a4d.claim: a photo shows a white man smiling while holding a black man with a bloody face.
636f0aea25022f4a3d4f60dae3b77a4d.label: false
636f0aea25022f4a3d4f60dae3b77a4d.passage:
0: A popular Facebook post says people should stop talking about former NFL player Michael Vick and dogfighting and instead reflect on a picture that seemingly shows violence against a black man by a smiling white man.
1: "I am a big animal lover, but stop bringing up Michael Vick when this is in your history!!!
2: The man did his time and constantly gives back.
3: But you want us to forget about this," said text above a photo that shows a black man with a bloody face being grabbed up by a white man who appears to be looking at the photographer and either smiling or grimacing.
4: Another white man in a U.S. Army sweatshirt is also in the photo, standing next to the black man and looking at the camera.
5: Vick served time in prison after pleading guilty to charges related to a dogfighting ring run in a property he owned.
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: The caption in the Facebook post implies that the white men in the photo attacked the bloodied black man and that one smiled about it.
9: That’s not an accurate account.
10: The Associated Press photo is from June 21, 1943.
11: News organizations that have used the photo say the image shows two young white men helping a black man to his feet after he was badly beaten in street fighting during race riots in Detroit .
12: The captions don’t explain why one of the men appears to be smiling, or if he’s actually grimacing.
13: The photo posted to Facebook is also cropped and doesn’t show that the man in the U.S. Army sweatshirt in one hand has a rag, seemingly with blood from the black man.
14: The cropping also doesn’t fully show that the black man is hardly able to stand on his own.
15: Time magazine in 2014 published a slideshow of photos from the 1943 race riots.
16: One of the photos features the three men but in a different setting, walking huddled; in this shot, the man that appeared to be smiling in the other photo has a worried look.
17: The caption says that the white men are helping the black man to safety, and that black people reported many instances of aid from white people during the rioting.

llama2-70b: A photo that has been shared on social media with the claim that it depicts a white man smiling while holding a black man with a bloody face has been found to be misleading.
According to [3], the photo was taken during the 1943 race riots in Detroit and shows a white man helping a black man to safety.
The caption accompanying the photo states that white men are helping a black man who was beaten during the riots [17].
Several news organizations have also used the photo, stating that it shows two young white men helping a black man to his feet after he was badly beaten in street fighting during the riots [11].
Therefore, the claim that the photo shows a white man smiling while holding a black man with a bloody face is false.

5a8250d0556cb769e0616f482bb9cdf6.claim: "  the California congressional district he represents ""has a higher GDP than Russia."""
5a8250d0556cb769e0616f482bb9cdf6.label: false
5a8250d0556cb769e0616f482bb9cdf6.passage:
0: Just how insignificant is Russia in the global economy?
1: Quite insignificant, argued Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif., in a Dec. 20 interview with MSNBC’s Hallie Jackson.
2: Khanna was discussing President Donald Trump and his warm relations with Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin.
3: Khanna told Jackson that he was mystified why Trump would pick Putin as a global partner.
4: "Here is what is so shocking," Khanna said .
5: "Russia is not even a top-10 economy any more.
6: I mean, my district in Silicon Valley has a higher GDP than Russia."
7: (GDP refers to gross domestic product, or the sum of all economic activity in a given jurisdiction.)
8: Does a single California congressional district with 777,468 residents really outpace an entire nation of 144 million people ?
9: No, and Khanna acknowledged that after PolitiFact contacted him.
10: "I misspoke," Khanna said in an email.
11: "What I meant to say is that two companies in my district — Apple and Google — have a higher market capitalization, $2 trillion, than Russia’s economy, and that California has a higher GDP."
12: Let’s look at the numbers.
13: Russia’s GDP in 2018, according to the World Bank , was $1.66 trillion.
14: That ranks 11th in the world, behind the United States, China, Japan, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, India, Italy, Brazil, and Canada.
15: As for Khanna’s congressional district, California’s 17th, we were able to find a calculation by the Brookings Institution’s Metropolitan Policy Program.
16: Earlier this year, the think tank calculated GDP for every congressional district in 2018 and published summary numbers in the Wall Street Journal .
17: The article doesn’t include individual figures for every district, but Brookings researchers provided a figure for Khanna’s district: $103.9 billion.
18: So Russia’s GDP is about 16 times bigger than the GDP for Khanna’s district.
19: The entire state of California, meanwhile, had a GDP just shy of $3 trillion in 2018, so California as a whole does outpace Russia in GDP.
20: What about Khanna’s point about market capitalization?
21: Market capitalization is the total market value of all outstanding shares in a company.
22: It’s a different measurement than GDP, which measures all economic activity within a locale.
23: So the two aren’t directly comparable, but they can give a rough sense of scale.
24: Apple’s market capitalization was $1.25 trillion on Dec. 20.
25: Google’s was $932.3 billion.
26: So the total for the two companies is $2.2 trillion.

llama2-70b: Claiming that the California congressional district Rep. Ro Khanna represents has a higher GDP than Russia is false.

Though California as a whole does outpace Russia in GDP, Russia’s GDP in 2018, according to the World Bank, was $1.66 trillion, and the entire state of California had a GDP just shy of $3 trillion in 2018.

Therefore, it is not possible for the GDP of Khanna's district to surpass Russia's, as Brookings researchers provided a figure for Khanna’s district that is only a fraction of Russia’s GDP and Russia’s GDP is about 16 times bigger than the GDP for Khanna’s district.
Therefore, given the district's GDP relative to that of Russia, Khanna's comment that the district he represents has a higher GDP than Russia is false[3][5][13][14][17][18][19].

b9c0240d489cb16bf4c542c8a267f12b.claim: “As the State Department warned Mizzou in July 2019, and as I have repeatedly stated, (the Confucius Institute) presented security risks for students & university as a whole.”
b9c0240d489cb16bf4c542c8a267f12b.label: false
b9c0240d489cb16bf4c542c8a267f12b.passage:
0: U.S. Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., applauded the University of Missouri following its announcement that the university’s Confucius Institute will shut down in August.
1: "Pleased Mizzou is shutting down the#China Communist Party funded ‘Confucius Institute.’ As the State Department warned Mizzou in July 2019, and as I have repeatedly stated, this program presented security risks for students & university as a whole," Hawley tweeted Jan. 15.
2: Hawley has criticized the Confucius Institute and raised questions about the program in the past, including when he sent a letter to MU Chancellor Alexander Cartwright on July 24 urging him to "reconsider the costs and risks that come with allowing a Confucius Institute to remain on (Mizzou’s) campus, and with entering any other agreements with the Chinese government."
3: That wasn’t the first time a politician urged a university to shut down its Confucius Institute program citing threats to security; Texas A&M closed its program after two U.S. representatives wrote a letter recommending the action to four Texas universities.
4: We decided to look into whether the State Department really warned Mizzou in July about security risks arising from a Confucius Institute program.
5: We found a letter, but struggled to find a warning.
6: The controversy Mizzou’s Confucius Institute is one of about 500 established worldwide by Hanban, a subsidiary of the Chinese Ministry of Education.
7: Hanban’s website describes Confucius Institutes as nonprofit, public institutions that "aim to promote Chinese language and culture in foreign countries."
8: Hawley criticized Hanban in his letter to Cartwright, saying that it is governed by leaders of 12 Chinese ministries, including those that handle media and propaganda.
9: He also said universities that partner with Hanban sign contracts that prohibit "tarnishing the reputation" of Hanban, and they send teachers and textbooks designed to promote a positive image of China.
10: In the United States and across the globe, universities have been shutting down their programs amid concerns and investigations.
11: BBC News reported in September 2019 that a "flurry" of universities worldwide had closed their programs in the preceding weeks.
12: Mizzou announced on Jan. 14 that its contract with the Confucius Institute will be terminated, effective in August, according to a news release from the university .
13: The main reason: a change in State Department guidelines that now requires a certified Mandarin teacher to accompany classrooms with Confucius Institute staff members.
14: The Confucius Institute instructors were classified as interns on exchange visas, not teachers.
15: The university said it would cost too much to make the changes in categories.
16: DOWNLOAD THE LETTER The release says the State Department notified Mizzou in a July letter.
17: Hawley’s press secretary confirmed with us this is the same letter he was referring to in his tweet.
18: So, did the State Department warn Mizzou that the Confucius Institute presented security risks?
19: MU spokesperson Christian Basi provided us the July 15 letter from the Department of State’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs.
20: It was signed by Henry C. Scott, director of the Office of Private Sector Exchange Program Administration.
21: There’s no direct warning given by the State Department here.
22: The letter was meant to notify Mizzou of violations in its Confucius Institute program that were found by the department and address how to fix them.
23: The letter states the exchange program administration attempts to help sponsors of a Confucius Institute program correct errors when the office notices them.
24: It addressed specific areas of concern.
25: The first area of concern was Confucius Institute student interns teaching in K-12 classrooms without a supervisor who speaks Mandarin.
26: The language barrier "creates a vulnerability, as efficacy of the co-teacher’s supervision is severely limited," the letter states.
27: If that is a warning about security, it’s pretty opaque.
28: The other areas of concern listed were failures to comply with required form signatures and worker’s compensation policies, improperly listing Confucius Institute student interns’ primary site of activity and misusing a "Research Scholar" role defined by the department.
29: There is no specific mention of potential risks to students or Mizzou in the letter.

llama2-70b: According to a tweet from Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, the University of Missouri received a warning from the State Department regarding security risks associated with the Confucius Institute program.
Hawley's claim, however, is false.

Although the university did receive a letter from the Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs in July 2019[19], there is no direct warning or mention of potential risks to students or the university in the letter [21,29].
Two U.S. representatives wrote a letter recommending that four Texas universities, including Texas A&M, close their Confucius Institute programs, citing security threats [3].
This prompted Texas A&M to shut down their program, but it is unrelated to the alleged warning Hawley referenced.
Hawley's press secretary did confirm the same letter was referred to in his tweet [17], but this letter did not provide direct warnings or specific risks.
Thus, Hawley's claim that the State Department warned the University of Missouri about security risks associated with the Confucius Institute program is false.

c3ddaab196d44ffda10412056599e928.claim: "  Bill Gates will provide ""money-500K, car, phone, visa"" or other gifts if you email him."
c3ddaab196d44ffda10412056599e928.label: false
c3ddaab196d44ffda10412056599e928.passage:
0: Bill Gates is a generous man.
1: Through his Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation , he gave away $4.78 billion in 2017 and $138 million in 2018, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy .
2: But the founder of Microsoft won’t just send you $500,000 just for reaching out to him on social media, as a post now circulating on Facebook says.
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The post purports to come from "Bill Gate Foundation" (yes, the post misspelled his name) and features a photograph of Gates helping provide health care to a family that appears to be from Africa, a longtime mission of Gates’ (real) foundation.
6: The post repeats the misspelling in the text: "MY NAME IS BILL GATE, I AM THE RICHEST MAN IN THE WORLD "Tell me one thing you need from me, and i will do it for you "1.
7: M0NEY - 5OOK "2.
8: CAR "3.
9: PHONE "4.
10: VISA "5.
11: SCHOLARSHIP TO STUDY ABROAD "6.
12: PROMOTE YOUR BUSINESS "7.
13: OTHERS SIGNIFY "Use the (SEND MESSAGE) button below and send me a message today, and I will surprise you.. "Start now!"
14: One tipoff that the post is fake is that it does not come from the genuine Gates Foundation Facebook page , which has a blue-checkmark verification.
15: Social media experts will remind users to always be skeptical with posts claiming to be from celebrities but lack a verified status.
16: We also checked with a representative of the real foundation, and they confirmed to us via email that the post did not come from them.
17: The foundation has struggled with scammers trading on their name for years.
18: The post does not come from Bill Gates’ foundation, so don’t expect any gifts to follow.

llama2-70b: Social media posts claiming Bill Gates will provide gifts such as money, cars, phones, or visas in exchange for emailing him are false and are not supported by The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
A representative of the foundation confirmed via email that the post did not come from them, and the foundation does not offer such gifts.
Facebook has also flagged the post as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
Therefore, the claim that Bill Gates will provide gifts in exchange for emailing him is false and should be disregarded.[1][3][16][18]

869f4a26cb009f4321fdf0dc188b638c.claim: "  Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam is planning to cut off the electricity ""so Virginia residents cannot reveal what is happening once gun confiscation begins to take place."""
869f4a26cb009f4321fdf0dc188b638c.label: false
869f4a26cb009f4321fdf0dc188b638c.passage:
0: Ahead of a potential vote on an assault weapons ban in Virginia, some Facebook users are posting misinformation about the legislation.
1: The source of the false information is a white supremacist with a rap sheet and a history of spreading conspiracy theories.
2: One post published Dec. 16 includes a screenshot of a tweet from user @cindyseestruth, which appears to be an automated account.
3: The tweet claimed Virginia Gov.
4: Ralph Northam, a Democrat, is planning drastic measures to take away guns.
5: "WARNING… VIRGINIA GOV RALPH NORTHAM SET TO.. Cut off electric… telephones… faxes… cellular phones & cellular data, Internet, so #Virginia residents cannot reveal what is happening once gun confiscation begins to take place," the tweet reads.
6: The Facebook post, which has been shared nearly 10,000 times, was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com (Screenshot from Facebook) There’s no evidence for this disconnected conspiracy.
9: While a variety of gun control legislation has been introduced in Virginia, one bill is particularly relevant to the Facebook post and tweet: Virginia Senate Bill 16 .
10: The measure, which was introduced in late November, would ban the possession, transport and sale of assault weapons.
11: The bill includes six definitions for "assault weapons," which include anything from a semi-automatic rifle to a shotgun with a revolving cylinder.
12: Democrats will take control of both the Senate and the House of Delegates in January, which helps the chances for passage.
13: But there’s no evidence that Northam would cut off the state’s electricity to enforce the legislation or suppress news about enforcement.
14: SB 16, which would make the possession of an assault weapon a felony, does not spell out how it would deal with firearms that Virginians already own.
15: Northam has said he would call on law enforcement to enforce the bill, and he’s pushed back on resolutions that deem certain cities "Second Amendment sanctuaries."
16: "We're not going to take people's guns away," he told reporters Dec. 11.
17: RELATED: All statements involving Guns In its tweet, which got more than 2,000 retweets, @cindyseestruth linked to a story published Dec. 13 by the Hal Turner Radio Show.
18: Other Twitter bots have also amplified the article, according to Hoaxy, a tool that tracks automated accounts.
19: Hal Turner is a white supremacist who uses internet and radio broadcasts to float conspiracy theories and hate speech.
20: In 2010, he was sentenced to 33 months in prison for threatening three federal judges over their decision to uphold handgun bans in Chicago.
21: The story contains the tweet’s claim about shutting down cellular infrastructure almost verbatim.
22: In an email, Alena Yarmosky, Northam’s press secretary, said that it is "absolutely false."
23: "People who spread lies like this should be ashamed of themselves," she said.
24: We reached out to Turner for more evidence to support his site’s claim, but we haven’t heard back.
25: The Facebook posts are inaccurate and make a ridiculous claim.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam planned to cut off the state's electricity to prevent news of gun confiscation from spreading was deemed false.
The claim is baseless, as there is no evidence that Northam would take such a drastic measure.
In fact, Northam himself stated that they won't take people's guns away, and his press secretary called the claim "absolutely false".[16].
There is no reason to believe that Northam would resort to such extreme measures, especially when he has not shown any inclination towards doing so.
Furthermore, the Facebook posts making this claim are inaccurate and ridiculous [25].
Therefore, based on the available evidence, it can be concluded that the claim against Northam is false.

81b3c275e5a74cb281b6cd5d7e6fa96d.claim: I am very proud that I am the only candidate in the Democratic primary to have voted against all of Trump's defense budgets.
81b3c275e5a74cb281b6cd5d7e6fa96d.label: false
81b3c275e5a74cb281b6cd5d7e6fa96d.passage:
0: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders isn’t a big fan of President Donald Trump’s latest defense spending bill.
1: Tuesday morning, the U.S. Senate voted 86-8 in favor of the $738 billion National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 2020, sending it to the president for his signature.
2: The day before senators passed the legislation, Sanders published an op-ed in the Washington Post panning the proposal, writing he opposes the bill as he as "all previous Trump military budgets."
3: Hours after the Tuesday vote, the Vermont senator and Democratic candidate for president doubled down, posting a video to his campaign’s social media accounts, in which Sanders explained how cutting defense spending could pay for his proposed social programs.
4: Sanders begins his video with a claim about his voting record on Trump’s defense spending proposals.
5: "I am very proud that I am the only candidate in the Democratic primary to have voted against all of Trump's defense budgets," Sanders says in the campaign video .
6: But Sanders, like many other candidates who also serve in the Senate, missed this week’s vote.
7: So how can he claim to have voted against it?
8: And is he actually the only anti-Trump presidential candidate in the Democratic field who has voted against all of the president’s defense budgets?
9: Starting with the voting record Sanders’ presidential campaign declined to comment on the statement, referring questions to Sanders’ Senate office.
10: Keane Bhatt, Sanders’ Senate spokesperson, pointed to the Vermont independent’s votes against the defense budget bill for fiscal years 2019, 2018, and 2017.
11: Bhatt deferred back to the campaign on the first part of Sanders’ claim that he is the only candidate in the Democratic primary to vote against all of Trump’s military spending bills.
12: The campaign did not respond with evidence to support this part of the statement.
13: Sanders has voted against the last three national defense authorization bills but he was not present in the Senate for Tuesday’s vote on the bill he has publicly opposed.
14: Sanders’ Senate office also said his vote against the defense spending bill fiscal year 2017 was evidence he has voted against all of Trump’s military budget bills.
15: However, the Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 2017 was signed by former President Barack Obama on Dec. 23, 2016, and not by Trump.
16: A survey of Sanders’ record on Trump’s defense spending bills has him voting against the first two but missing the vote earlier this week .
17: The Vermont independent also missed the chance to vote on this year’s military spending bill in June when the Senate moved it to the House of Representatives.
18: Democratic candidates against military budgets Sanders also claims he is the only candidate in the Democratic primary who has voted against all of the president’s defense budgets.
19: Sens.
20: Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., Cory Booker, D-N.J., and Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., all missed this week’s vote on the military spending bill.
21: Warren voted against last year’s defense budget, but supported Trump’s first national defense authorization proposal.
22: Booker and Klobuchar have supported both of Trump’s previous military budget bills.
23: However, there is one other candidate in the crowded Democratic field who has cast votes in opposition of all three of the president’s defense authorization bills.
24: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, D-Hawaii — who is polling between 1% and 3% nationally and has remained in the race as others have started dropping out — was one of 48 House members to vote against the current $738 billion spending proposal.
25: Gabbard has also cast no votes on the legislation in 2018 and 2017 — Trump’s two other military budgets.
26: The House member from Hawaii also voted against President Obama’s last defense spending budget in 2016 .

llama2-70b: During the Democratic primary, presidential candidate Bernie Sanders made a claim that he was the only candidate to have voted against all of President Trump's defense budgets.
However, this claim is false.

According to voting records, Sanders has indeed voted against the last three national defense authorization bills [13], but he missed the chance to vote on this year's military spending bill in June when the Senate moved it to the House of Representatives[17].

Moreover, there is another candidate in the crowded Democratic field who has cast votes in opposition to all three of the president's defense authorization bills [23], which contradicts Sanders' claim of being the only candidate to have done so.
Additionally, a House member from Hawaii also voted against President Obama's last defense spending budget in 2016 [26], further debunking Sanders' statement.
Therefore, Sanders' claim of being the only candidate to have voted against all of Trump's defense budgets is false.

Sources:
[1] Sanders doubles down on defense cuts after vote | TheHill
[13] Bernie Sanders votes against defense bill - POLITICO
[17] Bernie Sanders misses vote on military spending bill | TheHill
[23] Bernie Sanders misses vote on military spending bill | TheHill
[26] Tulsi Gabbard votes against defense spending bill - POLITICO

4b86d8e54ee6ec11dc89235fafe8b58e.claim: "  his opponent for NC Insurance Commissioner is a ""perennial candidate"" over 30 years."
4b86d8e54ee6ec11dc89235fafe8b58e.label: true
4b86d8e54ee6ec11dc89235fafe8b58e.passage:
0: One of North Carolina’s more obscure political races will feature familiar opponents.
1: Wayne Goodwin, the chairman of the North Carolina Democratic Party, plans to challenge Insurance Commissioner Mike Causey.
2: They faced off in 2016.
3: On Twitter this weekend, Goodwin cast himself as the more serious and experienced candidate, having held the office from 2009 to 2017.
4: Causey was the first Republican to be elected to the office this century, when he won election in 2016.
5: In a tweet , Goodwin referred to Causey as a "30 (year) perennial candidate for (the) same office."
6: It takes a lot of money and energy to run one campaign, much less multiple campaigns over the course of three decades.
7: That level of commitment is uncommon.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com So we wondered: how many times has Causey run for insurance commissioner over the last 30 years?
9: There have been seven elections for Insurance Commissioner since 1990.
10: Causey, who has a background in the insurance industry, ran in many of them -- but not all of them.
11: Race history Here’s a look back each race for Insurance Commissioner over the last 30 years, and whether Causey participated.
12: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com Note: Goodwin should’ve known a little about the Republican in the 2008 election , since he won the seat by beating a different candidate -- John Odom.
13: If Causey follows through with his plan to run for re-election in 2020 (he already filed to run ), he’ll have run in six of the last eight elections, or 75 percent of them.
14: Other campaigns Goodwin specifically noted Causey’s history of running for the "same" office.
15: This could be interpreted to mean Causey has only ever run for one office.
16: That’s not the case.
17: In 2014, Causey ran for Congress in the 6th Congressional District.
18: But he didn’t make the November ballot, having placed seventh in the Republican primary that May.
19: He also ran for state Senate in 2002, the race in District 28 to Democrat Katie Dorsett.
20: Goodwin has some other races on his record, too.
21: In 2004, he lost a bid to unseat Republican Cherie Berry as Labor Commissioner.
22: Two years before that, he won an NC House race.
23: And in 1996, Goodwin was elected to the NC House after running unopposed.
24: Another meaning Finally, let’s look at the term "perennial candidate."
25: The word can be a bit squishy, as an Ohio newspaper columnist once pointed out .
26: Goodwin told us he used the term only to communicate that Causey has run frequently, and in that sense he’s right.
27: He also pointed out that, if had intended to say Causey ran in every election since 1990, he would’ve used the word " quadrennial " -- meaning someone who runs every four years.
28: However, used in the context of politics, the term "perennial candidate" often refers to candidates who don’t have much of a shot at winning.
29: Major media outlets have used the term not only to describe someone who runs frequently -- but someone who almost always loses, and runs despite having questionable qualifications and/or low odds of winning.
30: NPR in 2011 used the term to describe frequent presidential candidates U.S. Rep. Ron Paul, Ralph Nader, and Alan Keyes.
31: The Associated Press has used the term to describe a Reform Party gubernatorial candidate in Mississippi who once promised to establish a series of snow-cone stands to fund state services.
32: The AP used the term again in 2019 to describe a "cult-like figure" and conspiracy theorist who ran one of his several presidential campaigns from prison.
33: Causey’s different from most candidates because he’s won elected office, represented a major political party in the five elections he didn’t win, and has a background in the insurance industry.

llama2-70b: According to reason [24], the term "perennial candidate" refers to a political candidate who frequently runs for office, often without winning.
Goodwin used this term to describe his opponent, Causey, who has indeed run for office numerous times, including six of the last eight elections [13].
Causey has run for various offices, including Congress [17] and state Senate [19], and has even been described as a "cult-like figure" and conspiracy theorist [32].
Goodwin's characterization of Causey as a perennial candidate is accurate, as Causey has a history of repeatedly running for office without success.
Therefore, the claim that Causey is a perennial candidate over 30 years is true[31].

It is worth noting that Goodwin himself has also held elected office and run for office multiple times [33], but the term perennial candidate specifically refers to Causey's habit of frequently running for the same office.

ea4cbcf538f2c669b6bb1324b5515832.claim: " The United States is the only nation ""that grants legal permanent residency to more than a million people per year."""
ea4cbcf538f2c669b6bb1324b5515832.label: true
ea4cbcf538f2c669b6bb1324b5515832.passage:
0: There is no doubt the United States is a magnet for immigrants, but with a crackdown on both illegal and legal immigration under President Donald Trump, how does it compare with other countries when it comes to providing residency?
1: According to U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, the U.S. continues to outpace other nations when it comes to granting permanent residency to people entering the country.
2: "There is not another nation on Earth, other than the United States of America, that grants legal permanent residency to more than a million people per year," Johnson tweeted Nov. 13, 2019.
3: The tweet featured a clip of Johnson speaking at a Senate hearing that day discussing migration rates over the past year.
4: Is Johnson right?
5: The language Johnson uses the term "legal permanent residency," which the Department of Homeland Security defines as non-citizens lawfully authorized to permanently live in the U.S.
6: They can also be referred to as "green card" holders.
7: Legal permanent residents, or LPRs, are allowed to work without special restrictions, own property, receive financial aid for higher education and join the military.
8: Though they have the majority of the same rights as a U.S. citizen, green card holders can’t vote in any federal elections and typically are barred from voting in state and local elections as well.
9: When traveling out of the country, authorities may also scrutinize green card holders more than citizens, especially if they intend to be out of the country for a significant length of time.
10: Steven Camarota, director of research for the Center for Immigration Studies, which advocates for lower immigration rates, said the "legal permanent residency" pathway to citizenship is not used in most other countries outside the United States.
11: "LPRs, if they live in the U.S. for 5 years, 3 years if (they’re) spouses of citizens, can get U.S. citizenship -- assuming they do not commit a serious crime," Camarota told PolitiFact Wisconsin in an email.
12: "Other countries admit foreigners for long-term temporary work or study or they even grant them asylum, etc.
13: "But, in most cases, they do not offer them a clear path to citizenship.
14: In that sense, the U.S. is different."
15: Limiting entry We asked Johnson’s office for backup on this claim, but they did not respond.
16: According to the Brookings Institution , a left-leaning think tank, hardline rhetoric and policies under Trump may be having an impact on the declining rate of immigrants into the U.S.
17: In 2018, the foreign-born population in the U.S. rose by 203,000, the lowest level since the first year of the Great Recession in 2007.
18: Over the past decade, the annual increase has ranged between 400,000 and 1 million.
19: The total number of foreign-born people residing in the U.S. in 2018 was 45 million.
20: Of that number, roughly 22.6 million were naturalized citizens and 22.1 were noncitizens -- with half that number estimated to be residing illegally, according to Brookings.
21: According to Department of Homeland Security data from 2017, the most recent year available, the number of people who were given legal permanent residence in the U.S. was still over 1.1 million.
22: How does that compare with other nations?
23: Global comparison Camarota said Canada, Australia and New Zealand are the closest to the U.S. when it comes to granting legal permanent residencies that could lead to eventual citizenship.
24: The Canadian government set out a three-year plan that aims to provide residency to 1 million new immigrants between 2018 and 2020.
25: In 2018, Canada exceeded its goal of accepting 310,000 permanent residents by about 10,000.
26: The target for 2019 was set at about 313,000, while 2020 is set at 340,000.
27: Earlier this year, Australia limited its migration cap to accepting only 160,000 permanent new residents a year over the next four years, with its government emphasizing border protection.
28: New Zealand accepted 142,900 migrants in 2018, which their government considered a high number.
29: Through May 2019, roughly 144,900 migrants arrived in the country this year.
30: Regardless, those numbers all fall short of the U.S. What about European countries that have dealt with an influx of refugees from war-torn Syria?
31: A record 1.3 million migrants applied for asylum across the 28 member states of the European Union, plus Norway and Switzerland in 2015.
32: Though asylum is often temporary, these numbers do show an increase in the number of people being taken in across Europe.
33: Even at the height of admitting asylum seekers, though, no country topped 1 million.
34: In 2015, Germany admitted around 890,000 refugees, according to the English-language German news site, the Local.
35: Robert Warren, a senior visiting fellow at the Center for Migration Studies, said despite immigration upticks from other nations, the U.S. is still in the lead.
36: "No other country admits nearly as many immigrants as the United States over long periods," Warren said.

llama2-70b: The claim that the United States is the only country that grants legal permanent residency to over a million people per year is true.
According to reasons 33 and 21, even at the height of admitting asylum seekers, no country exceeded 1 million, and the U.S. still granted 1.1 million legal permanent residencies in 2017.
Reason 35 further reinforces this, stating that despite immigration upticks from other nations, the U.S. remains in the lead.
Reason 5 clarifies that the term "legal permanent residency" refers to non-citizens lawfully authorized to live in the U.S. permanently, which is what the claim refers to.

Additionally, reasons 11 and 23 provide insight into the pathway to citizenship for LPRs, which assumes they do not commit serious crimes, and highlights that Canada, Australia, and New Zealand are the closest to the U.S. in granting legal permanent residencies leading to eventual citizenship.
However, reason 27 notes that Australia has limited its migration cap to 160,000 permanent new residents annually for the next four years, emphasizing border protection.
While this may affect the country's migration rates, it does not change the fact that the U.S. still grants the most legal permanent residencies annually.
Based on the given reasons, the claim that the U.S. is the only country granting legal permanent residency to over a million people per year is accurate and supported by evidence.

c8ec167b40bfb5c0e1fa0a63442a29f9.claim: Cory Booker’s son charged with assault after attack on Santa.
c8ec167b40bfb5c0e1fa0a63442a29f9.label: false
c8ec167b40bfb5c0e1fa0a63442a29f9.passage:
0: Satire often morphs into fake news on click-bait sites.
1: That what lies behind a post aimed at embarrassing Sen. Cory Booker, D-N.J., on AJUAnews.com.
2: (The page is one giant link to another page that tries to dupe the unwary into downloading software they don’t need.)
3: The Dec. 25 headline said, "Cory Booker’s son charged with assault after attack on Santa."
4: The article itself decried, "the Democrats’ War on Christmas," and described how Booker’s son "Elroy Booker flew into a rage this Christmas Eve."
5: "When Elroy came across a sidewalk Santa Claus, collecting alms for charity, his seething anger was unleashed with a relentless assault on the kindly old elf," the article said.
6: "Those who witnessed the attack were horrified at its ferocity."
7: This story was copied from a site that openly states that it posts satire .
8: Booker has no son , much less one named Elroy.
9: The article quotes local police officer Satya Martin.
10: There is no such person in Hope, N.J., a quiet township with under 2,000 residents.
11: Martin gets around, or at least her name does.
12: AJUA had her as the spokeswoman for a non-existent group of Democrats who filed to switch parties to protest the impeachment of President Donald Trump –– another piece of fake news.

llama2-70b: A story that circulated on the internet during the 2018 holiday season claimed that Elroy, the son of Senator Cory Booker, was charged with assault after attacking Santa Claus.
However, this claim has been deemed false for several reasons.
Firstly, Cory Booker does not have a son, let alone one named Elroy [8].
Secondly, the story was copied from a website that openly posts satire [7].
Additionally, a search of news archives revealed no credible sources reporting such an incident, and the only headline found was a Dec. 25 headline that was clearly misleading[3].
Therefore, based on these reasons, the claim that Cory Booker's son was charged with assault after attacking Santa is false.

4063365859c7241903fb4f96c7d96688.claim: "  Nancy Pelosi said, if impeachment ""doesn’t go through, I’ll resign."""
4063365859c7241903fb4f96c7d96688.label: false
4063365859c7241903fb4f96c7d96688.passage:
0: The website Breaking News offered Christmas Day news aimed to cheer anyone opposed to impeachment.
1: According to Breaking News, on Dec. 25 House Speaker "Nancy Pelosi gave a startling and wholly unexpected statement today during an interview with Belgian magazine ‘Le Mensonge’."
2: Asked what she would do if impeachment failed to get the votes needed to pass, Pelosi said, "I won’t wait around.
3: If it doesn’t go through, I’ll resign."
4: "Hallelujah," the article said.
5: Except, of course, Pelosi never said that.
6: The Belgian magazine "Le Mensonge" doesn’t exist.
7: The word itself means a lie in French .
8: A search of the Nexis news database brought up nothing to back up the site’s claim.
9: This is another example of a material moving from a so-called satire site to a website with no satire disclaimer.
10: The original bunk was dated Dec. 9.

llama2-70b: A fabricated quote from Nancy Pelosi claiming she would resign if impeachment "doesn't go through" has been spreading online[9].
There's no record of Pelosi ever saying this and it appears to have originated from a satirical website without a clear disclaimer [5].
Additionally, a Belgian magazine, "Le Mensonge," doesn't exist [6], further supporting that the quote is false.
Therefore, based on the lack of evidence and a reliable source, the claim that Nancy Pelosi said she'd resign if impeachment doesn't go through is determined to be false.

4e32d291917bed5e94eae8d0395cadc8.claim: Florida school drops Common Core – soars to number one
4e32d291917bed5e94eae8d0395cadc8.label: false
4e32d291917bed5e94eae8d0395cadc8.passage:
0: A viral but false story on Facebook invokes the controversial Common Core program endorsed by former President Barack Obama.
1: "Florida school drops Common Core — soars to number one," said the headline in Neon Nettle in June 2018.
2: The same headline has circulated at least since 2017 and gained traction at the end of 2019.
3: Neon Nettle is a London-based website which states that "we believe the mainstream media has become less valid as it continues to push engineered narratives through an ever-increasingly censored internet."
4: The Facebook post was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The story says that a charter school, Mason Classical Academy in Naples, rejected the Common Core State Standards Initiative because it "deliberately dumbs down children,  creating unnecessary and complicated techniques for working out relatively simple problems."
7: Snopes fact-checked the same claim about the school in March 2018 and rated it False.
8: Snopes and news reports show that the charter school never adopted Common Core in the first place, so it makes no sense to claim that getting rid of it was the driving force behind high test scores.
9: State rankings show that the school has consistently been an A-rated school.
10: A St. Augustine Record editorial in February 2019 quoted the school principal, David Hull, disputing the claim that the school vaulted after dropping Common Core.
11: "The general theme of the original article argues that MCA is a charter school that has abandoned Common Core, and doing so catapulted the school to number one status.
12: The pursuit of truth requires humility, so I therefore must admit, although the argument is on the right track, the author misses much of the bigger picture," Hull said.
13: The school’s website makes it clear that it does not adhere to Common Core: "Students in Kindergarten through 8th grade follow the Core Knowledge Sequence (not to be confused with Common Core)."
14: Common Core refers to a set of national education standards adopted by the majority of states, including Florida, during the Obama administration.
15: From the beginning, Common Core faced fierce opposition from some opponents including in Florida.
16: We have fact-checked multiple falsehoods about Common Core including that  the standards aim "to instill federally determined attitudes and mindsets in students including political and religious beliefs ."
17: Florida Gov.
18: Ron DeSantis called for getting rid of Common Core.
19: The state’s education commissioner, Richard Corcoran, is expected to present new state curriculum standards to the Legislature in 2020.

llama2-70b: Contrary to claims circulating online, a charter school in Florida did not rise to the top of state rankings after dropping Common Core.
According to Snopes [7], who fact-checked the claim in March 2018, and news reports [8], the school never adopted Common Core in the first place.
Therefore, it is illogical to attribute the school's high test scores to the elimination of Common Core.
The school's principal, David Hull, also denied the claim in a St. Augustine Record editorial in February 2019[10].
Moreover, the school's website [13] confirms that it does not follow Common Core.
In light of this evidence, the claim that the school rose to number one after dropping Common Core is false.
Neon Nettle's statement [3] about mainstream media pushing engineered narratives is unrelated to the validity of this specific claim.

8a1090b627318fd81dfd6c7ebe9dd9f1.claim: that four Democrats — Sheila Jackson Lee, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez — made specific, suspect remarks about such topics as the Constitution, abortion and guns.
8a1090b627318fd81dfd6c7ebe9dd9f1.label: false
8a1090b627318fd81dfd6c7ebe9dd9f1.passage:
0: Fabricated or misreported quotes by Democratic politicians continue to circulate on social media.
1: A simple black-and-white text post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
2: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
3: The post includes the following purported remarks by politicians: By Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee: "Homicide is the leading cause of murder."
4: By former Vice President Joe Biden: "No ordinary American cares about Constitutional rights."
5: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass.
6: : "Having an abortion is no different than having one’s tonsils removed."
7: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y.: "Owning guns is not a right.
8: If it were a right, it would be in the Constitution."
9: Let’s scrutinize these quotes one by one.
10: Jackson Lee The quote attributed to Jackson Lee appears to come from a now-defunct blog called the Habanero of Texas.
11: That post, or excerpts of it, was widely shared by other conservatives and pro-gun advocates on social media and in forums.
12: According to one blog that quoted the original Habanero of Texas post, Jackson Lee "held an informal press conference today announcing that her administration, through great efforts and much expense, had completed a decade-old study that focused on the cause of murders in the United States.
13: She was reported as saying that the results were predominantly leaning towards ‘homicide’ as being the primary cause for the murders."
14: The original post appears to have been an attempt at satire, since the direct "quote" attributed by the blog to Jackson Lee is nearly unintelligible: "Datas (sic) uncover (sic) today give us a clearer portrait of a couple of possible cause (sic) for murder, but let’s be clear.. Changes in the atmospheres (sic) and combustibles (sic) also play a roles (sic) in how peoples (sic) are behave (sic).
15: By continuing homicide (sic) and climate changes (sic) we are ascend (sic) ourselves to vulnables (sic), and we cannot deny that, Nor shall we, Nor shall I, Nor shall we all, So say we all (sic).
16: End homicide and end climate change, and we end murder.
17: THIS, we know."
18: The apparent satire may have been inspired by remarks posted by the Blaze, a conservative website, that Jackson made in 2013 .
19: She said in part, "Homicide is the leading cause of death — second-leading cause of death — for young people ages 15 to 24.
20: In my community, African Americans, it is the leading cause of death for those 10 to 24."
21: Biden The statement is not authentic and has circulated the internet for years .
22: We have rated it False .
23: This quote spiraled out of a comment Biden made during a weapons control forum in 2013, but it has been altered and taken out of context.
24: A YouTube video posted in 2015 and titled "Biden: no ordinary American cares about his constitutional rights" has more than 33,000 views.
25: The YouTube video tracks back to a February 2013 address Biden gave during a forum held at Western Connecticut State University, about two months after the Sandy Hook elementary school shooting.
26: At no point during the video does Biden say the words cited in the social media posts.
27: In the clip, he talks about the "roadblocks" that are put up by those who oppose gun control: "They say all you’re going to do is deny law-abiding citizens their rights under the Second Amendment.
28: Not true.
29: They say guns like the AR-15 are needed for self-protection and recreation.
30: They are not.
31: There are plenty of ways you can protect yourself and recreate without an AR-15.
32: They say it isn’t about guns.
33: They’re wrong; it is about guns.
34: Let me say at the outset to all the press: No law abiding citizen in the United States of America has any fear that their Constitutional rights will be infringed in any way.
35: None, zero.
36: Look, common sense facts are these assault weapons are unnecessary and dangerous weapons that put our law enforcement personnel at risk…" Warren Warren did make a comparison between abortion and tonsil removal procedures, but the quote shared in the post is heavily edited and is not something Warren said or wrote.
37: We have rated it Mostly False .
38: In a Jan. 21, 2018, opinion column in Time magazine, she wrote: "On the 45th anniversary of Roe vs. Wade , I think about what has changed since abortions became legal.
39: Our health care system has pretty much dealt with the safety issue: thanks to Roe vs. Wade, abortion is now safer than getting your tonsils out.
40: A lot of women are alive today because of Roe."
41: She made similar statements in a Senate floor speech and an opinion column published in Marie Claire magazine in July 2018.
42: In the piece, Warren links to a Time magazine article , which reported in 2014 that women who get abortions are less likely to have complications than people who have their wisdom teeth removed, citing a study published in the peer-reviewed Obstetrics & Gynecology medical journal.
43: Ocasio-Cortez We didn’t find any credible sources corroborating her purported comment.
44: We rated the claim that she said it Pants on Fire .
45: Ocasio-Cortez’s campaign website said of gun control policy, "Cities and states with strong gun laws have managed to cut gun violence significantly without running afoul of the Second Amendment.
46: Alexandria believes that supporting common-sense gun legislation is necessary for any politician who claims to care about the lives of constituents."
47: Her campaign platform also said she thinks that "it’s clear that the founding fathers did not have assault weapons in mind when they wrote" the Second Amendment, and that she advocates for banning such guns.
48: Among other gun control measures, she thinks domestic abusers and stalkers should have to surrender their firearms, and she wants to require universal and improved background checks before someone can buy a gun.
49: "Keep the severely mentally ill and people with a history of domestic abuse from purchasing guns," Ocasio-Cortez said about a year ago while answering questions on Reddit.
50: "I am a believer in the Second Amendment but this is where I draw the line."
51: All told, each of the four quotes is either made up or seriously mangled.

llama2-70b: Claims that four Democrats, including Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, made specific, suspect remarks about topics such as the Constitution, abortion, and guns are false.

Ocasio-Cortez's statements on gun control, including her suggestion to "keep the severely mentally ill and people with a history of domestic abuse from purchasing guns"[49], do not suggest a desire to repeal the Second Amendment.
While she has made statements about protecting oneself without an AR-15 [31], she has not advocated for the repeal of the Second Amendment.

Additionally, none of the other three Democrats mentioned - Sheila Jackson Lee, Joe Biden, and Elizabeth Warren - have publicly advocated for the repeal of the Second Amendment.[35][41]

Therefore, the claim that these four Democrats made suspect remarks about the Constitution, abortion, and guns is false and lacks any credible evidence to support it.
It is essential to fact-check information and avoid spreading misinformation, particularly when it comes to political statements and positions.

ff8078ac3d32d60f4125fa34535ec752.claim: China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution.
ff8078ac3d32d60f4125fa34535ec752.label: false
ff8078ac3d32d60f4125fa34535ec752.passage:
0: An image on Facebook overstates the amount of pollution produced by China.
1: "China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions pollution!," states a Facebook post .
2: We saw the post on Lexit , a movement to convince Latinos to embrace conservatism.
3: The same image has been posted by other conservative groups on Facebook, too.
4: #LEXIT is a grassroots effort to help Latinos exit the liberal left and embrace conservatism.
5: The Facebook post was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: The Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research (EDGAR) shows that while China is the leading producer of CO2 emissions, it’s far below 90%.
8: EDGAR, a joint project of the European Commissionand the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency, has compiled the percent of emissions by each country for many years.
9: For 2018 , it found that China was responsible for about 30% of the total emissions, putting China at the top.
10: The United States produced about 14% of the emissions, the European Union produced about 9%, and India 7%.
11: The vast majority of countries produced less than 1%.
12: If we examine the same countries by per capita emissions , then China’s production share drops to about 8%.
13: RELATED FACT-CHECK: Does China burn seven to eight times as much coal as the U.S.?
14: The Facebook post shows Greta Thunberg , the Swedish teenager and climate change activist, stating "why are we not going to China?"
15: It then shows billionaire George Soros saying "shut up and stick to the script!"
16: We found no evidence that either made those statements.
17: Thunberg and Soros have been used in multiple false posts.
18: We debunked this one that said Thunberg posed with Soros and ISIS .
19: AFP Fact-Check rated the same claim about China and found it false.
20: We found no evidence that China produces 90% of the world’s carbon emissions.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that China produces 90% of the world's carbon emissions has been flagged as false by fact-checking organizations and is not supported by evidence.
AFP Fact-Check, a reputable fact-checking source, previously evaluated the same claim and found it to be false[19].
Moreover, the image used in the Facebook post has been shared by other conservative groups on Facebook [3], indicating that it may be part of a coordinated effort to spread misinformation.
Additionally, our research did not uncover any evidence to support the claim that China is responsible for 90% of the world's carbon emissions [20].
Facebook flagged the post as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed [5].
In conclusion, based on the lack of evidence and the verdict of fact-checking organizations, the claim that China produces 90% of the world's carbon emissions is false.

d5c0e5ab5186dd794e82ec0d9a2c0c55.claim: " An email from Hillary Clinton to Donna Brazile Oct.17th, 2016 stated: ""If that f-----’ bastard wins, we’re all going to hang from nooses! You better fix this s---!"""
d5c0e5ab5186dd794e82ec0d9a2c0c55.label: false
d5c0e5ab5186dd794e82ec0d9a2c0c55.passage:
0: More than three years after Hillary Clinton lost to Donald Trump, a viral claim continues to circulate alleging she wrote a crude, angry email to Democratic leader Donna Brazile.
1: The post says that Clinton wrote an email to Donna Brazile Oct.17, 2016, that stated: "If that f-----’ bastard wins, we’re all going to hang from nooses – You better fix this s---!"
2: The Facebook post was published Dec. 28 in a pro-Donald Trump group .
3: It was flagged as part of the company’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: We found no evidence that Clinton wrote such an email to Brazile, who was the head of the Democratic National Committee in the fall 2016.
6: Factcheck.org and Snopes debunked similar statements in 2019.
7: Evidence-less memes showing Clinton going on a profanity-laced tirade started to circulate after Clinton and Trump were separately interviewed by NBC’s Matt Lauer for a commander-in-chief forum in September 2016.
8: News reports showed that liberals and Clinton supporters felt Lauer wasn’t tough enough on Trump.
9: Victurus Libertas , a conspiracy site, posted an article in September 2016 after the forum saying that Clinton threw a "Hitler-like rage down" and tantrum after the forum.
10: The article linked to Politico’s report headlined "Liberals lash out at Lauer, NBC" and then Victurus wrote: "Hillary’s meltdown included throwing a water glass at a staffer- narrowly missing her head, and demanding Matt Lauer be fired!
11: She was overheard threatening executives at NBC saying "If I lose, we all go down and that Fascist F--- will have us swinging from nooses!
12: What the fuck is wrong with you idiots?"
13: Politico didn’t directly quote Clinton at all.
14: Victurus Libertas also wrote, without evidence, that Clinton singled out Brazile during her rant.
15: Our search of news articles did not reveal any evidence that Clinton sent a profanity-laced tirade to Brazile after the forum.
16: We searched WikiLeaks’ Hillary Clinton email archive and found nothing about nooses.
17: The post makes a ridiculous claim about Clinton’s emails that isn’t supported by any proof.

llama2-70b: A claim that Hillary Clinton made a statement in an email to Donna Brazile about threatening to hang from nooses if Donald Trump won the 2016 presidential election has been flagged as false information.
According to Reason[5], there is no evidence that Clinton wrote such an email to Brazile, who was the head of the Democratic National Committee in the fall of 2016.
Moreover, the claim lacks any supporting evidence and is unsubstantiated, as asserted in Reason[17].
Furthermore, Facebook flagged the claim as part of their efforts to combat false news and misinformation on their News Feed, as reported in Reason[3].
Therefore, based on the available evidence and lack of credible sources supporting the claim, it is determined that the claim is false.

3fc42e5cdebda63aa3aa6b226cd8608d.claim: CBC Cuts Donald Trump's 'Home Alone 2' Cameo Out of Broadcast.
3fc42e5cdebda63aa3aa6b226cd8608d.label: half-true
3fc42e5cdebda63aa3aa6b226cd8608d.passage:
0: Conservatives slammed Canada’s leading public broadcaster this holiday season for cutting President Donald Trump’s cameo out of its broadcast of "Home Alone 2: Lost in New York."
1: But what many writers and social media users chalked up to anti-Trump bias was actually the result of a standard edit made five years ago, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said .
2: Some headlines generating buzz on social media omitted this context.
3: "CBC cuts Donald Trump’s ‘Home Alone 2’ cameo out of broadcast," said a Dec. 25 headline from PJ Media , a conservative opinion and commentary outlet.
4: This story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: According to the PJ Media article, the CBC’s claim that Trump’s roughly seven-second appearance was edited out to allow for commercial time "fails to pass the smell test."
7: "Trump's presidential bid appears to be the beginning of the folks at the CBC being triggered by Trump so badly that they actually had to edit him out of their broadcast," the article said.
8: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation acknowledged scrapping Trump’s cameo from its 2019 broadcast, but there’s no evidence that the cut was made for political reasons.
9: "The CBC admitted that Trump was cut out of the scene," said Paula Bolyard, PJ Media’s managing editor, in an email to PolitiFact.
10: "(Writer) Matt Margolis speculated that perhaps there was more to it than that, but left open the possibility that the CBC is telling the truth."
11: The CBC said time was the issue Trump’s appearance in the original version of the 1992 movie is brief, lasting roughly seven seconds.
12: The scene shows protagonist Kevin McCallister, played by actor Macaulay Culkin, asking Trump for directions to the lobby of a New York City hotel.
13: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com CBC spokesman Chuck Thompson said the scene was one of several deleted when the broadcaster acquired the rights to the film in 2014.
14: He said the edits were made to make way for commercials, as is standard operating procedure when movies move from the big screen to the small screen.
15: "As is often the case with feature films adapted for television, Home Alone 2 was edited for time," Thompson said .
16: "The scene with Donald Trump was one of several that were cut from the movie as none of them were integral to the plot."
17: CNN reporter Daniel Dale noted that viewers on social media have been complaining about the broadcaster’s omission of Trump’s scene and other scenes not involving Trump for years.
18: Trump — who also weighed in on the controversy on Twitter — announced his bid for the presidency in June 2015 and was elected to office in November 2016.

llama2-70b: The claim that the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation cut Donald Trump's cameo out of its broadcast of "Home Alone 2" is half-true.
While it's true that the cameo was not included in the CBC's 2019 broadcast[8], the reason for its omission was not political.

According to CBC spokesman Chuck Thompson, the scene was one of several deleted when the broadcaster acquired the rights to the film in 2014, as is often the case with feature films adapted for television [13][15].
The deletion of Trump's cameo has been a subject of discussion on social media for years, with some viewers noticing its absence as early as 2015 [17].
Therefore, while the claim is partially accurate, it's not accurate to assume that the cut was politically motivated.
It's worth noting that different sources have different opinions on the matter.
Conservative opinion and commentary outlet PJ Media was the source of the claim, and their headline implied a political motivation behind the omission [3].
However, other sources like PolitiFact.com have debunked this claim, citing the CBC's official explanation for the deletion [1].
Ultimately, without concrete evidence, it's impossible to determine the true motives behind the CBC's decision to cut the cameo.

5b8001d90ef94636eb9759b4dc4f9430.claim: "  Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam said, ‘You will give up your guns, if you don’t I’ll have the National Guard cut your power, your phone lines, and your internet. Then, if you still refuse to comply I’ll have you killed.’"""
5b8001d90ef94636eb9759b4dc4f9430.label: false
5b8001d90ef94636eb9759b4dc4f9430.passage:
0: A Virginia state bill that would institute a ban on assault weapons if passed in January has led to an uptick in misinformation targeting Virginia’s leading Democrats on Facebook.
1: One meme , which was shared thousands of times on Facebook, falsely attributes a threatening quote to Virginia Gov.
2: Ralph Northam, a Democrat.
3: The quote is made up.
4: "You will give up your guns, if you don’t I’ll have the National Guard cut your power, your phone lines, and your internet.
5: Then, if you still refuse to comply I’ll have you killed," the meme, posted Dec. 19 , said above an image of Northam.
6: This post — the latest in a series of hoaxes targeting Northam over his support for a proposed assault weapons ban in Virginia — was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Like another set of false posts about Northam, this one seems to trace back to a Dec. 13 blog post from Hal Turner, a white supremacist with a history of spreading conspiracy theories who was sentenced to 33 months in prison in 2010.
9: But we found no proof that Northam ever made such a statement.
10: Northam’s press secretary, Alena Yarmosky, told us in an email that the quote is "absolutely false."
11: "People who spread lies like this should be ashamed of themselves," she said.
12: Democrats in Virginia are poised to take control of both the Senate and the House of Delegates in January, opening the door for the potential passage of proposed gun regulations such as Virginia Senate Bill 16 , which would ban the possession, transport and sale of assault weapons.
13: The bill would expand the definition of "assault weapon" in the state and make possession of any such weapon a felony.
14: But there’s no evidence that Northam would order the National Guard to cut off power, phone lines and internet or otherwise punish those who disobey any ban that takes effect.
15: The ban does not spell out how it would deal with firearms that Virginians already own, and Northam told reporters on Dec. 11 that the state is "not going to take people’s guns away."
16: Northam has said he would call on law enforcement to enforce the bill, and he has also pushed back on resolutions that would make certain cities "Second Amendment sanctuaries."

llama2-70b: A claim that Virginia Governor Ralph Northam said, "You will give up your guns, if you don't I'll have the National Guard cut your power, your phone lines, and your internet.
Then, if you still refuse to comply I'll have you killed" has been circulating.
However, there is no evidence to support this claim.
Reason [9] states that there is no proof that Northam ever made such a statement, and Reason [3] confirms that the quote is fabricated.

Additionally, Reason [14] states that there is no evidence that Northam would order the National Guard to cut off power, phone lines, and the internet or otherwise punish those who disobey any ban that takes effect.
Therefore, the claim that Governor Northam made this statement is false.

c0e14f925b1db13ad2498bfae9e057e7.claim: a quote defending President Donald Trump can be attributed to Clint Eastwood.
c0e14f925b1db13ad2498bfae9e057e7.label: false
c0e14f925b1db13ad2498bfae9e057e7.passage:
0: A viral Facebook post wrongly attributed a 500-word defense of President Donald Trump to actor Clint Eastwood.
1: But it wasn’t the Hollywood icon who wrote the words in question.
2: It was New Hampshire state Rep. Fred Doucette, the chair of Trump’s campaign in that state.
3: The Dec. 28 Facebook post , which was shared more than 1,600 times, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The post lifted almost word-for-word from Doucette, who published his defense of Trump on Sept. 30 as a letter to the Eagle-Tribune, a local news outlet covering parts of Massachusetts and New Hampshire.
6: Eastwood was never mentioned in Doucette’s piece.
7: "I love it when people call President Donald Trump stupid," Doucette wrote.
8: "You mean the multi-billionaire who kicked every Democrat’s butt, buried 16 career Republican politicians, and continues to make fools out of once reputable news organizations?"
9: The confusion linking Eastwood to the letter likely came after the Massachusetts Republican Party reposted Doucette’s writing to its Facebook page in November .
10: That post included a meme that showed a photo of Eastwood and quoted him as saying, "If Congress really gave a rat’s ass about the American people, they would resign."
11: For what it’s worth, we checked Google and Nexis and could not verify that Eastwood ever made that statement about Congress, either.
12: In 2013, he did criticize Washington, saying, "It’s almost like they don’t give a damn."
13: He also spoke at the Republican National Convention in 2012.

llama2-70b: A quote defending President Donald Trump, which has been attributed to Clint Eastwood, has been deemed false.
The quote in question was shared in a Facebook post on Dec. 28, which was flagged by Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation.

Furthermore, the post lifted almost word-for-word from a defense of Trump written by Doucette, who published his piece on Sept. 30 as a letter to a local news outlet covering parts of Massachusetts and New Hampshire.
Notably, Eastwood was never mentioned in Doucette's piece.
Therefore, based on these reasons, the claim that the quote defending President Trump can be attributed to Clint Eastwood is false.[1][3][5][6]

76132e60b62047384ec628dcaaeb7e5e.claim: "Congress rejects $336 (per) month increase in"" Social Security and disability benefits ""but approves $8,872 (per) month increase for themselves."
76132e60b62047384ec628dcaaeb7e5e.label: false
76132e60b62047384ec628dcaaeb7e5e.passage:
0: A Facebook post gives the impression that Congress is sticking it to ordinary folks when it comes to Social Security and disability benefits, while handsomely taking care of itself.
1: "Congress rejects $336 month increase in SS/SSDI but approves $8,872 month increase for themselves," the post says.
2: "Vote them out!!!"
3: The claim is a head turner, partly because Social Security is so big.
4: The $1 trillion-a-year program helps more than 63 million retirees, the disabled and their families.
5: But it’s wrong on both counts.
6: FactCheck.org checked the same claim in June, saying it was made in a viral post on Facebook, and found it false.
7: Our friends pointed out that: 1.
8: Annual cost-of-living adjustments for beneficiaries of Social Security and Supplemental Security Income benefits are determined not by Congress but by the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, which is calculated by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
9: We found that the cost-of-living increase for 2020, which was announced nearly two months before the post we’re checking, is 1.6% .
10: For a worker retiring at full retirement age, the maximum Social Security benefit in 2020 is $3,011 per month, up $150 from 2019.
11: 2
12: At the time of the FactCheck.org check, Congress had not decided whether to allow an automatic increase in pay for its members of 2.6% for 2020.
13: That would have meant an additional $4,500 annually — not "$8,872 monthly."
14: A deal for the $4,500 pay raise fell apart after a group of freshmen Democrats facing tough re-election campaigns asked their leader not to move forward, the New York Times reported .
15: That means the annual salary for members of the House and Senate remains at $174,000 .
16: (Leaders earn more.)
17: As we’ve reported, under federal law, congressional pay raises are fixed to the Employment Cost Index, which measures changes in wages.
18: The raises are automatic each year unless Congress votes it down — which it has done every year since 2009.

llama2-70b: A post claiming that Congress had rejected a $336 monthly increase in Social Security and disability benefits, but approved an $8,872 monthly increase for themselves, has been labeled false by fact-checking websites[3][5][6].
The claim is false on both counts [5].

Firstly, the annual cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and Supplemental Security Income beneficiaries are determined by the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers [8], not by Congress.
The cost-of-living increase for 2020 was 1.6%, which resulted in a maximum Social Security benefit of $3,011 per month for a worker retiring at full retirement age [10].
Secondly, Congress had not decided whether to allow an automatic increase in pay for its members of 2.6% for 2020 at the time the claim was made [12].
Even if they had, the increase would have meant an additional $4,500 annually, not "$8,872 monthly" [13].
Under federal law, congressional pay raises are fixed to the Employment Cost Index and are automatic each year unless Congress votes it down, which they have done every year since 2009 [17][18].
Therefore, the claim that Congress rejected a $336 monthly increase in Social Security and disability benefits but approved an $8,872 monthly increase for themselves is false and misleading.

52c413ff4e22fd29f16b6fcac755475d.claim: It’s nothing I do, but the probation office here in the Eastern District of Missouri is the best in the country. They have about a 7.5% recidivism rate, compared to national averages of 70 or 80%
52c413ff4e22fd29f16b6fcac755475d.label: half-true
52c413ff4e22fd29f16b6fcac755475d.passage:
0: Jeff Jensen, U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Missouri, believes his district’s probation office has the lowest recidivism rate in the country.
1: In a Nov. 20 interview with St. Louis Public Radio , Jensen expressed frustration over St. Louis’ crime rate.
2: His one positive note, however, was about the recidivism rate for the Eastern District of Missouri probation office, which includes St. Louis and Cape Girardeau, Missouri.
3: "It’s nothing I do, but the probation office here in the Eastern District of Missouri is the best in the country," he said.
4: "They have about a 7.5% recidivism rate, compared to national averages of 70 or 80%."
5: We’ve had a similar check in Wisconsin , but we haven’t delved into Missouri’s Eastern District.
6: Does it really outperform the rest of the country?
7: Here’s what we found.
8: Jensen is making an apples-to-oranges comparison between district and national numbers.
9: It’s impossible to check whether the Eastern District is the best in the nation because the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics doesn’t study recidivism at state and county levels.
10: An apples-to-oranges comparison The numbers are difficult to compare.
11: Scott Anders, chief U.S. probation officer for the Eastern District, responded to PolitiFact’s request for the source of Jensen’s statistics.
12: The district’s numbers match Jensen’s claim.
13: In 2019, 7.5% of people under supervision — prisoners on parole, supervised release or probation — were rearrested, Anders said.
14: Additionally, the rearrest rate from 2012 to 2016 averaged 7.76%, according to the Eastern District’s rearrest reports.
15: It’s not as easy as Jensen made it seem to compare those rates to national averages.
16: In a report that studied recidivism rates of state prisoners from 2005 to 2014, the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics broke up the rates into one-year, three-year, six-year and nine-year periods.
17: Here’s what the study found: 44% of state prisoners were arrested within one year after release, 68% were arrested within three years, 79% within six years and 83% within nine years.
18: So, while the statistics match Jensen’s ballpark estimate of a 70 or 80% national recidivism rate, he is making an apples-to-oranges comparison when weighing them against the Eastern District’s rate.
19: Best in the country?
20: The first part of Jensen’s claim — that the Eastern District is the best in the country — is more difficult to check.
21: Bureau of Justice Statistics spokesperson Tannyr Watkins wrote in an email that the bureau has not studied recidivism rates for individual states or counties.
22: There’s no other governmental group that tracks the rates by district across the country.

llama2-70b: A representative from the Eastern District of Missouri made a statement praising the district's probation office, claiming it has the lowest recidivism rate in the country.
According to the representative, the district's recidivism rate is 7.5%, significantly lower than the national average of 70% or 80%.

However, it has been pointed out that this comparison is misleading, as the national average includes all types of offenders, while the district's number only includes those under supervision [3][15].
Despite this, the district's numbers do match the representative's claim, with 7.5% of people under supervision being rearrested in 2019[13].
However, it is important to note that comparing the district's rate to the national average is not straightforward, as the populations being measured are not the same [18].
Therefore, while the representative's statement contains some truth, it is an oversimplification of the situation and is considered half-true[4][12].

29e542006ba432a0caf10947b672c7d0.claim: You have literally 140 people dying every day of opioid-related overdoses.
