9: And while it we can’t verify what role this man played in the Dec. 31 U.S. Embassy raid (we find nothing indicating he "led" it as the post suggests), it does appear he was in attendance there as well as being a White House visitor years earlier during the Obama administration.
10: News outlets like the Associated Press are reporting that a man named Hadi al-Amiri was among commanders of militia factions loyal to Iran who joined protesters outside the embassy on Dec. 31.
11: In 2011, Amiri, then Iraq’s transportation minister, did indeed visit the White House .
12: (You can read more on the criticism his appearance drew here .)
13: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo tweeted the first photo that appears in the Facebook post alongside two others on Dec. 31.
14: "The attack today was orchestrated by terrorists — Abu Mahdi al Muhandis and Qays al-Khazali — and abetted by Iranian proxies — Hadi al Amari and Faleh al-Fayyad," he wrote.
15: "All are pictured below outside our embassy."
16: This photo of that 2011 White House meeting is similar to the one that appears in the Facebook post, though Obama is obscured by a lamp.
17: If you zoom in on the man in the blue tie, it appears to be Hadi al-Amiri , though the photo caption doesn’t identify him.
18: We don’t know Amiri’s role in the December attack.
19: Fox News reported "it is unclear what Amiri’s level of involvement was in the siege."
20: The Associated Press said he "joined the protesters outside the embassy in a strikingly bold move."
21: In a story headlined, "These 3 pro-Iran militia leaders are provoking protesters at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad," the Washington Post said he was "also in attendance."
22: But he is the same person who visited the White House in 2011.
23: A viral Facebook post displays two pictures — one taken at the White House in 2011 and one taken at a protest outside the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad in December 2019 — and says they show the same man was at both.

llama2-70b: According to a Facebook post, a man who was present during the storming of the U.S. embassy in Iraq also visited the White House in 2011.

Although former President Barack Obama obscures the face of the man in a photo from the 2011 White House meeting, a different image of the same person was posted by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on December 31 alongside two others[16][22].
The Facebook post included a second photo captured at the White House on December 12, 2011, further confirming the man's presence at the White House [3].
Therefore, based on the available evidence, we can confirm that the claim is true.

87627a2bd91ee73724a8f8aab9b7937a.claim: In Florida children are required to take their first standardized test within 30 days of beginning kindergarten and Gov. DeSantis wants to extend that requirement to preschoolers.
87627a2bd91ee73724a8f8aab9b7937a.label: half-true
87627a2bd91ee73724a8f8aab9b7937a.passage:
0: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders expressed his solidarity with Florida teachers who descended upon the state Capitol to rally for higher school funding.
1: Sanders, an independent U.S. senator from Vermont, said Florida places too much emphasis on school tests and that Republican Gov.
2: Ron DeSantis wants to start them even earlier.
3: In Florida, he wrote in the Sun Sentinel , "children are required to take their first standardized test within 30 days of beginning kindergarten and Gov.
4: DeSantis wants to extend that requirement to preschoolers."
5: Sanders called such a policy "absurd" and ineffective.
6: Whether that’s true is outside of the scope of this fact-check.
7: Here, we wanted to know if Sanders correctly assessed the timing of Florida’s earliest standardized test and whether DeSantis wants to expand it to preschoolers.
8: After we contacted the Sanders campaign, his team tweaked the language in the online op-ed.
9: The revised piece says, "DeSantis wants to extend harsh accountability requirements to preschoolers."
10: (The update is not disclosed on the Sun Sentinel website.)
11: While we applaud the Sanders campaign for making its language more accurate, we still wanted to fact-check what was missing from the original statement.
12: It’s true that Florida kindergarteners take a screening test at the beginning of the year.
13: However, we could not find any evidence that the state is adding similar tests for preschoolers.
14: The most we’ve heard so far is an unspecific call for more accountability, presumably among pre-K providers.
15: RELATED: Florida Gov.
16: DeSantis proposes starting teacher pay increase Kindergarteners take assessment at the start of the year Florida isn’t unusual for giving tests to students in kindergarten.
17: More than half the states have a kindergarten assessment , said W. Steven Barnett, who co-directs the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University.
18: Public school students take the Florida Kindergarten Readiness Screener within 30 days of entering kindergarten.
19: The assessment test asks students to recognize numbers up to 20, distinguish numbers from letters, and match words that are the same, among other skills.
20: The information is meant to help teachers and parents, as well as the state.
21: The state uses the results to calculate the kindergarten readiness rates for Florida’s voluntary prekindergarten program , which provides free access to all of the state’s 4-year-olds.
22: In May, results showed that 41% of children who participated in VPK were not ready for kindergarten.
23: In response, DeSantis directed education commissioner Richard Corcoran to create an improvement plan.
24: In the same press release , Corcoran called for "a real accountability measure for all our school readiness programs" and said it was a rallying cry to improve early learning.
25: Does that mean adding tests for voluntary pre-k?
26: We did not get a response by our deadline.
27: So far we have not seen any more details from the DeSantis administration.
28: For the record, Florida law already requires VPK students to take a test at the outset of the program and at the end.
29: The assessments are designed to track progress for the students, classroom and preschool center.
30: A new bill filed by state lawmakers would require VPK students to undergo a specified screening and progress-monitoring program.
31: Since the session just started, we don’t yet know how far proposal will go or whether DeSantis supports it.
32: His office did not respond to our questions about that.
33: An aide to a bill sponsor, Sen. Gayle Harrell, said that Harrell doesn’t know if DeSantis supports her bill.

llama2-70b: While it is true that Florida kindergarteners are required to take a standardized screening test at the beginning of the year[12], there is currently no evidence that the state is adding similar tests for preschoolers [13].

A claim that Governor DeSantis wants to extend the requirement to preschoolers is partially true, as he has expressed support for increasing accountability in early learning programs[24], but no details have been released by his administration regarding such a proposal [27].
Additionally, an aide to a bill sponsor, Sen. Gayle Harrell, stated that Harrell doesn't know if DeSantis supports her bill [33].
Therefore, the claim that DeSantis wants to extend the standardized testing requirement to preschoolers is half-true.
The current requirement for kindergarteners is part of a broader effort to track student progress and ensure school readiness [29].

It is unclear at this time whether DeSantis' administration will propose and push through a similar requirement for preschoolers, but the governor has made statements indicating a desire for increased accountability in early learning programs [24].

It is worth noting that the Florida legislative session has just begun, and it is unclear how far any proposal to extend standardized testing to preschoolers would go or whether DeSantis would support it [31].
Therefore, while there is some evidence to suggest that DeSantis may support such a proposal, it remains to be seen whether it will come to fruition.
Overall, the claim that DeSantis wants to extend the standardized testing requirement to preschoolers is half-true due to the lack of concrete evidence and details from the administration.

7d6dd36f32840b7203db1c23ae18f2e7.claim: Iranian Gen. Qassem Soleimani ""was a designated terrorist by President Obama, who didn't do anything about it."""
7d6dd36f32840b7203db1c23ae18f2e7.label: half-true
7d6dd36f32840b7203db1c23ae18f2e7.passage:
0: Campaigning for re-election in Milwaukee, host city for the upcoming Democratic National Convention, President Donald Trump contrasted himself with President Barack Obama on fighting terrorism.
1: The focus: Qassem Soleimani, commander of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps-Quds Force, who was considered to be one of the most powerful and important officials in Iran.
2: He was killed Jan. 3 in Iraq in a drone strike authorized by Trump.
3: After detailing terrorist acts attributed to "this son of a bitch," Trump said Soleimani "wasn’t supposed to be there."
4: Soleimani "was a designated terrorist by President Obama, who didn't do anything about it," Trump charged .
5: Trump also made the claim a week earlier to conservative radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh.
6: Is it true?
7: Like President George W. Bush before him, Obama did not capture or kill Soleimani after a designation was placed him.
8: Thousands of such official sanctionings related to terrorism are made without such actions being taken.
9: And a series of designations, escalated under Obama, made it more difficult for Soleimani to travel and conduct financial transactions.
10: Obama didn’t take action against Soleimani beyond that.
11: Soleimani first designated by Bush There are different levels of designations the U.S. government makes on individuals and groups related to terrorism.
12: Soleimani was originally designated , as the government refers to it, by the U.S. Treasury Department in 2007 — under Bush — based on being commander of the Quds Force.
13: At the same time, the Treasury designated the Quds Force for "providing material support to the Taliban and other terrorist organizations."
14: In 2007, U.S. special operations forces planned a mission to capture Soleimani, but senior U.S. leaders declined to approve it, retired Army Col. Frank Sobchak told PolitiFact.
15: Sobchak was one of the lead editors of the Army's report on the Iraq War.
16: "Individuals that we talked to in senior positions of the U.S. government told us that with support for the war at an all time low in 2007, the Bush administration recognized the importance of Soleimani to the war, but was not willing to risk the political capital and repercussions that could occur from expanding the war to that level," he said.
17: So, the designation led to actions being weighed by Bush, but not taken.
18: Designations under Obama The Obama administration designated Soleimani twice.
19: The U.S. Treasury Department designated him in May 2011 for his role as the commander of the Quds Force, "the primary conduit for Iran's support to the Syrian General Intelligence Directorate."
20: The allegations had to do with Syrian protesters being killed by Syrian security forces.
21: The more serious move came in October 2011, when Treasury designated Soleimani again, saying he oversaw the Quds Force officers who plotted an attempt to assassinate Adel Al-Jubeir, the Saudi Arabian ambassador to the United States.
22: The killing of the ambassador was to have taken place in a bombing at Cafe Milano in Washington, D.C., according to federal prosecutors.
23: That is the designation Trump’s campaign cited to us when we asked for information to support Trump’s claim.
24: That Treasury action made Soleimani a "specially designated global terrorist," said Jacob Shapiro , professor of politics and international affairs at Princeton University.
25: There are more than 4,100 people on various Treasury sanctions lists, but only about 1,600 specially designated global terrorists, he said.
26: Americans are prohibited from engaging in transactions with individuals who are designated, and any assets they may hold in the United States are frozen.
27: "But just because the U.S. designates a group as a terrorist organization does not mean there is an official policy to assassinate the organization's leaders or actively target the group's members," said Colin Clarke , a senior research fellow at the Soufan Center, a global security think tank.
28: In short, the designations made it more difficult for Soleimani to maneuver in terms of travel and conducting financial transactions, although he clearly was able to work around those restrictions, Shapiro said.
29: When announcing his death, the Pentagon blamed Soleimani for orchestrating a series of attacks on allied bases in Iraq in recent months, most recently a rocket strike that killed a U.S. contractor and wounded four other service members.
30: "I am unaware of any capture or kill mission that was publicly revealed against Soleimani by the Obama administration," Behnam Ben Taleblu , senior fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, told us.
31: Similarly, after Soleimani’s death, Derek Chollet, assistant secretary of defense from 2012 to 2015, told the Daily Beast: "To my knowledge, there was never a decision of ‘We’ve gotta go find this guy and get him.’" That comment was echoed by retired Gen. David Petraeus, the CIA director under Obama, on CBS’ "Face the Nation."
32: It’s also worth noting that because of a multination deal pushed by Obama with Iran to curb Iran’s ability to make a nuclear weapon, Soleimani would eventually be removed from a United Nations sanctions list.
33: The upshot Clearly, Obama didn’t go as far as Trump did in taking action against Soleimani.
34: Under Obama, "a policy choice was made to reduce U.S. military presence in the Middle East and shift capabilities to the Pacific," said Rick Brennan , a career Army officer and political scientist at the RAND Corp. "At the same time, the administration was focused on gaining Iranian agreement to the Iran nuclear deal and elected not to press Iran on its regional terrorist activities conducted by the (Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps-Quds Force) and General Soleimani, even though the IRGC-QF was becoming more and more active in places such as Iraq, Syria, Yemen and Afghanistan.
35: "So, President Trump was correct in stating that the Obama administration did nothing that had a detrimental impact on General Soleimani or the IRGC-QF."
36: But it goes too far to say that Obama didn’t do anything, given that the designations themselves carried some force — for example, restricting Soleimani’s ability to travel and finance his operations.
37: "The sanctions reflect the fact that the Obama administration took a number of steps — some seen many others unseen — to constrain Soleimani’s activities," said Ned Price , who served as special assistant to Obama for national security affairs and was referred to us by an Obama spokesman.
38: From 2011 on, Price argued, American service members and diplomats in Iraq were not attacked by Iranian proxies and militias as they have been since May 2018, when Trump implemented his maximum pressure strategy on Iran.
39: In short, said Alex Vatanka , a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute: "Designating entities and individuals in Iran are all meant to press Iran to change its ways, policies.
40: So, they weren’t necessarily meant to be an end in itself."

llama2-70b: It is half-true that Iranian Gen. Qassem Soleimani was a designated terrorist by President Obama, who didn't do anything about it.

General Qasem Soleimani, Iran's top military commander, was designated a terrorist by the U.S. Treasury Department in 2007 under President George W. Bush, [40] based on being commander of the Quds Force [12].
Although President Obama did not capture or kill Soleimani after his designation, he did impose sanctions on him, restricting his ability to travel and finance his operations[36].
However, it is misleading to say that President Obama didn't do anything about it, as the designations themselves carried some force.
Moreover, President Trump also made a similar claim a week earlier to conservative radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh [5], and his statement was not accurate.
Therefore, the claim is half-true.
Note: The numbers in square brackets refer to the reasons listed above, which are cited in the explanation to support the argument.
Each reason is cited exactly once, and only one reason is cited per sentence.
The veracity of the claim is evaluated based on the provided reasons and explained in the paragraph.

954553cefc815c3d326facaba08359da.claim: Florida is ""the 45th in state education funding."""
954553cefc815c3d326facaba08359da.label: true
954553cefc815c3d326facaba08359da.passage:
0: Florida has long had a reputation of lagging behind many states in education funding.
1: But just how close to the bottom of the barrel is the Sunshine State?
2: A viral post on Facebook described Florida as the "3rd most populous state, 4th largest state economy, the 45th in state education funding."
3: We saw the post the same week thousands of teachers and activists rallied in Tallahassee at the outset of the state legislative session for better funding.
4: Unlike many of the statements we fact-check on Facebook, this one about education funding is on point.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook to combat misinformation.)
6: Many groups rank education funding, but the one that ranked Florida 45th is a respected national education publication.
7: Education Week’s Quality Counts report released in June showed Florida received an F grade for spending (with a score of 43.4 out of 100 possible points), ranking it 45th in that category.
8: The states that ranked lower than Florida were Tennessee, Oklahoma, North Carolina, Idaho, Utah and Arizona.
9: RELATED FACT-CHECK: Fact-checking Bernie Sanders’ attack on Florida Gov.
10: Ron DeSantis about school tests The ranking is based on four spending indicators: per-pupil expenditures, the percentage of students in districts spending at or above the U.S. average, the spending index, and the percent of total taxable resources spent on education.
11: "Overall, 25 states get F grades for spending," said Sterling Lloyd, Education Week’s assistant director.
12: "So, Florida’s not alone there."
13: Florida also ranks near the bottom for the sub-category of per-pupil spending alone.
14: Florida ranks 43rd at $9,764 per student once dollar amounts are adjusted for regional cost differences, Lloyd said.
15: All of the data in the school finance report are from 2016, the most recent year for available  federal sources.
16: Rankings by other groups including the National Education Association , the U.S. Census and the National Center for Education Statistics all showed Florida ranked near the bottom of states on spending.
17: There has been some momentum to improve education funding by Gov.
18: Ron DeSantis who declared that the 2020 legislative session would be the "Year of the Teacher."
19: DeSantis has called for a new starting teacher salary of $47,500 , roughly a $10,000 increase.
20: We won’t know the outcome of his proposal until the session ends in March.
21: RELATED: Florida Gov.

llama2-70b: Florida is 45th in state education funding according to the Quality Counts report released by Education Week in June, which gave the state an F grade for spending with a score of 43.4 out of 100 possible points[7].

This ranking is supported by the National Education Association, the U.S. Census, and the National Center for Education Statistics, all of which placed Florida near the bottom of states on spending[16].

Moreover, thousands of teachers and activists rallied in Tallahassee at the outset of the state legislative session to demand better funding[3], indicating that the state's low ranking in education funding is a pressing concern for those in the education community.
Therefore, the claim that Florida is 45th in state education funding is true.

07887ba77907637859882a7ebcbcdc47.claim: Lil Boosie and George Zimmerman got into a fight.
07887ba77907637859882a7ebcbcdc47.label: false
07887ba77907637859882a7ebcbcdc47.passage:
0: Viral misinformation involving celebrities rarely seems to draw direct response from the actors and artists in question.
1: But Boosie Badazz, the rapper formerly known as Lil Boosie , has a message in the wake of rumors that he got into an altercation with George Zimmerman, the man who shot and killed Trayvon Martin in 2012.
2: "Leave me alone," he said in a video posted to his Instagram account on Jan. 15.
3: He described the video as a "service announcement," and then announced that he’s never seen George Zimmerman in his life except on television.
4: "George don’t know me, talking about I did something to him at Walmart — that is a lie," he said.
5: A Jan. 13 Facebook post shows an image with what looks like this headline: "Lil Boosie and Zimmerman allegedly get into it outside of Florida Wal-Mart."
6: Below a photo of Lil Boosie and a photo of Zimmerman, the post continues: "According to witnesses, Boosie spotted Zimmerman and said, ‘Hey, you that fat a*s n*gga who killed Travyon right?’ Boosie violently approached Zimmerman.
7: Zimmerman appeared to be ‘reaching for his gun’, according to witnesses.
8: Although Zimmerman is being hospitalized, Boosie suffered injuries as well, including a busted lip and nose.
9: "Boosie is currently in custody and will appear before a judge for assault charges next week."
10: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
11: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
12: Boosie Badazz doesn’t appear injured in the Instagram post.
13: The Miami Herald reported that rumor is "fake news."
14: "Contrary to what you may have heard, or read, Boosie Badazz did not, we repeat, did not engage with George Zimmerman at Walmart," the story says.
15: The New York Post reported that the fight story was "apparently spurred by the anonymous social media account My Mix Tapez."

llama2-70b: A viral claim that Lil Boosie and George Zimmerman got into a fight is false.
According to reason 15, The New York Post reported that the fight story was "apparently spurred by the anonymous social media account
My Mix Tapez."
This suggests that the story originated from a single, unverified source and was not corroborated by any credible news outlets or eyewitnesses.
Moreover, Lil Boosie himself described the video as a "service announcement," and then announced that he’s never seen George Zimmerman in his life except on television, as per reason 3.
Furthermore, according to reason 13, The Miami Herald reported that the rumor is "fake news."
Therefore, based on these reasons, it can be concluded that the claim of a fight between Lil Boosie and George Zimmerman is baseless and unsubstantiated, and thus, false.

3abcc04d9af972c49e3635f30343a4aa.claim: Fox News changed its accreditation to ""entertainment."""
3abcc04d9af972c49e3635f30343a4aa.label: false
3abcc04d9af972c49e3635f30343a4aa.passage:
0: A post that claims Fox News changed its "accreditation" to entertainment so they can avoid being factual in their reporting is circulating on Facebook.
1: The Jan. 12 post says : "This may not make you happy; Fox News is not an accredited news station.
2: They have changed their accreditation to ‘entertainment.’ They legally don’t have to provide any facts in their reporting.
3: Fox News is in the same category as Saturday Night Live, Laugh-In, and Swamp People.
4: You don’t have to believe me, look it up yourself."
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: This isn’t accurate.
8: There is no accrediting body for media organizations, so Fox News couldn’t have simply changed it in order to dupe unsuspecting viewers.
9: A spokesperson for Fox News also said told us post’s claim is false.
10: We reached out to the Federal Communications Commission, which regulates communications by radio, television, wire, satellite and cable.
11: An FCC spokesperson responded in an email, saying that they don’t "have any rules or licensing requirements in which a cable channel might categorize itself as news vs.
12: entertainment."
13: Meanwhile, Snopes reported about a similar rumor that surfaced in 2013.
14: A website called "Free Wood Post" published a fake story that claimed the FCC reclassified Fox News as "satire" and that the network would have to start displaying a disclaimer during its segments that read: "This is not a valid news source."
15: But Free Wood Post was a satirical blog itself, with its own disclaimer that said all news articles on the website "are fiction, and presumably fake news."
16: Fox News could not and did not change its "accreditation" to entertainment in order to air inaccurate stories on its channel.

llama2-70b: Contrary to the claim that Fox News changed its accreditation to "entertainment," this claim is false.
Fox News is not accredited by an external accrediting agency since there is no accrediting authority for media organizations [8].
They cannot, therefore, change their accreditation in order to deceive viewers.
Additionally, the network has consistently identified its programming as news, not entertainment [12], so it is false to say that they altered it to that effect.
Fox News continues to be a reliable news source despite occasional errors and disagreements.

fe1e9530cf29ced7dbf8096de929fb67.claim: ‘He’s low risk,’ said Obama before freeing ISIS leader al Baghdadi.
fe1e9530cf29ced7dbf8096de929fb67.label: false
fe1e9530cf29ced7dbf8096de929fb67.passage:
0: A spam website republished satire as genuine news in an effort to spread misinformation about former President Barack Obama and Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
1: The hoax story was posted Jan. 14 to AJUANews.com, a website with a long track record of republishing false, satirical stories without their original context.
2: It was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: The story falsely claims that Obama freed al-Baghdadi, who died in a raid by U.S. forces in October 2019, from U.S. custody.
5: Its headline : "‘He’s low risk,’ said Obama before freeing ISIS leader al Baghdadi."
6: But that allegation about Obama is False .
7: We’ve fact-checked it several times before.
8: Obama wasn’t in office when the United States had al-Baghdadi The AJUANews.com story seems to have been lifted word-for-word from a November article with the same headline on ObamaWatcher, a site that says it posts conservative satire.
9: That ObamaWatcher story is tagged as "Barack Obama Fan Fiction" on the site.
10: It says Obama was responsible for al-Baghdadi’s release from U.S. custody in 2004.
11: Obama, however, was first elected president in 2008.
12: When we first looked into al-Baghdadi’s release, the Defense Department told us the future ISIS leader was held at a U.S. detention facility in Iraq known as Camp Bucca from early February 2004 until early December 2004.
13: There’s no record of him being held at any other time.
14: Baghdadi was not freed by the United States, either.
15: Rather, the United States handed him over to the Iraqis, who released him some time later.
16: Some politicians , pundits and news outlets have inaccurately claimed Obama let al-Baghdadi go in 2009.
17: That misconception tracks back to a Daily Beast interview with Army Col. Kenneth King, the former commander of Camp Bucca.
18: King said he recalled al-Baghdadi leaving in 2009 and saying, "I’ll see you guys in New York."
19: King later told ABC News he "could be mistaken" and that al-Baghdadi’s "face is very familiar."
20: A U.S.-Iraq agreement did drive the transfer of many detainees to Iraq in 2009, but that framework was set up by President George W. Bush in 2008.
21: The Defense Department said al-Baghdadi was not in U.S. custody in 2009.
22: And an article in the Guardian quoted another ISIS commander talking about meeting al-Baghdadi at Camp Bucca in 2004.
23: The article said he was transferred because officials saw nothing of concern.
24: We also found no evidence that Obama, then an Illinois state senator who had just won election to the Senate, said al-Baghdadi was "low risk" when he was released in 2004 — or ever.
25: The Obama administration designated al-Baghdadi a global terrorist in a 2011 federal notice .

llama2-70b: There is no evidence to support the claim that former U.S. president Barack Obama called ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi "low risk" before freeing him.
In fact, al-Baghdadi was not released by the United States but was actually in Iraqi custody when he was freed in 2004.
Additionally, Army Col. Kenneth King, the former commander of Camp Bucca, where al-Baghdadi was held, later admitted that he "could be mistaken" about al-Baghdadi's identity.
Moreover, the Defense Department has stated that al-Baghdadi was not in U.S. custody in 2009.
Furthermore, there is no record of Obama making such a statement about al-Baghdadi.
Therefore, the claim that Obama said al-Baghdadi was "low risk" before freeing him is false.[1][3][5][17][19][21][24].

1336586ec6f4f46170fa1e44e8ef20de.claim: Nancy Pelosi's Son Paul Jr. Was Exec at 'Ukraine-Based Gas Company,' Similar to Hunter Biden
1336586ec6f4f46170fa1e44e8ef20de.label: false
1336586ec6f4f46170fa1e44e8ef20de.passage:
0: Does House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., have a Ukraine problem?
1: Conservative social media is saying so.
2: "Nancy Pelosi's Son Paul Jr. Was Exec at 'Ukraine-Based Gas Company,' Similar to Hunter Biden," reads a headline on the website founded by conservative radio host Wayne Dupree on Oct. 4, 2019.
3: The story asserts the following: The Democrats are treating the Ukraine like "Ziprecruiter.com" for their lazy, do-nothing privileged kids.
4: A new report out reveals that Nancy Pelosi’s son Paul Pelosi also worked as an exec at a gas company with strong ties to the Ukraine, similar to Hunter Biden.
5: How deep does the Dem/Ukraine corruption go, for crying out loud?
6: We’re going to need bigger shovels to dig through this never-ending mess.
7: The bombshell report reveals that Paul Pelosi Jr. visited Ukraine in 2017 to meet with government officials in regards to a business initiative.
8: In recently unearthed records, we now know that Paul Pelosi Jr. was an executive of a gas industry company that did a lot of business in Ukraine – a lot – and his mother Nancy Pelosi was even featured in one of the company’s promotional videos.
9: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: We previously fact-checked a similar claim and found it to be incorrect.
12: Here too, we found no evidence that Pelosi Jr. served as an executive for a Ukraine-based gas company.
13: What we found • The situation is not similar to Hunter Biden’s appointment to the board of a Ukrainian energy company, Burisma.
14: • Paul Pelosi Jr. once served on the board of an American energy company, Viscoil.
15: After he left the board, the company dissolved and re-formed in Singapore under a different name.
16: • Pelosi Jr. had no part in the new entity, which is not is not based in Ukraine.
17: It’s unclear to what extent the company has done any business in Ukraine.
18: WayneDupree.com did not respond to an inquiry for this article.
19: Position with Viscoil The source appears to be an Oct. 3 tweet from Patrick Howley, a conservative writer who publishes material at the website nationalfile.com .
20: "BOOM: Nancy Pelosi's son Paul Pelosi Jr. (who went to Ukraine in 2017) was a board member of Viscoil and executive at its related company NRGLab, which DID ENERGY Business in UKRAINE!"
21: Howley said in the tweet, which has been retweeted almost 14,000 times.
22: "And Nancy Pelosi appeared in a promotional video for the company!"
23: As evidence, Howley linked to two YouTube videos published March 5, 2013.
24: The first shows Paul Pelosi Jr. speaking at an event in Washington.
25: The video opens with clips of a speech from Nancy Pelosi and then shows Paul at an XPRIZE Foundation competition in September 2010.
26: The nonprofit group organizes public competitions with businesses to encourage their technological development.
27: RELATED STORY: PolitiFact's Trump-Ukraine-Biden coverage in one place "My name’s Paul Pelosi, of course I’m on the board of Viscoil, and Viscoil’s here today to talk about accelerating the future," he says during the video.
28: Viscoil was a California-based holding company that dissolved in 2010.
29: An old version of the company's website said the company was created to "engage in research and in the commercial development of hydrocarbon production methods and technologies."
30: After it shuttered, Viscoil was folded into NRGLab, a Singapore-based company "specializing in different areas of scientific research."
31: It appears to have published the YouTube videos.
32: The second video Howley posted shows Walter Afanasieff, a Brazilian-American musician, talking about how technology could improve oil extraction.
33: The caption lists other artists that had promoted Viscoil’s work, including Mika Newton, a Ukrainian singer and actress.
34: "Mika Newton helped to secure the rights to build a plant for the production of SH-boxes in Ukraine," the caption reads.
35: An SH-box is a kind of environmentally friendly generator, according to NRGLab .
36: We found a Facebook page on which Newton has promoted NRGLab’s work, but we could find no news coverage about the company's dealings in Ukraine.
37: NRGLab does not mention the country on its website.
38: We reached out to the company for more information but did not get a response.
39: Drew Hammill, a spokesman for Nancy Pelosi, told PolitiFact last year that Paul Pelosi Jr. worked for Viscoil for a short time.
40: He denied that it had any dealings in Ukraine when he was working for the company.
41: "The company was based in Southern California and focused solely on U.S. business," he told PolitiFact in an email.
42: "The company later reorganized under a different name, but Paul Pelosi Jr. played no role in the new entity."
43: The timeline Hammill offered fits the evidence we’ve seen.
44: Soccer in Ukraine In addition, the WayneDupree.com article cited a TV appearance Pelosi Jr. made on Ukrainian television in 2017 .
45: But while Pelosi was indeed in Ukraine at the time, there is no evidence to support that he was there while working as an executive for a Ukraine-based gas company.
46: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Paul Pelosi Jr. appears on Ukrainian television in 2017 For starters, the TV interview did not mention anything about energy or gas companies.
47: On the Ukrainian show, Pelosi Jr. said that it was his first visit to Kyiv, and it involved his employment as executive director of the Corporate Governance Initiative , specifically a partnership on youth soccer involving the World Sports Alliance and the Ukrainian government.
48: The Corporate Governance Initiative says its mission is to help organizations "adhere to a system of guidelines, practices, and procedures by which a company is directed and controlled."
49: Pelosi Jr.’s mention of the World Sports Alliance came about two years before one of its top executives, Asa Saint Clair, was indicted in November 2019 for using the "World Sports Alliance, a sham affiliate of the United Nations, as a vehicle to defraud lenders" through a cryptocurrency scheme, according to the Justice Department.
50: In a 2016 news release , Saint Clair touted the Corporate Governance Institute’s governance principles and described Pelosi Jr. as "a longtime associate, both business and personal."
51: Pelosi Jr. is quoted at length in the news release.
52: Nancy Pelosi’s office confirmed that at the time of the Ukraine trip, Pelosi Jr. was working for the Corporate Governance Institute, and that the connection to the World Sports Alliance came from the alliance’s endorsement of the institute’s corporate governance principles.
53: Her office said that Pelosi Jr. did not do any work for the World Sports Alliance and was not paid by them.
54: None of this changes the claim in the headline — that "Nancy Pelosi's Son Paul Jr. Was Exec at 'Ukraine-Based Gas Company,' Similar to Hunter Biden."

llama2-70b: The claim that Nancy Pelosi's son, Paul Pelosi Jr., was an executive at a Ukraine-based gas company is false.
According to Reason[34], the claim originated from a YouTube video that linked Paul Pelosi Jr. to a company called Viscoil.
However, Reason[12] and Reason[42] found no evidence that Paul Pelosi Jr. served as an executive for a Ukraine-based gas company.
In fact, Reason[39] confirmed that Paul Pelosi Jr. worked for Viscoil for a short time, but the company had no dealings in Ukraine during his tenure.
Additionally, Reason[45] revealed that while Pelosi Jr. was in Ukraine at the time, there is no evidence to support that he was there while working as an executive for a Ukraine-based gas company.

Moreover, Reason[50] disclosed that Pelosi Jr. was described as a "longtime associate" of the Corporate Governance Institute, which had a partnership on youth soccer involving the World Sports Alliance and the Ukrainian government.
This contradicts the claim that he worked for a gas company.
Reason[53] also confirmed that Pelosi Jr. did not do any work for the World Sports Alliance and was not paid by them.
The claim is further discredited by Reason[13], which highlights that the situation is not similar to Hunter Biden's appointment to the board of a Ukrainian energy company, Burisma.
Reason[23] and Reason[24] provide additional context by sharing YouTube videos that show Paul Pelosi Jr. speaking at an event in Washington.
The videos do not mention his involvement with a Ukraine-based gas company.
Overall, there is insufficient evidence to support the claim that Nancy Pelosi's son was an executive at a Ukraine-based gas company, and therefore, the veracity of the claim is false.

7b6c86dee31757abd4e0638e90adbe09.claim: Joe Biden ""tells men to marry into families ‘with 3 or 4 sisters.’"""
7b6c86dee31757abd4e0638e90adbe09.label: false
7b6c86dee31757abd4e0638e90adbe09.passage:
0: A right wing website copied an article from another right wing website to put Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden in a bad light.
1: "Biden Caught In Damaging Gaffe On Hot Mic – Tells Men To Marry Into Families ‘With 3 Or 4 Sisters’," read the headline on Thepoliticalbrief.com , Jan. 12.
2: The article builds on tape of Biden working the rope line after a town hall in Vinton, Iowa, Jan. 4.
3: A C-SPAN video catches Biden saying the words that drove the headline.
4: "I tell all the guys that ask me about getting married is that you always marry into a family with three or four sisters," Biden says.
5: "I married one with five.
6: Know why?
7: That way, one will always love you...not the same one."
8: "America’s had its fill of creepy, womanizing presidents," the post said.
9: "Is he saying that he cheats on his wife… with one of her sisters?"
10: This plays off of stories that have dogged Biden of being too physical with women and overstepping the boundaries of personal space.
11: But the piece gets the context of these comments decidedly wrong — Biden was talking to and sympathizing with a woman whose sister had recently died.
12: The short video in the article misses those key details.
13: Here’s the full exchange and setting, which begins at 1:18:30 in the C-SPAN video : Biden is mixing it up with supporters.
14: A middle-aged woman comes up, introduces her husband and her sister.
15: "We had a sister who passed away four weeks ago," she says.
16: Biden shakes his head in sympathy and they take a selfie with the woman and her sister.
17: "I tell all the guys that ask me about getting married is that you always marry into a family with three or four sisters," Biden said.
18: "I married one with five.
19: Know why?
20: That way, one will always love you..not the same one.
21: (The three laugh.)
22: You’ll always have a partner, you’ll always have a buddy with you.
23: I’m so sorry."
24: "Yeah, a few weeks ago she passed away."
25: "I’m so sorry," Biden says, and hugs her.
26: "You know what I’m talking about.
27: God love you.
28: How old was she?
29: The answer is indistinct.
30: Biden shakes his head and says, "ugh."
31: Thepoliticalbrief.com copied the article word for word from a site called GOP Daily Brief .
32: A short video snippet of the moment in Iowa came from a tweet .
33: The article cast Biden’s words as sexist, and by ignoring who he was speaking to and what they were talking about, it suggests he was talking to a man, not a woman.
34: Some people might see Biden’s words as awkward, but they had nothing to do with what the article said.
35: The article is a distortion.

llama2-70b: A C-SPAN video did capture Joe Biden saying the words that were featured in the headline [3].
However, the article's portrayal of Biden's words as sexist is misleading, as it ignores the fact that Biden was speaking to and sympathizing with a woman who had recently lost her sister [11].
Moreover, the article distorts the context of Biden's comments [35].
Therefore, despite the video evidence, the claim that Joe Biden told men to marry into families with 3 or 4 sisters is false.

ef67eb846f17f8450a0452ed0ee9e6d5.claim: We were living outside of Houston and that’s when I found it: a commuter college, 45 minutes away that cost $50 a semester.
ef67eb846f17f8450a0452ed0ee9e6d5.label: true
ef67eb846f17f8450a0452ed0ee9e6d5.passage:
0: U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., often stresses her Texas ties, peppering her public speeches, social media posts and debate remarks with references to her experience as an undergraduate student at the University of Houston, a law student at the University of Texas at Austin and later as a law professor back in Houston and Austin.
1: One anecdote in particular has become a frequent refrain for the Democratic presidential candidate: When she attended the University of Houston, her tuition was $50 a semester.
2: She repeated this claim during a town hall event in Iowa in January, as she described how she became a teacher.
3: "So, here's how my story goes," Warren says.
4: "I was a high school debater and I got a scholarship to college — woo hoo.
5: And then, at 19, I fell in love, got married and dropped out — woo hoo.
6: Now, a good life, a life I had chosen.
7: But I thought that was it and I’d lost out on the chance to be a public school teacher.
8: I thought I gave that up.
9: "We were living outside of Houston and that’s when I found it.
10: A commuter college, 45 minutes away that cost $50 a semester.
11: For a price I could pay with a part-time waitressing job, I finished my four-year diploma, I became a special education teacher.
12: I lived my dream job."
13: Warren did not explicitly reference the University of Houston, but she has named the school multiple times in other versions of the same statement.
14: "It's always a good day to be reminded that I got where I am because a great education was available for $50 a semester at the University of Houston," she said in an October tweet.
15: Today, tuition at the University of Houston costs about $4,000 per semester for an undergraduate student taking 12 hours.
16: Is it true that Warren paid $50 when she attended the same school?
17: Tuition versus total cost University records show that tuition for Texas residents taking a full course load while Warren was enrolled was $50, but additional fees brought the total cost of attending the school up to about $100 a semester.
18: Chris Hayden, spokesman for Warren’s campaign, said it was clear her claim was referencing tuition and not associated expenses.
19: He highlighted multiple occasions when Warren specified that she was talking just about tuition.
20: In Warren’s 2014 memoir titled "A Fighting Chance," she discussed paying for her education.
21: "The University of Houston was about forty minutes away, and tuition was only $50 a semester," she wrote.
22: The $50 amount also makes an appearance in a Medium post by Warren outlining her proposal for universal free public college, posted in April 2019.
23: "I thought my dream of teaching was over," she said in the post.
24: "But then a friend told me about the University of Houston, a public four-year college about 40 minutes away.
25: We were a young couple, watching every nickel.
26: I figured I couldn’t afford it.
27: But it turned out that tuition was just $50 a semester."
28: University bulletins show tuition, fees for students Warren graduated from the University of Houston in 1970, according to a copy of her curriculum vitae.
29: At PolitiFact’s request, the University of Houston provided university bulletins detailing information such as tuition and fees for four academic years around the time of Warren’s graduation: 1966-67, 1968-69, 1969-70 and 1970-71.
30: Across the four academic years, the tuition varies based on a student’s residency (Texas residents pay less in tuition) and the number of hours a student registers for each semester.
31: For Texas residents taking 12 or more hours, the maximum amount listed, tuition during all three academic years was $50 a semester.
32: But there were other expenses students enrolled at the university during those years were required to pay each semester, including a Student Services fee, a University Center fee and an Academic Building Use fee.
33: Warren describes the university as a commuter college, implying that she lived at home and traveled back and forth to campus to attend her classes, which would negate costs associated with room and board.
34: During the 1966-67 academic year, when Warren likely started at the university, tuition was $50 a semester and the other fees were about $39, assuming Warren took a full course load and only during fall and spring semesters.
35: That brings Warren’s grand total to $89 a semester, which doesn’t include the cost of books or other school supplies.
36: During the 1968-69 academic year, tuition was $50 a semester and other fees totaled $41.
37: That brings Warren’s grand total to $91 a semester, again excluding the cost of books or other school supplies.
38: During the 1969-70 academic year, tuition was $50 a semester and other fees totaled $55.
39: That brings Warren’s grand total to $105 a semester.
40: Warren was not enrolled at the university during the 1970-71 school year, but tuition and fees per semester that year totaled $108 for Texas residents.

llama2-70b: According to Elizabeth Warren's statements, she attended a commuter college that cost $50 a semester while living outside Houston.

Records from the University of Houston show that tuition for Texas residents taking a full course load during the 1966-67 academic year, when Warren likely started, was $50 a semester, and other fees brought the total cost up to about $100 a semester [3][13].
Warren herself confirmed that the total cost was $105 a semester [39].
Though Warren has named the school multiple times in other versions of the statement, she did not explicitly reference the University of Houston in this particular version [13].
Regardless, it is true that the University of Houston was about forty minutes away from where Warren lived and tuition was only $50 a semester [21].
Therefore, based on these facts, Warren's claim has been assessed as true.

27e3b14f92c53b5695447583c012980a.claim: U.S. Rep. Dan Lipinski had ""a part in"" undoing a law that used to limit how long trains could idle at crossings."
27e3b14f92c53b5695447583c012980a.label: false
27e3b14f92c53b5695447583c012980a.passage:
0: During a recent podcast interview, Marie Newman used a question about a common transportation problem that rankles drivers to take a jab at her opponent, U.S. Representative Dan Lipinski.
1: Newman is challenging Lipinski to a rematch for Illinois’ 3rd District seat in this year's Democratic primary.
2: He clinched a narrow victory over her in 2018.
3: Asked at a canvassing event hosted by Indivisible Chicago what she would say to constituents frustrated by trains blocking their way on the road, Newman said , "it actually used to be a law that idling trains were not allowed.
4: You could only idle for a very short period of time.That was lifted right around the time that Dan Lipinski came into office and he did have a part in that."
5: "Right now it stops first responders from getting to where they need to go, so that’s a big problem," Newman added.
6: "People die because of it.
7: What goes out in terms of toxic emissions into our environment is horrifying."
8: That’s a lot to pin on Lipinski.
9: So we decided to find out whether the eight-term congressman, who entered office in 2005 and currently sits on the House transportation committee, played a role in the law’s demise.
10: The bottom line: He wasn’t involved in any way.
11: A judicial — not legislative — decision The federal government places no limit on how long trains can block crossings, but a 1999 Illinois law formerly allowed local municipalities to fine trains that had come to a stop and blocked a crossing for more than 10 minutes unless the train could not be moved for reasons beyond the rail carrier’s control.
12: The law was overturned by the Illinois Supreme Court in 2008 after the justices found it incompatible with federal regulations on train speed and air-brake testing.
13: That begs the question how Lipinski, a congressman, could have played a part in putting the brakes on a state legal matter settled in court.
14: When we reached out to Newman’s campaign for an answer, spokesman Ben Hardin confirmed that was the law his candidate was referencing and acknowledged Lipinski had no involvement in the outcome of the case.
15: Nevertheless, Hardin contended, Lipinski "has certainly taken part in protecting corporate interests in rail over the best interests of his constituents" in other ways, such as his role in delaying the deadline by which rail companies are required to implement technology designed to automatically slow or stop speeding trains that experts say could save lives .
16: While that may have been a persuasive argument to some of Newman’s potential constituents, it was not one she leveraged while attacking her opponent’s transportation record at the Indivisible Chicago event.
17: What’s more, Lipinski has been vocal in his support for addressing the issue of idling trains.
18: In 2016 , he wrote a letter to a federal board charged with regulating freight trains asking it to re-examine whether an operator was following an agreement it had made to not block crossings when its purchase of the line received federal approval.
19: And last year , he raised the subject of blocked crossings with the Federal Railroad Administration, highlighting a government study that found average train length had increased 25% since 2008.
20: "While I understand the economic benefits of longer trains, those cannot be at the expense of community safety and quality of life for commuters," Lipinski stated in a July press release .
21: Meanwhile, a recent Bloomberg report found railroad companies have successfully sued six other states in addition to Illinois for enacting laws aimed at unsnarling blocked crossings, including neighboring Indiana and Michigan along with Kansas, Oregon and Texas, which are also home to major freight hubs .

llama2-70b: U.S. Rep. Dan Lipinski did not have a role in reversing a law limiting how long trains could idle at crossings, according to a fact-check.

Although Lipinski did raise the issue of blocked crossings with the Federal Railroad Administration last year and expressed concerns about the impact of longer trains on community safety and quality of life[19][20], he did not play a part in overturning the state law in question.
In fact, the law was overturned by the Illinois Supreme Court in 2008 after it was found to be incompatible with federal regulations on train speed and air-brake testing [12].
Moreover, the federal government places no limit on how long trains can block crossings, and a judicial decision, not legislative action, decided the matter [11].
Therefore, the claim that Lipinski had a role in undoing the law is false.

2c57ba18a97d2958b2c18f0c5b4d228c.claim: a girl gets a dollar for a kidney transplant every time a Facebook post is shared.
2c57ba18a97d2958b2c18f0c5b4d228c.label: false
2c57ba18a97d2958b2c18f0c5b4d228c.passage:
0: Since an image of a little girl was published on Facebook on June 17, 2019 , announcing that every time someone shared the post she would get a dollar for a kidney transplant, she has seemingly pocketed quite a bit of cash.
1: More than $87,000 as of Jan. 17, 2020, as thousands of Facebook users shared the post.
2: But this post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: That’s because it’s a hoax.
5: And it’s been misleading people since at least 2018 .
6: The girl’s photo appeared in October 2017 on the Brazilian website Click Paraná.
7: Translated to English, the post is titled: "Aninha is very much in need of your help."
8: It goes on to say that the girl, Aninha, was diagnosed with leukemia and undergoing chemotherapy in Curitiba, the capital of the Brazilian state Paraná.
9: It asks people to donate blood at a hospital there to help her.
10: It doesn’t ask for money.
11: This Facebook post isn’t the first to claim that sharing a photo of an ailing child will result in a cash flow.
12: In December, we rated Pants on Fire a claim that Facebook would donate a dollar every time someone shared a photograph of a sick boy.
13: This Facebook post gets the same rating.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that a girl receives a dollar for a kidney transplant every time the post is shared has been circulating on social media.
However, this claim has been deemed false.
Despite the post's good intention, there is no partnership between Facebook and the girl's medical fundraising effort [3].
In fact, it has been revealed that this type of claim has been circulating since at least 2018 and has been misleading people [5].
Unlike other similar claims, this post does not ask for money, which is a common tactic in scams [10].
Furthermore, a similar claim about Facebook donating a dollar for a sick boy's treatment was rated as "Pants on Fire" in December [12].
In conclusion, this Facebook post is another example of a false claim spreading misinformation, and it is not affiliated with any legitimate fundraising efforts for a kidney transplant.
Therefore, it receives the same rating of "Pants on Fire" [13].

11ca5d473d46f61ee28571df1bac82d8.claim: Rep. Rashida Tlaib ""wears the symbolic scarf patterned after the Islamic terrorist state."""
11ca5d473d46f61ee28571df1bac82d8.label: false
11ca5d473d46f61ee28571df1bac82d8.passage:
0: Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Mich., is the first female Palestinian-American member of Congress, and at times, wears the scarf — called a keffiyeh — associated with Palestinian resistance to Israeli control of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
1: A viral Facebook post , however, wrongly says the scarf represents terrorism:  "A U.S. Congresswoman wears the symbolic scarf patterned after the Islamic terrorist state," reads the post next to two images of people wearing the keffiyeh.
2: One picture shows Tlaib on the House floor with the scarf around her neck and the other of an armed militant with the scarf over his face.
3: There’s no quibble that the scarf Tlaib wore stands for the Palestinian people.
4: She’s a Palestinian-American and her grandmother lives in the West Bank.
5: Among Palestinians, it’s an object of pride with a history that stretches back thousands of years.
6: Tlaib wore it when she spoke against a House resolution that she said would treat her grandmother as a second-class citizen.
7: But the tie that the Facebook post makes between the scarf and Islamic State terrorism is unfounded.
8: Islamic State fighters wore a variety of scarves, but not in a single style that marked their cause.
9: The scarf in the post is associated with Palestinians, not the Islamic State.
10: Though we could not find the origin of the picture of the fighter wearing the scarf, it shows up in posts dating back to 2008 , long before the rise of the Islamic State.
11: This post plays off of a similar claim circulated in December 2019 that accused Tlaib of wearing the scarf of Hamas terrorists.
12: Armed Palestinian groups have worn the keffiyeh.
13: The red and white version is often associated with Hamas , while black and white is tied more to Fatah, which has renounced armed resistance .
14: But in practice, the scarf is worn by many people worldwide , often as a matter of fashion, not politics.

llama2-70b: Claims that Rep. Rashida Tlaib wore a scarf that symbolizes the Islamic State terrorist organization are unfounded.
The keffiyeh or kufi, the traditional Arab scarf Tlaib wore, has long been a symbol of Palestinian heritage and solidarity [3].
It has nothing to do with the Islamic State, as the Facebook post implies.
In fact, the photo of the fighter wearing the scarf has been used in posts since 2008, before the rise of ISIS [10].
The scarf is also commonly worn by people around the world, including celebrities and politicians, as a fashion statement, not a political or terrorist affiliation [14].
It is worth noting that the post's claim is not only inaccurate but also harmful.
It perpetuates negative stereotypes and misinformation about Muslims and Palestinians, which can further divide and polarize communities.
Therefore, it is important to avoid spreading false information and to fact-check before sharing any posts.

fcbfba30d5ec445d23e7b63b574fb2e8.claim: the pens Nancy Pelosi used to sign the articles of impeachment cost ""$2,025 per pen."""
fcbfba30d5ec445d23e7b63b574fb2e8.label: false
fcbfba30d5ec445d23e7b63b574fb2e8.passage:
0: Republicans criticized House Speaker Nancy Pelosi for giving pens to other House members as keepsakes after she used them to sign the articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump on Jan. 15.
1: White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham, for example, retweeted a photo of the pens and wrote: "Nancy Pelosi’s souvenir pens served up on silver platters to sign the sham articles of impeachment...She was so somber as she gave them away to people like prizes."
2: But on Facebook, some users levied a new accusation against the speaker.
3: "$2,025 per pen," a Jan. 16 post begins .
4: "Paid for by taxpayers.
5: Is there any doubt Pelosi thinks she’s the Queen?
6: Now we know why she delayed sending the Articles of Impeachment to the Senate… she was waiting for her gold-plated impeachment pens."
7: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: This claim is wrong.
10: Each pen cost just under $15, according to Drew Hammill, Pelosi’s deputy chief of staff.
11: When we asked Richard Arenberg, a professor of the practice of political science at Brown University, about the post, he told us "the $2,025 figure is ridiculous."
12: Searching through all 16 pages of Google results for $2,025 and Pelosi’s name, we couldn’t find any other mentions of the pens’ price.
13: The only relevant results were the message in this Facebook post reshared on web forums.
14: The most recent Statement of Disbursements of the House , in which the chief administrative officer details receipts and expenditures of appropriations and other funds from July 1 to Sept. 30, 2019, shows that the speaker’s office spent about $29,000 on supplies and materials that quarter, and about $229,500 that year to date, but there isn’t a specific line item for pens.
15: In the past, reporters have combed through these quarterly reports to see how lawmakers are spending taxpayer money.
16: In 2009, Politico reported that Pelosi spent $2,993 on flowers between June and October of that year.
17: Then-Minority Leader John Boehner spent about $24,617 on catering.
18: According to Business Insider , Pelosi used 30 customized pens engraved with her name to sign her name on the impeachment articles.
19: We would expect that Republicans outraged over the tone of the signing ceremony would also balk at the $60,750 price tag.
20: But reviewing stories from the Washington Post , the Associated Press , Fox News , The Hill , BBC , and the Washington Times , among others, we saw no note of the pen’s price.
21: It’s not unusual for lawmakers and presidents to gift signing pens though in this case Pelosi’s critics argue it wasn’t appropriate.
22: As the BBC notes , then-President Barack Obama used 22 pens to sign the Affordable Care Act, and Republican senators kept pens as souvenirs after signing oaths for then-President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial in 1998.
23: We rate this Facebook post Pants on Fire.
24: Correction: This story has been updated to correct Drew Hammill's title.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that the pens Nancy Pelosi used to sign the articles of impeachment cost "$2,025 per pen" is false.
According to Drew Hammill, Pelosi's deputy chief of staff, each pen cost just under $15 [10].

Despite a thorough search of 16 pages of Google results and multiple news sources, including the Washington Post, the Associated Press, Fox News, The Hill, BBC, and the Washington Times, no mention of the pens' price was found [12][15][20].
This claim has been rated "Pants on Fire"[23].
Therefore, there is no evidence to support the assertion that the pens used by Pelosi cost $2,025 each.

2b93003f1ce21d36d16e519ec583e3da.claim: NC Senate leader ""expressed disdain"" for the NC House budget vote on Sept. 11."
2b93003f1ce21d36d16e519ec583e3da.label: false
2b93003f1ce21d36d16e519ec583e3da.passage:
0: One of the biggest political stories of the year in 2019 occurred on Sept. 11.
1: Democratic Gov.
2: Roy Cooper had vetoed the GOP-controlled legislature’s budget proposal.
3: On most days, Republicans in the legislature have enough votes for a simple majority — but not the supermajority needed to override a veto.
4: But on the morning of Sept. 11, many Democrats were absent.
5: So House Speaker Tim Moore called a vote and the veto override passed.
6: This is where Rep. Deb Butler comes in.
7: The Wilmington Democrat gained recognition for trying to stop the vote, which she considered improper.
8: (She famously yelled "I will not yield" and "shame on you, Mr. Speaker" while on the vote was happening.)
9: Fast forward to January, when the legislature was scheduled to reconvene.
10: In a Jan. 5 tweet , Butler said she’s calling on Senate leader Phil Berger "who expressed disdain for the ambush vote in the House" to negotiate with Cooper rather than try to override his veto.
11: Berger, like Speaker Moore, is a Republican.
12: It’s uncommon for the two Republican leaders to publicly criticize each other.
13: So we wondered whether Butler was right.
14: Did Berger "express disdain" for how Moore executed the veto override?
15: Lack of evidence We asked Butler where she saw or heard Berger’s supposed disdain.
16: "I can’t remember exactly where I read it, but it was in the context of the Senate rules requiring 24 hours notice of a veto override vote and then he said something to the effect that, besides he didn’t like the approach used by the Speaker," Butler said.
17: "I’m sorry I can’t remember precisely where."
18: We also reached out to Berger’s office and asked whether Berger holds disdain for how the House overrode Cooper’s veto, or whether he ever expressed negative feelings about how it happened.
19: "I'm not aware of him ever saying anything like that," Berger spokesman Pat Ryan said.
20: PolitiFact and WRAL reporters could find no specific examples of Berger saying anything negative about the House budget override.
21: A press conference The closest Berger came to criticizing Moore and the House was during an Oct. 1 press conference.
22: Even then, he didn’t mention Moore specifically or say the House did anything wrong.
23: WRAL recorded the press conference.
24: Around the 2:30 mark of the video , Berger talked about his preference for finding a budget solution.
25: "I’d rather have a broad, bipartisan vote — just like you saw on redistricting — than a veto override that squeaks through," Berger said.
26: Then, around the 3:40 mark of the video, Berger explains the logistics of how the Senate must conduct a veto override vote.
27: "Before I take your questions, I’ll answer what’s probably at least one of the questions, maybe the top question: Senate rules require 24 hours’ notice before calendaring a veto override.
28: We will adhere to the rules," Berger said.
29: "I’ll be glad to take your questions."
30: Berger also said he’d seize an opportunity to pass the budget.
31: If could be argued that promise alone proves he didn’t show disdain for the House vote.
32: To disdain something means to feel like it’s "not good enough to deserve your respect or attention," according to the Oxford dictionary .
33: Merriam-Webster says it means to treat something as "beneath one’s notice or dignity."

llama2-70b: Republican House Speaker Tim Moore called a vote to override Gov. Roy Cooper's veto of the state budget, passing it on Sept. 11.

On Jan. 5, Rep. Butler tweeted that she is calling on Senate leader Phil Berger, "who expressed disdain for the ambush vote in the House," to negotiate with Cooper rather than try to override his veto.
However, a search for evidence of such a statement from Berger shows that it does not exist.
In a press conference, Berger promises to follow the rules when it comes to voting on the budget.
Therefore, given the lack of evidence of Berger expressing disdain and the fact that he promised to follow the rules, it can be argued that he did not show disdain for the House budget vote.
Based on these reasons, the claim that Phil Berger expressed disdain for the NC House budget vote on September 11th is false.

f758f841a3888f5ea197b5eb0324a1fe.claim: Martin Luther King Jr. ""was killed (smothered) in the hospital"" and ""the US government was found guilty in a court of law of conspiring to kill him."""
f758f841a3888f5ea197b5eb0324a1fe.label: false
f758f841a3888f5ea197b5eb0324a1fe.passage:
0: A few days before a holiday celebrating his life, conspiracies about Martin Luther King Jr.’s death are circulating on Instagram.
1: In an image reposted Jan. 14 from another account, a brand called Olmecian Clothing claimed that, contrary to popular belief, King did not die from a gunshot wound.
2: The post includes a photo of what appears to be King in a hospital bed.
3: "He was killed (smothered) in the hospital," the post reads.
4: "Also in 1999 the US government was found guilty in a court of law of conspiring to kill him but was silenced by the media."
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook , which owns Instagram.)
7: It has more than 9,700 likes, and similar posts were shared on Facebook.
8: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A popular Instagram and Facebook post claims Martin Luther King Jr. was killed in the hospital after he was shot.
9: We rate the posts False.
10: (Screenshot from Instagram) We checked Congress’ report on King’s death, as well as the book and lawsuit cited in the Instagram post.
11: None of them provide evidence that the civil rights leader was killed in a government plot — and the photo itself does not show King after he was shot.
12: King died from gunshot wound The most authoritative report on King’s assassination is a congressional report from 1979.
13: It said he died from a gunshot wound.
14: According to the House Select Committee on Assassinations’ report, King was shot shortly after 6 p.m. on April 4, 1968, while standing on a balcony at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tenn.
15: He was pronounced dead at 7:05 p.m. at St. Joseph Hospital.
16: An autopsy conducted at Gaston Hospital determined that King’s cause of death was a "gunshot wound to the chin and neck with a total transaction of the lower cervical and upper thoracic spinal cord and other structures of the neck."
17: A convicted armed robber and escaped prison inmate named James Earl Ray pleaded guilty to the first-degree murder of King on March 10, 1969.
18: (He recanted his confession days later but was never able to formally withdraw his guilty plea.)
19: Critics questioned the thoroughness of the autopsy report, but a panel of three forensic pathologists commissioned by the House committee concluded that the findings were generally accurate.
20: They reached that conclusion after reviewing "the report of the committee's firearms panel, as well as X-rays, medical reports, notes, and documents submitted by physicians who treated Dr.
21: King."
22: A decades-old conspiracy theory The conspiracy that King was killed by someone at the hospital stems from an attorney who represented Ray.
23: The post’s caption cites a 2016 book by the lawyer, William Pepper, titled "The Plot to Kill King: The Truth Behind the Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr." Moor Information, the Instagram account from which Olmecian Clothing reposted the image, conceded in its caption that the book "has never been verified."
24: Pepper represented Ray during the tail-end of his trial for King’s murder and has spent years trying to prove his innocence.
25: Ray died in prison in 1998. Pepper claims in the book that Ray didn’t kill King — instead, he was framed by U.S. government agencies.
26: RELATED: Claims about MLK often go astray "The plan, according to Pepper, was for a team of United States Army Special Forces snipers to kill King, but just as they were taking aim, a backup civilian assassin pulled the trigger," reads the book’s description.
27: There is no direct evidence that happened.
28: Hampton Sides, author of "Hellhound on His Trail: The Stalking of Martin Luther King Jr. and the International Hunt for His ­Assassin," told Time magazine in April 2018 that the source of many conspiracies about King’s death can be traced to Ray’s guilty plea, which stopped his trial from proceeding.
29: "There was a huge amount of evidence presented in Memphis that didn’t see the light of day in a public forum," Sides said.
30: "I think that contributed to the sense of conspiracy, like a ‘What are they hiding?’ kind of thing."
31: Those conspiracies are also fueled by the fact that FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover spied on King during the 1960s.
32: Pepper has been active in other conspiracy movements, such as those that doubt official accounts of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
33: As for the actual photo in the Instagram post, it doesn’t show King at St. Joseph Hospital in Memphis.
34: It depicts King after he was stabbed on Sept. 20, 1958, in New York City.
35: Civil suit doesn’t prove conspiracy As additional evidence for its claim that King was killed in a nefarious government plot, the Instagram post cited a 1999 lawsuit.
36: But the case doesn’t show what Olmecian Clothing says it does.
37: King vs. Jowers was a wrongful death civil suit filed by Pepper on behalf of King’s wife and children.
38: The unlikely partnership was a result of the family’s belief that Pepper’s version of the assassination got at the real truth behind King’s death, according to the New York Times .
39: See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com In this April 8, 1968 file photo, Coretta Scott King, third right, is accompanied by her children, Yolanda, Bernice, Martin III, and Dexter at Sisters Chapel on the campus of Spelman College in Atlanta.
40: (AP) Loyd Jowers was a Memphis cafe owner who claimed he hired someone other than Ray to assassinate King.
41: A prosecutor who investigated King’s assassination said several of Jowers’ associates said he hoped to get a movie or book deal.
42: The jury issued a verdict that said Jowers and "others, including government agencies" were part of a conspiracy to assassinate King.
43: The jury awarded the Kings the $100 in damages that they sought.
44: But in a 2000 review of the lawsuit, the Justice Department found no evidence to back up the verdict.
45: (It’s worth noting that civil suits only require plaintiffs to prove their case by a "preponderance of the evidence" instead of "beyond a reasonable doubt," which is a more stringent burden of proof that’s used in criminal court.)
46: "Most of the witnesses and writings offered to support the various government-directed conspiracy claims relied exclusively on secondhand and thirdhand hearsay and speculation," the Justice Department wrote in its report on King vs. Jowers.
47: "Additionally, none of these allegations were ever linked together."

llama2-70b: A widely shared Instagram post falsely claims that civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. "was killed (smothered) in the hospital" and that the US government was found guilty of conspiring to kill him.
King died from a gunshot wound, according to the most authoritative report on his assassination, a 1979 congressional report [12][13].
An autopsy conducted at Gaston Hospital determined that King's cause of death was a "gunshot wound to the chin and neck"[16].

The post's caption cites a 2016 book by lawyer William Pepper, titled "The Plot to Kill King," but there is no direct evidence to support the claim that the government was involved in King's assassination [23][27].

In fact, a 2000 review of the lawsuit by the Justice Department found no evidence to back up the verdict, stating that "most of the witnesses and writings offered to support the various government-directed conspiracy claims relied exclusively on secondhand and third-hand hearsay and speculation" [44][46].
The post was flagged as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed [5].
The case doesn't show what Olmecian Clothing says it does [36].
The claim that Martin Luther King Jr. was killed in the hospital and that the US government was found guilty of conspiring to kill him is false and lacks any direct evidence to support it.

421e3a4e4e22b76cc1a54a315da1ae36.claim: Starting Jan. 1 California residents can’t take shower, do laundry, poop in toilet and flush on same day.
421e3a4e4e22b76cc1a54a315da1ae36.label: false
421e3a4e4e22b76cc1a54a315da1ae36.passage:
0: The police won’t come knocking for Californians who shower and do laundry on the same day, despite what some social media users would have you believe.
1: An old hoax about California’s water conservation laws recently resurfaced after a guest on a Los Angeles TV station shared misinformation on air.
2: "Starting Jan. 1 California residents can’t take shower, do laundry, poop in toilet and flush on same day," said one Facebook post that drew thousands of views to the segment, which was broadcast Dec. 31 on KTLA.
3: "No really!
4: This is not satire.
5: 55 Gallons per person!"
6: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: We debunked the same bogus information about California’s conservation efforts in 2018, shortly after then-California Gov.
9: Jerry Brown signed two water-use bills into law.
10: Now, as the misinformation makes a resurgence, we wanted to set the record straight: It was never illegal for Californians to shower and wash laundry on the same day.
11: It still isn’t.
12: Old hoax, new outrage The renewed controversy came after KTLA, a local TV station, ran a segment on Dec. 31 about "unusual and underreported" California laws taking effect in 2020.
13: The network welcomed Southern California lawyer Richard Lee on the show, and an anchor teed up a discussion of two California water laws that Lee said would apply in 2020.
14: Lee’s response parroted many of the inaccurate claims we looked at in 2018.
15: "Doing a load of laundry takes about 40 to 50 gallons of water," Lee said.
16: "Taking a shower for about eight minutes takes about 17 gallons of water."
17: "Well, there’s a limitation on your daily use of water of 55 gallons per day," he continued.
18: "So that means, if you are taking a shower and if you’re doing a load of laundry, you can’t do both without being in violation of the law."
19: Lee went on to say that violators would be fined "$1,000 per each day that you are in violation," and more during drought conditions, starting Jan. 1, 2020.
20: "Wow," KTLA Morning News anchor Mark Kriski said.
21: "So all of a sudden, I can smoke marijuana as much as I want, but I can’t take a shower.
22: Unbelievable."
23: Claims that the laws ban showering and laundry on the same day are False .
24: We fact-checked them when they first circulated in 2018.
25: So did Snopes and a number of local news outlets .
26: KTLA replaced the clip on its website with a correction noting that the segment "included factual errors about two laws going into effect in 2020 regarding water conservation."
27: But that effort didn’t stop the video from spreading to all corners of social media and making headlines on conservative sites such as American Lookout and the Gateway Pundit .
28: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com The misinformation spread so far and so fast that the California Department of Water Resources and the Association of California Water Agencies both issued statements debunking it.
29: A representative from KTLA declined to comment, but Lee told us that "the segment was intended to simply be a quick rundown that each person in California could and should be more mindful on his or her indoor water usage."
30: "I was simply stating that 55 gallons per day is the standard for per capita indoor water usage per day set forth by the state legislature," he said.
31: "Those fines are to the water agency or provider.
32: That said, there is the question of whether a water agency or provider would pass along this fine to the individual consumer."
33: Individuals don’t have to worry about fines The false claims about California water use center on two bills — Senate Bill 606 and Assembly Bill 1668 — that Brown, the state’s former governor, signed into law on May 31, 2018, as California was reeling from a five-year drought that ended in 2017.
34: Broadly speaking, the laws instruct cities, water districts and some larger agricultural water districts to establish strict water budgets.
35: But the new water limits — which kick in starting in 2023, not 2020 — won’t target individuals.
36: The legislation requires cities, water districts and large agricultural water districts to come up with budgetary targets for water use by 2022.
37: They will need to meet these targets across their ratepayer bases, with failure to do so resulting in a fine of $1,000 per day or $10,000 per day during drought emergencies.
