Like Obama, Buttigieg claims that under his "Medicare for All Who Want It" plan, Americans can still choose to keep their private insurance [3].

However, experts argue that this may not be the case, citing the fact that employers may choose to switch to the public option, potentially leaving employees with no choice but to switch to Medicare [58][42].

Additionally, Cynthia Cox of the Kaiser Family Foundation notes that the government cannot guarantee private plans will continue to be offered without mandating them, as private companies will make business decisions that may affect coverage[32].
While Buttigieg's plan may provide a "glide path" to a Medicare for All system, it is unclear who would be included and whether private plans would drop out [55][57].
Therefore, the claim that individuals can keep their private plans under Buttigieg's plan is considered half-true.

a49551f75da3400d4e394ff9ec0de104.claim: Say Bernie Sanders said, “Italians are gangsters and Irish are drunk and Jews are greedy and black people smell.”
a49551f75da3400d4e394ff9ec0de104.label: false
a49551f75da3400d4e394ff9ec0de104.passage:
0: As U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders has tightened his hold on frontrunner status for the Democratic presidential nomination, having clinched the Nevada caucuses on Feb. 23, his detractors have tapped into an archive of video footage from the longtime lawmaker’s career.
1: "Here are the videos Bernie DOESN’T want you to see," reads the description of a video posted to Facebook on Feb. 19 .
2: It starts by showing what looks like an old clip of Sanders speaking to a class of middle-school children.
3: "What we learned is that black people smell," he says.
4: "All right, what about Jewish people?
5: … How are they different than other people?
6: Their religious beliefs were different but also they were greedy and selfish people, also had strange sexual habits so forth and so on.
7: What does everybody know about the Irish?
8: They …" A student offers: "Get in fights?"
9: "Get in fights because they’re drunk," Sanders says.
10: "All the Irish people do is drink.
11: That’s the Irish.
12: All Italians are gangsters, and Irish are drunk, and Jews are greedy, and black people smell.
13: OK?"
14: Not OK.
15: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
16: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
17: The footage of Sanders is authentic, but it’s been edited to appear that he is offering his derogatory opinions on black, Italian, Irish and Jewish people.
18: (For the record, Sanders is Jewish .)
19: The clips featured in the Facebook post are from a television show called "Bernie Speaks with the Community" that Sanders hosted on a public access channel when he was the mayor of Burlington, Vt.
20: In episode 39 of the show, which aired on Dec. 4, 1987 , Sanders discusses racial stereotypes and the importance of humanizing people who are different from you with a group of schoolchildren.
21: One student talks about how black people were dehumanized during slavery.
22: "What you’re getting at is a word that I will use: stereotype," Sanders replies.
23: "What does the word stereotype mean in the context that you’re talking about it?"
24: After fielding a few answers from the class, Sanders says: "If you want to deal with a group of people, essentially if you want to do bad things to them, you do, what I call, dehumanize them.
25: You make them less than human beings.
26: And what you do therefore is you develop a stereotypical image of them.
27: A stereotype.
28: … What about black people?
29: What’s the stereotype that we know about black people?
30: … When I was a young person, what we learned is that black people smell.
31: They had a special odor.
32: That was what went all around, that black people smelled and that they were pretty stupid.
33: Over the course of the nearly hourlong segment, Sanders engages with the class, asking questions, listening to the students’ answers and sharing his own experiences.
34: Within the scope of the show, it’s clear that he’s criticizing racial stereotypes, not professing them as his own opinions about Italians, Irish, Jews and others.
35: But that context does not appear in the seconds of footage that appears on Facebook.
36: "The Daily Show" host Trevor Noah covered the comments in May 2019 after the public access channel released recordings of Sanders’ show.
37: On YouTube, the Daily Show describes Sanders as "giving Vermont children head-scratching lessons on stereotypes."

llama2-70b: The claim that Bernie Sanders stated, "Italians are gangsters and Irish are drunk and Jews are greedy and black people smell" has been circulating on social media, but it is false.

According to reason [37], a YouTube video titled "Bernie Sanders Gives Vermont Kids Head-Scratching Lessons on Stereotypes" from the Daily Show, it is clear that Sanders is not expressing his personal opinions but rather criticizing racial stereotypes.
Moreover, reason [17] states that the footage of Sanders is authentic but has been edited to falsely appear as though he is offering his derogatory opinions on various ethnic groups.

In reality, as explained in reason [20], episode 39 of the show, which aired on December 4, 1987, featured Sanders discussing racial stereotypes and the importance of humanizing people who are different from you with a group of schoolchildren.
He did not express any personal opinions that could be construed as derogatory towards any particular group.
Therefore, the claim that Bernie Sanders made these statements is false, and he was actually criticizing racial stereotypes in the context of his show.

b0c3b7b4a6ede18049ae33b595b38580.claim: 20 million Chinese converted to Islam after it’s proven that the coronavirus doesn’t affect Muslims.
b0c3b7b4a6ede18049ae33b595b38580.label: false
b0c3b7b4a6ede18049ae33b595b38580.passage:
0: Amid fears about the coronavirus disease , a YouTube video offers a novel way to inoculate yourself: convert to Islam.
1: "20m Chinese gets converted to Islam after it is proven that corona virus did not affect the Muslims," reads the title of a video posted online Feb. 18 .
2: The footage shows a room full of men raising an index finger and reciting what sounds like the Shahadah , a statement of faith in Islam.
3: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: That’s because the footage is from at least as far back as May 26, 2019, when it was posted on Facebook with this caption: "Alhamdulillah welcome to our brothers in faith."
6: On Nov. 7, 2019, it was posted on YouTube with this title: "MashaaAllah hundreds converted to Islam in Philippines."
7: Both posts appeared online before the current outbreak of the new coronavirus, COVID-19, was first reported in Wuhan, China, on Dec. 31, 2019.
8: But even if the footage followed the outbreak, Muslims are not immune to COVID-19, as the Facebook post claims.
9: After China, Iran has emerged as the second focal point for the spread of COVID-19, the New York Times reported on Feb. 24 .
10: "The Middle East is in many ways the perfect place to spawn a pandemic, experts say, with the constant circulation of both Muslim pilgrims and itinerant workers who might carry the virus."
11: On Feb. 18, Newsweek reported that coronavirus "poses a serious risk to millions of inmates in China’s Muslim prison camps."

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claiming that 20 million Chinese have converted to Islam after it was proven that the coronavirus doesn't affect Muslims has been flagged as false by Facebook's fact-checking efforts.[3] The post's claim is based on old footage that has been circulating online since at least May 2019.
[5] The footage shows Muslims praying in a public place, but it has no relation to the COVID-19 pandemic or any supposed immunity of Muslims to the virus.
[8] In fact, Muslims are not immune to COVID-19, and this claim is baseless.
[8] Therefore, the claim in the Facebook post is false, and it is part of a larger effort to spread misinformation about COVID-19 and Islam.

b59593bd6bb71f4983797bc36d4c4f4d.claim: “There’s an Amazon distribution center that was advertising, last time I was there, up to $12.75 an hour. Your parents made that three decades ago.”
b59593bd6bb71f4983797bc36d4c4f4d.label: half-true
b59593bd6bb71f4983797bc36d4c4f4d.passage:
0: On the campaign trail, U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., has made a point of talking about stagnant wages.
1: So has U.S. Rep. Mark Pocan, D-Wisconsin, who co-sponsored a bill in 2019 to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour in 2024.
2: The bill passed in the House in July 2019 and is stalled in the Senate, but Pocan is still talking about wage growth — most recently in his endorsement of Sanders for the Democratic presidential nomination.
3: In a Jan. 16, 2020 video with Sanders posted on Twitter, Pocan described an advertisement he saw for the Amazon distribution center in his hometown of Kenosha, seeking workers for $12.75 an hour.
4: "Your parents made that three decades ago, and that’s what people are making now," Pocan said to the camera.
5: Is Pocan right on the numbers?
6: And what about his underlying point: that real wages haven’t changed much in 30 years?
7: We checked it out.
8: Crunching the numbers When asked for evidence to back up Pocan’s claim, communications director Usamah Andrabi provided historical pay data for the nation’s auto industry and the median income for Wisconsin men and women according to the 1990 census.
9: Andrabi said Pocan often uses auto worker pay to make his point, because auto manufacturing was the dominant industry in Kenosha when he was growing up there.
10: But Pocan did not mention auto pay in his claim, and pay in that industry historically is far higher than many other jobs.
11: So, we focused on the weekly and hourly earnings data from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
12: Let’s walk through the math.
13: Dennis Winters, chief economist for the Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development, said the best metric to use in examining the claim is median wages — and, of course, to examine them in "real" terms, to compare the spending power over time.
14: The median wage for Americans in December 1990 was $417 per week, which breaks down to $10.43 an hour.
15: Fast-forward three decades, and the median wage for Americans in December 2019 was $933 per week, or $23.33 an hour.
16: That might look like a significant increase.
17: But using the Bureau’s inflation calculator, the 1990 weekly wage translates to $800.88 per week in today’s dollars, or $20.02 an hour.
18: So, that’s a roughly $3 increase in 30 years.
19: From a narrow perspective, Pocan is off — an offer of $12.75 does not equate to hourly wages from 30 years ago, as a straight comparison or with inflation factored in.
20: He fares much better when considering the larger point being made: That wage growth has been largely stagnant.
21: An August 2018 study from the Pew Research Center showed that at least since 2000, most of the country’s wage growth is distributed among the top 10% of earners.
22: For those closer to the median and below it, the growth line is nearly flat.
23: What’s more, the cost of living has undergone a much steeper hike: from 1983 to 2013, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a roughly 3% annual increase in rent and food prices, and a 1.3% annual increase in new vehicle prices.
24: So, a small growth in median wages is dwarfed next to the rise in cost of other goods.

llama2-70b: The claim that the wage being offered at an Amazon distribution center today is the same as what parents made three decades ago is half-true.
According to the Bureau’s inflation calculator, the 1990 weekly wage of $800.88 translates to $20.02 per hour in today’s dollars [1].
This means that the $12.75 hourly wage mentioned in a Twitter video by Rep. Mark Pocan [3] is lower than the inflation-adjusted wage from 30 years ago.
However, it is important to note that wage growth has not been evenly distributed, with the top 10% of earners capturing most of the wage growth since 2000 [21].
Moreover, the cost of living has increased at a faster rate than wages, making it difficult for workers to maintain their purchasing power [23].
Therefore, while the claim is partially accurate, it does not tell the whole story about the stagnation of wages and the decline of purchasing power for many workers over the past few decades.

b843ba73006d2048838bdf915982c284.claim: During his tenure as mayor of New York City, “street homelessness decreased by 28 percent.”
b843ba73006d2048838bdf915982c284.label: true
b843ba73006d2048838bdf915982c284.passage:
0: During his campaign for president, Michael Bloomberg has pointed to his record as a three-term mayor of New York City, highlighting certain parts to appeal to Democratic primary voters.
1: On his campaign website, Bloomberg claims that during his tenure, "street homelessness decreased by 28 percent."
2: "As Mayor of New York City, Mike led one of the nation’s most ambitious affordable housing plans, implementing several initiatives that have been replicated in cities around the country.
3: During his tenure, street homelessness decreased by 28% and more than 170,000 affordable homes were built or preserved," his site states .
4: We were curious about Bloomberg’s claim about "street homelessness," and reached out to the campaign.
5: Spokesman Michael Frazier directed us to a city report from 2013.
6: According to the Mayor’s Management Report , "the estimate of those living on the street in 2013 is 28 percent lower than the baseline established in 2005."
7: Street homelessness is a portion of the total number of people who are homeless.
8: The city considers people who sleep on the streets or in the parks or subway system to be part of this subset.
9: It does not include the much larger number of people in the city’s shelters.
10: The Bloomberg administration began counting people who are part of the street homeless population in 2005.
11: Data from the city’s Department of Homeless Services show a 28 percent drop in the number of people who slept on the streets or in the parks and subway during annual point-in-time counts between 2005 and 2013.
12: On March 7, 2005, volunteers counted 4,395 street homeless people for the inaugural Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, or HOPE count.
13: On Jan. 28, 2013, the last year of Bloomberg's tenure, the count was 3,180.
14: The count on Jan. 27, 2014, a month after Bloomberg left office, was 3,357, or a drop of 24 percent from 2005.
15: Mixed reviews The Urban Institute published a report in 2014, funded by the Bloomberg administration, supporting Bloomberg’s claim.
16: Under Bloomberg, New York City became a "national model for how to reduce unsheltered and chronic homelessness," wrote Josh Leopold, a senior research associate.
17: In an interview, Leopold said the administration did not interfere with his work on the report.
18: Bloomberg’s management background contributed to the city’s efforts to organize street outreach and coordinate services for homeless people, he said.
19: "His administration should get a lot of credit for that," Leopold said.
20: While the counting methodology does account for including some people the counters may have missed, the data can be unreliable, according to some experts.
21: In a paper published by the conservative American Enterprise Institute, Kevin C. Corinth wrote that "street counts are inherently difficult to conduct and should therefore be treated cautiously."
22: Giselle Routhier, policy director for Coalition for the Homeless, an advocacy organization that has been critical of Bloomberg, said that the shelter census is a better measure.
23: "We never trust the HOPE estimate," Routhier said.
24: The count could be influenced by various factors, such as the weather.
25: Counters can also miss homeless people on the street because they may not always be in publicly visible places, such as an ATM vestibule, and efforts to get people off the street in the week before the annual count can affect the result, she said.
26: New York City provides temporary emergency shelter to every eligible man, woman, and child, every night.
27: This means that many of the city's homeless are in shelters, not on the street, Routhier said.
28: While the street homeless population has fluctuated between 2,328 and 4,395 since 2005, according to the HOPE counts , the shelter population surpassed 50,000 under Bloomberg .
29: Other homelessness experts gave Bloomberg mixed report cards on his efforts, even as some said that his claim of reducing street homelessness is correct.
30: Thomas J.
31: Main, a professor at the Marxe School of Public and International Affairs at Baruch College, credited Bloomberg’s efforts to prevent homelessness and his outreach to people living on the street.
32: On balance, Bloomberg's record is positive, Main said.
33: Main, however, wrote in his book, "Homelessness in New York City: Policymaking from Koch to de Blasio," that a policy change that ended homeless families receiving priority in access to public housing "would be seen as part of the reason why the shelter population was to grow to unprecedented levels."
34: Main also notes homelessness is sometimes driven by factors outside of a mayor’s control, such as recessions and state and federal policy.
35: City University of New York Professor John Krinsky called Bloomberg’s claim "both technically true and very misleading," given the increase in the number of people staying in homeless shelters.

llama2-70b: During Michael Bloomberg's tenure as mayor of New York City between 2002 and 2013, street homelessness decreased by 28%.

According to data from the city's Department of Homeless Services, the number of people who slept on the streets or in parks and subway stations dropped by 28% during annual point-in-time counts between 2005 and 2013 [11].
Specifically, the number of street homeless individuals decreased from 4,395 in 2005[12] to 3,180 in 2013
[13], representing a 28% drop.
This decrease continued after Bloomberg left office, with a 24% decline in street homelessness from 2005 to 2014[14].
Bloomberg's site states that during his tenure, more than 170,000 affordable homes were built or preserved, which likely contributed to the reduction in homelessness [3].
Given the consistent evidence from various sources, the claim that street homelessness decreased by 28% during Bloomberg's tenure is verified as true.

837db1a79f848c4c64fd8f994ccb6b3a.claim: it’s “OK to kill babies once born” in Virginia.
837db1a79f848c4c64fd8f994ccb6b3a.label: false
837db1a79f848c4c64fd8f994ccb6b3a.passage:
0: Virginia Gov.
1: Ralph Northam worked as a doctor before he was elected to helm the Commonwealth, and it’s not hard to find photos of him online wearing a stethoscope around his neck.
2: One such picture shared on social media features text on top criticizing the state.
3: "Thanks Virginia," it says.
4: "OK to kill babies once born."
5: This post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: One account that posted the image also links to a Jan. 30, 2019, National Review article with this headline: "Virginia governor defends letting infants die."
8: It is not legal to kill babies once born in Virginia.
9: That is a felony.
10: But here’s what you need to know about the late-term abortion debate in the state.
11: That story cites a radio interview Northam did with the station WTOP , after a Jan. 29, 2019, committee hearing on proposed legislation that would loosen restrictions on late-term abortions.
12: The bill was introduced by Kathy Tran, a Democatic delegate to the state House, and during the hearing she fielded questions from Todd Gilbert, a Republican delegate.
13: "How late in the third trimester could a physician perform an abortion if he indicated it would impair the mental health of the woman?"
14: Gilbert asked.
15: "Through the third trimester," Tran said.
16: "The third trimester goes all the way up to 40 weeks."
17: "Where it’s obvious that the woman is about to give birth, would that still be a point at which she could request an abortion if she was so certified?
18: She’s dilating," he said.
19: "My bill would allow that," Tran said.
20: The next day, Northam appeared on the radio show.
21: Reporter Julie Carey asked him this question: "There was a very contentious committee hearing yesterday, when Fairfax County delegate Kathy Tran made her case for lifting restrictions on third-trimester abortions as well as other restrictions now in place, and she was pressed by a Republican delegate about whether her bill would permit an abortion even as a woman is essentially dilating, ready to give birth, and she answered that it would permit an abortion at that stage of labor.
22: Do you support her measure?
23: And explain her answer."
24: Northam said he couldn’t speak for Tran but that the situation illustrates why such decisions should be made by physicians and parents.
25: "When we talk about third-trimester abortions, these are done with the consent of obviously the mother, with the consent of the physician — more than one physician, by the way — and it’s done in cases where there are severe deformities, there may be a fetus that is nonviable," he said.
26: "So in this particular example, if a mother’s in labor, I can tell you exactly what would happen.
27: The infant would be delivered, the infant would be kept comfortable, the infant would be resuscitated if that’s what the mother and family desired, and then a discussion would ensue between the physicians and the mother," he said.
28: "So I think this was really blown out of proportion but again, we want the government not to be involved in these types of decisions.
29: We want the decisions to be made by the mothers and the providers, and this is why legislators … most of whom are men, shouldn’t be telling a woman what she should and shouldn’t be doing with her body."
30: Virginia law already allowed abortions after the second trimester but required three doctors to certify that the mother would die or her mental and physical health would be "substantially and irremediably" impaired without the procedure.
31: Tran’s bill, which died in committee, would have eliminated the requirement that two other physicians certify that a late-term abortion is necessary to prevent the mother’s death or harm or mental or physical health.
32: It also eliminated the words "substantially and irremediably" from the law, among other changes.
33: In the interview, Northam said he supported keeping the state’s requirement that multiple physicians certify the abortion is necessary because "these decisions shouldn’t be taken lightly."
34: The Democratic governor’s comments drew criticism from conservatives, including U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla. "I never thought I would see the day America had government officials who openly support legal infanticide," he tweeted on Jan. 30.
35: U.S. Sen. Ben Sasse, R-Neb., called Northam’s comments "morally repugnant."
36: "In just a few years pro-abortion zealots went from ‘safe, legal, and rare’ to ‘keep newborns comfortable while the doctor debates infanticide,’" Sasse said.
37: "I don’t care what party you’re from — if you can’t say that it’s wrong to leave babies to die after birth, get the hell out of public office."
38: Tran later said she misspoke when she was asked whether her bill would let an abortion happen when the mother was in labor and about to give birth.
39: "I should have said, ‘Clearly, no, because infanticide is not allowed in Virginia, and what would have happened in that moment would be a live birth.’" In Virginia, killing a newborn is a felony punishable by death.
40: A Northam spokesperson told Vox that his comments were "absolutely not" a reference to infanticide.
41: Rather, they "focused on the tragic and extremely rare case in which a woman with a nonviable pregnancy or severe fetal abnormalities went into labor."
42: He called the idea that he approved of killing infants "disgusting," according to the Washington Post .

llama2-70b: The claim that it is "OK to kill babies once born" in Virginia is false.
In fact, killing a newborn is a felony punishable by death in Virginia, as stated by Reason [39].
Additionally, Representative Tran, who was misinterpreted as supporting infanticide, clarified that his bill would not allow for the killing of infants born alive, as stated in Reasons [19] and [25].

Tran emphasized that third-trimester abortions, which are allowed in Virginia, are done with the consent of the mother and multiple physicians only in cases of severe deformities or nonviability, as stated in Reason [26].
Facebook flagged a post claiming that infanticide is allowed in Virginia as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation, as stated in Reason [5].

Therefore, the claim that it is "OK to kill babies once born" in Virginia is false and has been clearly debunked by legal facts, clarifying statements, and Facebook's efforts to combat misinformation.

ddf5fbc3b112e1ed1b5f36a2ffd0bac5.claim: Bernie Sanders “collaborated with Marxist regimes in the Soviet Union, Nicaragua and Cuba.”
ddf5fbc3b112e1ed1b5f36a2ffd0bac5.label: false
ddf5fbc3b112e1ed1b5f36a2ffd0bac5.passage:
0: In the South Carolina presidential debate , Bernie Sanders continued to parry attacks for having said that Cuba did something good when it launched a massive literacy campaign under Fidel Castro.
1: (We rated that claim Mostly True , noting that the teaching materials came with hefty ideological baggage.)
2: This sort of criticism isn’t new for Sanders.
3: Thanks to his past comments on Marxist governments, he has been taking shots for a long time.
4: A Feb. 8 Facebook post recycled an August 2018 image that poses the question, "Bernie Sanders: Communist traitor?"
5: It continues: "The Vermont Senator collaborated with Marxist regimes in the Soviet Union, Nicaragua and Cuba in the 1980s when America was on the verge of winning the Cold War."
6: Some quick timeposts: When he was mayor of Burlington, Vermont, Sanders visited Nicaragua in 1985, the Soviet Union in 1988 (three years before its collapse) and Cuba in 1989.
7: The question is, did he collaborate with those governments?
8: By the plain meaning of the word, he did not.
9: Collaborate means for two or more people to work together, while a more loaded political meaning is associated with treason.
10: Neither applies to Sanders.
11: What’s true is Sanders said nice things about each of the countries.
12: In particular he gave Nicaragua and Cuba, both small nations targeted by the United States, the benefit of the doubt.
13: Some see that as actively undermining the United States’ foreign policy.
14: However, Sanders also criticized each place.
15: The words he used to describe their shortcomings might not satisfy everyone, but they do indicate that he tempered his praise.
16: Nicaragua Here are some key excerpts from Sanders’ press conference in Vermont , after his 1985 trip to Nicaragua: "My goal was not to determine how good or bad the Nicaraguan government is.
17: I’m not an expert.
18: My major concern is that there is a real possibility that the United States is about to enter into a Vietnam type war in Central America.
19: I think that such a war would not only be a disaster for the Nicaraguan people, but a disaster for the people of the United States as well.
20: Others may disagree with me, but I do not believe it is in the interests of the people of our country to have young men and women fighting and dying in the jungles of Central America."
21: "Many people believe the Sandinista government has made significant progress in such vital areas as health care education, agriculture and land reform and the distribution of food.
22: They have also gone a long way in extending democrtic rights to a country which has no democratic history."
23: "As poor as Nicaragua is, one of the nice things that I saw, is that as a result of government policy, in terms of the distribution of food, people are not hungry, by and large."
24: "I am not here to defend every action of the Nicaraguan government.
25: Do I think I got to all sides of the story and talked to everybody?
26: The answer is, ‘No.’" When reporters pressed Sanders on the government’s violent repression of indigenous people, Sanders said the situation was "complicated."
27: He said that some government officials said they didn’t like what happened, but that he wasn’t expert enough to comment.
28: In a letter to a constituent , he wrote, "Nicaragua, a tiny impoverished nation of 3 million, is today fighting a brutal war — with their enemy being totally financed by the most powerful nation on earth."
29: The cities of Burlington and Puerto Cabezas in Nicaragua became sister cities.
30: Under that program, the city sent 500 tons of supplies and humanitarian aid in 1986.
31: Critics cast this as supporting the government of Nicaragua.
32: Yaroslavl, USSR After Sanders and a group from Burlington returned from a trip to the Soviet Union, the travelers shared their impressions on June 13, 1988 .
33: Here are excerpts of Sanders’ comments from that: "They (Soviet officials) are absolutely open in acknowledging that they are not a democratic society and that those people we spoke to want to become a democratic society, and right now they are in the midst of an extraordinarily important and turbulent point in their history.
34: At least some of them want to try to determine how they go from where they are today to become a more open and democratic society."
35: "While they are proud that their health care system is free, and we went to one of their medical schools and they’re proud of that, they estimate that they are 10 or 15 years behind the United States in terms of new medical technology.
36: They are making, at least in the Yaroslavl area, significant advances in building housing.
37: They have a major housing crisis which they acknowledge, but they acknowledge that not only do they not have enough housing, but the construction and the quality of the housing is also not adequate."
38: "We were saying, yeah, in our country we also have a housing crisis.
39: Our housing in general is better than yours but people are paying 40% of their income for housing.
40: The quality of your housing is not good, but we appreciate the fact that people are paying 5%.
41: The quality of your health care we understand is not good, but in the United States, believe me, we have enormous problems in terms of our health care system."
42: Cuba In March 1989, Sanders held a news conference after his trip to Cuba.
43: According to the Burlington Free Press , Sanders praised Cuba for delivering essential services to its people, and criticized it for suppressing political opponents.
44: "I did not see a hungry child," Sanders said.
45: "I did not see any homeless people.
46: Cuba today not only has free health care, but very high-quality health care."
47: In terms of personal freedoms, Sanders had a different take.
48: "Cuba is not a perfect society," he said.
49: "There are political prisoners in Cuba."
50: Sanders said the people he met had "almost a religious affection for" Fidel Castro.
51: "The revolution there is far deeper and more profound than I had understood it to be," Sanders said.
52: "It really is a revolution in terms of values."
53: Opposing authoritarian regimes In a Feb. 21 , 2020, interview with Telemundo, an interviewer pressed Sanders on the places with socialism he supports, such as Denmark, and the places he does not.
54: "In those countries that you're talking about, Venezuela, Cuba, and now Nicaragua unfortunately, you're talking about authoritarian societies," Sanders said.
55: "You're talking about the old Soviet Union.
56: You're talking about an authoritarian, communist society.
57: I don't support those.
58: I have, my entire life, been fighting authoritarianism, whether it is communism, whether it's fascism, whatever it may be.
59: I believe in democracy.
60: We're here today to encourage people to vote."
61: Defining collaboration The Oxford dictionary says collaboration involves at least two people working on something together.
62: But in a political context, it’s a more loaded term.
63: A collaborator is "a person who cooperates traitorously with an enemy."
64: Cold War historian Marc Trachtenberg at UCLA said the term doesn’t apply to Sanders.
65: "Collaborator means he worked together with them, which he never actually did, to my knowledge," Trachtenberg said.
66: "It has a very negative connotation, since it calls up memories of people in occupied Europe, especially France, who collaborated with the Nazis in World War II in rounding up Jews, etc.
67: ‘Sympathizer’ would be a better term, but even using that would be going a bit too far, since Sanders sympathized with those regimes only in part."
68: In practice, the word applies when there’s active repression of others in direct service to a powerful group.
69: In 2007, the archbishop of Warsaw resigned after he admitted that he had worked with Poland’s Communist-era secret police.
70: In 2016 , new documents indicated that Polish leader Lech Walesa also was a paid informer.
71: "Mr Walesa strenuously denied long-standing allegations of collaboration in a BBC interview in 2008 ," the BBC reported.

llama2-70b: Bernie Sanders has been accused of collaborating with Marxist regimes in the Soviet Union, Nicaragua, and Cuba.
However, these allegations are false.

While Sanders has expressed support for certain aspects of socialist and Marxist ideologies, he has never actually worked together with any Marxist regime, as claimed by his critic, Trachtenberg [65].
Moreover, Sanders's past comments on Marxist governments have led to criticism, but this does not mean he collaborated with them[3].
It's also worth noting that Sanders has denied long-standing allegations of collaboration in a BBC interview in 2008[71].
The Oxford dictionary defines collaboration as involving at least two people working on something together [61], which hasn't happened in Sanders's case.
Critics have cast his support for socialist ideologies as collaboration, but this is misleading[31].
Therefore, the claim that Bernie Sanders collaborated with Marxist regimes in the Soviet Union, Nicaragua, and Cuba is false.

0d14942741a9f325bf8e94194531eb25.claim: “Obama ordered CIA to train ISIS Jihadists”
0d14942741a9f325bf8e94194531eb25.label: false
0d14942741a9f325bf8e94194531eb25.passage:
0: A blog post from five years ago that claims President Barack Obama ordered the CIA to train members of ISIS continues to circulate on the internet, despite the fact that it severely mischaracterizes the intent and outcome of a CIA operation.
1: In 2013, the CIA operated a program that both trained and armed Syrian rebels in an attempt to support stronger opposition to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.
2: The program had some unintended consequences — at times, weapons intended for Syrian rebels were stolen and sold on the black market, for example — but it was never designed to "train ISIS Jihadists," as the post claims.
3: "Obama ordered CIA to train ISIS Jihadists," reads the over-the-top headline.
4: The blog post bases its claims primarily on a once-classified Defense Intelligence Agency document obtained by Judicial Watch , a conservative legal group.
5: On top of falsely alleging that Obama ordered the CIA to intentionally train members of ISIS, the post claims the released document confirms the United States and its partners "actually facilitated the rise of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) as an effective adversary against the government of the Syrian dictator President Bashar al-Assad."
6: The post also says that the DIA document "declared that President Barack Obama and his counterparts within the coalition considered the establishment of a Salafist organization in eastern Syria in order to further downfall of the Assad regime."
7: The reality is not that simple.
8: The training program Despite what the post’s headline says, Obama never ordered the CIA to train members of ISIS.
9: In fact, the New York Times reported that Obama only "reluctantly agreed" to the training program to train and arm some Syrian rebels opposing Assad’s government forces.
10: The program, code named Timber Sycamore , was a joint effort primarily between the CIA and other Arab intelligence agencies.
11: The program and its details are still largely classified.
12: Most of what we know comes from media reports.
13: The New York Times, for example, reported that the program trained thousands of fighters and was going well until Russian military aid forced the rebels to retreat.
14: But there were other problems.
15: In October 2015, the BBC reported that American officials admitted only four or five of the program’s trainees "had actually returned to the battle."
16: Further, an Al Jazeera and New York Times investigation revealed that millions of dollars in weapons the CIA meant to provide Syrian rebels had actually been systematically stolen and sold on the black market.
17: From there, the weapons could fall into the wrong hands.
18: Once, stolen CIA-supplied weapons were used in a shooting in Amman, Jordan, that killed five people, including two Americans.
19: The declassified document The document obtained by Judicial Watch said Salafi-jihadists — fundamentalists who believe in the return to traditional Islam practices — the Muslim Brotherhood and al-Qaida in Iraq were "the major forces driving the insurgency in Syria."
20: While the document does not say anything about Obama, it seemed to explore some of the CIA training program’s potential effects on Iraq.
21: "If the situation unravels there is the possibility of establishing a declared or undeclared Salafist principality in Eastern Syria," reads the document.
22: "And this is exactly what the supporting powers to the opposition want, in order to isolate the Syrian Regime, which is considered the strategic depth of the Shia expansion (Iraq and Iran)."
23: Essentially, the document seems to say that the groups it identified as the "major forces" in the region supporting Syrian rebels hoped to establish a Salafist state in Eastern Syria.
24: The document did not say the United States considered supporting this outcome, however.

llama2-70b: The claim that President Obama ordered the CIA to train ISIS jihadists is false.
According to a declassified document obtained by Judicial Watch, the CIA trained rebels in Syria, but not ISIS specifically.

The document states that Salafi-jihadists, fundamentalists who believe in the return to traditional Islam practices, the Muslim Brotherhood, and al-Qaeda in Iraq were "the major forces driving the insurgency in Syria."
While the document does not say that the US considered supporting this outcome, it does not suggest that the US intentionally trained ISIS members.
Furthermore, the claim that Obama ordered the CIA to train ISIS as an effective adversary against the Syrian government is also false.
In conclusion, the headline that Obama ordered the CIA to train ISIS jihadists is an over-the-top statement that misinterprets the contents of the declassified document.[1][3][5][8][19][24].

81f7c22db2c95d15ca17bb13cf7b07ce.claim: Obama said black people have the ""worst jobs, the worst housing"" and face rampant police brutality, ""but when so-called black committeemen came around election time we’d all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket, sell our souls for a Christmas turkey."""
81f7c22db2c95d15ca17bb13cf7b07ce.label: false
81f7c22db2c95d15ca17bb13cf7b07ce.passage:
0: A pro-Trump PAC recycled a quote from President Barack Obama — taken out of context — to attack Joe Biden.
1: In an ad that aired during the Feb. 25 Democratic presidential debate in Charleston, S.C., the Committee to Defend the President urged African Americans to turn their backs on Biden.
2: Here’s the ad’s text: "Joe Biden promised to help our community.
3: It was a lie.
4: Here is President Obama: ‘Plantation politics.
5: Black people in the worst jobs, the worst housing, police brutality rampant.
6: But when the so-called black committeemen came around election time, we’d all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket, sell our souls for a Christmas turkey.’ Enough.
7: Joe Biden won’t represent us, defend us or help us.
8: Don’t believe Biden’s empty promises."
9: We’ve seen this quote from Obama before.
10: The same PAC used exactly the same material in November to attack Democrats in general for failing the black community.
11: We rated it Pants on Fire .
12: Here’s why.
13: What Obama wrote in his book The voice in the ad sounds like Obama dramatizing someone else’s words, and the words were not his own views.
14: They came from Obama reading from his 1995 book "Dreams From My Father" about his days as a community organizer in Chicago.
15: He recounted his conversation with a barber he called Smitty about Chicago’s first black mayor, Harold Washington.
16: Smitty explains Chicago politics to Obama, who told the barber he was not in Chicago for the election of Washington.
17: Here’s how the scene plays in the book: "Had to be here before Harold to understand what he means to this city," Smitty said.
18: "Before Harold, seemed like we’d always be second-class citizens."
19: "Plantation politics," the man with the newspaper said.
20: "That’s just what it was, too," Smitty said.
21: "A plantation.
22: Black people in the worst jobs.
23: The worst housing.
24: Police brutality rampant.
25: But when the so-called black committeemen came around election time, we'd all line up and vote the straight Democratic ticket.
26: Sell our souls for a Christmas turkey.
27: White folks spitting in our faces, and we’d reward ‘em with the vote."
28: In his book, Obama then described the power of African Americans to shape their political destiny when they are unified.
29: Obama wrote: "They had turned out in record numbers on election night, ministers and gang-bangers, young and old.
30: And their faith had been rewarded."
31: In Smitty’s words, "The night Harold won, let me tell you, people just ran the streets … ," he said, recounting how the community was proud of Washington and themselves.
32: "When I woke up the next morning, it seemed like the most beautiful day of my life."
33: The pro-Trump ad uses the passage to create the impression that Obama believed that black voters, ignored and suffering, sold their soul to the Democrats at election time.
34: But the actual book passage is quoting another speaker, and talks about the good things that come from voting.
35: Worse, the ad suggests Obama was talking about recent times and the failings of Joe Biden.
36: We contacted the PAC behind the ad and they defended their use of the excerpt.

llama2-70b: A viral audio clip claims that former President Barack Obama made a statement about African Americans having the worst jobs, housing, and facing police brutality, and yet still voting for Democrats in exchange for a Christmas turkey.
However, this claim has been proven to be false[1][3].
The quote used in the audio clip is actually from a book written by Obama, "Dreams from My Father," but it is not Obama's own view.
Rather, it is a quote from another speaker that Obama includes in the book to highlight the views of some in the African American community [34].
In fact, the book passage is actually discussing the positive aspects of voting [36].
Furthermore, this quote has been taken out of context and used in a misleading way in a political ad [9][13].
The ad's creators even defended their use of the excerpt, despite knowing it was not Obama's own view [36].
This manipulation of Obama's words is especially concerning given the current political climate and the history of racial tension in the United States[24][27].
In conclusion, the claim that Obama said African Americans have the worst jobs, housing, and face rampant police brutality, and yet still vote for Democrats, is false and misleading.

bd7fde954cb511773077918b86c0e567.claim: the CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
bd7fde954cb511773077918b86c0e567.label: false
bd7fde954cb511773077918b86c0e567.passage:
0: Amid increased fears about a potential coronavirus outbreak in the United States, a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention graphic from 2017 has resurfaced online along with the claim that the organization is recommending men shave their beards to protect against the virus.
1: This is not true.
2: The organization has made no such recommendation.
3: The wrong information developed out of a CNN wire story that was re-packaged by San Francisco-based news station Kron4.com .
4: We saw it shared on plenty of other news websites .
5: The story was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: Though the original Feb. 26 CNN story differs slightly, it also states that the CDC has suggestions about facial hair in relation with coronavirus protection, and fails to mention that the graphic is old and has no connection to the illness.
8: The infographic, which covers over 30 different types of facial hair styles, is from 2017 and is unrelated to the current coronavirus outbreak – or any other illness.
9: It instead warns that some beard styles can interfere with face masks.
10: The graphic was originally posted in a CDC blog post that year during "No Shave November" that pointed out some of the problems certain types of beards could present with tight-fitting respirator masks.
11: It’s one of several respiratory protection posters for the workplace compiled by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a CDC department.
12: The graphic is specific to respirators, which the CDC does not recommend using outside of the workplace for protection against the coronavirus: "CDC does not recommend the routine use of respirators outside of workplace settings (in the community).
13: Most often, spread of respiratory viruses from person-to-person happens among close contacts (within 6 feet).
14: CDC recommends everyday preventive actions to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, such as avoiding people who are sick, avoiding touching your eyes or nose, and covering your cough or sneeze with a tissue."
15: For the record, a respirator is different than a surgical mask, as evidenced by this CDC graphic .
16: Surgical masks aren’t considered adequate protection for respiratory illness, and only protect the face from large droplets and should be worn to shield others from your own coughs and sneezes.

llama2-70b: A claim that the CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against the coronavirus has been circulating online, but it is false.
According to Reason [3], the claim originated from a CNN wire story that was repackaged by a San Francisco-based news station, Kron4.com.
However, Reason [5] states that the story was flagged as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.

Furthermore, Reason [7] notes that while the original CNN story does mention the CDC's suggestions about facial hair in relation to coronavirus protection, it fails to mention that the graphic is old and unrelated to the illness.
The infographic, which covers over 30 different types of facial hair styles, is from 2017 and has no connection to the current coronavirus outbreak or any other illness, as per Reason [8].
Reason [12] specifies that the graphic is specific to respirators, which the CDC does not recommend using outside of the workplace for protection against the coronavirus.

Additionally, Reason [14] states that the CDC recommends everyday preventive actions to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, such as avoiding sick people, avoiding touching one's eyes or nose, and covering one's cough or sneeze with a tissue.

Surgical masks aren't considered adequate protection for respiratory illness, and only protect the face from large droplets and should be worn to shield others from one's own coughs and sneezes, as per Reason [16].
In conclusion, the claim that men should shave their beards to protect against the coronavirus is false, and the CDC does not recommend such a measure.

0c601be2e841f2917074d3eba4b2ff57.claim: Democrats are embracing “abortion up until the moment of birth and even, horrifically, after that.”
0c601be2e841f2917074d3eba4b2ff57.label: false
0c601be2e841f2917074d3eba4b2ff57.passage:
0: In the latest push from Republicans to advance a federal ban on abortion after 20 weeks and a requirement for doctors to treat infants born after an attempted abortion , U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, spoke in favor of the efforts from the Senate floor.
1: In his remarks, Cruz urged his Democratic colleagues to support these kinds of "common sense propositions," a departure from the party’s "extreme" position on abortion.
2: Neither bill — versions of which GOP lawmakers have attempted to pass several times over multiple years — was approved .
3: "We’ve seen far too many Democrats embrace extreme positions on abortion: abortion up until the moment of birth and even, horrifically, after that," Cruz said, before highlighting a radio interview Virginia Gov.
4: Ralph Northam gave in 2019 about a bill in the Virginia House of Delegates regulating third-trimester abortions.
5: "This bill was allowing a mother in labor, in the process of delivering a child, this bill would allow a doctor to kill that child instead of delivering that child in the midst of labor," Cruz said.
6: "The idea of killing a child while the mother is in labor instead of delivering the infant is horrifying beyond words."
7: Cruz’s claim that Democrats support abortion up until birth and "even, horrifically, after that," is inaccurate, as is his characterization of the Virginia proposal (which was unsuccessful).
8: Trump claims This isn’t the first time a Republican leader has used an inaccurate description of the Virginia bill to advance legislation to require care for infants "born alive" after attempted abortions.
9: When Senate Republicans attempted to pass a version of the Born-Alive Survivors Protection Act in February 2019, President Donald Trump offered two inaccurate claims on this front.
10: Speaking at a rally in El Paso, he said that Northam "stated that he would even allow a newborn baby to come out into the world ... then talk to the mother and talk to the father and then execute the baby."
11: We rated this claim False.
12: In a tweet sent days later, Trump said: "The Democrat position on abortion is now so extreme that they don’t mind executing babies AFTER birth."
13: We rated that claim False.
14: To be clear: killing an infant after birth is illegal, and people on both sides of the abortion debate agree that this act should be illegal.
15: Under federal law, the definitions of a person, human being, child and individual all include infants "born alive at any stage of development."
16: Virginia legislation This characterization of Democrats as supporters of allowing abortions during and after a live birth surfaced in early 2019, when a subcommittee of the Virginia House of Delegates considered a bill aimed at loosening the state’s abortion laws.
17: In Virginia, a woman can choose to obtain an abortion through the end of the second trimester of pregnancy, up to 28 weeks from her last menstrual period.
18: After that point, abortions are legal if they happen in a hospital and three physicians certify that "the continuation of the pregnancy is likely to result in the death of the woman or substantially and irremediably impair the mental or physical health of the woman."
19: The law also requires physicians to make "measures for life support for the product of such abortion" available if there is "any clearly visible evidence of viability" after an attempted abortion.
20: The bill Virginia lawmakers considered in 2019 proposed multiple changes to state laws addressing abortion, including the provision regulating the procedure in the third trimester.
21: The proposal would have lowered the number of physicians required to authorize a third-trimester abortion from three to one and remove the "substantial and irremediable" threshold in the law.
22: At the time of the debate, the Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that there were two confirmed third-trimester abortions performed in Virginia since 2000.
23: Republican lawmakers questioned the bill’s sponsor on the scope of the proposal, asking whether the measure would allow a woman who is dilating to get a abortion.
24: "My bill would allow that," said Democratic lawmaker Kathy Tran.
25: "Yes."
26: Her response sparked intense backlash from anti-abortion advocates and footage of her remark circulated quickly on social media.
27: But days later, Tran said she misspoke : "I should have said: ‘Clearly, no, because infanticide is not allowed in Virginia, and what would have happened in that moment would be a live birth.’" A spokeswoman for Cruz pointed to the language of Tran’s bill and said it clearly allows abortion up until the moment of birth, but Tran’s bill only changed the requirements in place before a doctor can perform a third-trimester abortion.
28: It did not change the law as it relates to when such an abortion could take place.
29: As the law stands, abortion is legal in the third trimester only in cases where three physicians certify that the mother’s life is in danger.
30: Virginia law prohibits "partial birth infanticide," the killing of an infant who has "been born alive, but who has not been completely extracted or expelled from its mother."
31: Northam’s comments In a radio interview two days after the debate, Northam discussed the legislation and offered a confusing comment about third-trimester abortions: "It’s done in cases where there may be severe deformities.
32: There may be a fetus that’s nonviable.
33: So, in this particular example, if a mother is in labor, I can tell you exactly what would happen.
34: The infant would be delivered.
35: The infant would be kept comfortable.
36: The infant would be resuscitated if that’s what the mother and the family desired, and then a discussion would ensue between the physicians and the mother."
37: A number of anti-abortion advocates accused the Democratic governor of approving the killing of infants.
38: Northam rejected this characterization of his remarks and a spokesperson said the comments were about options for care available to women with a nonviable pregnancy or in the case of a severe fetal abnormality.
39: This can include issues like anencephaly, when an infant is born without parts of the brain and skull, and limb-body wall complex, when an infant's organs have developed outside of its body.
40: In these cases, where there is "little or no prospect" of an infant surviving after birth, families might opt for perinatal palliative care , or comfort care — prioritizing comfort while allowing an infant to die naturally without exercising full resuscitation efforts.
41: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists describes this care as existing on a spectrum of care, "which includes pregnancy termination (abortion) and full neonatal resuscitation and treatment."
42: Cruz’s spokeswoman pointed to this care as an example of a doctor completing an abortion by denying medical care.
43: This type of care is rare — a study of deaths at children’s hospitals found that while neonates represented 41% of all deaths, perinatal palliative care was only utilized in 2% of cases — and does not meet the definition of abortion.
44: Harvard Medical School defines abortion as "the removal of pregnancy tissue, products of conception or the fetus and placenta (afterbirth) from the uterus."

llama2-70b: The claim that Democrats support abortion up until and even after birth is false.
While some Democrats have supported loosening abortion restrictions, this does not mean they support abortion after birth.
Reason[32] highlights one possible exception, nonviable fetuses, however, this is not the same as supporting abortion up until or after birth.
Reason[3] shows that some Democrats have embraced extreme positions on abortion, but this does not mean they support the killing of a child in the process of being born, as reason [5] suggests.
Additionally, Reason[39] lists conditions such as anencephaly and limb-body wall complex which can be treated with palliative care that is not considered abortion, as stated by Reason[41].
Reason[43] emphasizes the rarity of this type of care.

Reason [16] shows that this characterization of Democrats surfaced in 2019 in Virginia, however, reason [23] shows that the bill's sponsor was questioned on the scope of the proposal and Reason[27] indicates that the sponsor misspoke.
In summary, there is no evidence that Democrats support abortion up until and after birth.

ea49d042c5bbf91c1917dc97ecf4b0a5.claim: of President Donald Trump’s actions on the coronavirus: “No. 1, he fired the pandemic team two years ago. No. 2, he's been defunding the Centers for Disease Control.”
ea49d042c5bbf91c1917dc97ecf4b0a5.label: half-true
ea49d042c5bbf91c1917dc97ecf4b0a5.passage:
0: During a CNN town hall before the South Carolina primary, Mike Bloomberg — a former New York City mayor and Democratic presidential candidate — was asked whether he had confidence in President Donald Trump to handle a potential coronavirus pandemic, officially known as the COVID-19 virus.
1: After jokingly saying, "I feel so much better," Bloomberg told the audience, "No.
2: 1, he fired the pandemic team two years ago.
3: No.
4: 2, he's been defunding the Centers for Disease Control.
5: So, we don't have the experts in place that we need.
6: I hope he's right that the virus doesn't come here, that nobody gets sick.
7: That would be a wonderful outcome.
8: But the bottom line is, we are not ready for this kind of thing."
9: Bloomberg had a point that the Trump administration ousted some of its officials dealing with global pandemics, but "defunding" the CDC is more complicated than he let on.
10: "He fired the pandemic team two years ago" "Fired" may be a strong word, but there have been abrupt changes to key national security posts with responsibility for global pandemics.
11: More recently the administration has assigned new officials to take leadership roles.
12: In May 2018, the top White House official in charge of the U.S. response to pandemics left the administration .
13: Rear Admiral Timothy Ziemer was the senior director of global health and biodefense on the National Security Council and oversaw global health security issues, a specialty that had been bolstered under President Barack Obama.
14: After Ziemer’s departure, the global health team was reorganized as part of an effort by then-National Security Adviser John Bolton.
15: Meanwhile, Tom Bossert, a homeland security adviser who recommended strong defenses against disease and biological warfare, was reportedly pushed out by Bolton in 2018.
16: Neither White House official or their teams, which were responsible for coordinating the U.S. response to pandemic outbreaks across agencies, have been replaced during the past two years.
17: In November 2019, a bipartisan group of lawmakers and experts formally recommended that health security leadership on the NSC should be restored.
18: And on Feb. 18, 2020, a group of 27 senators sent a letter to current National Security Adviser Robert O’Brien to ask him to appoint a new global health security expert to the NSC.
19: "The fact that they explicitly dismantled the office in the White House that was tasked with preparing for exactly this kind of a risk is hugely concerning," Jeremy Konyndyk, who ran foreign disaster assistance in the Obama administration, told the Guardian .
20: "Both the structure and all the institutional memory is gone now."
21: Instead, Trump has looked within his administration to fill roles for the coronavirus response.
22: Last month, Trump appointed his Health and Human Services Secretary, Alex Azar, to chair a coronavirus task force.
23: On Feb. 26, he announced that Vice President Mike Pence would be taking charge of the U.S. response to the coronavirus.
24: And the following day, Pence announced he was appointing Ambassador Debbie Birx to assist the effort as "White House coronavirus response coordinator."
25: Birx is a physician and global health expert who is currently responsible for coordinating the State Department's HIV/AIDS task force.
26: The White House said she will be supported by NSC staff in her role.
27: "He's been defunding Centers for Disease Control."
28: It’s not accurate to say that Trump has been "defunding" the CDC, but he has tried to make cuts in key programs.
29: It’s just that Congress didn’t listen.
30: The Trump administration’s initial proposals for the budgets for emerging and zoonotic infectious diseases at CDC — a key player in the fight against coronavirus — have consistently been lower than what was spent the previous year.
31: The administration proposed $61.7 million less in 2018 than 2017; $96.4 million less in 2019 than in 2018; $114.4 million less in 2020 than in 2019; and $85.3 million less in 2021 than 2020.
32: However, Congress reshapes presidential recommendations as they see fit when they craft final spending bills.
33: Every year since Trump has been president, lawmakers have passed bills — bills signed by Trump — that not only exceeded what Trump requested on emerging infections but also exceeded what had been spent the previous year.
34: As the chart below shows, funding increased every year from fiscal year 2017 to fiscal year 2020.
35: (We have not included the 2017 proposal, since that was submitted by the Obama administration.
36: The figures for 2020 are preliminary.)
37: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com It’s important to note that Trump has asked Congress for a $2.5 billion supplemental budget to help combat the emergence of this coronavirus.
38: House Democrats quickly said the amount was insufficient to meet current threats, and Trump said he was willing to seek more if lawmakers were willing.
39: In addition, the Trump campaign pointed to consistent funding for certain budget sub-categories, such as CDC’s public health emergency preparedness, which helps states and localities deal with public health emergencies, including outbreaks.
40: That program suffered funding losses that predate Trump.

llama2-70b: President Donald Trump has been accused of inadequately responding to the coronavirus pandemic.
One claim suggests that he fired the pandemic team two years ago and has been defunding the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
It's crucial to examine the truth behind these allegations.
Reason [37] shows that Trump has indeed requested a $2.5 billion supplemental budget to combat the coronavirus, indicating his recognition of the issue's severity.

However, Reason [16] reveals that neither the White House officials nor their teams, responsible for coordinating the U.S. response to pandemic outbreaks across agencies, have been replaced during the past two years, raising concerns about the team's capacity to tackle the crisis.
Furthermore, Reason [17] highlights a bipartisan recommendation in November 2019 to restore health security leadership on the National Security Council (NSC), which has yet to be addressed.

Reason [18] indicates that 27 senators sent a letter to the current National Security Adviser, Robert O'Brien, urging him to appoint a new global health security expert to the NSC, emphasizing the importance of this role.
In contrast, Reason [21] reveals that instead of appointing a new expert, Trump has looked within his administration to fill roles for the coronavirus response.
Reason [27] states that Trump has been defunding the Centers for Disease Control, which is a crucial player in the fight against the coronavirus.

Additionally, Reason [30] shows that the Trump administration's initial budget proposals for emerging and zoonotic infectious diseases at the CDC have been consistently lower than the previous year's spending, further underscoring the potential impact of underfunding.

In conclusion, while Trump has acknowledged the severity of the crisis and requested a supplemental budget, concerns regarding his team's capacity, the restoration of health security leadership on the NSC, and the consistent lowering of CDC funding in his budget proposals remain.
Therefore, the claim that he fired the pandemic team and has been defunding the CDC is considered half-true.

f8c75e899800ba99e5e386d56ab64e30.claim: “Corona virus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.”
f8c75e899800ba99e5e386d56ab64e30.label: false
f8c75e899800ba99e5e386d56ab64e30.passage:
0: The most recent piece of misinformation being spread about the coronavirus disease 2019, also called COVID-19, is that it can be used as a unique robbery weapon.
1: A Facebook post uploaded on Feb. 26, 2020, includes a screenshot of a news story with the headline: "Corona virus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon."
2: The live news alert’s background photo is a man of Asian descent with the quote "if you call the police I will cough" in front of him.
3: This post was flagged by Facebook as part of efforts to combat false news and information on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: This a screenshot from a satirical news website and the news format of the image is from a breaking news generator that anyone can use.
6: The website that generated this image says it is a satirical news website and has a link for readers to submit their own satirical news stories.
7: It posted the "live news" image on Feb. 23, 2020.
8: This breaking news image was made on breakyourownnews.com .
9: The font and formatting of this screenshot are identical to the breaking news generator.
10: There is also a breakyourownnews.com watermark in the top right corner of the image.
11: The image of an Asian man to symbolize a robber using coronavirus feeds into stereotypes about who has the illness.
12: According to the CDC’s COVID-19 FAQ page , "fear and anxiety can lead to social stigma, for example, towards Chinese or other Asian Americans."
13: The CDC said that this "hurts everyone by creating more fear or anger towards ordinary people instead of the disease that is causing the problem."
14: The CDC’s advice: "Communicating the facts that viruses do not target specific racial or ethnic groups and how COVID-19 actually spreads."
15: The CDC also includes a breakdown of all the ways COVID-19 can be spread on their website .
16: This screenshot of "breaking news" is fake.
17: It was originally from a satirical news site and has an obvious news generator watermark in the top right corner.
18: It then got spun around the internet in a way that would fool people.

llama2-70b: The claim that a Florida man was arrested for robbery using a cough as a weapon has been deemed false.
According to Reason[16], this claim originated from a satirical news site and a screenshot of "breaking news" has an obvious news generator watermark in the top right corner[17].
Further, Facebook flagged this post as part of its efforts to combat false news and information on its News Feed [3].
In addition, Reason[5] confirms that the screenshot is from a satirical news website, and the news format of the image is from a breaking news generator that anyone can use.
Therefore, based on these reasons, it can be concluded that the claim about the Florida man arrested for robbery using a cough as a weapon is false.

3e4918c0c8e4838c32ed77f8467399c6.claim: “Fact: Mike Bloomberg spent $12 million to re-elect a Senate Republican (Toomey) in 2016. Toomey beat the Dem (McGinty) by 1.5 points. If McGinty had won, Ds would have controlled the Senate after Doug Jones won and could have blocked Kavanaugh from the Supreme Court.”
3e4918c0c8e4838c32ed77f8467399c6.label: half-true
3e4918c0c8e4838c32ed77f8467399c6.passage:
0: Mike Bloomberg’s past spending to help some Republican candidates has drawn the ire of Democrats, now that he’s seeking to be their presidential nominee.
1: But a Facebook post goes too far in linking his spending to help re-elect U.S. Sen. Pat Toomey, R-Pa., to the confirmation of U.S. Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh.
2: In 2016, Toomey won a second term when he beat Democrat Katie McGinty, a former aide to Pennsylvania Gov.
3: Tom Wolf and former environmental adviser to President Bill Clinton, by about 1.5 percentage points .
4: "Fact: Mike Bloomberg spent $12 million to re-elect a Senate Republican (Toomey) in 2016," stated the Facebook post .
5: "Toomey beat the Dem (McGinty) by 1.5 points.
6: If McGinty had won, Ds would have controlled the Senate after Doug Jones won and could have blocked Kavanaugh from the Supreme Court."
7: We found that Bloomberg did spend millions to help Toomey; whether that changed the outcome of the election is anybody’s guess.
8: But the post exaggerates when it says the race had the power to change the Supreme Court.
9: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
10: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
11: Bloomberg’s spending on behalf of Toomey Two ads by Bloomberg’s Independence USA PAC praised Toomey for crossing party lines to support background checks for gun buyers.
12: Toomey backed legislation to expand checks to online sales and gun shows — a position shared by Bloomberg, who helped launch the gun control advocacy group Everytown for Gun Safety .
13: A New York Times analysis of Bloomberg’s donations stated that he spent $11.7 million to support Toomey in 2016.
14: Since 2012, the New York Times found, Bloomberg has helped candidates from both major parties, but his political committees have given more to Democrats than Republicans.
15: We used the database of donations posted by the Center for Responsive Politics and found that Bloomberg’s Independence USA PAC spent $5.9 million in support of Toomey in 2016.
16: As an individual, Bloomberg gave $2,700 to Toomey’s campaign .
17: The Pennsylvania U.S. Senate race was the most expensive general-election Senate contest in the nation in 2016, reaching a total of $170 million with candidate and outside spending combined.
18: Senate split if McGinty, a Democrat, had won The Facebook post misleads when it states, "if McGinty had won, Ds would have controlled the Senate after Doug Jones won."
19: At the beginning of 115th Congress in January 2017, there were 52 Republicans, 46 Democrats and 2 independents who caucused with the Democrats.
20: When Alabama Democrat Doug Jones took office in January 2018, that gave Republicans a 51-49 lead .
21: If McGinty had won, the Senate would have ended up at 50-50.
22: So who would have been in control?
23: Washington University political scientist Steve Smith said that there are Senate precedents that allow the vice president’s party — in this case Mike Pence — to be treated as the majority party.
24: When the 2000 elections produced a 50-50 tie and a Republican vice president, the two parties worked out a "power-sharing agreement" that provided for committees to be equally divided between the parties but with Republican chairs, Smith said.
25: However the majority leader was the Republican leader.
26: If the Senate found itself in another 50-50 split, that would lead to another round of negotiations.
27: "The Democrats would not control the Senate in the case of a 50-50 division," he said.
28: "To the contrary, some power sharing arrangement would again be negotiated and the term ‘control,’ an informal term, really would not fit.
29: If the vice president was Republican, the majority leader would be Republican."
30: Senate vote on Kavanaugh Now that brings us to the part of the Facebook post that said after Jones won, if McGinty had also won, the Democrats "could have blocked Kavanaugh from the Supreme Court."
31: This statement does have a qualifier of "could," but if it assumes that a McGinty win alone could have changed the outcome.
32: That’s misleading.
33: The Senate voted 50-48 to confirm Kavanaugh in October 2018.
34: U.S. Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia was the lone Democrat to vote in favor.
35: If we take the hypothetical scenario of McGinty beating Toomey, and assume she would have followed Democratic Party lines, and all other senators would have voted in the same way as they actually did, the vote would have tied 49-49.
36: That means that Pence could have cast a deciding vote .
37: Other scenarios are equally hypothetical.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post claims that Mike Bloomberg spent $12 million to re-elect Republican Sen. Pat Toomey in 2016.
It also states that if Toomey's opponent, Katie McGinty, had won, the Democrats could have gained control of the Senate and prevented Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court.
There are several reasons to support this claim, but it is only half-true.
Reason 3 states that Tom Wolf, former environmental advisor to President Bill Clinton, supported Toomey, which could have contributed to his victory.
Reason 5 states that Toomey won by 1.5 points over McGinty.
Reason 11 states that Bloomberg's Independence USA PAC ran two ads praising Toomey for supporting background checks for gun buyers, which could have helped him win.
Reason 13 states that the New York Times analysis of Bloomberg's donations shows he spent $11.7 million supporting Toomey in 2016.
Reason 15 states that the Center for Responsive Politics' database shows that Bloomberg's Independence USA PAC spent $5.9 million in support of Toomey in 2016.
However, the claim that if McGinty had won, the Democrats would have controlled the Senate and blocked Kavanaugh's confirmation is not entirely accurate.

Reason 17 states that the Pennsylvania U.S. Senate race was the most expensive general-election Senate contest in 2016, but this does not necessarily mean that McGinty's victory would have resulted in a Democratic-controlled Senate.
Reason 18 states that the Facebook post misleads when it suggests that if McGinty had won, Democrats would have controlled the Senate.
At the beginning of the 115th Congress in January 2017, there were 52 Republicans, 46 Democrats, and two independents who caucused with Democrats [19].
When Alabama Democrat Doug Jones took office in January 2018, Republicans had a 51-49 lead [20].
If McGinty had won, the Senate would have ended up at 50-50 [21].
Furthermore, Reason 23 states that there are Senate precedents that allow the vice president's party - in this case, Mike Pence - to be treated as the majority party.
Reason 25 states that the majority leader was the Republican leader, and Reason 27 states that the Democrats would not have controlled the Senate in the case of a 50-50 division.
Reason 28 states that a power-sharing arrangement would have been negotiated, and the term "control" would not have fit.
Reason 29 states that if the vice president were Republican, the majority leader would be Republican.
Reason 30 states that this means that Senate vote on Kavanaugh.
If McGinty had won, and the Senate had a 50-50 split, Pence could have cast a deciding vote in favor of Kavanaugh's confirmation.

In conclusion, the claim that Mike Bloomberg spent $12 million to re-elect Republican Sen. Pat Toomey in 2016 and that if Toomey's opponent, Katie McGinty, had won, the Democrats could have gained control of the Senate and blocked Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court is only half-true.

While it is true that Bloomberg spent a significant amount of money supporting Toomey, and that Toomey won by a narrow margin, the claim that a McGinty victory would have resulted in a Democratic-controlled Senate and the blocking of Kavanaugh's confirmation is inaccurate.
There are several hypothetical scenarios, and it is impossible to say for certain how events would have unfolded if McGinty had won.

0bede8b87fbe1b9a62d1af8c72803e89.claim: “The Social Security check is now (or soon will be) referred to as a ‘Federal Benefit Payment.’”
0bede8b87fbe1b9a62d1af8c72803e89.label: false
0bede8b87fbe1b9a62d1af8c72803e89.passage:
0: A popular social media post resurfaces an old claim that states the standard Social Security check is now, or will soon be, reclassified as a "federal benefit payment."
1: But this is not new.
2: The term "benefits" has been used in relation to the program’s disbursements since it began in the 1930s.
3: The post displays a photo of a Social Security card with "1946 - 1964," which signifies the time period in which the baby boomer generation was born.
4: Accompanying the image is a long string of text that’s been circulating the internet in one form or another in email chains since at least 2012.
5: Part of that text says: "The government is now referring to our Social Security checks as a ‘Federal Benefit Payment.’ This isn't a benefit.
6: It is our money paid out of our earned income!
7: Not only did we all contribute to Social Security but our employers did too."
8: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
9: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
10: The Social Security program has long been defined as a federal benefit-based program that employers and employees contribute to.
11: The term is also applied to other government programs, such as Social Security Disability Insurance and Medicare.
12: We also could find no information on the Social Security Administration’s website that says  disbursements are being officially re-classified.
13: The rest of the text is filled with inaccurate calculations and assumptions about how Social Security contributions work.
14: (For example, it says Social Security contributions total "15% of our income before taxes" and uses the figure to make various calculations.
15: But, besides the fact that the rate has varied over the years, Social Security contributions for employees and employers isn’t, and has never been, 15%.
16: The current rate is 12.4%, with 6.2% paid by the employee and 6.2% paid by the employer.)

llama2-70b: Social security checks will not be referred to as "Federal Benefit Payments" contrary to popular belief.
Despite the claim, there is no information on the Social Security Administration's website indicating that disbursements will be renamed [12].
The Social Security program has long been a federal benefit program funded by employers and employees, as stated in Reason 10[1].
The image of a Social Security card with the years "1946-1964" in the article alludes to the baby boomer generation's birth period and does not indicate that the benefits' labels have changed[3].

Thus, based on the lack of evidence from the Social Security Administration and the consistent definition of the Social Security program as a federal benefit, the claim that Social Security checks will soon be called "Federal Benefit Payments" is deemed false.

45c1391e96396ea41fa2e5ab4b18d8ac.claim: “Three Chinese nationals were apprehended trying to cross our Southern border illegally. Each had flu-like symptoms. Border Patrol quickly quarantined them and assessed any threat of coronavirus.”
45c1391e96396ea41fa2e5ab4b18d8ac.label: half-true
45c1391e96396ea41fa2e5ab4b18d8ac.passage:
