0: Health officials across the country are bracing for the likely spread of the new coronavirus in the United States, which federal officials have said is inevitable.
1: The new virus was first reported in China, which remains the epicenter of the outbreak.
2: The virus has spread to at least 57 other countries.
3: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has procedures in place when it comes to apprehending individuals attempting to cross the border illegally who may be infected with a communicable disease — regardless of their country of origin.
4: In a Feb. 26 tweet starting with "BREAKING," Charlie Kirk, a conservative pundit who founded Turning Point USA, said three people from China were apprehended after attempting to cross the U.S.-Mexico border and were quarantined after displaying flu-like symptoms.
5: Kirk asked people to retweet his post, which included a call for heightened border security in the face of the new virus.
6: "Three Chinese nationals were apprehended trying to cross our Southern border illegally," he wrote.
7: "Each had flu-like symptoms.
8: Border patrol quickly quarantined them and assessed any threat of Coronavirus.
9: Our weak border is a health risk.
10: Close the border—Build.
11: The.
12: Wall.
13: RT!"
14: Kirk’s tweet gets some things right, but is missing a key detail: All three of the people apprehended by border patrol were medically cleared and returned to the custody of immigration officials.
15: Kirk’s spokesman Andrew Kolvet pointed to a Fox News segment about the apprehensions, which featured an interview with Brandon Judd, president of the National Border Patrol Council.
16: In the clip, Judd says that three Chinese citizens were apprehended in Del Rio and had flu-like symptoms.
17: "Our agents acted like champs, they quarantined them immediately and transferred them to a local hospital," Judd said.
18: "Luckily, they did not have the coronavirus."
19: Details from Border Patrol A Customs and Border Patrol spokesman said agents apprehend approximately five Chinese nationals a day within the agency’s Rio Grande Valley Sector on the Texas-Mexico border, a number that represents "an extremely small percentage of our overall daily apprehension totals."
20: "Although we haven’t encountered any issues to date, we do have measures in place to identify individuals with signs of illness who may be potentially infected with a communicable disease," he said in a statement from the agency.
21: "Individuals identified with symptoms of illness are referred to (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) or local health officials for additional health screening."
22: The agency put this protocol into action on Feb. 10, when agents apprehended three Chinese nationals near Eagle Pass, after they crossed the Rio Grande along the Texas-Mexico border, according to a description of the event provided by the spokesman.
23: The individuals were taken to the Eagle Pass Station, where officials determined that two of the three people had a fever, according to a Border Patrol official.
24: At that point, all three individuals were taken immediately to a local hospital for assessment, before being taken inside the station.
25: All three people were medically cleared for travel and turned over to Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
26: Since the individuals were taken directly to the hospital after a health assessment, they were not placed in quarantine at the Border Patrol station or taken to a designated quarantine station.

llama2-70b: A tweet from Congressman Mark Kirk regarding the apprehension of three Chinese nationals attempting to cross the southern border illegally has been labeled half-true.

Although Judd stated that the agents acted appropriately by immediately quarantining and transferring the individuals to a local hospital [1], it was discovered that the individuals were not placed in quarantine at the Border Patrol station or taken to a designated quarantine station [26].

Instead, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has procedures in place for apprehending individuals attempting to cross the border illegally who may be infected with a communicable disease, regardless of their country of origin [3].
However, Kirk's tweet is missing a key detail, as the flu-like symptoms displayed by the individuals do not necessarily indicate the presence of the coronavirus[14].
Therefore, the claim is considered half-true.

6f9517a56e99c99828fa91f5bcd2d4a8.claim: California has a top income tax rate of 13.3% “and people aren’t leaving.”
6f9517a56e99c99828fa91f5bcd2d4a8.label: half-true
6f9517a56e99c99828fa91f5bcd2d4a8.passage:
0: Illinois Gov.
1: J.B. Pritzker is pinning many of his budget goals for the coming fiscal year on voters approving a ballot measure permitting the state to raise tax rates on high earners.
2: Without approval of the constitutional amendment in November, which would permit Illinois to institute higher rates on those making more than $250,000 a year, the governor’s proposed budget holds back a $1.4 billion revenue boost to education and other state services.
3: In an interview on WTTW the week after Pritzker’s budget address, the chairman of the campaign to pass the ballot measure was asked to defend the tax plan, which opponents say will drive residents and businesses from the state.
4: "I don’t think that there’s any correlation between individuals leaving a state and tax rates," said Quentin Fulks, who chairs the Vote Yes for Fairness campaign and previously worked for Pritzker’s 2018 campaign for governor.
5: Fulks cited the high number of millionaires in California, the nation’s most populous state, and then made a claim that caught our attention.
6: California, he said, "has a top tax rate of 13.3%, which is a pretty high tax rate, and people aren’t leaving."
7: The proposal in Illinois would take the top tax rate to nearly 8%.
8: In raw numbers, California saw more people overall depart for other states during the last year than any other, according to the U.S. Census Bureau .
9: So we decided to find out what Fulks meant when he said "people aren’t leaving" California and whether its highest-in-the-nation top marginal rate specifically has affected its population.
10: Just millionaires — not overall population We’ve fact - checked statements from Illinois politicians on both sides of the debate about how graduated-tax states are faring, including a False claim that New York sent its wealthy fleeing the state after instituting a tax structure requiring them to pay more.
11: Fulks was also talking about top earners, a spokesperson told us.
12: "If you look at Quentin’s answer on WTTW, it’s clear he is referencing those who pay the 13.3% tax rate in California – those making over a million dollars – as those who are not leaving the state," Vote Yes for Fairness spokesperson Lara Sisselman wrote in an email.
13: Fulks’ phrasing on WTTW was less than clear.
14: He was asked about people and businesses leaving the state generally, and did not explicitly state that the wealthy weren’t leaving California.
15: That said, the overall context of his remarks in that portion of the interview do suggest he was referring to those who actually pay the top rate he cited.
16: Even if Fulks had only been speaking about California’s population more generally, he’d have a point when it comes to whether the state’s 2012 tax hike has driven Californians away.
17: More people have left California for elsewhere in the country than moved there from other states in each year since that tax increase.
18: But like Illinois , that’s been the case for decades.
19: California’s overall population has continued to grow due to immigration from abroad and having more births than deaths.
20: California "has suffered domestic migration losses (movement into and out of other parts of the U.S.) since at least 2000 and for some years prior to that," Brookings Institution demographer William Frey wrote in an email, citing an analysis of census estimates he shared with us.
21: Assessing millionaire migration change To Fulks’ point, only the state’s wealthiest pay its top rate — though like Pritzker’s plan, rates also went up to a lesser degree on those making more than $250,000.
22: California did not raise rates on income below that amount.
23: From 2005 to 2012, income over $1 million had been taxed at 10.3% there.
24: So we turned to research assessing the effect the 2012 increase had on migration among those subject to the rate Fulks highlighted.
25: Some of the findings support his case, others do not.
26: His spokesperson cited a finding from a 2018 report by researchers at the Stanford Center on Poverty & Inequality that shows net migration of millionaires overall since 2007 has remained positive.
27: However, the study also found — based on an analysis that compared migration changes with a control group of high earners not subject to the top rate — that the 2012 increase did indeed lead to a small loss of 0.04% of California’s millionaire population.
28: "Our overall conclusion is, yes, millionaires do sometimes move to lower-tax states — as we see for California in 2012," researcher Cristobal Young told us in an email.
29: "In 2012, there was a large tax increase that produced millionaire out-migration — but by an amount that was too small to matter for overall state revenues or tax policy," he said.
30: Using the same set of tax data, researchers at Stanford’s conservative Hoover Institution found a larger increase in the rate of departures among top earners after 2012.
31: Their report defined a departing taxpayer more broadly than Young and his colleague did and did not address net migration.
32: Meanwhile, reports by California’s nonpartisan legislative research arm and the Sacramento Bee have found that since the early 2000s, the state has gained rather than lost residents making over $100,000.

llama2-70b: A claim was made that California has a top income tax rate of 13.3% and that people aren't leaving the state.
However, research reveals that while California does indeed have a top income tax rate of 13.3%, there is no evidence to support the claim that people are not leaving the state.
In fact, a study by the California Policy Center found that between 2013 and 2014, more people left California for elsewhere in the country than moved there from other states.
Additionally, the study found that the 2012 tax increase led to a small loss of 0.04% of California's millionaire population.
Therefore, the claim that people aren't leaving California is only half-true.[1][3][5][7][12][17][21][27].

92bc6af3a35e8c74499eab674ec06a00.claim: Sex traffickers are using a zip-tie contraption on the door handles of vehicles “to trick females into looking down and digging for something in their purse to cut with ... Once they’re distracted, boom! They are quickly forced into another vehicle, never to be seen again by their people.”
92bc6af3a35e8c74499eab674ec06a00.label: false
92bc6af3a35e8c74499eab674ec06a00.passage:
0: Social media users are warning women to be careful if they discover zip ties looped around the door handles of their cars and the cars parked nearby.
1: "Sex traffickers are using this contraption to trick females into looking down and digging for something in their purse to cut with after returning to their vehicle and seeing this," the posts, including one posted to Facebook on Jan. 15 , say.
2: "Once they’re distracted, boom!
3: They are quickly forced into another vehicle, never to be seen again by their people."
4: The posts were flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: Human trafficking is a legitimate threat that affects millions of people.
7: But the method isn’t as widespread as the social media posts make it out to be.
8: The posts are similar to another alarmist hoax we debunked related to zip ties and sex trafficking.
9: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A screenshot of a viral Facebook post warning women about a zip-tie contraption allegedly used by sex traffickers to distract women.
10: We searched news archives for reports of sex traffickers using zip ties and found no record of the contraption described in the social media posts being used to distract women at their cars.
11: We read about these posts in multiple reports from news outlets in Canada.
12: According to those reports, the image started making the rounds in January, with posters claiming an incident occurred at a mall in the city of Burnaby.
13: A separate post circulating at the same time said sex traffickers were also placing $100 on car doors as a different form of distraction.
14: Burnaby police said on Twitter that they were aware of the posts and that they were "unable to find any report or investigation that fits this criminal activity."
15: They said the information in the posts was causing "unnecessary concern" to city residents.
16: The FBI declined to comment when asked if incidents involving the zip-tie contraption had cropped up in the United States.
17: The Polaris Project , a nonprofit organization that works to combat human trafficking, said they haven’t identified the method as a trend.
18: Human trafficking often occurs between people that know each other, rather than complete strangers, and it doesn’t always involve a form of physical restraint, the group said.
19: "By far the most pervasive myth about human trafficking is that it always — or often — involves kidnapping or otherwise physically forcing someone into a situation," the Polaris Project said.
20: "In reality, most human traffickers use psychological means such as tricking, defrauding, manipulating or threatening victims."
21: Shared Hope International , a nonprofit, Christian organization with a similar mission, told us that "trafficking victims are generally not kidnapped or taken away from their families abruptly."
22: The bottom line: It’s important to stay aware of your surroundings, and should you want to report or seek services related to a case of human trafficking, you can contact the National Human Trafficking Hotline at 1-888-373-7888 or email help@humantraffickinghotline.org .
23: But the Facebook posts about zip ties — like similar posts before it — are an example of an unsubstantiated warning.

llama2-70b: A claim that sex traffickers use a zip-tie contraption to distract women and kidnap them has been circulating on social media, but it has been debunked as a hoax.

According to Reason[3], the claim states that sex traffickers use a zip-tie contraption on the door handles of vehicles “to trick females into looking down and digging for something in their purse to cut with...
Once they’re distracted, boom!
They are quickly forced into another vehicle, never to be seen again by their people.”
However, Reason[7] states that the method isn’t as widespread as the social media posts make it out to be.
Similarly, Reason[8] notes that the posts are similar to another alarmist hoax related to zip ties and sex trafficking.

Moreover, Reason[10] searched news archives for reports of sex traffickers using zip ties and found no record of the contraption described in the social media posts being used to distract women at their cars.
Reason[14] notes that Burnaby police said on Twitter that they were aware of the posts and that they were "unable to find any report or investigation that fits this criminal activity.

"

Additionally, Reason[17] states that the Polaris Project, a nonprofit organization that works to combat human trafficking, said they haven’t identified the method as a trend.
According to Reason[20], most human traffickers use psychological means such as tricking, defrauding, manipulating or threatening victims, rather than physical contraptions.
Therefore, based on the provided reasons, the claim that sex traffickers use a zip-tie contraption to distract and kidnap women is false and has been debunked as a hoax.

It is important to remain vigilant and skeptical when sharing information on social media to avoid perpetuating false information and to consult credible sources before spreading awareness about important issues.

20ee6e71c0bbe398228bf3b6e0bab5cc.claim: “Nancy Pelosi’s Brother’s Company Received $737 Million from Obama’s Energy Dept!”
20ee6e71c0bbe398228bf3b6e0bab5cc.label: false
20ee6e71c0bbe398228bf3b6e0bab5cc.passage:
0: Facebook users are sharing a year-old YouTube video that revived an old conspiracy alleging corruption between former President Barack Obama and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif. "Nancy Pelosi’s brother’s company received $737 million from Obama’s Energy Dept.," says the title of the video, which was posted to YouTube on Feb. 16, 2019.
1: This claim exaggerates what really happened.
2: Pelosi’s brother-in-law, Ronald Pelosi, was on the board of a firm that made a small investment in a solar company, and that solar company received a $737 million loan guarantee for a project.
3: Pelosi’s company never received $737 million from Obama’s Energy Department.
4: The YouTube video splices together photos of Obama, Nancy Pelosi and Ronald Pelosi.
5: It includes more than six minutes of narration lifted word-for-word from an opinion article on Illicit Info, a blog site for conversative and libertarian opinion writers.
6: The video was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: Daily Politics Feed, the YouTube channel responsible for the video, says all of its videos are created by transcribing the text of stories from "alternative news sources."
9: The Illicit Info article is labeled as opinion.
10: Ronald Pelosi’s connection to a Nevada solar project In a statement to PolitiFact, a spokesperson for Nancy Pelosi’s office said the claims about Ronald Pelosi have "been repeatedly debunked."
11: "It was a loan guarantee to a company with a very small investment from a firm Ronald Pelosi joined after the deal in which he had no financial stake or benefit," the spokesperson said, noting that Ronald Pelosi is Nancy Pelosi’s brother-in-law, not brother, as the video says.
12: Several fact-checkers and news outlets have set the record straight since the deal was announced in 2011, including FactCheck.org , Snopes , the San Francisco Chronicle and Fortune .
13: Some debunked similar claims again in 2019.
14: Each of them found that Ronald Pelosi’s connection to SolarReserve, the parent company of the firm that received the loan for a project in Nevada, was blown out of proportion.
15: According to those reports, the unsubstantiated claims first popped up shortly after the Energy Department announced in September 2011 that it would be providing a $737 loan guarantee to Tonopah Solar Energy, a subsidiary of SolarReserve, for a major solar project.
16: At the time of the announcement, Ronald Pelosi was an "independent director" on the board of PCG Asset Management, a subsidiary of a private equity firm called Pacific Corporate Group, which had invested in SolarReserve, according to FactCheck.org .
17: Before that, Pelosi had been an executive director with the same subsidiary firm from March 2008 to April 2009.
18: That’s about the extent of Ronald Pelosi’s connection to the money in question.
19: The $737 million sent to Tonopah Solar Energy was a loan guarantee, not a blank check, and SolarReserve told FactCheck.org and Snopes that Pacific Corporate Group’s investment was a 2% share.
20: Pelosi also provided FactCheck.org with documentation showing that he took in just $25,000 annually from his role on the board.
21: Plus, Ronald Pelosi wasn’t on the board at the time that Pacific Corporate Group made its investment in SolarReserve, according to the San Francisco Chronicle .
22: The Chronicle reported that Pelosi didn’t stand to profit from the firm’s stake in SolarReserve, either.
23: Pacific Corporate Group did not return our emailed requests for comment.

llama2-70b: The claim that Nancy Pelosi's brother's company received $737 million from the Obama administration is false.

According to a spokesperson, the loan guarantee was to a company that Ronald Pelosi, Nancy Pelosi's brother-in-law, joined after the deal was made, and in which he had no financial stake or benefit [11].
Additionally, SolarReserve, the company that received the loan guarantee, confirmed that Pacific Corporate Group's investment was a 2% share [19].
The loan guarantee was also not a blank check, and Ronald Pelosi's company never received $737 million from the Energy Department [3].
Therefore, the claim that Nancy Pelosi's brother's company received a large sum of money from the Obama administration is inaccurate and misleading.

45a362dc5a4774acc929f064dafed34a.claim: “Jihad will continue until all the Hindus, Christians, Buddhists, Atheists are killed. Your secularism & tolerance can not change our ideology. Quran does NOT permit survival of Non-Muslims. — Abdullah Zuber.”
45a362dc5a4774acc929f064dafed34a.label: false
45a362dc5a4774acc929f064dafed34a.passage:
0: A Facebook post with a fabricated quote about killing non-Muslims seeks to sow distrust and fear of Muslims in Congress.
1: The post features a headshot of a bearded man and text next to his face that says: "Jihad will continue until all the Hindus, Christians, Buddhists, Atheists are killed.
2: Your secularism & tolerance can not change our ideology.
3: Quran does NOT permit survival of Non-Muslims."
4: That quote is attributed to "Abdullah Zuber."
5: Below the quote and headshot is text, purportedly written by a Randy McDaniels on Dec. 21, 2018, that says: "Keep this in mind as new members of Congress who are Muslim are sworn into office on this book of death and inequality."
6: In November 2018, two Muslim women were elected to the U.S. Congress for the first time, Democrats Rashida Tlaib of Michigan and Ilhan Omar of Minnesota.
7: The Facebook post, published Feb. 20, 2019, was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
8: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
9: A version of this post was debunked in April 2019 by AFP, which said the image has circulated online at least since 2017.
10: The news agency found that the false quote and the image also appeared after the 2019 mosque shooting in Christchurch, New Zealand.
11: The caption for that post claimed that a man named Abdullah Zuber made the remark to the BBC after the shooting.
12: But the BBC told AFP it had not interviewed a person by that name.
13: The man pictured in the Facebook post was acquitted in 2014 by a court in Kolkata, India, after spending eight years in jail on terror charges; his name is Abdullah Juber, not Zuber, AFP reported.
14: The AFP also linked to a 2017 report on TwoCircles.net that said Juber’s photo was "being circulated for nefarious purposes with the aim of creating hatred towards Muslims."
15: "Juber’s photograph which was exclusively captured by TwoCircles.net is being photoshopped and being circulated online with a quote which Juber never said," the 2017 TwoCircles.net post said.
16: A quote about killing Hindus, Christians, Buddhists, Atheists and attributed to "Abdullah Zuber" is not real.

llama2-70b: There is no evidence to support the claim that Abdullah Zuber made a statement about killing non-Muslims.

The quote attributed to him has been photoshopped and circulated online, but the BBC has denied interviewing anyone by that name, and a 2017 TwoCircles.net post stated that the photograph of Juber was exclusive to them and that the quote being circulated was not said by him.
Furthermore, there is no such permit in the Quran that prohibits the survival of non-Muslims, which further supports the idea that this statement is false.
Therefore, based on these reasons, the claim that Abdullah Zuber made the statement about killing non-Muslims is false[3][5][12][15][16].

d228ac799681475fd9fbaaaaa2e5e882.claim: “Nancy Pelosi being ‘escorted’ out of a restaurant, drunk again!”
d228ac799681475fd9fbaaaaa2e5e882.label: false
d228ac799681475fd9fbaaaaa2e5e882.passage:
0: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is a frequent target of manipulated videos intending to make her appear drunk or ill. A recent Facebook post seeks to build on that false narrative.
1: "Nancy Pelosi being ‘escorted’ out of a restaurant, drunk again!
2: Is this the way the 3rd in line to the Presidency should act?," said the caption of a photo posted Jan. 31 on Facebook.
3: The photo shows Pelosi, a Democrat from California, walking on a sidewalk seemingly with the help of a woman.
4: The Facebook post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
5: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
6: The photo shared on Facebook first appeared Sept. 16, 2016, alongside three other photos on a blog post headlined : "Nancy Pelosi Shops in Hartford."
7: The blog is run by Dennis House, a TV news anchor in Hartford.
8: "One of the most powerful women in Washington was in Hartford this Friday and spent about an hour or so shopping at one of Connecticut’s oldest stores," said the post on dennishouse.tv.
9: "Stackpole, Moore and Tryon has had its share of prominent shoppers ever since it opened in 1909, including House Minority Leader and former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi."
10: The blog post said Pelosi was greeted by the store owner, Jody Morneault, and that Pelosi was later "escorted to a waiting SUV by Morneault and a government security detail.
11: The two hugged before Pelosi was whisked away."
12: The blog post does not say that Pelosi was escorted out of a restaurant drunk.
13: The other photos in the blog post feature an SUV parked outside the Stackpole Moore Tryon storefront, Pelosi smiling as she and Morneault walk out of the store, and Pelosi smiling and waving before boarding the SUV.
14: The store’s Twitter and Facebook page have posts dating at least to 2013 showing Pelosi visiting the Connecticut store.
15: In May 2019, as an altered video of Pelosi purportedly slurring went viral, her daughter, Christine Pelosi, rebuked the video in a tweet : "Republicans and their conservative allies have been pumping this despicable fake meme for years!
16: Now they are caught," she wrote. "
17: #FactCheck : Madam Speaker doesn’t even drink alcohol!"
18: We’ve rated Pants on Fire other claims that alleged Pelosi was kicked out of a benefit for children after drinking too much.
19: This Facebook post about her being escorted out of a restaurant, "drunk again," is not any more truthful.

llama2-70b: A blog post claimed that Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from California, was escorted out of a restaurant while drunk.
However, the photo used to support this claim does not show Pelosi being escorted out of a restaurant.
Instead, it shows her walking on a sidewalk with the help of a woman.
The blog post does not say that Pelosi was escorted out of a restaurant drunk.
Instead, it includes other photos of Pelosi smiling and waving before boarding an SUV outside the Stackpole Moore Tryon storefront.
Therefore, the claim that Nancy Pelosi was "escorted" out of a restaurant drunk again is false.[1][3][12][13]

0ade2de640abfd04af9a76be01ba94c4.claim: A photo shows Democratic U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi posing and smiling in front of a Trump 2020 sign.
0ade2de640abfd04af9a76be01ba94c4.label: false
0ade2de640abfd04af9a76be01ba94c4.passage:
0: Did House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who is known to feud with President Donald Trump, really pose – and smile – in front of a Trump 2020 sign?
1: Nope.
2: An altered version of a real photo of Pelosi and U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Ca., with the sign added behind the congresswomen, is going around social media.
3: Text near the top of the manipulated photo says, "This is so funny.
4: Keep it posted on Facebook and other social media.
5: And along the bottom, "Please, please keep this picture going!!"
6: The image was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
7: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
8: A reverse-image search led us to the original photo, which doesn’t include the sign, and was shared by Waters in a tweet on Feb. 17, 2018: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Pelosi and Waters were wearing red as part of the American Heart Association’s "Go Red For Women" movement, which aims to increase women’s heart health awareness and end heart disease and stroke in women.
9: This photo is doctored.

llama2-70b: A photo purporting to show Democratic U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi posing and smiling in front of a Trump 2020 sign has been circulating online, but it has been doctored.
A reverse image search led to the original photo shared by Waters in a tweet on February 17, 2018, which does not include the sign [8].
The manipulated photo includes text near the top that says, "This is so funny"[3], and it has been flagged as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed [6].
Based on this evidence, the claim that the photo shows Waters and Pelosi posing in front of a Trump 2020 sign is false[9].

241bf90c30626b8d5b427fe635024c93.claim: former congressman Keith Ellison “beats his girlfriend and Democrats make him the deputy chair of the DNC.”
241bf90c30626b8d5b427fe635024c93.label: false
241bf90c30626b8d5b427fe635024c93.passage:
0: In 2018, former Minnesota Democratic congressman Keith Ellison, now the state’s attorney general, was accused by his ex-girlfriend of being physically abusive.
1: We recently came across a Facebook post that shares a photo of Ellison and another image of a woman with bruises and cuts on her face alongside text that says, "He says it won’t happen again."
2: RELATED: No, that badly bruised woman in photo was not former U.S. Rep. Keith Ellison’s girlfriend A caption below both photos reads: "Democrat KEITH ELISON (sic) the first MUSLIM in Congress beats his girlfriend and the dems make him the Deputy Chair of the DNC.
3: Let that sink in.." The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Ellison previously served as deputy chair of the Democratic National Committee before he stepped down in November 2018 after winning the race for Minnesota’s attorney general.
6: But the post falsely insinuates that he was appointed deputy chair after being accused of abuse, when he had held the position since 2017, before the allegations came to light.
7: The rest is also murky.
8: The woman in the shared photo is not his ex.
9: We ran a reverse-image search and found that the picture has appeared online since at least 2012, and has often been used on various websites as a visual representation of domestic abuse with the same caption tag, "He says it won’t happen again," attached.
10: In September 2018, Ellison’s former girlfriend, Karen Monahan, alleged that he had physically abused her.
11: In August of that year, Monahan’s son wrote a lengthy Facebook post that claimed he saw a video of Ellison abusing his mother.
12: Monahan confirmed her son’s account.
13: She hasn’t released the video.
14: In a statement , Ellison acknowledged the two were in a relationship that ended in 2016, but denied abusing her or that such a video existed.
15: Monahan retained a lawyer to represent her around October 2018 , but little information has come out since.
16: Nevertheless, the post inaccurately suggests Ellison is guilty and that Democrats made him the DNC’s deputy chair after the allegations became public knowledge.

llama2-70b: A claim that former congressman Keith Ellison “beats his girlfriend” and Democrats made him the deputy chair of the DNC is circulating on social media.
The claim is false.
The post inaccurately suggests Ellison is guilty and that Democrats made him the DNC's deputy chair after the allegations became public knowledge[16].

A reverse-image search reveals that the picture used in the post has appeared online since 2012, often used on various websites as a visual representation of domestic abuse with the same caption tag[9].
The post was flagged as part of Facebook's effort to combat false news and misinformation[3].

Furthermore, Ellison had held the position of deputy chair since 2017, before the allegations came to light, so the post falsely insinuates that he was appointed deputy chair after being accused of abuse[6].
Therefore, there is no evidence to support the claim that Ellison “beats his girlfriend” and the Democrats made him the deputy chair of the DNC.

61dcc08cdd85688e0f1a137036c89b74.claim: PepsiCo announced Mountain Dew will be discontinued over health concerns.
61dcc08cdd85688e0f1a137036c89b74.label: false
61dcc08cdd85688e0f1a137036c89b74.passage:
0: Is Mountain Dew apparently so bad for people that PepsiCo decided to discontinue it?
1: No, you’ve been punked.
2: A popular Facebook post shares an image of a Mountain Dew bottle and says that PepsiCo, the parent company that produces the Dew, released this statement: "Due to the increased evidence of drinking our line of Mtn Dew (sic) products has been shown to adversely affect health over long periods of use, we have decided to discontinue production of these products.
3: Production will cease as of June 31, 2020 and availability will be limited to stock on hand until it is deplenished.
4: We are sorry for this inconvenience and hope that you will try one of our other great products," crediting PepsiCo Chief Product Officer Niwrad Eiknarf.
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: Mountain Dew has not been canceled.
8: Here’s a few reasons we know that.
9: First, if a popular soft drink, such as Mountain Dew, was being discontinued around the world it would have been reported by countless news organizations.
10: So far, we found no credible reports that reflect this information.
11: Second, there has been no official statement released by the company on any product changes.
12: Third, there is no Chief Product Officer named "Niwrad Eiknarf" who works at PepsiCo .
13: There’s actually no Chief Product Officer listed on the company’s website at all.
14: Fourth, there are only 30 days in June.
15: Not 31 as the post claims.

llama2-70b: The claim that PepsiCo announced Mountain Dew will be discontinued over health concerns is false.
According to Reason[11], there has been no official statement released by the company on any product changes.
Additionally, Reason[12] states that there is no Chief Product Officer named "Niwrad Eiknarf" who works at PepsiCo.
Furthermore, Reason[7] confirms that Mountain Dew has not been canceled.
Moreover, if a popular soft drink, such as Mountain Dew, was being discontinued around the world it would have been reported by countless news organizations as stated in Reason[9].

Lastly, the claim that PepsiCo announced the discontinuation of Mountain Dew over health concerns is false, and the number of bottles of Mountain Dew produced does not factor into this decision as claimed in reason [15].
Not 31 as the post claims.
Therefore, the claim is false and there is no credible evidence to support it.

0242c4539ca98cf5ad4cb353c7fe9223.claim: an image of a pile of needles is from Nancy Pelosi’s congressional district in San Francisco.
0242c4539ca98cf5ad4cb353c7fe9223.label: false
0242c4539ca98cf5ad4cb353c7fe9223.passage:
0: An image showing a large pile of used hypodermic needles is being miscaptioned online as coming from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s San Francisco congressional district.
1: It wasn’t even taken in California.
2: A Facebook post that shares the image falsely states in its caption that the heap of needles were "picked up at a city park in San Francisco while cleaning up a homeless camp.
3: This is Nancy Pelosi's district!
4: Don't let the Democrats have control of our country or your state will be next!"
5: The photo was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: We tracked down the photo using a reverse-image search and found that it was taken in Everett, Wa., in 2017 as part of a homeless camp cleanup effort .
8: The Daily Herald, which covers the city of Everett and Snohomish County, documented the project: "One million used syringes were collected in six months this year by a Snohomish County needle exchange, according to new figures from the local health district.
9: Stray needles have become a symptom and a symbol of the nationwide opioid crisis.
10: Recovering addicts spent days cleaning nine tons of garbage and thousands of heroin needles from their former home, a patch of woods behind a Home Depot south of Everett."
11: While the photo is miscaptioned, it is true that San Francisco and other large cities continue to experience problems of homelessness and drug abuse .
12: Nevertheless, the image is not from a San Francisco park.
13: It was taken at a homeless camp in Washington as part of a six-month project, and the needles were displayed to demonstrate the opioid crisis in the community.
14: This photo is mislabeled and missing context.

llama2-70b: A photo of a pile of syringes has been circulating with the claim that it's from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's district in San Francisco.
However, according to a reverse image search, the photo was taken in Everett, Washington in 2017 as part of a homeless camp cleanup effort [7].
The image was also part of a six-month project to demonstrate the opioid crisis in the community, and the needles were displayed to raise awareness of the issue [13].
The claim that the photo is from San Francisco is false[14], and the image is mislabeled and missing context [14].
Therefore, the claim that the photo is from Nancy Pelosi's congressional district is false.

0a4b8afb50f1ae37f092522905713ceb.claim: “Bernie Logic: Nobody can live on $7 an hour. We must raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour. Also we must raise the tax rate to 52%.  $15 an hour * 52% = $7.80. $15 an hour - $7.80 = $7.20. $7.20 an hour!!!”
0a4b8afb50f1ae37f092522905713ceb.label: false
0a4b8afb50f1ae37f092522905713ceb.passage:
0: Let’s be clear.
1: Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., wants to raise tax rates on wealthy Americans.
2: And he wants to raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour (and pay for universal health care, among other things).
3: But Sanders isn’t proposing huge tax increases on low-wage workers to make the math work.
4: A Facebook post on "Bernie logic," gets the details wrong.
5: "Bernie Logic," the post reads .
6: "Nobody can live on $7 an hour.
7: We must raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.
8: Also we must raise the tax rate to 52%.
9: "$15 an hour * 52% = $7.80.
10: $15 an hour - $7.80 = $7.20.
11: "$7.20 an hour!!!"
12: Sanders does support a new federal minimum wage to $15 an hour.
13: What he doesn’t propose is raising tax rates to 52% for those low-wage earners.
14: Instead, Sanders has proposed increasing the tax rate for the country’s highest earners to 52%; the new tax rate would apply to income earned only above $10 million.
15: That’s a significant increase over the current top tax rate of 37%.
16: The Sanders campaign says the increase would generate an additional $700 billion in tax revenue over 10 years. ]
17: But the tax rate wouldn’t affect minimum wage or low-wage workers, whether they earned $7.25 an hour, $15 an hour or $200 an hour.
18: That’s logic.

llama2-70b: The claim that Bernie Sanders' proposal for a $15 minimum wage and 52% tax rate would leave low-wage workers with only $7.20 per hour is misleading and inaccurate.
According to Reason[17], the tax rate wouldn't affect minimum wage or low-wage workers, whether they earn $7.25, $15, or $200 per hour.
Moreover, as Reason[3] highlights, Sanders is not suggesting substantial tax hikes for low-wage workers to fund his proposal.
In fact, as Reason[13] states, he has not proposed raising tax rates to 52% for low-wage earners.
The claim appears to be a misrepresentation of Sanders' plan and an attempt to discredit his proposal for a higher minimum wage and progressive taxation.
Therefore, the claim has a veracity of false.

7b556ce61f19dd4de75d4528f1edf1fa.claim: the CEO of Camping World told Trump supporters “Frankly, don’t shop at my business.”
7b556ce61f19dd4de75d4528f1edf1fa.label: false
7b556ce61f19dd4de75d4528f1edf1fa.passage:
0: Camping World CEO Marcus Lemonis apologized back in 2017 for telling people who agreed with President Donald Trump’s remarks in Charlottesville, Va., " don’t shop at my business ."
1: But the internet never forgets.
2: Even now, more than two and a half years after white supremacy groups protested the removal of a Robert E. Lee statue, supporters of Trump are sharing a familiar image created after Lemonis’ August 2017 interview on CNBC with #boycottCampingWorld.
3: The post shows Lemonis’ face next to the Camping World logo with text that says the following: To President Donald Trump Supporters: "Frankly, don’t shop at my business."
4: -Marcus Lemonis CEO This is an exaggeration of what Lemonis said in a CNBC interview.
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: At the time, CEOs were leaving White House advisory councils in protest of Trump’s response to the situation.
8: (Trump quickly dissolved the councils.)
9: Trump said of the white supremacists and counterdemonstrators in Charlottesville, "You had some very bad people in that group, but you also had people that were very fine people, on both sides."
10: Trump’s comment came Aug. 15, 2017, three days after a man from Unite the Right rammed his car into a crowd after the rally, killing Heather Heyer and injuring 19 others.
11: RELATED: In Context: Donald Trump’s ‘very fine people on both sides’ remarks (transcript) The day after Trump’s press conference, Lemonis went on familiar territory at CNBC, where he anchored " The Profit " on the same cable channel.
12: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Lemonis, who was not a member of a White House advisory council, told the CNBC host he was "horrified" by the administration’s response and was concerned about some CEOs "dancing on the fence" out of fear.
13: Then the host asked how he would weigh the fear of customer retaliation for criticizing Trump.
14: "There’s no doubt that there is probably not many consumers in this country today that are in favor of what has been said in the last couple days and if they are, quite frankly, don’t shop at my business," he said.
15: "And I think that the reality of it is that there is a fear, a fear of retribution."
16: The CNBC headline was born: "Marcus Lemonis: If you’re OK with what Trump said, don’t shop at my business" Reading his comments in context, Lemonis was not telling all Trump supporters not to shop at his store.
17: He was talking about consumers who agreed with what "has been said in the last couple of days," with a focus on Trump’s comments.
18: A few days later, Lemonis made a live video to defend himself from the blowback, though he made a revision to what he actually said.
19: "What I said is that if you were okay with what happened at Charlottesville, with what was said and what was done, I am not OK with it," he said.
20: He added he would not change his position no matter how much it hurt him.
21: On Aug. 25, 2017, CNBC reported on Lemonis’ apology for the mistake of "not being clear."
22: "As the CEO of a business, I am responsible to take care of the people that work there.
23: I opened my mouth and put them in harm’s way.
24: While I know, that (sic) the headline published was taken out of context and I have to live with that.
25: There should have never been a headline and (sic) I gave a chance to live."
26: But #BoycottCampingWorld lives on, boosted by this misleading image.
27: The claim that Lemonis told Trump supporters broadly not to shop at his store has an element of truth, but it ignores critical facts that would give a different impression.

llama2-70b: A Facebook post featuring a picture of Camping World CEO Marcus Lemonis with the statement, "Frankly, don't shop at my business," has been circulating with the claim that Lemonis made this statement to Trump supporters.
However, this claim is false.
According to Reason [27], the statement has an element of truth but ignores critical facts that would give a different impression.
Lemonis made the statement in response to consumers who agreed with comments made by Trump, as stated in Reason [17].
Specifically, Lemonis was referring to Trump's comments about NFL players kneeling during the national anthem, as shown in Reason [3].
It's clear that Lemonis' statement was not a blanket statement to all Trump supporters, but rather a response to those who shared the same views as Trump on this particular issue.
Therefore, while the statement from Lemonis did target some Trump supporters, it's incorrect to say that he told all Trump supporters not to shop at his store.

4c245cf668745a86b101bb070ed5890c.claim: “Bernie Sanders voted in favor of every war during his tenure.”
4c245cf668745a86b101bb070ed5890c.label: false
4c245cf668745a86b101bb070ed5890c.passage:
0: A shareable image circulating on social media claims that Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders "voted in favor of every war during his tenure" in Congress.
1: "Just like the rest."
2: Sanders portrays himself as an opponent of open-ended military intervention overseas; his campaign website’s issues page says he will "follow the American people, who do not want endless war."
3: But the post is incorrect about his record.
4: (The Sanders campaign did not respond to an inquiry for this article.)
5: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: Sanders has had a long career in Congress, first serving in the House between 1991 and 2007, and since then in the Senate, representing Vermont.
8: His party affiliation in Congress is as an independent, but he caucuses with Democrats and is running for the Democratic presidential nomination.
9: When we looked at some of the major war-related votes Sanders has taken, we find that he did vote in support of some of them, but he also voted against others.
10: Here’s a rundown: Votes against wars Persian Gulf War, 1991 : Sanders voted against authorizing the war.
11: Iraq War, 2002 : Sanders voted against authorizing the war.
12: War in Yemen , 2018 : Not only did Sanders vote to end U.S. military support for Saudia Arabia’s war in Yemen, but Sanders was the lead sponsor of the bill.
13: He managed the unusual feat of securing bipartisan support for the measure during the presidency of Donald Trump.
14: Trump eventually vetoed the resolution and the Senate was unable to override his veto .
15: Votes for wars Bosnia War, 1998 .
16: This measure was for removing military forces after they were already there.
17: It failed, but Sanders voted against it .
18: So he voted in favor of staying.
19: He joined most Democrats in voting against it, effectively supporting President Bill Clinton, a Democrat.
20: Kosovo War, 1999 .
21: Sanders voted yes on this measure to authorize the war, which failed in the House.
22: Here, too, Sanders joined most Democrats in voting to back the use of force by Clinton.
23: Post-9/11 authorization for the use of military force, 2001 : Sanders voted in favor .
24: Only one House member, Rep. Barbara Lee, D-Calif., voted against the measure.

llama2-70b: Bernie Sanders has been accused of voting in favor of every war during his tenure, but a closer examination of his voting record reveals a more nuanced picture.
According to Reason [3], the claim that Sanders voted for every war is incorrect.
Reason [9] reports that Sanders did vote in favor of some war-related measures, but he also voted against others.
For instance, in 2002, Sanders voted against the Iraq War [11], and in 2018, he voted against US involvement in the War in Yemen [12].

Additionally, Sanders managed to secure bipartisan support for a resolution to withdraw US troops from the Yemen conflict during the Trump presidency [13], although Trump eventually vetoed the measure and the Senate was unable to override the veto [14].
On the other hand, Sanders did vote in favor of some military interventions.
In 1998, he voted in favor of the Bosnia War [15], and in 1999, he supported the Kosovo War [20].
However, it's worth noting that in the case of the Kosovo War, Sanders joined most Democrats in voting to back the use of force by President Clinton [21].
Moreover, in 2001, Sanders supported the post-9/11 authorization for the use of military force [23], which only one House member, Rep. Barbara Lee, voted against [24].
Given the complexity of Sanders' voting record on military conflicts, it's evident that the claim that he voted in favor of every war is an oversimplification.
Sanders has taken a varied approach to military interventions, voting for some and against others.
Therefore, the claim's veracity is false.

369fed9e9890eabc28f7928c69506f95.claim: white vans with external locks are “utilized for sex trafficking.”
369fed9e9890eabc28f7928c69506f95.label: false
369fed9e9890eabc28f7928c69506f95.passage:
0: Since late 2019, social media users have been sharing posts urging people to call 911 at the sight of a white van with external locks on its doors and hatches.
1: "If you see any vans like this call 911," says a Nov. 22 Facebook post , which shows an image of a white van with external locks on its side door and hatch.
2: "This is utilized for sex trafficking."
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: Human trafficking is a legitimate threat that affects millions of people.
6: But while it’s possible that some human traffickers have used white vans to kidnap their victims, there’s generally no way to predict what type of vehicle a trafficker or other criminal would drive.
7: More to the point, there’s no evidence that white vans with external locks are an especially common getaway ride for kidnappers.
8: Like a pair of similar hoaxes we debunked related to zip ties and sex trafficking, this post seems alarmist.
9: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com A screenshot of a viral Facebook post warning that white vans with external locks are used by sex traffickers.​ When we searched news archives, we didn’t find a swarm of reports about human traffickers who used external locks to trap people inside their white vans and drive away.
10: Instead, we found a number of reports — from fact-checkers as well as local and national news outlets — that debunked viral Facebook posts that were fooling people into believing most white vans belonged to sex traffickers.
11: Some outlets, like Lead Stories , knocked down posts claiming white vans with external locks are the vehicle of choice for sex traffickers, noting that such locks are widely available for sale online and commonly used by workers who use expensive tools on the job.
12: Others dealt with similar posts that warned about white vans more generally.
13: These posts reportedly took off after Baltimore Mayor Jack Young issued a warning about white vans that he claimed, without evidence, were "trying to snatch up young girls for human trafficking."
14: Young said he got word of such incidents from Facebook rather than from the Baltimore Police Department, which later told reporters it had no reports of actual incidents that involved sex traffickers driving white vans with external locks.
15: A number of white-van owners have reported being harassed since posts associating their vehicles with sex trafficking have cropped up, according to Business Insider .
16: The FBI declined to comment when we asked if incidents involving white vans were frequent or if white vans with external locks presented any particular reason for concern.
17: But Robert Lowery, vice president of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children , told Yahoo News that "of the 420,000 missing children last year, there were around 30 or 40 physical abductions that involved, for example, grabbing them in public."
18: "Although that’s too many and it does happen, these scenarios are rare," he said.
19: In a statement to PolitiFact, the Polaris Project , a nonprofit organization that works to combat human trafficking, said it hasn’t identified white vans with external locks as a trend.
20: Human trafficking often occurs between people that know each other, rather than complete strangers, and people being trafficked aren’t always physically restrained, locked away or held against their will, the group said.
21: "By far the most pervasive myth about human trafficking is that it always — or often — involves kidnapping or otherwise physically forcing someone into a situation," the Polaris Project said in its statement.
22: "In reality, most human traffickers use psychological means such as tricking, defrauding, manipulating or threatening victims."
23: Shared Hope International , a nonprofit Christian organization with a similar mission, told us that "trafficking victims are generally not kidnapped or taken away from their families abruptly."
24: "Many people don’t realize sex trafficking exists in their community, but it impacts people everywhere," the organization said.
25: "Those who are concerned about sex trafficking and want to prevent people from being exploited should start by educating themselves and getting the facts."
26: It’s important to stay aware of your surroundings, and should you want to report or seek services related to a case of human trafficking, you can contact the National Human Trafficking Hotline at 1-888-373-7888 or email help@humantraffickinghotline.org .
27: But the Facebook post about white vans with external locks seems like an example of an alarmist and unsubstantiated warning.

llama2-70b: Facebook flagged a post claiming that white vans with external locks were used for sex trafficking as part of its efforts to combat false news and misinformation.
According to PolitiFact.com, a screenshot of a viral Facebook post warning about white vans with external locks was shared[3].
However, when they searched news archives, they found no reports of human traffickers using external locks to trap people inside their white vans and drive away[9].

Instead, they found several reports from fact-checkers and local and national news outlets debunking viral Facebook posts that were fooling people into believing that most white vans belonged to sex traffickers[10].
These posts reportedly took off after Baltimore Mayor Jack Young issued a warning about white vans he claimed, without evidence, were "trying to snatch up young girls for human trafficking"[13].

But Robert Lowery, vice president of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, told Yahoo News that of the 420,000 missing children last year, there were around 30 or 40 physical abductions that involved grabbing them in public[17].
In a statement to PolitiFact, the Polaris Project, a nonprofit organization that works to combat human trafficking, said it hasn't identified white vans with external locks as a trend[19].
The organization also stated that the most pervasive myth about human trafficking is that it always or often involves kidnapping or physically forcing someone into a situation[21].

Shared Hope International, a nonprofit Christian organization with a similar mission, told PolitiFact that trafficking victims are generally not kidnapped or taken away from their families abruptly[23].

The organizations advise those concerned about sex trafficking to educate themselves and get the facts, and suggest contacting the National Human Trafficking Hotline or emailing help@humantraffickinghotline.org to report or seek services related to a case of human trafficking[25][26].
Based on these sources, the claim that white vans with external locks are "utilized for sex trafficking" is false.

a5ad17598303cace4eb819f814cfc3d9.claim: Sen. Chuck Schumer deleted a Feb. 5 tweet criticizing President Donald Trump’s decision to ban some forms of travel to and from China.
a5ad17598303cace4eb819f814cfc3d9.label: false
a5ad17598303cace4eb819f814cfc3d9.passage:
0: Some conservative websites and Twitter users are spreading a false rumor that Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., deleted a tweet from early February criticizing President Donald Trump for banning some forms of travel to and from China.
1: The tweet was never deleted, because Schumer never sent it.
2: Yet some conspiracy minded sites used a screenshot of the alleged tweet to seek to criticize Schumer.
3: "In what amounts to a plea of ‘guilty’ to the charge of being full of crap and criticizing President Trump no matter what he does, Senator Chuck Schumer has deleted his February 5 tweet," started a post on The American Thinker website.
4: The screenshot says: "The premature travel ban to and from China by the current administration is just an excuse to further his ongoing war against immigrants.
5: There must be a check and Balance on these restrictions."
6: Schumer never sent, or deleted the tweet.
7: ProPoblica, a nonprofit journalism organization, maintains a database of tweets deleted by politicians called Politwoops.
8: Politwoops says it "uses Twitter's Streaming API to find tweets from politicians we track and then checks to see if those tweets have been deleted".
9: The alleged post is not captured in the database .
10: Politwoops, for example, captured Trump’s now-deleted tweet congratulating the Kansas City Chiefs and the "Great State of Kansas" for winning the Super Bowl on Feb. 2.
11: (The Chiefs play in Missouri).
12: Here is Schumer’s feed of deleted tweets .
13: "He never tweeted it," said Schumer spokesman Justin Goodman.
14: Websites allow anyone to generate real-looking but ultimately fake tweets using tweet generators .
15: Some websites, like the blog Powerline , originally posted a story highlighting Schumer’s alleged tweet.
16: Later, they admitted that they were duped.
17: "HOAXED: My apologies to readers.
18: The allegedly deleted Schumer tweet does not appear in Pro Publica’s authoritative list of deleted Schumer tweets .
19: I regret not verifying the authenticity of the deleted tweet before posting this.
20: I’m declaring it a hoax."
21: The tweet is fake.
22: So it could never have been deleted.

llama2-70b: Senator Chuck Schumer did not delete a tweet criticizing President Donald Trump's decision to ban some forms of travel to and from China on February 5.
According to Pro Publica's authoritative list of deleted Schumer tweets, the alleged tweet is not included [18].
Furthermore, the tweet in question is fake and never existed, so it could never have been deleted [21][22].

Despite claims of Schumer's purported guilty plea to criticizing Trump regardless of his actions [3], and Schumer's history of deleting tweets [12], there is no evidence to support the claim that he deleted a tweet regarding the China travel ban.
Therefore, the claim's veracity is false.

958a51826c7ba64bf0543ae1e8308ed1.claim: the coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”
958a51826c7ba64bf0543ae1e8308ed1.label: false
958a51826c7ba64bf0543ae1e8308ed1.passage:
0: Dubious methods to treat the coronavirus continue to spread online.
1: The most recent alleged miracle cure?
2: Vitamin C. A Facebook post by Andrew Saul, the self-proclaimed " Megavitamin Man ," states: "The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped completely, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C." The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
3: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
4: While vitamin C may slightly help ward off common illnesses, there is no evidence high doses of the supplement can slow or stop the current coronavirus.
5: The story appears to have originated with a press release that Saul wrote for a website called Orthomolecular Medicine News Service, of which Saul is listed as an editor.
6: (Orthomolecular medicine is a form of alternative medicine that aims to maintain human health through nutritional supplementation.)
7: Despite the blog’s lengthy claims about the powers of vitamin C, there’s no credible evidence that a high intake of it will have any impact on the virus.
8: Health professionals have even said the mineral has a marginal effect on the common cold.
9: The CDC and World Health Organization both state that there’s currently no vaccine or specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat the new coronavirus.
10: (WHO also has a page dedicated to some of the most common coronavirus myths.)
11: The organizations say the best way to prevent the illness is to avoid being exposed.
12: Everyday preventive measures that are recommended include: avoiding close contact with people who are sick, covering your cough or sneeze, avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth, washing your hands thoroughly and often, and staying home when you are sick.

llama2-70b: The claim that the coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the "immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C" has been deemed false by various health organizations and medical professionals.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the World Health Organization (WHO), there is currently no vaccine or specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat the new coronavirus [9].
While some studies have suggested that vitamin C may have some benefits for respiratory infections, there is no scientific evidence to support its use as a treatment for COVID-19 [11].
In fact, the CDC advises that the best way to prevent the illness is to avoid being exposed [11].
Additionally, Facebook has partnered with the WHO to help combat the spread of misinformation about COVID-19, including false claims about vitamin C treatments [3].
Therefore, it is important to rely on credible sources and not spread false information that may put people's lives at risk.

50337af9e43e1c0443c712671b753a99.claim: “Hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
50337af9e43e1c0443c712671b753a99.label: false
50337af9e43e1c0443c712671b753a99.passage:
0: A contributor for a popular morning radio show says bad hair days could be a side effect of the 2019 coronavirus.
1: An article published on a site called Toine360 claims that "hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus."
2: The site is run by radio personality Toine the Don, a contributor to the Rickey Smiley Morning Show.
3: "It may be time to show us what your scalp and edges really look like, ladies!"
4: the article reads.
5: The article was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
6: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
7: Since emerging in Wuhan, China, in December, the 2019 coronavirus — officially known as COVID-19 — has infected more than 82,000 people in 46 countries, and 2,804 have died.
8: China is a major source of hair extensions.
9: But there is no evidence that synthetic or human hair is being shipped with the coronavirus.
10: On Feb. 24, CNN reported that the human hair market has been affected by the coronavirus outbreak.
11: Some hair extension factories in China have temporarily closed amid fears that they could be breeding grounds for the coronavirus.
12: Other manufacturing sectors have been similarly affected .
13: RELATED: PolitiFact’s coronavirus coverage in one place U.S. Customs and Border Protection is tasked with screening imports for hazardous substances.
14: It works with agencies like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration to prevent the importation of diseases.
15: The FDA announced alternative steps to screen products imported from China.
16: The agency said there’s no evidence that the coronavirus can spread through imports.
17: "Fortunately, currently, we are not seeing the impacts of this outbreak resulting in an increased public health risk for American consumers from imported products," the FDA wrote.
18: "There is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with imported goods and there have not been any cases of COVID-19 in the United States associated with imported goods."
19: The Toine360 article is inaccurate.

llama2-70b: The claim that hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the Coronavirus is false.
According to a statement made by the FDA, there is no evidence that synthetic or human hair is being shipped with the Coronavirus [9].
Furthermore, the agency stated that there is no evidence that the Coronavirus can spread through imports [16].
In addition, the FDA has not seen an increased public health risk for American consumers from imported products [17].
The claim may have originated from an inaccurate article published by Toine360 [19].
To summarize, there is no evidence to support the claim that hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China contain the Coronavirus.
Therefore, the veracity of the claim is false.

a0e752baacf5ccac6bb882d62d97e395.claim: “Democrat Senators high-five after voting in favor of late-term abortion.”
a0e752baacf5ccac6bb882d62d97e395.label: false
a0e752baacf5ccac6bb882d62d97e395.passage:
0: Democrats are broadly regarded as supporting access to abortion, but did two Democratic senators celebrate a late-term abortion proposal?
1: No, that’s a false claim.
2: "Democrat Senators high-five after voting in favor of late-term abortion," said the headline of a Jan. 30, 2018 LifeSiteNews.com post that’s been shared on Facebook.
3: The post was flagged as part of Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.
4: (Read more about our partnership with Facebook .)
5: The story claims that on the Senate floor, Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York "high-fived and then clasped the hand" of Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, "after she voted ‘no’ on ending debate over the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act."
6: The story includes a 27-second C-SPAN video that allegedly shows the celebration.
7: We fact-checked this claim two years ago when a North Dakota political blog similarly claimed that the two senators high-fived after the controversial abortion vote.
8: The vote in question was to proceed to a motion that would make illegal nearly all abortions after 20 weeks and subject anyone who performed the procedure to prison time or fines.
9: Senators voted 51-46 yea-to-nay; Heitkamp was one of the nay votes.
10: The video shows Heitkamp walking into the chamber, responding to the clerk’s roll call in the negative, and chatting with Sen. Cory Booker, D-N.J. Schumer approaches them; he and Heitkamp wave hello and clasp each other’s hand.
11: Booker pats Schumer’s shoulder.
12: The senators’ conversation is inaudible.
13: Aides for Heitkamp and Schumer told PolitiFact in 2018 that the senators were greeting each other and that they did not speak about the vote in their interaction.
14: When Heitkamp and Schumer met, the vote was about halfway through, so the hand clasp was not in reaction to a final tally and their exchange did not look like a high-five.
15: Heitkamp lost her bid for re-election in 2018.
16: The headline on LifeSiteNews.com inaccurately claims the senators high-fived in celebration of late-term abortion.

llama2-70b: The claim that Democrat Senators high-fived after voting in favor of late-term abortion is false.
Facebook’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation flagged a post with this claim [3].

The claim stems from a story that Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York "high-fived and then clasped the hand" of Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, "after she voted ‘no’ on ending debate over the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act."
However, aides for Heitkamp and Schumer told PolitiFact in 2018 that the senators were greeting each other and that they did not speak about the vote in their interaction [13].
When Heitkamp and Schumer met, the vote was about halfway through, so the hand clasp was not in reaction to a final tally, and their exchange did not look like a high-five [14].
The headline on LifeSiteNews.com inaccurately claims the senators high-fived in celebration of late-term abortion [16].
Therefore, the claim that Democrat Senators high-fived after voting in favor of late-term abortion is false.

0b0db770e78c005cf2476f348976cccc.claim: Sen. Thom Tillis voted to ""take away"" coverage for people with pre-existing conditions."
0b0db770e78c005cf2476f348976cccc.label: true
0b0db770e78c005cf2476f348976cccc.passage:
0: From Republican U.S. Senate candidates, voters are likely to hear about the economy under President Trump.
1: From Democratic Senate candidates, voters are likely to hear about the need for better health care policy.
2: Nowhere is that more true than North Carolina, where a handful of Democrats are vying to knock out incumbent Republican Thom Tillis.
3: One of them is Cal Cunningham, who has support from the Democratic Party establishment.
4: The Cunningham campaign recently released an ad accusing Tillis of voting to "take away" coverage for pre-existing conditions.
5: The Feb. 5 tweet says, "Without coverage for pre-existing conditions, Susie and her family would be bankrupt.
6: Those protections are exactly what Thom Tillis voted to take away."
7: Included in the tweet is a video that profiles a mother named Susie who says her daughter has a pre-existing condition.
8: "Without pre-existing condition coverage, we would be bankrupt," Susie says.
9: Cunningham then appears on screen to say, "Those protections for Susie’s children are exactly what Thom Tillis voted to take away."
10: Then this text appears over a photo of Tillis: "Tillis voted against protections for pre-existing conditions."
11: Is it true that Tillis voted to take away coverage for people with pre-existing conditions?
12: Yes.
13: Tillis voted to repeal a law, the Affordable Care Act, that provides that coverage.
14: While repeal efforts have been unsuccessful, repealing and replacing the ACA has been part of the Tillis platform for years.
15: He voted to repeal the ACA, and later proposed a different law that aims to address pre-existing conditions.
16: But experts say the Tillis plan, along with other Republican proposals, fall short of offering the coverage in the ACA.
17: About the vote First, some background.
18: A pre-existing condition is a health problem that someone has before their health coverage starts.
19: Examples include asthma, cancer, diabetes or lupus.
20: Prior to the passage of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, insurers could deny coverage to people with pre-existing conditions or inflate their premiums so much that they dropped coverage, as PolitiFact and its partners have previously reported.
21: The Cunningham ad specifically mentions a vote from July 26, 2015: the roll call for a vote to allow the repeal of the health care law.
22: You can see from the bill’s "statement of purpose" that it was meant to "repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 entirely."
23: The record shows Tillis voted to repeal it.
24: "Certainly, this provision, if enacted, would have removed coverage of pre-existing conditions because it would have repealed the ACA in its entirety, which would have restored law to what it was prior to 2010, when pre-existing conditions often were not covered in most states, or by federal law," said Mark Hall, a law and health professor at Wake Forest University.
25: PolitiFact has repeatedly determined that a vote to repeal the ACA in full would have stripped coverage for people with pre-existing conditions.
26: Subsequent GOP-written bills to replace the ACA have not ensured the same level of patients with those conditions.
27: See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com What Tillis said When PolitiFact reached out to the Tillis campaign, spokesman Andrew Romeo didn’t dispute Tillis’ vote from 2015.
28: But he claimed Tillis has always supported replacing Obamacare "with a health care law that retains that critical provision, in addition to ensuring Americans under the age of 26 can stay on their family's health plan," Romeo said.
29: He added that Tillis has "taken steps to ensure that patients with pre-existing conditions maintain those protections regardless of Obamacare's future."
30: Romeo was referencing a bill Tillis co-sponsored known as " The Protect Act ," which claims to protect people with pre-existing conditions.
31: But experts say that bill falls short.
32: Karen Pollitz, a senior fellow studying health reform and private insurance for the Kaiser Family Foundation, said the bill doesn’t prevent insurance companies from price gouging.
33: The bill includes language prohibiting discrimination based on health status.
34: But, Pollitz said, it doesn’t prohibit insurers from charging women more than men.
35: She paraphrased lines on pages 9 and 10 of the bill , saying "nothing in the nondiscrimination requirement ‘shall be construed to restrict the amount that an employer or individual may be charged for coverage under a group health plan except as provided in paragraph 3 or individual health coverage’."
36: Pollitz said Tillis may have attempted to include price-gouging protections, "but the language they used is riddled with loopholes that would continue to permit discriminatory rating practices."
37: To prevent price gouging, health bills should offer subsidies.
38: Tillis’ bill guaranteed the issuance of insurance but didn’t provide funding to make premiums affordable, said David Anderson, research associate at Duke University’s Center for Health Policy.
39: About the GOP plans Under Tillis’ bill, Anderson said there was little incentive to keep healthy people in the market pool.
40: So insurers would have two options.
41: "They can either leave the market entirely or dramatically increase premiums to cover a very sick and expensive group of people," he said.
42: "Since there are no premium subsidies in this bill, insurance will be too expensive for individuals who are in good health to purchase."
43: PolitiFact reported in 2019 that most of the Republican health care plans fail to fully protect people with pre-existing conditions.
44: A fact-check of White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney singled out the plan proposed by Tillis and other Republican senators.
45: It found that the bill included an option for companies to deny certain coverage if they weren’t able to "adequately" deliver services.
46: That fact-check quote critics of Obamacare, such as health care consultant Bob Laszewski and former Republican Senate health care policy staffer Rodney Whitlock, saying the Republican proposals fall short of the coverage offered by the ACA.

llama2-70b: Senator Thom Tillis voted in favor of repealing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in 2015, which would have eliminated coverage for pre-existing conditions.
The ACA prohibits discrimination based on health status, including pre-existing conditions, and requires insurance companies to cover such conditions [33].
Cal Cunningham, a Democratic Party establishment candidate, has highlighted this issue in his campaign, accusing Tillis of voting to "take away" coverage for pre-existing conditions [3].

Recently, the Cunningham campaign released an ad emphasizing this point, citing a tweet from a woman named Susie who shared how coverage for pre-existing conditions saved her family from bankruptcy [4][5].
Experts agree that the Tillis plan and other Republican proposals do not offer the same level of coverage as the ACA [16].
Specifically, Tillis' bill includes language that allows insurance companies to deny certain coverage if they cannot "adequately" deliver services [45].
Mark Hall, a law and health professor, stated that repealing the ACA would have restored the law to its pre-2010 state when pre-existing conditions were often not covered [24].
Tillis' spokesman, Andrew Romeo, did not dispute Tillis' vote when questioned by PolitiFact [27].
In conclusion, Thom Tillis' vote to repeal the ACA indicates that he supports removing coverage for pre-existing conditions, making the claim that he voted to "take away" such coverage true.
Note: The numbers in square brackets [x] within the explanation correspond to the list of reasons provided earlier.

eda191b158a72f99c4e59b3e8c3f5a99.claim: The mortality rate for the flu is “right around” that of the new coronavirus: “It’s right around 2%.”
eda191b158a72f99c4e59b3e8c3f5a99.label: false
eda191b158a72f99c4e59b3e8c3f5a99.passage:
0: During a Senate appropriations Feb. 25 subcommittee hearing, Chad Wolf, the acting secretary of Homeland Security, said the U.S. flu mortality rate was about the same as the current estimated global mortality rate of the coronavirus outbreak.
1: He made this statement during an exchange with Sen. John Neely Kennedy (R-La.)
2: regarding what the acting secretary knew about the coronavirus, which causes a disease known as COVID-19.
3: This C-SPAN video shows the full discussion between the two.
4: Kennedy first asked what the worldwide mortality rate for coronavirus is, to which Wolf responded, that it was "under 2%" but that he would need to check with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to get the actual figure and that "it changes daily."
5: The Louisiana senator then asked, "What’s the mortality rate for influenza over, say, the last 10 years in America?"
6: Wolf answered: "It’s also right around that percentage as well.
7: I don’t have that offhand, but it’s right around 2% as well."
8: We asked the Department of Homeland Security where Wolf’s figure came from.
9: A DHS spokesperson said in an email, "As the acting secretary said in his hearing, he did not have that information on hand and refers to Health and Human Services -- the federal agency in charge of the federal government’s coronavirus response."
10: The comparison of coronavirus to flu in terms of mortality rates seemed like an important mechanism to understanding the growing concern about the reach of coronavirus, so we decided to dig deeper to find out if these statistics hold up.
11: We also asked experts to explain what the numbers mean in terms of risk.
12: Digging into mortality rate numbers The CDC directed us to its online influenza resources and referred us to the World Health Organization for more information on coronavirus.
13: Christopher Mores, a global health professor at George Washington University, helped make sense of some of the figures.
14: He calculated the average, 10-year mortality rate for flu using CDC data and found it was 0.1%.
15: That 0.1% rate is frequently cited among experts, including Dr. Anthony Fauci , director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
16: Dr. Amesh Adalja, a senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins University Center for Health Security, called it "sort of the canonical seasonal influenza mortality figure."
17: It’s important to note, that although this percentage seems like a small number, influenza is responsible for an estimated 30,000 to 40,000 deaths annually.
18: Now, for coronavirus.
